opportunities.description:
Do good for your community while using your professional expertise. Work with talented peers on a rewarding non-profit cause related program. The Rare Genomics Institute is making a difference. RG is a nonprofit organization that helps families in need of genome research.

Responsibilities include

  • Develop and write grant proposals to foundations and other grant-making organizations, persuasively communicating RG’s mission and programs to potential funders

  • Assemble and submit grant requests, including letters, proposals, budgets, and presentations

  • Maintain calendar to ensure timely submission of letters of inquiry, proposal deadlines, and reports

  • Identify, define, and develop funding sources to support existing and planned program activities

  • Prioritize projects to keep multiple projects moving in a timely manner and meet deadlines

  • Must be able to attend team meetings every other Thursday at 8pm EST

  • Must have an interest or background in science and technology


Desired skills and experience:

  • Masters Degree in relevant field

  • 3+ years professional experience

  • Excellent written and verbal communication skills

  • 5-10 hour commitment each week (required)

  • Solid understanding of budgets as they relate to proposals and grants

  • Work collaboratively and independently to achieve stated goals

  • Ability to thrive in a fast-paced, self-starter environment


You will:

  • Meet a tremendous group of like-minded professionals

  • Deepen your connection with your community

  • Keep your skills sharp by applying them in the nonprofit sector

  • Share your expertise with others

  • Boost your resume and portfolio

  • Stand out from others in your field

  • Create lasting relationships

  • Network with an active online community of professionals

opportunities.description:
RRRcomputer.org's mission is to reclaim computer from recycling to reuse for education for low income K-6 kids. We reduce computer waste by refurbishing the computers to put back into circulation for the kids to use for internet search for research, and doing their homework assignment at home. The computers that are going to recycling is still useful for their needs. We do our part in saving the planet and improve the education of children.

Looking for Bilingual Spanish/English interpreter to help with Computer Donation/Distribution Drive to reach Spanish community for them to get the info on how to apply for free computer from RRRcomputer.org. You will be directly helping children from your communities to get their computers.

Thank you.

Hue

opportunities.description:
The All Stars Project (ASP) is a nationally-recognized, independently funded non-profit that was founded 35 years ago. Our mission is to transform the lives of youth and poor communities, using the developmental power of performance.

The All Stars Talent Show Network (ASTSN) provides young people with an opportunity to produce and perform in hip-hop talent shows in their neighborhoods. Every young person that auditions - between the ages of 5 and 25 - makes the show and talent isn’t a requirement!

We are currently looking for volunteers to help with community outreach and support with the production of the auditions and performance itself. This is a wonderful opportunity for someone who is passionate about providing opportunities for growth and personal development for our inner-city youth.

Hours are ongoing, varied, and flexible.

For more information, please contact: Adam Odsess-Rubin, Program Coordinator, All Stars Project of the San Francisco Bay Area Phone: 415-986-2565 www.allstars.org aodsess-rubin@allstars.org

opportunities.description:
Reading Partners needs volunteers like you to provide students in under-resourced elementary schools in your community with the proven, individualized reading support they need to read at grade level by fourth grade.

Reading is the foundation for all future learning.The ability to read transforms lives and can empower children to reach their full potential. Research shows that when students can read at grade level by fourth grade, they have a greater opportunity to succeed in school and in life.

With your help, we can equip students with the foundational skills they need to read at grade level. Each week, you will meet one-on-one with your student every week to help them develop strong literacy skills and discover a passion for reading. We'll provide a structured curriculum, in-person training, and ongoing support to help your student thrive. Rigorous research has proven that Reading Partners significantly increases reading proficiency.

No teaching experience required and anyone over the age of 14 can volunteer. Flexible Monday to Thursday volunteer times between 9am and 5pm.

Visit our website at www.readingpartners.org/volunteer to sign up and learn more.

opportunities.description:
The Excelsior Community Food Pantry (ECFP) distributes free groceries to families in need every Saturday from 10 AM to 1 PM. Our sign-ups for individuals are informal, which sometimes results in our being understaffed. Please come join us; we need your help!

We are located in the parking lot at Jewish Home San Francisco (Silver and Mission). If you drive, please park on the street as Jewish Home does not have enough room in their parking lots to accommodate our volunteers. We operate completely outdoors, so please dress accordingly.

All are welcome, so invite your family and friends. Children are welcome too! Thank you for your support!

Please feel free to email us with any questions. You can also check out our Facebook page: https://www.facebook.com/groups/ECFoodPantry/

Inneract Project seeks Volunteer Teachers and TAs for
Youth Design Academy (YDA) starting Spring 2017.

YDA is a free 8-week program for middle school students from underserved communities in East Bay and San Francisco. As an IP Volunteer Teacher/TA, you will work with a team of designers to help our nonprofit mission of providing a fun and well-rounded design education program. Our program strives to inspire young people to pursue higher education and to consider design as a viable career opportunity.

Timeline
Application deadline: January 11, 2017
Lesson Preparation: February 2017 (Start)
Teaching Commitment: March - April 2017 (8 Saturdays)
Reception: May 2017

Learn more here https://goo.gl/nm37s6

opportunities.description: During the course of a busy day, our educators, administrators, and therapists are at work with students and their needs, and our very well-used facilities are often in need of a little facelift. Some work --like tidying classrooms or therapy rooms, organizing and upkeeping students' materials, our outdoor environments, and painting the halls-- would work wonders for upkeeping our clean, friendly environment as well as student/staff morale, and this is where we could use some help. Additionally, we are improving our digital presence, so assistance with website design, digital outreach, and mobile marketing would be appreciated.

opportunities.description:
Do you have wisdom to share? Are you 60 or better and enjoy offering guidance to younger generations?

Members of the Elder Wisdom Circle are seniors who share their wisdom with young advice seekers from across the world. Via the Internet, Elders answer advice requests at their own convenience, offering young readers personalized and free advice on a wide range of topics - love and relationships, family and child-rearing, career and self-improvement, and more.

Based in the San Francisco Bay Area, the Elder Wisdom Circle has more than 600 Elders (aged 60 to 105) across North America. The EWC program and our Elders have been featured on ABC, BBC, CBS, FOX, NPR and in such publications as Glamour, the LA Times, Ladies Home Journal, Real Simple, Time & USA Today. We are one of the largest providers of personal advice, with hundreds of thousands of readers.

We are looking for seniors in your area to help expand our national reach. Please visit our site at www.ElderWisdomCircle.org and then the 'Offer Advice' tab on the top of the homepage. All advice providers must be 60 or better, no exceptions. Volunteers must complete an application and screening process.

opportunities.description:
In San Francisco alone, there are over 1,000 abused and neglected foster youth removed from their families in need of someone to nurture their development and advocate for their best interest.

As a Court Appointed Special Advocate (CASA), you will be empowered by the foster care system to investigate, facilitate, advocate, and monitor the needs of foster children in order to represent their best interests. At the end of the day, it is the goal of a CASA to help ensure these children don't struggle alone and are given a safe place to live.

We are especially in need of male advocates!

If you’re looking to have a life-changing experience and work one-on-one with abused and neglected foster children, attend our next volunteer orientation to learn how you can make a lasting difference in a foster child's life! Sign-up by going to http://www.sfcasa.org/volunteer/.

With strength and compassion you can be an advocate and prevent another child in your community from falling through the cracks of the system.

opportunities.description:
Community Awareness & Treatment Services, Inc. (CATS) is seeking new board members for our organization.

Founded in 1975, and incorporated in 1978, CATS is a private non-profit serving high risk, chronically homeless men and women in San Francisco. Our mission is helping those most in need get off the street, achieve stability and establish permanent housing by providing compassionate, culturally sensitive services. Our 6 programs span a continuum of care of services providing drop-in, emergency shelter, transitional housing, residential substance abuse treatment for seniors, and permanent supportive housing as well as medical respite through a partnership with Department of Public Health. With a budget of $6,823,000 comprised largely of government funding we employ 88 employees and have a current board of 10 members. Also see CATS website www.catsinc.org.

Qualifications:
-A strong supporter of the organization's mission
-Ability to attend monthly board meetings as well as periodic fundraising or related meetings
-Effective interpersonal relationship skills including leadership and communication skills
-Fundraising experience desirable, but not required


To Apply:
Submit cover letter and resume to Rod Finetti, Board Vice President (responses to this VolunteerMatch posting will be routed directly). In the cover letter, please highlight particular skills and experience you will bring to the board.


Thank you for your interest!

opportunities.description:
JOIN OUR NOBLE QUEST AS A VOLUNTEER

American CareQuest Hospice is looking for kind and passionate volunteers who want to support the elderly and the sick. Our volunteers’ empathy and time make an enormous difference in the lives of those affected by terminal illness. The volunteer’s role is greatly rewarding and perfect for those interested in working with older adults, working in the healthcare field, or having a general passion of helping others. Duties may include administrative tasks, calling patients or their families or making visits to patients’ homes. Your specific role and time commitment as hospice volunteer are flexible and dependent upon your preferences and availability.

We welcome you to join our great team!

Please call us at (415) 885-9100 or send your resume to:

hr@americancarequest.com

Pennsylvania Street Gardens is looking for people to volunteer at our public garden - everyone is welcome. Our master gardners will provide all the necessary tools and training. There is always plenty to do to keep the gardens looking their best: weeding, pruning, planting, propagating, composting and building hardscape. Also, if you're interested in drought-tolerant plants or native species you can learn about those too.

We have a volunteer day on the first Saturday of every month from 10am to 12pm, and are happy to organize additional volunteer times outside that window, just let us know!

Hope to see you at the garden,

Emily, Annie and Matt

contact: emily@psgsf.org

www.psgsf.org

opportunities.description:
JDRF is the leading global organization focused on type 1 diabetes (T1D) research. The goal of JDRF research is to improve the lives of all people affected by T1D by accelerating progress on the most promising opportunities for curing, better treating, and preventing T1D.

The JDRF Hope Gala is an annual event at The Ritz-Carlton, San Francisco. The evening starts with a cocktail reception and silent auction, and concludes with a dinner program with live auction, fund a cure, and an after party.


Please Note:

- VOLUNTEER OPPORTUNITIES CAN START AS EARLY AS 1:00PM AND END AROUND 12:30AM

- VOLUNTEERS MUST BE COMFORTABLE WITH SALES, CUSTOMER SERVICE AND USING IPADS

- VOLUNTEERS MUST BE AGE 18 AND UP

opportunities.description:
Reading Partners needs volunteers like you to provide students in under-resourced elementary schools in your community with the proven, individualized reading support they need to read at grade level by fourth grade.

Reading is the foundation for all future learning.The ability to read transforms lives and can empower children to reach their full potential. Research shows that when students can read at grade level by fourth grade, they have a greater opportunity to succeed in school and in life.

With your help, we can equip students with the foundational skills they need to read at grade level. Each week, you will meet one-on-one with your student every week to help them develop strong literacy skills and discover a passion for reading. We'll provide a structured curriculum, in-person training, and ongoing support to help your student thrive. Rigorous research has proven that Reading Partners significantly increases reading proficiency.

No teaching experience required and anyone over the age of 14 can volunteer. Flexible Monday to Thursday volunteer times between 9am and 5pm.

Visit our website at www.readingpartners.org/volunteer to sign up and learn more.

opportunities.description:
Our Microenterprise Development Program assists rural women "self-help" groups develop and grow small business ventures. We have beenactive in helping set up small income-generating activities (IGA) for rural self-help groups since the early 2000's (primarily thru grants), but only recently began focusing our work on providing more advice, consulting assistance, and small loans to the groups. MDP volunteers work with the existing microenterprise groups to help them grow and improve their existing projects, as well as help newly forming groups start an IGA.

The 5 main areas of volunteer activity in the MDP are as follows: (1) Progress Assessment, (2) Facilitate Project Discussions and Evaluations and Provide Project Advice, (3) Facilitate Knowledge and Resource Sharing Within the Network of Groups, (4) Provide Small Loans, (5) Provide General Business Skills Training Seminars.

Most volunteers spend their time doing a combination of all the above 5 items.Our value-added is not just in the form of providing financial resources (loans) but includes project planning advice, basic management and accounting training, and (very importantly) volunteers act as facilitators between our vast network of groups in order to facilitate knowledge and resource sharing among the groups. Our microlending program has just gotten off the ground and we currently have about $10,000 USD in outstanding loans. The MDP volunteers will be spending a lot of their time over the next several months meeting with the loans groups to ensure that are on schedule with paying back their loans and that they are investing their money prudently (e.g., in productivity enhancing resources versus consumption items). The lending part of our program is very new and is growing rapidly.

As a volunteer in the MDP you would spend the vast majority of your time out in the field meeting and working with the women microenterprise groups, which is a very rewarding and educational experience. All of the microenterprise groups within our network are independent groups. We do not manage their day to day operations and do not charge any type of fee for our services. We are a strict volunteer non-for-profit organization. All interest that we receive from the microloans goes towards new loans for additional groups. We are now have a network of around 100 microenterprise groups within the western Kenya region.

As of June 2007, our organization has had over 400 volunteers since 1998 from over 6 different countries. Volunteers in our Microenterprise Development have come from a variety of backgrounds including undergrad business students (Duke, Rice, Miami, Indiana), MBA and graduate students on their summer break (Stanford, Penn, etc.), management consultants (BCG, McKinsey, CRA), retired professionals, and accountants. See www.volunteerkenya.org for more information.

opportunities.description:
Provide seniors in Northeast San Francisco with the ability to remain living independently in their homes by offering rides to and from a medical appointment or a social event, or even just to the local grocery store. Make new friends and expand your San Francisco connections through volunteerism with NEXT Village SF. A little support goes a long, long way!

95% of us want to grow old in the comfort of our own home. NEXT's goal is to help the elderly in Northeast SF does just that! We also work to increase the member's well being by reducing social isolation and loneliness by hosting workshops, cultural events and outings. Some of our members have lived in their homes/apartments for 40 years. Volunteers help by: Providing transportation to medical appointments or offering a lift to our social events. Taking someone to the grocery store, and if needed, help them carry their groceries up to their apartment. Help with technology. Leading a class or speaking about something interesting to a group. They even just provide companionship.

Become a part of our NEXT Neighbor team and start making a difference today!

opportunities.description:
On March 3rd 2017, Jumpstart will be hosting an event at Portola Family Connections in celebration of Read Across America Day. Read Across America Day is a national celebration of reading and learning held every year on Dr. Seuss's birthday. At this celebration, program staff will host a reading of The Cat in the Hat by Dr. Seuss and volunteers will support a variety of interactive learning stations for 45 children and families.

This is a great way for individuals or small groups to engage with the children and families of their communities in a fun way while also promoting early literacy and a love for reading!

opportunities.description:
The School Fund provides scholarships to over 500 students in developing countries every year. Scholarships are crowdfunded through our online platform where we aim to provide donors with a personalized connection to students and a high level of transparency.

We recently updated the website, and are now looking to develop marketing materials to accompany the new design. We already have great photos, a brand guide and background research. We just need someone to help us pull these together and help tell our story.

Our first priority is a one pager that can be given to corporate partners, foundations, and major donors. After that, we may explore other media (inforgraphics, slide decks, etc).

opportunities.description:
Protect our environment and the special place in which we live!

Citizens’ Climate Lobby (CCL) wants you! As a volunteer, you’ll be a member of the fastest growing and most effective climate advocacy group. You will work with concerned California citizens to slow the effects of climate change. Let's work together to protect our beautiful ecosystems, livelihoods and way of life. Please respond to our posting for an invitation to learn more.

You will:

  • Meet with Congressional leaders.
  • Write letters to the editors and op-eds.
  • Meet with local media.
  • Educate your community about global warming and legislative solutions.

We provide:

  • Monthly national conference calls with expert guest speakers.
  • Weekly skill building sessions.
  • On-line network with CCL volunteers across the U.S.
  • National conference and lobby week in D.C.

Volunteers commit to an average of 4-6 hours a month. Some of our volunteers dedicate more time than that. We hold no upper limit on your dedication to a stable climate and livable world.

To learn more about us, please join an Introductory Conference Call. The next call is Wednesday at 5:00 p.m. Pacific/6:00 p.m. Mountain/7:00 p.m. Central/8:00 p.m. Eastern. This is an opportunity to learn about CCL. It is one hour, and there will be opportunities to ask questions. The conference call number is 1-866-642-1665, passcode 440699#.

opportunities.description:
22 Veterans take their own life every day. Help us save them.

The Soldiers Project is a non-profit organization dedicated to providing confidential, free, ongoing psycho-therapy to Post 9/11 Veterans and their loved ones regardless of discharge status. As our Assistant Director, you will be key to helping us further our mission throughout the East Bay and San Francisco communities. If you believe veterans deserve better mental health services for their sacrifices they have made and want to see them thrive, we would love to have you join us.

Duties and Responsibilities

?Assist in recruitment efforts of licensed psychotherapists, marriage and family therapists, and psychologists in the San Francisco and East Bay areas.

Conduct outreach to community partners in the both the Veteran and Mental Health space in order to spread awareness and gain support for The Soldiers Project in the region.

?Supports the national communications and fundraising objectives for the organization.

?Help in engaging volunteers in order to better support the mission of The Soldiers Project.

?Provide presentations/trainings to partners and local organizations as needed.

opportunities.description:
UniversalGiving is seeking a Development Executive to help direct the strategy and execution of our Fundraising Plan. This seasoned professional would work directly with the CEO on a wide range of donors, from small to high networth.

UniversalGiving's Returnships offer exciting opportunities to those wishing to make a significant impact and contribution to our global communities. We are interested in people who want to expand their skills while helping the world.

Full Description

UniversalGiving, an award-winning global social-entrepreneurship nonprofit organization, is seeking a Development Professional for a Returnship. This experienced professional would work directly with the CEO and play a critical strategic and operational role in the execution of the UniversalGiving Fundraising Plan. He or she would work on a wide range of strategic communications to UniversalGiving’s current donors and UniversalGiving’s list of potential donors.

UniversalGiving is an award-winning website allowing people to donate and volunteer with top performing projects all over the world. Unique to UniversalGiving, 100% of a donation goes directly to the cause. UniversalGiving has been profiled on CBS and in FOX Business Network, and has also been featured in BusinessWeek Fast Company, CSRWire, WomenEntrepreneur, Oprah.com, NBC News.

Join UniversalGiving and work closely with the CEO and a dedicated international team, while gaining valuable skills and insight into social entrepreneurship.

Responsibilities:

  • Strategize appropriate high net worth donor asks via letters, emails and newsletters
  • Strategize appropriate donor asks for small to mid range donors, via letters, emails, newsletters and social media
  • Perform research/lead qualification on UniversalGiving’s potential and existing donors
  • Customize Salesforce tool for better Development prospecting and results reporting
  • Maintain Salesforce Database entries
  • Execute on our fundraising plan with the CEO

Qualifications:

  • Strong fundraising experience
  • Strong fundraising operations/system setup experience
  • Diverse communications skill set across writing, social media, visuals
  • Excellent writing skills and attention to detail
  • Creative background for fundraising materials
  • Salesforce, Microsoft Word, Excel and PowerPoint skills
  • Balance of taking ownership while working with a team
  • Interest in nonprofit work, international issues, and philanthropy
  • Full support of the mission and vision of UniversalGiving

Benefits:

  • Contribute to UniversalGiving’s work to create a world where giving and volunteering are a natural part of everyday life
  • Work directly with the CEO
  • Experience at a unique global, social-entrepreneurship nonprofit
  • Collaboration within a positive team environment
  • Increased understanding of global issues
  • Networking with other nonprofit professionals

Duration: Minimum 15-20 hours per week required for the duration of the Returnship, at least a minimum of 3 to 4 months. Ideal candidates are available to work out of our San Francisco office 3-4 days/week (Monday through Friday) with possibly some work completed remotely.

Testimonial
"I came to UniversalGiving at a time when I was looking for a way to have more meaning with my work. After years in management consulting, finance, and then home raising two young children, I was ready to give back to the world in a different way. I began as a volunteer in their Returnship program and four years later, am leading Operations. UniversalGiving is a professional environment that has given me meaning, experience in new realms, and flexibility in my work schedule. I am so proud to be a part of this amazing team that is doing great things in the world."

Adriana Rabkin

Senior Manager, Operations

About UniversalGiving
 UniversalGiving is an award-winning website allowing people to donate and volunteer with top performing projects all over the world. Our projects are vetted through a proprietary Quality Model to ensure the most effective, trustworthy philanthropy possible. Unique to UniversalGiving, we take no cut on donations. 100% of your donation goes directly to the cause.

UniversalGiving Corporate consults with Fortune 500 companies on the strategy, operations and NGO Vetting for their international giving and volunteering programs all over the world. Some clients include Cisco, Symantec, Fluor, Sabre, MTV.

Located in the heart of San Francisco, UniversalGiving has been profiled on CBS and in FOX Business Network, and has also been featured in BusinessWeek Fast Company, CSRWire, WomenEntrepreneur, Oprah.com, NBC News, The Christian Science Monitor, The New York Times, The Financial Times, MarketWatch, CNNMoney.com, Change.org and See Change Magazine. UniversalGiving has been voted as one the top nonprofits on Great Nonprofits in 2012, and was a Webby Award Honoree.

CEO Pamela Hawley is a winner of the Jefferson Award (the Nobel Prize in Community Service) and was selected as one of 50 leaders to the White House's Next Generation Leadership and Social Innovation event. She is a Finalist for Ernst & Young’s Entrepreneur of the Year Award, and a Colburn S. Wilbur Leadership Fellow at the Global Ethics Institute. She is a Fast Company Expert Blogger on CSR.

UniversalGiving’s Mission: We Connect People to Top Performing Opportunities Worldwide.

UniversalGiving’s Vision: "To Create a World Where Giving and Volunteering Are a Natural Part of Everyday Life."

To Apply:

Email your resume, cover letter, and writing sample (2 pages max) to volunteers@universalgiving.org with "Development Returnship" in the subject line. Applications are reviewed on a rolling basis. No phone calls please.

UniversalGiving is committed to understanding and representing the diverse populations it serves worldwide. Members of all ages, genders, sexual orientations, races, ethnicities, nationalities, physical abilities or disabilities, religions or beliefs, and cultures are welcome as employees and volunteers in our organization. We believe that a diverse team will best serve our diverse populations.

For more information please visit:

  • UniversalGiving’s website
  • UniversalGiving’s Blog: PhilanthroPost
  • CEO Pamela Hawley’s Blog: Living and Giving
  • Follow Us on Twitter: @ UniversalGiving and @ PamelaHawley
  • Like us on Facebook

I am so proud to be a part of this amazing team that is doing great things in the world.\" Adriana Rabkin Senior Manager, Operations About UniversalGiving UniversalGiving is an award-winning website allowing people to donate and volunteer with top performing projects all over the world. Our projects are vetted through a proprietary Quality Model to ensure the most effective, trustworthy philanthropy possible. Unique to UniversalGiving, we take no cut on donations. 100% of your donation goes directly to the cause. UniversalGiving Corporate consults with Fortune 500 companies on the strategy, operations and NGO Vetting for their international giving and volunteering programs all over the world. Some clients include Cisco, Symantec, Fluor, Sabre, MTV. Located in the heart of San Francisco, UniversalGiving has been profiled on CBS and in FOX Business Network, and has also been featured in BusinessWeek Fast Company, CSRWire, WomenEntrepreneur, Oprah.com, NBC News, The Christian Science Monitor, The New York Times, The Financial Times, MarketWatch, CNNMoney.com, Change.org and See Change Magazine. UniversalGiving has been voted as one the top nonprofits on Great Nonprofits in 2012, and was a Webby Award Honoree. CEO Pamela Hawley is a winner of the Jefferson Award (the Nobel Prize in Community Service) and was selected as one of 50 leaders to the White House's Next Generation Leadership and Social Innovation event. She is a Finalist for Ernst & Young’s Entrepreneur of the Year Award, and a Colburn S. Wilbur Leadership Fellow at the Global Ethics Institute. She is a Fast Company Expert Blogger on CSR. UniversalGiving’s Mission: We Connect People to Top Performing Opportunities Worldwide. UniversalGiving’s Vision: \"To Create a World Where Giving and Volunteering Are a Natural Part of Everyday Life.\" To Apply: Email your resume, cover letter, and writing sample (2 pages max) to volunteers@universalgiving.org with \"Development Returnship\" in the subject line. Applications are reviewed on a rolling basis. No phone calls please. UniversalGiving is committed to understanding and representing the diverse populations it serves worldwide. Members of all ages, genders, sexual orientations, races, ethnicities, nationalities, physical abilities or disabilities, religions or beliefs, and cultures are welcome as employees and volunteers in our organization. We believe that a diverse team will best serve our diverse populations. For more information please visit: UniversalGiving’s website UniversalGiving’s Blog: PhilanthroPost CEO Pamela Hawley’s Blog: Living and Giving Follow Us on Twitter: @ UniversalGiving and @ PamelaHawley Like us on Facebook

opportunities.description:
St. Anthony's Free Clothing Program (FCP) is San Francisco's largest free clothing program serving both individuals and families. FCP provides warm clothing to 125 guests each day, including low-income families and homeless individuals.

In order to give out enough warm, clean clothing, we need volunteers who can can sort and hang clothing donations, or assist guests directly by finding the clothing items they need from 8-9am any day Monday through Friday.

Duties include:

  • Assist with the processing of donations per FCP guidelines and standards.
  • Prepare clothing racks for display in our free clothing store.
  • Communicate with guests to understand their needs and help find the clothing they are looking for.
  • Retrieve clothing and other requested items from the back of house donations for our guests.
  • Organize free clothing store by picking up fallen clothes, collecting empty hangers, and tidying shopping space.

Skills Required:

  • Ability to be professional, polite, and tactful with our guests and maintain appropriate boundaries.
  • Ability to successfully volunteer with a diverse client population including people who are homeless and/or low-income, and people with physical and/or mental health disabilities.
  • Excellent interpersonal, listening, and oral and written communication skills.
  • Excellent volunteer habits: professional, punctual, reliable, cooperative and team oriented.
  • Ability to lift 10 lbs.
  • Commitment to St. Anthony Foundation Statement of Values.

Please contact St. Anthony's Free Clothing Program (FCP) Volunteer Coordinator, Sophie Wasacz, swasacz@stanthonysf.org for more information.

opportunities.description:
At Make-A-Wish, we grant wishes for kids with life-threatening medical conditions. Volunteers are the driving force of Make-A-Wish, out in the community, meeting with wish families, presenting the wishes, and raising awareness and funds to grant the wishes. The Volunteer Services Department is looking for a volunteer to assist with administrative tasks related to keeping volunteer records up-to-date.

We are looking for a volunteer who can help 3-4 hours per week, on a regular, weekly basis. The shift must be done during our office hours - 9am-5pm M-F. We can mutually decide what shift time works with your schedule (e.g. Monday 9am-1pm, Friday, 1pm-5pm, or whatever works best with your schedule). We also require that the volunteer be willing to agree to a minimum six-month commitment. All the office work will be done at the Make-A-Wish office in San Francisco.

Duties include monthly updates for background checks, following up with volunteers for their annual recommitment forms, entering contact information into spreadsheets, closing records of inactive volunteers, and documenting information in the database. The volunteer must have experience with Microsoft Excel and/or Google Spreadsheets, Outlook, and should be detail-oriented. Database experience preferred, especially Raiser’s Edge experience. This position will involve data entry, phone calls, and email. The Volunteer Updates Assistant must be at least 18 years old. If you are interested in this position, please email our Volunteer Manager to express interest, and include a resume.

opportunities.description:
You will work with middle school students in small groups (4-7 students). These are students who have chosen to take an elective class that supports college readiness. The students are primarily in the "academic middle" with high potential, but some academic struggle. Many aspire to be the first in their family to attend college. Students bring questions they are confused about in other content classes to their tutorial group. The tutor facilitates the group of students in a Socratic Tutorial, where students learn by asking each other questions. Students learn not only the answer to the problem, but critical thinking and problem solving steps. Training is provided for you, the tutor, in this highly effective, research based method, which was developed by AVID (Advancement Via Individual Determination - see www.avid.org for more information). Have the satisfaction of helping an adolescent develop college and career readiness skills.

Upcoming training dates beginning in October and running through February. Begin working with students in Fall 2016 or Spring 2017. Make a difference in just 1-2 hours a week! All tutoring times are during the school day, between 8 AM and 4 PM.
opportunities.tags: mentor, critical thinking, education, college readiness, Tutor
opportunities.title: Do You Love to Ask Questions? Become a Socratic Tutor!

opportunities.description:
Be a part of the nation's largest showcase for new Asian American and Asian films! We are looking for fun, exciting and reliable VOLUNTEERS for CAAMFest35 2017. This year the film festival will be held March 9th-19th, 2017 in San Francisco presented by the Center for Asian American Media (CAAM).

CAAMFest volunteers help make it happen! Volunteers are essential to our festival and assist in such roles as:

  • Usher: Ticket Taker, Line Control, Stage Hand
  • Box Office: Will Call
  • Hospitality: VIP Check-In, Guest Services, Theater Host
  • Events: Support at Galas & Events, Bartending

As a thank you, all volunteers receive exciting complimentary benefits including:

  • Festival Screening Vouchers (see wonderful films for free!)
  • Festival T-Shirt
  • A Volunteer Appreciation Party
  • The opportunity to meet and mingle with other film buffs and make friends that will last a lifetime!

Register at: http://www.shiftboard.com/caam

Questions? Please Volunteer Coordinator at volunteeradmin@caamedia.org

For more info visit: caamedia.org

CAll for Photographers!

We are looking for Photographers for CAAMFest35 2017! Please email Anna Leal, Marketing Assistant, your portfolio and equipment list (must have DSLR) to aleal@caamedia.org. We are looking forward to hearing from you!

ABOUT CAAM

CAAM envisions a world where Asian Pacific American stories, histories and viewpoints are recognized as fundamental to the American experience.

CAAM’s mission is to present stories that convey the richness and diversity of the Asian American experience to the broadest audience possible. We fund, produce, distribute and exhibit Asian American films, videos and new media.

CAAM was founded in 1980 by Asian American film, video and radio producers and community activists to counter the scarcity of images of Asians in film and television; correct the often-distorted portrayals of them in the mainstream media; and create opportunities for the full participation of Asian American producers in the public media. Once an association of groups around the country, CAAM is now a nationally recognized arts and cultural institution based in San Francisco, California.

opportunities.description:
Become a volunteer visitor for a lonely elder in San Francisco! Next New Volunteer Trainings occur often! Great Opportunity for Busy Folks Who Still Want to Volunteer!! We will match you to someone in a convenient location!

  • Want to help an isolated elder to feel less alone?
  • Interested in making a difference in an elderly person's quality of life?
  • Interested in visiting with an elder adult community member in their home?

As a volunteer visitor for "ElderWISE" ("Working in Service to Elders"), an outreach program of Episcopal Senior Communities, Senior Resources, you will:

  • Receive free training in interpersonal and listening skills
  • Be matched with an elder to whom you will provide friendly companionship and a compassionate presence
  • Benefit from joining a community of caring volunteers who receive ongoing support

Time Commitment: 6-month minimum, visiting your elder client 2-4 times/month.

Qualifications: a free background check & fingerprinting; availability for our next new volunteer training, coming up soon!

Bilingual volunteers are also encouraged to apply but everyone welcome and much appreciated!

For more information, please contact: Brian Stannard at 415-290-8885 or at bstannard@jtm-esc.org

opportunities.description:
The Hospital Elder Life Program (HELP) is a unique program with goals to decrease confusion and loss of independence in older patients while in the hospital.

Volunteers are the core of the program and trained to provide bedside interventions in ambulating, orientating, hydrating and activities.

Our trainings are held annually in March and September. The training consists of 8 hours of classroom training, followed by 16 hours of precepted training at the bedside. We hold interviews for the orientation beginning 2 months before the training all the way up to the day before the training.

Must have good English speaking skills. Second language is a plus!

If you're interested please contact Shannon at cottersa@sutterhealth.org or 415.600.3916, please contact us! We are currently holding interviews for the Fall 2016 orientation.

cottersa@sutterhealth.org or 415.600.3916

http://www.cpmc.org/volunteer/volunteerhelp.html

opportunities.description:
Reading Partners needs volunteers like you to provide students in under-resourced elementary schools in your community with the proven, individualized reading support they need to read at grade level by fourth grade.

Reading is the foundation for all future learning.The ability to read transforms lives and can empower children to reach their full potential. Research shows that when students can read at grade level by fourth grade, they have a greater opportunity to succeed in school and in life.

With your help, we can equip students with the foundational skills they need to read at grade level. Each week, you will meet one-on-one with your student every week to help them develop strong literacy skills and discover a passion for reading. We'll provide a structured curriculum, in-person training, and ongoing support to help your student thrive. Rigorous research has proven that Reading Partners significantly increases reading proficiency.

No teaching experience required and anyone over the age of 14 can volunteer. Flexible Monday to Thursday volunteer times between 9am and 5pm.

Visit our website at www.readingpartners.org/volunteer to sign up and learn more.
opportunities.tags: School, reading, children, tutoring, low-income, mentoring, literacy, teaching, youth, students, kids, STEM

opportunities.description:
Enjoy a delicious catered dinner and rub elbows with 250+ other people passionate about local journalism and local nature. Join our team of volunteers at the Annual Bay Nature Local Hero Awards Dinner on Sunday, March 26, 2017. We are looking for team players to help with tasks such as the following:

- warmly greet guests

- register guests

- help people bid on items at the silent auction

- collect donation forms at guest tables

- pack up forms, materials, signage after the event

In the days following the event, help to thank everyone who played a role in its success.

Qualifications:

opportunities.description:
Hi

The Alliance Francaise of San Francisco is a cultural center, a public library and a language school. We promote French language and Frenchspeaking culture.
We are a very small team with a lot of great projects going on.

We are looking for sociable and responsible volunteers to help us with various administrative tasks including data entry, contacting students and members, database management, and other office duties.

Ideally, volunteers with half week mornings or afternoons commitment will be perfect.

You will receive on-the-job training, support and supervision, and valuable work experience. Our system allow volunteers to earn points with their volunteering time that can be transformed in French classes.

You are organized and dynamic, join us !

opportunities.description:
Reading Partners needs volunteers like you to provide students in under-resourced elementary schools in your community with the proven, individualized reading support they need to read at grade level by fourth grade.

Reading is the foundation for all future learning.The ability to read transforms lives and can empower children to reach their full potential. Research shows that when students can read at grade level by fourth grade, they have a greater opportunity to succeed in school and in life.

With your help, we can equip students with the foundational skills they need to read at grade level. Each week, you will meet one-on-one with your student every week to help them develop strong literacy skills and discover a passion for reading. We'll provide a structured curriculum, in-person training, and ongoing support to help your student thrive. Rigorous research has proven that Reading Partners significantly increases reading proficiency.

No teaching experience required and anyone over the age of 14 can volunteer. Flexible Monday to Thursday volunteer times between 9am and 5pm.

Visit our website at www.readingpartners.org/volunteer to sign up and learn more.

opportunities.description:
You will work with middle school students in small groups (4-7 students). These are students who have chosen to take an elective class that supports college readiness. The students are primarily in the "academic middle" with high potential, but some academic struggle. Many aspire to be the first in their family to attend college. Students bring questions they are confused about in other content classes to their tutorial group. The tutor facilitates the group of students in a Socratic Tutorial, where students learn by asking each other questions. Students learn not only the answer to the problem, but critical thinking and problem solving steps. Training is provided for you, the tutor, in this highly effective, research based method, which was developed by AVID (Advancement Via Individual Determination - see www.avid.org for more information). Have the satisfaction of helping an adolescent develop college and career readiness skills.

Upcoming training dates beginning in October and running through February. Begin working with students in Fall 2016 or Spring 2017. Make a difference in just 1-2 hours a week! All tutoring times are during the school day, between 8 AM and 4 PM.

opportunities.description:
Welcome to the ASD Climber Foundation! ASD stands for Autism Spectrum Disorders. We are working with a family in your area with a child on the autism spectrum. The family wants to train volunteers to help them run a home based social skills program called the Son-Rise Program. No experience necessary. Free training provided. Time commitment is 2-4 hours a week for 6 months or more.

PLEASE READ: After completing the "I want to help" page, you will immediately receive an auto reply email with our Volunteer Profile. Please fill this out, and we will forward it directly to the family in your area that requires help. Thank you for your time!!

opportunities.description:
Are you excited to build a volunteer program from the roots up? Apply your recruitment and organizational talents to help cultivate healthy youth and communities in San Francisco?

The Volunteer Program Coordinator will play a vital role on our team by creating and implementing an amazing volunteer program, outreaching to the community, organizing special events, and working closely with our staff to strengthen our partnerships.

This is a wonderful opportunity for an organized, outgoing, person who wants to make their mark on an organization and a real impact on the community.

Check out the job description for more information: https://my.americorps.gov/mp/listing/viewListing.do?id=71113&fromSearch=true

We're accepting applications until February 24th through the VISTA portal. Please contact Kelly ErnstFriedman at kelly@communitygrows.org for more information.

VISTAs receive several benefits, including a stipend, education award, health benefits and more. VISTAS are permitted to have another part-time job or be in school during their term. Learn more about the AmeriCorps VISTA Program here: https://www.nationalservice.gov/programs/americorps/americorps-vista

opportunities.description:
St. Anthony’s (FCP) is San Francisco’s largest free clothing program serving both individuals and families. FCP provides warm clothes, interview and employment apparel, and children’s clothing to low-income families and individuals, including those who are homeless. We refer to the people we serve as our "guests."

One of the biggest obstacles for our guests seeking a job is obtaining appropriate job interview clothing. One of our guests named Steven B. said it best: "I don’t even feel comfortable filling out a job application, let alone going on a job interview, because my clothes are dirty and smelly." To remedy this, the Free Clothing Program operates a free suit room to provide brand new suits and shoes to our male guests who are unemployed and seeking work.

The Suit Specialist will be a volunteer lead in our Free Clothing Program Suit Room. He or she will assist our guests by identifying their clothing sizes, helping them choose appropriate job interview clothing, and work with guests to find a suit that fits their needs. Such service provides men not only with a fitted new suit, but also gives our guests a confidence boost that can enhance prospects for a new job.

Duties & Tasks:

  • Welcome guests to the suit room and review what items guests may receive.
  • Assist and instruct guests on how to determine their clothing sizes.
  • Assist and instruct guests on how to put together an appropriate job interview outfit.
  • Help guests find a well fitted suit for their needs.
  • Stock racks with the highest quality clothing possible.
  • Maintain a clean and professional shopping environment.

Skills Required:

  • Customer service or retail experience preferred but not required.
  • Ability to be professional, polite, and tactful with our guests and maintain appropriate boundaries.
  • Ability to successfully volunteer with a diverse client population including people who are homeless and/or low-income, and people with physical and/or mental health disabilities.
  • Excellent interpersonal, listening, and oral and written communication skills.
  • Excellent volunteer habits: professional, punctual, reliable, cooperative and team oriented.
  • Ability to volunteer with minimal supervision and as part of a team
opportunities.tags: Customer Service, homelessness, employment readiness

opportunities.description:
You will work with middle school students in small groups (4-7 students). These are long term English Language Learners in a class that supports the development of academic language skills and college readiness. The students are primarily in the "academic middle" with high potential, but some academic struggle. Many aspire to be the first in their family to attend college. Students bring questions they are confused about in a specific text to their scholar group. The tutor facilitates the group of students in a supportive process, where students learn by asking each other questions and reading a text closely. Students not only enhance their language skills, but develop critical thinking and problem solving abilities. Training is provided for you, the tutor, in this highly effective, research based method, which was developed by AVID (Advancement Via Individual Determination - see www.avid.org for more information). Have the satisfaction of helping an adolescent develop their language and college and career readiness skills.

Upcoming training dates beginning in October and running through February. Begin working with students in Fall 2016 or Spring 2017. Make a difference in just 1-2 hours a week! All tutoring times are during the school day, between 8 AM and 4 PM.

If you think you haven't seen the work of Baratunde Thurston, you are most likely wrong. Whether it's The Daily Show, The Onion, Jack & Jill Politics, Cultivated Wit, or his stand-up comedy, odds are good that he has had a hand in creating something that has made you laugh and think about race, politics, technology, and more.

Volunteer as an usher and attend for Free!

Join California Institute of Integral Studies Public Programs and Performances for an evening that includes a special stand-up set with Baratunde followed by a conversation with Rotimi Agbabiaka about comedy, technology, race, politics, and everything in between.

Fill out our volunteer form here: https://goo.gl/forms/ct0izPafeYsUKmAc2

opportunities.description:
Who you are:

You are an aspiring software engineer and quick study, comfortable learning new development languages, tools, and technology. You can work well in a team but can also put on headphones and power ahead on a challenge. You not only talk the talk of a developer but can also explain to non-developers what your work means and how it impacts users. You’re open to new projects, new ideas, and excited about figuring out first-to-market solutions for a rewarding data-intensive domain.

You'll be essential in building and scaling the products, services and APIs that power Rare Genomics research. You could be working on our patient or researcher facing interfaces, internal systems, help spec and design new products and features, or improve our core abilities. Most of our systems are written in Python, Ruby, or Javascript. We're a small team, conscious of encouraging a productive and rewarding culture of inclusivity, diversity and fun, with opportunities to grow and shape the role and organization.

Skills we'd love to see:

Experience with modern languages and systems
- Some years of Python, Ruby, NodeJS, Go or similar languages
- Comfort with databases such as Postgres, MongoDB, ElasticSearch, or Redis
- Excited to use containers, Docker, new cloud techs in a project
- Git, Mercurial, etc; Linux experience; can setup own dev environment
- Bonus for having built/used data analysis frameworks or pipelines

Experience developing web and mobile applications
- Have worked with or built APIs for web and mobile
- Comfortable with basic HTML / CSS / JS
- Knowledge of the JS ecosystem
- Familiarity with the D3 library or writing code for charts and visualizations
- Bonus for experience with Ionic, Cordova or native iOS and Android apps

General awesomeness criteria
- Someone who is comfortable with wearing many hats
- Analytics/data wrangling experience is greatly appreciated
- Experience writing software for a startup or tech company or CS coursework is a plus
- A background in engineering or science and a track record of building interesting projects
- Extra bonus points for having contributed to open source projects!

opportunities.description:
Help change and save lives and the world with Qigong and Traditional Chinese Medicine. Need a creative person to help with publicity and fundraising for exciting educational and clinical programs for veterans, children and all people. Great opportunity to also learn to heal with Medical Qigong and create a valuable position for yourself. Website and social media and computer expertise most helpful. One should love interacting and communicating with people, developing, organizing and managing programs.

An exciting non-profit, EWAHA, for the last 39 years has been dedicated to training, clinical treatment, and the dissemination of information on Qigong and Complementary Alternative Medicine (CAM). Combining the best of Traditional Chinese Medicine (TCM) and Western Medicine is the core of our philosophy and practice.

Please send full resume and date and times available to eastwestqi@aol.com There is an opportunity for an ongoing paid job.

opportunities.description:
We are searching for community minded people who are interested in helping in the on-going and ever changing HIV Prevention arena. We provide training and opportunity for certification through the San Francisco Dept. of Public Health to do HIV Test Counseling.

We are looking for people who can volunteer for various shifts, including nights and weekends. We also do mobile testing on our van for special events, as well as street fairs (i.e., Dore, Folsom, Castro)

Our target audience for testing is MSM/TSM so you must be interested in working with a diverse group of people both in the agency as well as our clients.

What do you need to bring? An open mind, willingness to help and a commitment to volunteer!!

opportunities.description:
OUR MISSION: Meals On Wheels of San Francisco and its volunteers provide seniors what they need to live independent and dignified lives -- nutritious meals, professional social work, and friendly human contact.

HELP MAKE A DIFFERENCE IN THE LIVES OF SENIORS BY DELIVERING GROCERIES AND OTHER ESSENTIAL NUTRITIONAL AND SAFETY ITEMS!

Volunteers with wheels help hundreds of seniors every week in two of our core programs.

Home Delivered Groceries Program: Every Wednesday morning, volunteers pick up pre-packed bags of groceries donated by the San Francisco Food Bank and deliver them to over 240 seniors throughout San Francisco. Volunteer drivers pick up the grocery bags at the Meals on Wheels office around 8:30am and deliver the groceries to a pre-set route of 10-15 seniors. Each route takes about two hours to complete.

Client Needs Program: Each month, Meals on Wheels distributes small appliances and bottles of nutritional supplements to our senior clients who need these items to maintain their health and independence. Volunteers pick up the items at the Meals on Wheels office during office hours, and make arrangements with the client directly for delivery at the convenience of the volunteer and client.

WHO?: Volunteers with wheels! Car, current driver's license and auto insurance, and background check with clean auto record are required.

WHERE? Meals on Wheels of San Francisco offices are located at 1375 Fairfax Ave., San Francisco , CA. Office hours are 8:30am - 4:30am; Monday through Friday.

WHAT? Bring fresh food, nutritional supplements, health and safety items, and friendly smiles to seniors and make a positive impact on their lives!
opportunities.tags: Drive, san francisco, meals on wheels, delivery, Food, Driver, seniors, retired, groceries, Grocery, handy

opportunities.description:
Individual Donors Program ~ SF Day Labor Program and Women’s Collective

The San Francisco Day Labor Program and Women’s Collective (DLP/WC) is a grassroots-organized program deeply rooted in the community with strong support of key stakeholders. For over 20 years, the DLP/WC has been extremely successful at uniting, empowering, and organizing immigrant workers for dignified work and fair wages in San Francisco. Workers are organized in two collectives, one of men and one of women, to build collective power, develop skills, and operate a business.

Members of the collectives work together to eradicate the injustices that affect day laborers and domestic workers, fostering an organized environment where all workers can build their dignity, power and leadership. Members share a vision of a community where day laborers and domestic workers have the same opportunities and rights than any other worker. They accomplish this by offering each other opportunities to learn, work and participate in the movement of immigrant and domestic workers. The collectives are co-founders and leaders in the National Day Labor Organizing Network, National Domestic Workers Alliance, Progressive Workers Alliance, California Domestic Workers Coalition, Jobs with Justice, San Francisco Rising, among others.

In 2015, the DLP/WC started an exciting reorganization process with the objective of establishing a more sustainable and scalable model that enhances the impact of the program in the lives of immigrant workers.

The DLP/WC is looking for an Individual Donors Program to segment and create mailing lists. The ideal candidate is detailed oriented and able to use simple web applications to manage distribution lists, such as MailChimp.

Position Objective: This position supports the fundraising efforts amongst individual donors, which is directed to transforming the lives of low-wage immigrant workers at a personal level, in order to develop leaders who can promote the dignity of their work and transform the industries in which they work.


Responsibility:This person will segment and create mailing lists so as to streamline online fundraising efforts.


Expected Commitment: entire project is estimated at 30 hours total and to begin as soon as possible.


Desired Skills:

  • Some experience with using basic data

  • Familiarity with online web applications such as MailChimp

  • Commitment to social justice, specifically worker and immigrant rights

  • Compassionate and caring approach to supporting immigrant workers

ABOUT THE DLP/WC

Founded in 1991 and inspired by the socio-ecologic model, the DLP/WC unites, empowers and organizes immigrant workers to access dignified work and fair wages by building collective power, developing skills, and operating businesses. The DLP/WC power center offers on-demand labor for environmentally-conscious cleaning services, childcare, patient care, moving, hauling, painting, yard work, handyman repairs, installations and more.

The San Francisco Day Labor Program and Women’s Collective is a program of Dolores Street Community Services, an equal-opportunity employer that seeks applicants of the greatest diversity possible, including women, people of color, lesbian/ gay/ bisexual/ transgender individuals, people living with HIV and persons with disabilities.
opportunities.title: Individuals Donor Program

opportunities.description:
The Justice & Diversity Center (JDC) trains volunteer attorneys to represent low-income people and families who need legal help. We assist clients with divorces, child custody, support, guardianship petitions, conservatorships, wills, and powers of attorney. JDC trains attorneys of all practice areas and experience levels in basic family law. We then provide supervision and malpractice insurance as attorneys take on matters and cases for low-income clients in San Francisco. A volunteer attorney can take a case from start to finish, or provide limited-scope representation to assist with specific motions.

Volunteering with JDC is a great way for attorneys to contribute to our community while gaining legal experience and learning family law. Volunteer attorneys receive training and mentoring from JDC’s Family Law Supervising Attorney. Attorneys must take our free two-part CLE training in family law (3 hours online, followed by 1 hour in person). In exchange for the free CLE, volunteers commit to taking two family law matters in the next year.
opportunities.tags: family law, legal services, volunteer attorney, community work, pro bono
opportunities.title: Attorneys: Help Individuals and Families in Family Law Matters!

opportunities.description:
Hi Everyone,

We want to clean up, refresh and renovate our cultural center and school to make it more welcoming and help our community to feel home.

2017 will be the year for us to a new life!

We need some great volunteers to help us to :

For everyone :

- clean the carpeting

- paint the walls

- change some bulbs

- take out all trash

- organize the closets

- give a new look to our front desk

- take care of our plants/small garden

- make an inventory of everything for events

- hopefully get new tables and chairs if we can get a donation from an office

- maybe help us to find some donations for furniture, computers,....

- if you have some computer skills : clean up the computers, update antivirus,...

- If you speak French: take out of the library everything outdated, and if you have plenty of time start to enter all the book in our new library management system.

We need an army to make this happen!

Join us an become our heros!

opportunities.description:
Project Access offers a variety of programs and services to enrich the lives of our families and senior population.

Volunteer support is needed for a variety of programs including:

  • Chinese and/or Russian translation and interpretation
  • Assist the Services Coordinator with our Food Pantry and Senior Food Box
  • Provide support for community-building and holiday events
  • Assist with the instruction of onsite classes, programs, and other services
  • Conduct community outreach to connect residents with local resources and programs onsite
  • Provide administrative support to the Service Coordinator

Have another idea? We are always looking for volunteers to lead new activities!

opportunities.description:
Join Kidsave's Bay Area community team to help older Colombian orphans find families in 2017!

Four Reasons to Volunteer with Kidsave's Summer Miracles Program:

1. You will make a lasting impact on the life of a child.

2. You will have the most meaningful summer of your life.

3. You will see children come out of their shells and families grow.

4. You will engage your community and get others excited about our mission!

As a global voice for change, Kidsave makes miracles happen for children the world has forgotten. Kidsave shows communities worldwide how to get children out of government orphanages and foster care and into loving families. Kidsave's ultimate goal is to ensure that all communities, everywhere, are able to provide love, hope and families to every foster child and orphan.

Kidsave is currently seeking volunteers to help coordinate the SF Metro/Bay Area community Summer Miracles program. The Summer Miracles program brings children from Colombia, ages 10-14, who are growing up in orphanages to communities across the U.S. to stay with host families/individuals for a 5 week summer visit. During their stay, the children experience life in a family, attend summer camp, and meet prospective adoptive families. Volunteer responsibilities include planning weekend advocacy events, reaching out to local media to advocate for the children, supporting host families, engaging prospective adoptive families in meeting the kids, fundraising to bring a group of kids to the local community, managing host family paperwork, and more.

The time commitment is approximately 10 hours a week with additional hours when the children arrive in the summer (July). Weekends and weekday evening availability is required. Work can be done remotely and Kidsave will provide an email address for Kidsave related correspondence. A cell phone is required as is a vehicle to travel to summer events.
opportunities.tags: Child Advocacy, adoption, orphans, families, Colombia
opportunities.title: Help older Colombian orphans find adoptive families!

opportunities.description:
Meals On Wheels of San Francisco and its volunteers provide seniors what they need to live independent and dignified lives -- nutritious meals, professional social work, and friendly human contact.

Good Neighbor Match Program

Volunteering in our Good Neighbor program offers you the opportunity to help seniors in a variety of ways. As a Good Neighbor volunteer matched with a senior client, you can help your senior match with routine chores, like grocery shopping or light housecleaning, or be a companion and friend to take walks or meet for conversation and a cup of tea. Many of our Good Neighbor Match volunteers do both! We will match you according to your preferences for what you want to do, when, and in what neighborhoods!

It's all about being a Good Neighbor to our senior neighbors!

Please email Emilie at ebrometbauer@mowsf.org to let us know that you're interested in being a Good Neighbor Match Volunteer.

opportunities.description:
Pets Are Wonderful Support (PAWS) is seeking volunteers to help keep those most vulnerable in our community together with their beloved pets. By helping PAWS' clients care for their pets you will be ensuring that low-income and disabled individuals in our community can continue to benefit from the unconditional love and healing powers of the human-animal bond.

Since 1987, PAWS has been helping hundreds of people maintain their pets through the dedication of volunteers who do dog walking, help with cat care, distribute pet food at the PAWS pet food bank and/or deliver pet food to clients, transport pets and clients to vet appointments and provide temporary pet foster care. If you are an animal lover and want to help others who are at risk of losing their own beloved companion animal, come join our team of fabulous volunteers today!

As a pet support volunteer, you will:
--Go through the internationally-recognized Shanti Model of Peer Support training
--Be matched 1-on-1 with a client and their pet
--Join a community of thoughtful, supportive volunteers and staff

If you decide to enroll as a pet support volunteer there is a mandatory volunteer training. Each interested volunteer must attend ALL of the training dates listed below.

· Friday, March 24th from 6pm-9:30pm

· Saturday, March 25th from 9am-6pm

· Sunday, March 26th from 9am-6pm

· and Wed., March 29th from 6pm-9:30pm

The purpose of this training is to prepare volunteers to work with individuals with life-threatening illnesses and their pets. The training will supply information about cancer, HIV/AIDS and other disabilities as well as teach communication and listening skills through a variety of interactive exercises.

You can make an invaluable difference to an underserved person and their beloved pet, and have your life changed in the process.

For more information or to apply, please contact Volunteer Services, at volunteerservices@shanti.org
opportunities.tags: support, dogs, cancer, food bank, Pet care, HIV, san francisco, LGBT, cats, pets, Queer, women, animals, disabilities

opportunities.description:
The Borgen Project is an innovative, national campaign that works with U.S. leaders to improve their response to the global poverty crisis.

Do you care about global issues and have a knack for writing easy to follow content? If you answered "yes" and would like to see your articles featured on The Borgen Project’s Blog or Magazine, then we would like to hear from you:

To be a Guest Contributor:

  1. Email your article according to us for review.
  2. We’ll reply within a timely manner with a decision - either "Yes, we’ll publish your article on our Blog or Magazine" or "Please give it another shot - this one isn’t in-line with what we’re looking for".
  3. You can send in as many articles as you’d like as often as you’d like.

This is an excellent opportunity to have your original content read by over 200,000 people that visit the borgenproject.org each month.

For more details on the format of the articles and where to submit them, please visit our website: http://borgenproject.org/volunteer-opportunities/

If you have any questions about the position please email us at hr@borgenproject.org
opportunities.tags: hunger, poverty, women's rights, foreign policy, Aid, Refugees
opportunities.title: Guest Contributor - Writer

opportunities.description:
The Justice & Diversity Center (JDC) trains volunteer attorneys to represent low-income tenants facing eviction. The most vulnerable tenants often face homelessness if they lose their housing. Attorneys represent clients throughout their eviction proceedings and get excellent litigation experience. The procedures are the same as those in business litigation: discovery; motions; settlement; and sometimes trial.

Volunteering with JDC is a great way for attorneys to contribute to our community while gaining legal experience and learning landlord-tenant law. Volunteer attorneys receive training and mentoring from JDC’s Landlord-Tenant Supervising Attorney. Attorneys must take our free two-part CLE training in family law (4.5 hours online, followed by 1 hour in person). In exchange for the free CLE, volunteers commit to taking two cases in the next year.
opportunities.tags: housing rights, legal services, Landlord-Tenant Law, pro bono
opportunities.title: Attorneys: Volunteer to Help Defend Vulnerable Tenants!

parentOrg.name: Justice & Diversity Center of The Bar Association of San Francisco

Volunteering with JDC is a great way for attorneys to contribute to our community while gaining legal experience and learning landlord-tenant law. Volunteer attorneys receive training and mentoring from JDC’s Landlord-Tenant Supervising Attorney. Attorneys must take our free two-part CLE training in family law (4.5 hours online, followed by 1 hour in person). In exchange for the free CLE, volunteers commit to taking two cases in the next year.

opportunities.description:
Enthusiastic about ocean awareness and conservation issues? Have an interest in independent film festivals? Want to learn more about the inner workings of media relations at a nonprofit organization? The San Francisco International Ocean Film Festival is seeking a Media Relations Intern. This is a great opportunity for the right candidate to gain exposure to the independent film community while honing their PR/media skills.

Responsibilities:

  • Maintain media contact database
  • Draft announcements for upcoming events, press releases and other media-related correspondence
  • Work closely with Executive Director, Marketing Committee and Social Media Coordinator on event promotion strategies

We are requesting a 3 month commitment of 6-8 hours per week. This position is based in our Presidio office but has some flexibility for telecommuting. This would be perfect for an undergraduate or graduate student studying Public Relations, Media Relations, Marketing or other associated degree. To get involved, please send your resume, a short email about yourself, a link to your Twitter account, why you are interested in working with SFIOFF, and your weekly and longer-term availability to info@oceanfilmfest.org.
opportunities.tags: public relations, Social Media, communications, media, Marketing, Film Festival

opportunities.description:
The Chess Club gives youth (currently youngest participant is 7) an opportunity to study & play friendly games of chess against their peers. The Club needs a couple of additional adult volunteers to coach players. You can be a novice yourself--you just need an interest in chess, a willingness to learn, and a patient, encouraging manner with youth--although experienced players are of course welcome!

The Club meets regularly on Saturdays from 1-3 p.m. at the Excelsior branch of the San Francisco Public Library, plus there are occasional tournaments at nearby library locations.

We ask for at least a year's commitment for volunteers. (Youth participation is on a drop-in basis, so if you need to miss the occasional Saturday, that can be accomodated.)

opportunities.description:
Join A Living Library in our year-round, Branch Living Library & Think Parks helping us to transform our sites at six schools in SF and one in NYC. In SF, we are located in Bernal Heights, OMI/Excelsior, and Chinatown. We are greening each campus and neighborhood with local school children. We are also developing the Bernal Heights Living Library & Think Park Nature Walk linking multiple schools, parks, public housing, streets, and other open spaces leading to hidden Islais Creek at south side of St. Mary's Park. In NYC, we are on Roosevelt Island creating beautiful learning landscapes.

If you want to help with gardening, landscaping, working with children and youth, you are invited to join us !
opportunities.tags: Revitalization, and, ecological, education, development, urban, transformation, agriculture, Community, hands-on

opportunities.description: The Justice & Diversity Center (JDC) advises low-income clients facing debt collection lawsuits at a free clinic on Wednesdays twice a month from 6:00-9:00 pm. Volunteer attorneys take our free 3-hour CLE training to learn collection defense law and assist consumers who have been sued by creditors. Volunteering at our clinic is an excellent way to help low-income people deeply impacted by the current economic crisis while learning a new area of law and developing litigation skills, all with a supervising attorney’s support. Volunteers individually counsel clients and possibly draftin pro per litigation documents. Other opportunities include negotiating on behalf of clients and representing them at hearings or even trial.

opportunities.plaintextDescription: The Justice & Diversity Center (JDC) advises low-income clients facing debt collection lawsuits at a free clinic on Wednesdays twice a month from 6:00-9:00 pm. Volunteer attorneys take our free 3-hour CLE training to learn collection defense law and assist consumers who have been sued by creditors. Volunteering at our clinic is an excellent way to help low-income people deeply impacted by the current economic crisis while learning a new area of law and developing litigation skills, all with a supervising attorney’s support. Volunteers individually counsel clients and possibly draft in pro per litigation documents. Other opportunities include negotiating on behalf of clients and representing them at hearings or even trial.
