opportunities.description:
Seven Tepees Youth Program is a nonprofit, community based organization that provides comprehensive youth development and college access and persistence services to over 1,000 youth annually through two programs: The Learning Center and The College & Career Program. Our Learning Center works with low income middle and high school students as well as recent college graduates for a period of more than ten years - spanning middle school and high school graduation into the first few years of college or career - offering academic support and guidance, college and career advising, environmental education, mentoring, job training and counseling. Our College and Career Program at Mission High School, a public school serving predominantly low income and first generation students, includes college and career advising, scholarship assistance, scholarships, test preparation support and college application assistance. Seven Tepees has an annual operating budget of approximately $1 million and inhabits the top floor of a building owned by the organization.

Mission:

The mission of Seven Tepees is to work with urban youth to foster the skills they need to make lifelong positive choices and to create their own opportunities for success. Founded in 1995 by retired Juvenile Justice Daniel Weinstein and Native American healer Hully Fetico, Seven Tepees began as a summer camp where youth lived in seven tepees - one representing each continent of the world.


Host a Seven Tepees Intern:

Seven Tepees 11th grade students participate in our Career Exploration Program (CEP). Over the course of the school year, youth explore their career interests, participate in workshops on topics related to navigating professional work environments, and tour local businesses.


During the summer between 11th and 12th grades, Seven Tepees seeks to place each youth in an internship with companies and businesses in the Bay Area. Internships conclude with Presentations of Learning by youth, sharing their experience, learnings, and goals for the future.


CEP Summer Internships allow your business to:

  • Attract future young professionals

  • Expand your workforce to complete short-term projects

  • Evaluate long-term employment potential as well as assess and train potential future employees

  • Boost your organization’s profile while supporting communities in the Mission and broader San Francisco


Why an internship?

  • It is an opportunity that allows youth to gain professional experience in a career field they may be considering

  • It allows youth to acquire, apply and improve practical skills in real-world business environments.

  • It provides youth with meaningful work experience that will be relevant as they transition from high school to adulthood.

CEP summer internships will take place between June and July, and will last 5 weeks. Youth are expected to work with host for a minimum of 20 hours per week.


Students are awarded a $600 stipend by Seven Tepees for their participation in CEP, a portion of which they earn when they complete 100 work hours at their respective host site.


Seven Tepees is committed to developing qualified interns. We strive to learn about your organization’s business goals, initiatives, and culture, and work to ensure an overall positive experience for your organization.


Responsibilities of an Internship Host:

  • Provide a written job description including the internship responsibilities, and supervise youth intern throughout the internship

  • Evaluate intern’s performance at the end of the internship using the CEP Internship Agree Forms


Responsibilities of a CEP Youth:

  • Demonstrate professional standards of conduct, i.e. the ability to perform work tasks safely, competently, and with good judgement.

  • Observe and be active in as many different facets of host site as possible.


Host a Professional Site Visit:

Throughout the academic year, Seven Tepees’ high school youth have an opportunity to tour local businesses. As part of the CEP program, visiting work sites allow our youth to understand the structure of your business, begin to recognize expectations and professional standards, and envision potential career options for themselves.

Your host site visit may include an activity or workshop specific to your business or organization.


If you are interested in hosting an intern, scheduling a site visit or require any additional information, please contact CEP Coordinator, Kirin Rajagopalan at kirin@7tepees.org

opportunities.title: Host a Summer Intern

opportunities.description:
The Justice & Diversity Center (JDC) trains volunteer attorneys to provide limited-scope representation to low-income tenants facing eviction. Through this project, attorneys represent individuals and families during their pre-trial settlement conferences only, not the whole eviction case. Volunteer shifts are available every Wednesday and Thursday afternoon from 12:15 pm to 4:30pm.

This pro bono work is an excellent opportunity to get valuable negotiation experience with a short time commitment. Attorneys must attend our free 2-hour CLE training before volunteering for this project. After attending the training, we ask volunteers to commit to 4 afternoon sessions within 6 months.

opportunities.description:
About

Women in Comedy is seeking a passionate, independent, bad-ass woman to head up our San Francisco chapter.

Women In Comedy in a nonprofit 501(c) (3) that is headquartered in the Comedy Capital of the U.S. - Chicago. Our work has been featured in ELLE magazine, Full Frontal With Samantha Bee, NY Magazine, The Chicago Tribune, Comcast, and more. We are expanding our outreach to help women all over the country and we need your help!

If you have a passion for leadership, gender parity, love to laugh, and love the idea of empowering women and girls - you will love volunteering with our organization. This is a great resume builder and an exciting experience for the right person.

IF YOU ARE:

  • A Leader

  • Independent

  • A team-player

  • Responsive

  • Reliable

  • Outgoing

  • Committed and Passionate about empowering women

  • Comedy enthusiast who is fun to work with


We want to hear from you!



CHAPTER PRESIDENT OVERVIEW OF DUTIES

As a leader in our organization, your vital role as President of the San Francisco chapter will be to carry out our mission statement to empower, connect, and advocate for women and girls seeking paid careers in comedy. The President is the head planner and recruiter for our 3 key events each year (put on in sister cities across the nation in Feb, July, and Dec).

If you are an upbeat, hard-working, and reliable individual with a passion for planning and uplifting women then you will love this role as Chapter President of San Francisco.

KEY DUTIES

  • Will create a chapter in San Francisco and put on 2 to 3 events a year with support from our headquarters in Chicago

    • this role is a 1-year min commitment and is responsible for finding its replacement at the end of 2017

  • Responsible for recruiting 3 other part time volunteers to your chapter board to help with your chapter and meet for bi- monthly meetings (Recommended 2-3 other passionate people on your chapter board)

  • Coordinating event details as delegated by the Executive director of Women in Comedy (Chicago) including logistics, spreadsheets, phone calls, emails, on-site visits, etc.

  • Phone calls, emails, and outreach to build a network

  • 10 hrs of estimated volunteer work per week

    • commitment estimate is based on quality completion of tasks; workload can be lessened by recruiting a committed and reliable team


Requirements:

  • Has access to a computer, internet, and smart phone

  • Has reliable transportation

  • Lives within 30 min of SF

  • Knowledge of online platforms such as google drive and generally tech savvy






BENEFITS

  • Get to lead a chapter and have autonomy with whom you chose to fill your executive board

  • Help women in comedy

  • Meet and network with fascinating people

  • Gain skills in Leadership, Event Planning, HR, and Project Management

  • We always hire from within from our pool of dedicated volunteers

  • You get to be part of an entertaining, exciting, and unique community


Start date Feb 1st, 2017

opportunities.description:
Join our community of plant enthusiasts; learn about native plants as you help us grow our national park! Volunteer activities vary throughout the seasons and may include, seed collection, transplanting, pruning, weeding, nursery maintenance, and general care of our Habitat Demonstration Garden.

Volunteer programs take place on Wednesdays and Saturdays, 1-4 pm.

Visit our website to register and learn more about this program: http://www.parksconservancy.org/get-involved/volunteer/drop-in-programs/presidio-nursery.html

Volunteers must complete the Volunteer Agreement Form and volunteers under the age of 18 must have the parent/guardian approval section signed.

Visit our Volunteer Homepage for more details about individual, group, family-friendly, or long-term volunteer opportunities: www.parksconservancy.org/volunteer

The Golden Gate National Parks Volunteer Program is a cooperative parkwide effort of the Golden Gate National Parks Conservancy, the National Park Service, and the Presidio Trust.

opportunities.description:
RRRcomputer.org's vision is "1 Child, 1 Computer" to become a reality. Our mission is to reclaim, refurbish, reuse computers from recycling to reuse for education for low income K-12 kids. We reduce computer waste by refurbishing the computers to put back into circulation for the kids to use for internet search for research, and doing their homework assignment at home. The computers that are going to recycling is still useful for their needs. We do our part in saving the planet and improve the education of children.

We are looking for an experienced board member to be Chairman of the Board to guide the current board members. Preferably having been a leadership role to an organization. If you have the passion for education by providing the technology, it would be a plus. Looking forward to hearing from you.
Hue

opportunities.description:
Seven Tepees Youth Program is a nonprofit, community based organization that provides comprehensive youth development and college access and persistence services to over 1,000 youth annually through two programs: The Learning Center and The College & Career Program. Our Learning Center works with low income middle and high school students as well as recent college graduates for a period of over ten years - spanning middle school and high school graduation into the first few years of college or career - offering academic support and guidance, college and career advising, environmental education, mentoring, job training and counseling. Our College and Career Program at Mission High School, a public school serving predominantly low income and first generation students, includes college and career advising, scholarship assistance, scholarships, test preparation support and college application assistance. Seven Tepees has an annual operating budget of approximately $1 million and inhabits the top floor of a building owned by the organization.

Mission:

The mission of Seven Tepees is to work with urban youth to foster the skills they need to make lifelong positive choices and to create their own opportunities for success. Founded in 1995 by retired Juvenile Justice Daniel Weinstein and Native American healer Hully Fetico, Seven Tepees began as a summer camp where youth lived in seven tepees - one representing each continent of the world.


Volunteers make Seven Tepees Youth Program possible, as we rely on your support to offer students every opportunity available.

Seven Tepees is currently looking for after-school tutors for the 2016-2017 school year at our Learning Center in the Mission at 3177 17th Street at S. Van Ness.

Sign-up for our next volunteer orientation, which takes place on Thursday, January 19th from 6:30 to 8pm.

Tutoring is provided to Seven Tepees students Monday through Thursday as part of the after-school program. Tutors give youth an opportunity to achieve academic success by giving personalized support to each student. Our students are in middle school (6th-8th grades) and high school (9th-12th grades), and their studies include math, science, history and literature. Tutors should be comfortable supporting students in general studies, and tutors with specialized areas of expertise/study are encouraged to apply.

We are in need of tutors who are proficient in subjects such as high school math, biology, physics and chemistry.

Tutors commit to at least 1 day per week - we welcome more! - for 1.5 to 2 hours depending on grade level. We are currently in need of tutors Monday through Thursday.


Middle School: 4:00 to 6:00 pm
High School: 4:30 to 6:00 pm


To start tutoring with Seven Tepees, please contact Gaëlle Feliz, Volunteer Coordinator, at volunteer@7tepees.org to apply to become a volunteer and to sign-up for our next volunteer orientation, which takes place on Thursday, January 19th from 6:30 to 8pm.

opportunities.description:
Host Committee Member ~ SF Day Labor Program and Women’s Collective

The San Francisco Day Labor Program and Women’s Collective (DLP/WC) is a grassroots-organized program deeply rooted in the community with strong support of key stakeholders. For over 20 years, the DLP/WC has been extremely successful at uniting, empowering, and organizing immigrant workers for dignified work and fair wages in San Francisco. Workers are organized in two collectives, one of men and one of women, to build collective power, develop skills, and operate a shared business.

Members of the collectives work together to eradicate the injustices that affect day laborers and domestic workers, fostering an organized environment where all workers can build their dignity, power and leadership. Members share a vision of a community where day laborers and domestic workers have the same opportunities and rights than any other worker. They accomplish this by offering each other opportunities to learn, work and participate in the movement of immigrant and domestic workers. The collectives are co-founders and leaders in the National Day Labor Organizing Network, National Domestic Workers Alliance, Progressive Workers Alliance, California Domestic Workers Coalition, Jobs with Justice, San Francisco Rising, among others.

In 2015, the DLP/WC started an exciting reorganization process with the objective of establishing a more sustainable and scalable model that enhances the impact of the program in the lives of immigrant workers.

The DLP/WC is looking for Host Committee Members for the upcoming 25th Anniversary Gala this October. This volunteer works with a committed group of fundraising and event planning professionals. The ideal candidate considers one’s self an extrovert, loves social occasions, has experience in PR and/or Fundraising and is comfortable asking their individuals in their vast network for favors.

Position Objective: This position assists with fundraising and event planning efforts of the Host Committee for the upcoming 25th Anniversary Gala this November.

This position is part of a volunteer team that supports the fundraising initiatives of the Day Labor Program and Women’s Collective. It is directed to transforming the lives of low-wage immigrant workers at a personal level, in order to develop leaders who can promote the dignity of their work and transform the industries in which they work.

Anniversary Event: La Quinceañera

It has been 15 years since we started this work and is a great accomplishment to have reached this point. We have helped many people throughout the years and we want to both celebrate and raise money so that we can continue helping people. With this event, we want to fundraise $30,000-$50,000 to strengthen and expand the impact of La Collective programming in the lives of immigrant workers.

Objective

Our principal objective is to raise money towards the launch of a skills development initiative, that will allow La Colectiva's women discover and develop new skills and be able to find new jobs that will allow them to age with dignity. We also want to promote La Colectiva's brand to new SF employers as well as celebrate and recognize the path of La Colectiva during all these years.

It is important to understand that this event is not only a celebration for members of La Colectiva, but also a recruitment event to capture those professionals newly arrived to San Francisco, specially Tech workers between 21 and 40 years old (both men and women) who can become new employers for our women.

Message

Our message will be "Aging with dignity" and will be targeted towards all those women that are getting older and can't continue working cleaning related jobs. This money will go towards their development so that they can find other jobs.

Responsibilities:

  • Offers support and connections for event donations (both in kind and monetary)

  • Provides feedback and ideas regarding event planning

  • Conducts outreach and advertising

Expected Commitment:

5-6 hours per month

8 hours during October 2016

Desired Skills:

  • Very sociable with a large professional network

  • Previous experience with event planning and online outreach

  • Comfortable with and experienced in asking for donations and/or corporate sponsorships

  • Proven ability to build productive business relationships

ABOUT THE DLP/WC

Founded in 1991 and inspired by the socio-ecologic model, the DLP/WC unites, empowers and organizes immigrant workers to access dignified work and fair wages by building collective power, developing skills, and operating businesses. The DLP/WC power center offers on-demand labor for environmentally-conscious cleaning services, childcare, patient care, moving, hauling, painting, yard work, handyman repairs, installations and more.

The San Francisco Day Labor Program and Women’s Collective is a program of Dolores Street Community Services, an equal-opportunity employer that seeks applicants of the greatest diversity possible, including women, people of color, lesbian/ gay/ bisexual/ transgender individuals, people living with HIV and persons with disabilities.

opportunities.plaintextDescription: Host Committee Member ~ SF Day Labor Program and Women’s Collective The San Francisco Day Labor Program and Women’s Collective (DLP/WC) is a grassroots-organized program deeply rooted in the community with strong support of key stakeholders. For over 20 years, the DLP/WC has been extremely successful at uniting, empowering, and organizing immigrant workers for dignified work and fair wages in San Francisco. Workers are organized in two collectives, one of men and one of women, to build collective power, develop skills, and operate a shared business. Members of the collectives work together to eradicate the injustices that affect day laborers and domestic workers, fostering an organized environment where all workers can build their dignity, power and leadership. Members share a vision of a community where day laborers and domestic workers have the same opportunities and rights than any other worker. They accomplish this by offering each other opportunities to learn, work and participate in the movement of immigrant and domestic workers. The collectives are co-founders and leaders in the National Day Labor Organizing Network, National Domestic Workers Alliance, Progressive Workers Alliance, California Domestic Workers Coalition, Jobs with Justice, San Francisco Rising, among others. EF makes all arrangements and offers 24/7 support

opportunities.description:
Help restore and maintain park trails. Volunteer activities include, retreading trail, restoring native habitat, moving materials, replacing fence, and constructing trail structures. This program is great for those who are not afraid to get dirty, want a great workout, and enjoy meeting new folks!

Volunteer programs take place every 3rd Saturday, 9 am-noon.

Visit our website to register or learn more about this program:
http://www.parksconservancy.org/get-involved/volunteer/drop-in-programs/golden-gate-trail-crew.html

Volunteers must complete the Volunteer Agreement Form and volunteers under the age of 18 must have the parent/guardian approval section signed.

Wear clothes that can get dirty. Long pants and closed-toe shoes are required. Bring layers for changing weather and rain gear if necessary. Bring a personal water bottle and sunscreen.

Visit our Volunteer Homepage for more details about individual, group, family-friendly, or long-term volunteer opportunities: www.parksconservancy.org/volunteer

The Golden Gate National Parks Volunteer Program is a cooperative parkwide effort of the Golden Gate National Parks Conservancy, the National Park Service, and the Presidio Trust.

Cancer surviors can make a difference in the lives of newly diagnosed patients by connecting with them in a way that others cannot. As a Peer Support volunteer you will visit patients at their bedside and uplift their spirits while providing a compassionate, listening ear.

We ask that you commit to volunteering at least 1 hour per week. The program requires 2 screening interviews, a hospital orientation, and a 9 hour program training.

opportunities.description:
Your Words Can Make a Difference. Pro Bono Copywriting Projects.

The Taproot Foundation is looking for excellent wordsmiths interested in sharing their talents with local nonprofit organizations. The pro bono Copywriter is responsible for creating the marketing copy for website, brochure, naming, key messages, or annual report projects and will work closely with the nonprofit staff to improve existing marketing copy.

A successful pro bono Copywriter:

  • Has 3 years of experience in copywriting at a marketing or advertising firm
  • Must have the ability to translate ideas and concepts into words
  • Be able to take direction and feedback from the team and client
  • Be able to provide writing samples

A Service Grant project requires a 3-5 hour commitment each week over the course of approximately 6 months. This opportunity is flexible enough to work around the schedule of a full-time job.

Taproot Foundation makes it easy to make a difference. We’re a nonprofit organization that makes business talent available to organizations that are working to improve society. Our goal is to ensure that one day all organizations with promising solutions will be equipped to successfully take on urgent social challenges. To date, we have engaged close to 7,700 professionals on close to 2,300 pro bono projects benefiting education, health, environment, social service, and arts initiatives.

Now it’s your turn to join the movement and Make It Matter.

opportunities.description:
Protect our environment and the special place in which we live!

Citizens’ Climate Lobby (CCL) wants you! As a volunteer, you’ll be a member of the fastest growing and most effective climate advocacy group. You will work with concerned California citizens to slow the effects of climate change. Let's work together to protect our beautiful ecosystems, livelihoods and way of life. Please respond to our posting for an invitation to learn more.

You will:

  • Meet with Congressional leaders.
  • Write letters to the editors and op-eds.
  • Meet with local media.
  • Educate your community about global warming and legislative solutions.

We provide:

  • Monthly national conference calls with expert guest speakers.
  • Weekly skill building sessions.
  • On-line network with CCL volunteers across the U.S.
  • National conference and lobby week in D.C.

Volunteers commit to an average of 4-6 hours a month. Some of our volunteers dedicate more time than that. We hold no upper limit on your dedication to a stable climate and livable world.

To learn more about us, please join an Introductory Conference Call. The next call is Wednesday at 5:00 p.m. Pacific/6:00 p.m. Mountain/7:00 p.m. Central/8:00 p.m. Eastern. This is an opportunity to learn about CCL. It is one hour, and there will be opportunities to ask questions. The conference call number is 1-866-642-1665, passcode 440699#.

opportunities.description:
The Pediatric Brain Tumor Foundation is the world's leading nonprofit funder of childhood brain tumor research. We serve the more than 28,000 children and teens in the United States who are living with the diagnosis of a brain tumor. Our programs include free educational information about brain tumors, college scholarships, Ride for Kids motorcycle charity events and Starry Night walk/runs.

Position summary: The Sponsorship and Corporate Lead is responsible for securing local cash and in-kind sponsors, recruiting corporate teams, event entertainment and
coordinating PBTF pin-up distribution and sales in support of two fundraising events - Starry Night walk/run and one additional fundraiser TBD.

Major Responsibilities:

  • Recruit a sub-Task Force team of volunteers to assist with securing sponsors, corporate teams, inkind donations and local PBTF pin-up distribution
  • Work with PBTF staff to solicit sponsorship prospects, provide information about PBTF and Starry Night and secure sponsors and corporate fundraising teams
  • Contact local businesses about providing in-kind donations such as food, beverages, survivor goodie bag materials and more for Starry Night
  • Work with Community Outreach Lead to recruit day of event entertainment and a local celebrity emcee
  • Contact local businesses with information about PBTF pin-up program
  • Work with PBTF staff to coordinate the distribution of PBTF pin-ups and track sales
  • Attend monthly volunteer Task Force meetings and provide updates to Secretary and Task Force Chair
  • Coordinate and lead sub-Task Force meetings to meet goals and ensure volunteers stay on track with their assignments
  • Promote Starry Night through daily professional activities
  • Attend and provide volunteer leadership at events

Time Required (approximately):

Per month:

  • Attend volunteer Task Force meeting (1) - 2 hours
  • Coordinate sponsorship and corporate volunteers - 5 hours
  • Track sponsorship and corporate progress and complete tasks -7 hours
  • Provide correspondence to Chair, Secretary and PBTF staff - 1 hour

Total: 15 hours per month

Additional time requirements:
One initial planning meeting with Task Force Chair - 1 hour

opportunities.description:
The Spring Cleaning All Year Round program is a meaningful volunteer opportunity to provide light house cleaning to a MOWSF senior. Volunteers work in teams of 2-4 for no more than 3 hours per cleaning.

More than 65% of our seniors live alone and many of them have physical and financial limitations, so basic housework is difficult, if not impossible, to do. This volunteer opportunity is a great way to meet a homebound senior and lift their spirits by removing dust and clutter, as well as providing them with social interaction.

This opportunity is good for volunteers who are looking for flexible weekend opportunities and to meet a variety of MOWSF seniors and volunteers. We ask volunteers in the Spring Cleaning program to volunteer at least four times a year. Ideally volunteers might have access to a car to take turns with others in picking up & returning cleaning items but that is not a requirement.

Also volunteers are required to undergo a thorough training and a background check.

MOWSF provides the cleaning supplies, so all volunteers need to bring are friendly smiles and a willingness to roll up their sleeves!

OUR MISSION
Meals On Wheels of San Francisco and its volunteers provide seniors what they need to live independent and dignified lives -- nutritious meals, professional social work, and friendly human contact.

opportunities.description:
Corporate Client Services Internship

UniversalGiving(r), an award-winning global nonprofit, is seeking a committed, dedicated Corporate Client Services Intern. The Intern will play a strong role in serving our Fortune 500 clients by ensuring our corporate clients partner with top performing NGOs. You will work with a stellar team vetting NGO Partners all over the world by applying our 24-stage Quality Model(tm). With proven track record, you may be put on additional corporate projects. If you are passionate about social change and enjoy working with an international team, come join UniversalGiving!

Full Description

UniversalGiving(r) is an award-winning website allowing people to donate and volunteer with top performing vetted projects all over the world. Unique to UniversalGiving, 100% goes directly to the cause. UniversalGiving Corporate provides Strategy, Operations, and NGO Vetting to scale companies’ CSR programs in more than 120 countries; our Corporate Services allow us to become self-sustaining. UniversalGiving has been featured on the homepage of BusinessWeek,Oprah.com,CBS, The Wall Street Journal, and The New York Times.

The Corporate Client Services Intern will support the Corporate Services team in serving multiple local and international corporate partners. You will help perform critical Vetting Services by implementing UniversalGiving’s proprietary Quality Model(tm) and corporate client-specific requirements. The intern will help ensure that NGOs seeking corporate support are top-performing, quality organizations. With proven track record, you will be trained in other aspects of Corporate Services and given more responsibilities. This is a great opportunity to work with a very specialized CSR and non-profit vetting team.

As a UniversalGiving intern, you’ll have the opportunity to work with a diverse, passionate team representing over 25 cultures. Our work environment is fast-paced and entrepreneurial, yet collaborative and fun, including monthly potlucks and team events. Come work with us to achieve our vision "To Create A World Where Giving and Volunteering Are A Natural Part of Everyday Life(r)!

Responsibilities:

  • Draft correspondence for both corporate partners and nonprofits
  • Perform due diligence on international and domestic nonprofits
  • Familiarize yourself with tax code and legal status pertaining to nonprofits
  • Work both independently and as part of a team on multiple client service assignments
  • Work against deadlines in a dynamic environment where producing deliverables is expected
  • Other duties related to operations and administration

With proven track record

  • Special CSR projects as needed on an on-going basis

Qualifications:

  • Excellent written and verbal communication skills
  • Meticulous attention to detail
  • Strong critical thinking skills
  • Computer skills, Microsoft Word, Excel and PowerPoint
  • Commitment to using and updating Salesforce, our Relationship Database

Benefits:

  • Gain experience at a unique social entrepreneurship that has a global impact
  • Gain entry, exposure, and experience in the nonprofit industry
  • Increase your understanding of and alignment with global issues
  • Collaborate within a positive team atmosphere
  • Network with other for-profit and nonprofit professionals in an open office environment
  • Career mentoring with Pamela Hawley, Founder & CEO of UniversalGiving
  • For students, class credit can be arranged according to school requirements

Duration: Minimum 15-20 hours per week required for the duration of the internship, at least a minimum of 3 to 4 months. Ideal candidates are available to work out of our San Francisco office 3-4 days/week (Monday through Friday).

**With proven track record, this position may turn into a paid position.

Testimonial

"I came into UniversalGiving as a shy recent graduate. I soon saw that this internship was like no other-- I worked on high-level projects, I was mentored by the CEO (unheard of!), and I bonded with the grooviest team I have ever come across. The nerves left, but the values and experiences will stay."

Germaine Lau, former Executive Assistant Intern

"UniversalGiving is committed to providing corporations like Cisco with global strategy, policy, operations and rigorous NGO vetting that supports operational excellence. They strengthen our CSR programs locally and around the world."

Michael Yutrzenka, Senior Director, Corporate Affairs Cisco Foundation

About UniversalGiving

UniversalGiving’s Mission: To connect people to quality giving and volunteer opportunities worldwide.

UniversalGiving’s Vision: "To Create A World Where Giving and Volunteering Are A Natural Part of Everyday Life"(r)

UniversalGiving(r) is an award-winning website allowing people to donate and volunteer with top performing projects all over the world. Our projects are vetted through a proprietary Quality Model(tm) to ensure the most effective, trustworthy philanthropy possible. Unique to UniversalGiving, we take no cut on donations. 100% of your donation goes directly to the cause.

UniversalGiving Corporate consults with Fortune 500 companies on the Strategy, Operations and NGO Vetting for their international giving and volunteering programs all over the world. Some clients include Cisco, Symantec, Fluor, Sabre, Gap, BHP Billiton, RSF Social Finance, and inovia.

Located in the heart of San Francisco, UniversalGiving has been profiled on CBS and in FOX Business Network, and has also been featured in BusinessWeek, Fast Company, CSRWire, WomenEntrepreneur, Oprah.com, NBC News, The Christian Science Monitor, The New York Times, The Financial Times, MarketWatch, CNNMoney.com, Change.org and See Change Magazine. UniversalGiving has been featured three times on Great Nonprofits’ annual Top Nonprofits lists and is a Webby Award Honoree.

CEO Pamela Hawley is a winner of the Jefferson Award (the Nobel Prize in Community Service) and was selected as one of 50 leaders to the White House's Next Generation Leadership and Social Innovation event. She is a Finalist for Ernst & Young’s Entrepreneur of the Year Award, and a Colburn S. Wilbur Leadership Fellow at the Global Ethics Institute. She is a Fast Company Expert Blogger on CSR.

To Apply:

Email your resume, cover letter, two writing samples (two pages max), and three professional references with contact information (phone and email) to volunteers@universalgiving.org with "Corporate Client Services Intern" in the subject line. Applications are reviewed on a rolling basis. No phone calls please.

UniversalGiving(r) is committed to understanding and representing the diverse populations it serves worldwide. Members of all ages, genders, sexual orientations, races, ethnicities, nationalities, physical abilities or disabilities, religions or beliefs, and cultures are welcome as employees and volunteers in our organization. We believe that a diverse team will best serve our diverse populations.

Follow us on social media:

  • UniversalGiving’s website
  • Like us on Facebook
  • Follow Us on Twitter: @ UniversalGiving and @ PamelaHawley
  • Follow Us on Pinterest: @ UniversalGiving
  • CEO Pamela Hawley’s Blog: Living and Giving

opportunities.plaintextDescription: Corporate Client Services Internship UniversalGiving(r), an award-winning global nonprofit, is seeking a committed, dedicated Corporate Client Services Intern. The Intern will play a strong role in serving our Fortune 500 clients by ensuring our corporate clients partner with top performing NGOs. You will work with a stellar team vetting NGO Partners all over the world by applying our 24-stage Quality Model(tm). With proven track record, you may be put on additional corporate projects. If you are passionate about social change and enjoy working with an international team, come join UniversalGiving! Get to know people from across the globe on our International Pub Crawl! HI San Francisco Fisherman's Wharf partners with two sister hostels to bring guests together for one unforgettable night! Pub Crawls are a great way for guests to get to know one another. Leaders should be friendly, outgoing and responsible. There will always be at least two leaders present.

We are looking for volunteers to lead weekly or monthly. We are happy to work with your schedule. If you are on the shy side, feel free to bring a friend and volunteer together!

opportunities.description:
EWAHA is in need of a Web Master to improve, expand and update our Wordpress website. Basic HTML and social media savvy needed, including simple video editing. Also a chance to design flyers, posters and other collateral to advertise our courses and events.

An exciting non-profit, EWAHA and Qigong Grandmaster Dr. Effie Chow, have for 39 years been dedicated to training, clinical treatment, and the dissemination of information on Qigong and Complementary Alternative Medicine (CAM). Combining the best of Traditional Chinese Medicine (TCM) and Western Medicine is the core of our philosophy and practice.

Please send full resume and date and times available to eastwestqi@aol.com There is an opportunity for an ongoing paid job!

opportunities.description:
The RDNC's Grocery Giveaway program aims to reduce food waste and spread more free food around our community to those in need. The RDNC runs food pantries and a Home Delivered Groceries program twice every week. Volunteers in our Grocery Giveaway program use leftover food from these programs and bring them to community partner sites, so that families and community members have access to groceries.

We are looking for volunteers who can come to the RDNC (741 30th Ave) anywhere from 3:00-4:30 pm, load their car with some boxed groceries, and deliver them to a partner site in the Richmond District. We run Grocery Giveaways every day of the week, so we can be flexible with your schedule.

opportunities.description:
Mission Graduates' Extended Day Program (EDP) is an after-school program that focuses on positive youth development outcomes and helping needy children excel academically. The EDP serves 400 children across three sites, spanning K-5th grades.

The EDP at Bryant Elementary School (2641 25th Street, San Francisco, CA 94110) provides after-school programs from 2:40-6:00 pm Monday-Friday. Mission Graduates is seeking volunteers to give our students individual attention to help them succeed.

Volunteers help students with class work, participate in our themed-lessons and academic enrichment activities and support our Classroom Coordinators with daily lesson plans.

Join us for Homework Help Mon-Thurs from 3:45-4:30pm!

Note: The school year began August 17, but we can get started on paperwork and have you ready to begin!
---
Mission Graduates is a nonprofit organization that increases the number of K-12 students in San Francisco’s Mission District who are prepared for and complete a college education.

opportunities.description:
The Pediatric Brain Tumor Foundation is the world's leading nonprofit funder of childhood brain tumor research. We serve the more than 28,000 children and teens in the United States who are living with the diagnosis of a brain tumor. Our programs include free educational information about brain tumors, college scholarships, Ride for Kids motorcycle charity events and Starry Night walk/runs.

We are looking for a PBTF Task Force Chair to help lead our event fundraising committee.

Position summary: Work with PBTF staff and volunteer leads in recruiting and training a team of volunteers to plan and implement all aspects of our Starry Night run/walk event and one additional fundraising event (TBD)in accordance with campaign standards. The PBTF Task Force Chair assists in creating action plans and managing the volunteer Task Force leadership.

Major Responsibilities:

  • Coordinate and lead monthly meetings
  • Create meeting agendas
  • Offer leadership, guidance and support to volunteer Task Force members
  • Promote events through daily professional activities
  • Assist in securing event sponsors, teams and participants
  • Appoint volunteers to serve as volunteer Task Force members for the following categories of focus: Recruitment, Community Outreach, Race and Sponsorship & Corporate Outreach
  • Ensure Task Force members stay on track with their assignments
  • Attend and provide volunteer leadership at events
  • The PBTFTask Force Chair is responsible for recruiting a Task Force Secretary to assist with administrative duties such as meeting coordination, agenda preparation, sponsorship and donation tracking, etc.

Time Required (approximately):

Per month:

  • Attend and lead volunteer Task Force meeting (1) - 2 hours
  • Review volunteer Task Force member updates and correspond with PBTF staff -10 hours
  • Assist with securing sponsorships and other tasks - 9 hours
  • Total: 21 hours per month
  • Additional time commitments: One initial planning meeting - 2 hours

opportunities.description:
Reading Partners needs volunteers like you to provide students in under-resourced elementary schools in your community with the proven, individualized reading support they need to read at grade level by fourth grade.

Reading is the foundation for all future learning.The ability to read transforms lives and can empower children to reach their full potential. Research shows that when students can read at grade level by fourth grade, they have a greater opportunity to succeed in school and in life.

With your help, we can equip students with the foundational skills they need to read at grade level. Each week, you will meet one-on-one with your student every week to help them develop strong literacy skills and discover a passion for reading. We'll provide a structured curriculum, in-person training, and ongoing support to help your student thrive. Rigorous research has proven that Reading Partners significantly increases reading proficiency.

No teaching experience required and anyone over the age of 14 can volunteer. Flexible Monday to Thursday volunteer times between 9am and 5pm.

Visit our website at www.readingpartners.org/volunteer to sign up and learn more.

opportunities.description:
House Tours: Volunteers lead the public through tours of the exterior and interior of the house. Public tours are offered on Wednesday, Saturday, and Sunday. All tours of the house are guided. Volunteers complete training in order to conduct tours and must commit to two shifts per month.

Walking Tour: Volunteers lead walking tour of surrounding Pacific Heights Neighborhood. Tours last 1 ½ hours to 2 hours and are offered on Sundays Volunteers complete training in order to conduct tours and must commit to two shifts per month.


School Tours: Tours are offered to select 3rd-grade classrooms through our popular Heritage Hikes program. December through May school groups schedule visits for Tuesdays and Thursdays and are given a volunteer guided tour of the house. Teachers lead the students on a tour of the surrounding neighborhoods. House tours involve additional teaching aids and last around 1 hour. Volunteers and teachers complete training in order to conduct Heritage Hikes tours and must commit to two shifts per month.


Admissions/Bookstore: During public tour hours a bookstore is set up in the ballroom. Volunteers set up the cash register and book displays taking admissions and selling items. Volunteers must complete simple cashier training to work in the bookstore and must commit to two shifts per month.


In the meantime, you may want to learn more about what our docents do by taking a house tour. Tours of the house are given on Wednesdays and Saturdays 12:00 - 3:00 and Sundays 11:00 - 4:00.

opportunities.description:
Share your special skills! Lend a helping hand to make small maintenance repairs in seniors' home or teach a senior how to use their new computer or cut a homebound senior's hair!

Handyperson and special skilled volunteers help create safe and healthy living environments or improve a senior's quality of life.

Help create a safer living environment for homebound senior clients by changing light bulbs or installing smoke detectors, plugging in and testing a microwave, or making small repairs like securing locks and hanging curtain rods. Help improve a senior's quality of life by helping them with their computers, cutting hair, or hanging their favorite pictures on the wall.

While some of these tasks require some specialized skills, many require just the basics. Do you know how to use a hammer or the internet? We can use your help!

While we require a minimum commitment of four hours per month, volunteer hours are very flexible because of the "on-call" nature of the job. We typically call volunteers as repairs are needed. Volunteers in this program must be at least 18 years old. No car is necessary.

Other requirements include a volunteer training and successful completion of a background check.

OUR MISSION
Meals On Wheels of San Francisco and its volunteers provide seniors what they need to live independent and dignified lives -- nutritious meals, professional social work, and friendly human contact.

Volunteering in our Good Neighbor program offers the ability to help seniors in a variety of roles. Within the Good Neighbor program, volunteers can choose whether they want to help with grocery shopping, housecleaning, handy work, or foster a friendship with a senior!

Please email Emilie at ebrometbauer@mowsf.org if you are interested.

opportunities.description:
Nominations are now open for Social Enterprise Alliance, San Francisco Bay Area Chapter's 2016-2017 board of directors.

The current board members and officers will be completing their terms of service at the end of 2016. We will be electing new directors and officers at our membership meeting this coming November from a slate of candidates recommended by the current board or proposed by the chapter's membership.

You are invited at this time to nominate a candidate for the board, or volunteer to serve yourself. Serving as a board member allows you to meet and network with other leaders across sectors and generations using business for advancing social justice, support Bay Area social enterprise practitioners and social entrepreneurs, and help to define and build the field of social enterprise.

Here are the requirements to serve as a board member or officer:

  1. Maintain or obtain an active membership in SEA and live or work in the S.F. Bay Area. (Membership in the chapter is automatically included in your SEA membership.)
  2. Be actively engaged in social enterprise as a practitioner, supporter, advisor, entrepreneur or currently-enrolled student.
  3. Contribute 4-6 hoursper month to chapter activities (8-10 hours for officers and committee chairs).
  4. Attend one board meeting per month (meetings are in person every 3rd month; others are via teleconference).
  5. Actively serve on one standing committee of the chapter (e.g. Program or Membership).
The skills we've selected in this posting are what we're looking to add to our team, but need not be represented by one Board Member. Rather, if you have at least one (say, fundraising) then that's fantastic!

opportunities.description:
Sunday Streets is an open street program in San Francisco that creates miles of car-free space for people to enjoy free, fun activities provided by neighborhood groups, nonprofit orgs, and local merchants. Prior to each event, considerable outreach is involved. That’s where the Street Team comes in!

What: Street Team Volunteers get to explore San Francisco neighborhoods by foot and invite neighboring residents and the community to participate at Sunday Streets to ensure everyone is notified of parking and traffic changes. Times can be flexible. Street Team shifts are 3-hours.

When:

  • Saturday, February 25th
  • Thursday, March 2nd
  • Wednesday, March 8th

Time: 10am - 1pm

Where: We will meet on Valencia Street in the Mission District.

How to Sign Up: Respond to VolunteerMatch, or go to www.sundaystreetssf.com/get-involved/volunteers to sign-up for a shift.

Additional Help: If you'd like to do additional outreach in a particular neighborhood - deliver posters and fliers to neighbors and businesses - or would like to help out but are unable to attend the scheduled volunteer shift, please email volunteer@livablecity.org. We'd love to have your help!

Do you want to grow your skills in marketing and outreach? Apply your talents to help cultivate healthy youth and communities in San Francisco?

The Volunteer Program Coordinator will play a vital role on our team by creating and implementing an amazing volunteer program, outreaching to the community, organizing special events, and working closely with our staff to strengthen our partnerships.

This is a wonderful opportunity for an organized, outgoing, person who wants to make their mark on an organization and a real impact on the community.

Check out the job description for more information: https://my.americorps.gov/mp/listing/viewListing.do?id=71118&fromSearch=true

We're accepting applications until February 24th through the VISTA portal. Please contact Kelly ErnstFriedman at kelly@communitygrows.org for more information.

VISTAs receive several benefits, including a stipend, education award, health benefits and more. VISTAS are permitted to have another part-time job or be in school during their term. Learn more about the AmeriCorps VISTA Program here: https://www.nationalservice.gov/programs/americorps/americorps-vista

opportunities.description:
Position: Soccer Coach / Youth Mentor for America SCORES Bay Area

Location: A public elementary school in San Francisco, Oakland, Redwood City or San Rafael

Hours: One or two days per week for 1 hour between 3-5pm

Start date: March 2017

Position Summary

In this volunteer role you become a "SCORES Coach" to support America SCORES mission: to inspire urban youth to lead healthy lives, be engaged students, and have the confidence and character to make a difference in the world. The SCORES Coach’s role is to help coach and mentor students in a soccer program for public elementary school kids. This person is supervised by the School Site Coordinator and America SCORES staff.

Qualifications: Comfortable working with urban, multi-ethnic children. Strong verbal and interpersonal communication skills. Patient and able to multi-task. Background check and TB test may be required.

To Apply: Please email Yuri Morales at ymorales@americascores.org

opportunities.description:
Do you have a curiosity about global affairs? Lead a U.S. foreign policy discussion group today!

For over 55 years, the Foreign Policy Association's Great Decisions program has brought together people and communities to encourage individuals to engage in the world around them and to think critically about the global issues facing policymakers.

Each year, FPA produces the Great Decisions briefing book, examining eight U.S. foreign policy and global affairs topics. All across the U.S., discussion groups meet to consider and discuss these topics, constituting the largest civil-education network in the country. Discussion group leaders organize and lead these meetings in their communities. Become a group leader now!

We need experienced counselors with mental health backgrounds, substance abuse backgrounds, substance abuse counseling backgrounds and or people that have been in recovery for a minimum of 2 years to help facilitate groups at 3 SF - SRO locations once weekly.

We can schedule groups to fit most schedules of availability. Most important that the commitment is kept. If you have 3 hours per week that you can volunteer we need all the quality help we can get.

Please visit our website at www.rsn2000.org and many of the services we provide are listed on our website.

opportunities.description:
PARADE COMPARSA MONITOR

About Carnaval San Francisco

Carnaval San Francisco is a beloved Memorial Day Weekend event featuring a 2-day Festival and Grand Parade, celebrating music and cultural elements from Latin American and Caribbean traditions.

Job Description

Volunteers will be assigned to a comparsa* and will accompany that comparsa down the parade route. Volunteer will be responsible for communicating with the comparsa lead monitor and the comparsa coordinator regarding any

*A comparsa is a parade contingent


Responsibilities the day of Parade

1. Walk with a comparsa down the parade route

2. Help keep the parade’s pace steady by communicating with comparsas' lead monitors and motivating comparsas to keep moving forward

3. Prevent gaps between comparsas from happening during the parade

4. Communicate any issues with comparsa lead monitor and parade block captains

5. Post original content of the Carnaval on social media platforms on day of parade

Commitment

-Must be available on day of Grand Parade on Sunday, May 28th, from 8am to 12pm--Breakfast and Lunch will be provided!

-Attend one of the two mandatory parade volunteer meetings on either Saturday, April 8, 2017 or Saturday, April 15, 2017 from 3-5pm.

SIGN UP ON OUR WEBSITE IF INTERESTED! http://www.carnavalsanfrancisco.org/volunteers

Or email Yesenia Ruiz, our Parade Volunteer Coordinator, for any questions: ruiz.yessie@gmail.com

opportunities.description: We are looking for volunteers to assist with art classes for disabled adults and youth on Tuesdays, Wednesdays, and Thursdays. I am a City College instructor assigned to teach at the Pomeroy Recreation and Rehabilitation Center two days a week in the areas of painting, drawing, ceramics, scultpure and mixed mediums. I adapt the classes to suit the needs and interests of the students, ability and skill level. Volunteers are needed Tuesdays, Wednesdays and/or Thursdays. Volunteers are encouraged to commit to the entire semester, but adjustments can be made to your schedule. I teach a morning and afternoon session, either between 9:00am-12:00pm or 12:30-3:30pm, and volunteers are welcome to come to either session and volunteer 1-3 hours. I am looking for volunteers with some art background who are interested in assisting individual students or leading an art project of their own with an individual or small group. Classes have between 10-25 students with a wide range of interests and needs. Most semesters we culminate with a large scale art show and need help with framing and mounting artwork and setting up for the art show. Volunteer duties include: set up and clean up, modeling art techniques, special projects like the finale art show and sale.

opportunities.description:
YOU HAVE STEM EXPERTISE AND WANT TO GIVE BACK

Are you are one of many STEM (science, technology, engineering, and math) professionals who has a desire to share your passion with younger generations and make a difference for public school students?

STUDENTS NEED YOU

STEM achievement and career opportunities are disproportionately limited for youth in under-resourced school districts. The severe shortage of high-quality teachers to improve resources and outcomes leaves low-income and minority students particularly vulnerable. This isn’t right.

JOIN US!

The EnCorps STEM Teachers Program empowers STEM industry experts to become exceptional teachers, tutors, and educators. Heading into our 10th year of public service, we are the only nonprofit in California (or the nation) that enables STEM professionals, military veterans, and retirees to explore a career transition to teaching or volunteer tutoring in a low risk, highly supported way.

EnCorps Fellows directly impact the next generation of innovators, scientists and engineers, and are uniquely positioned to transform public STEM education. EnCorps provides comprehensive training and support as you personally engage with students in need and explore a move into a career that truly changes our world.

Visit our Website, check us out on Facebookand Twitter, and access our LinkedIn Careers Page.

BENEFITS

  • Immediate access to working with high need students

  • Mentorship from EnCorps staff and a host teacher

  • Exam support and credentialing guidance

  • Scholarship opportunities for credentialing and professional development

  • Access to networks and schools for full time teaching employment

  • Robust slate of professional development webinars and in person institutes

  • Cohort of peers who share ideas and best practices


HOW TO APPLY

EnCorps is a free, highly selective Fellowship requiring:

  1. Residence in an EnCorps service area (San Francisco Bay Area, Sacramento, Los Angeles County, Orange County, San Diego County)

  2. At least 3 years of full time work / research experience as a STEM industry professional

  3. Eligibility to work in the United States (US Citizen, Permanent Resident, Work Visa)

  4. An undergraduate degree with a GPA of 2.50 or higher

The EnCorps Fellowship is a volunteer, part time opportunity for current STEM professionals who are interested in exploring their personal role in teaching and education. *You do not need prior experience in education, and you must not currently hold a California single subject credential*

Selection for the 2017 Cohort is underway! Apply online between August 1 and May 16 at http://encorps.org/apply. It is in an applicant's best interest to attend the next possible event. See below for Bay Area Interview Day events and application deadlines for Winter / Spring, 2017.

Wed, January 18 - Belmont 4-7pm (Deadline is 1/13)
Wed, February 22 - San Jose 2-5pm (Deadline is 2/17)
Wed, March 15 - Oakland 4-7pm (Deadline is 3/10)
Sat, March 25 - San Francisco 9am-2pm (Deadline is 3/22)
Tues, April 11 - Redwood Shores 2-5pm (Deadline is 4/8)
Wed, May 17 - San Jose 2-5pm (Deadline is 5/16)
Sat, May 20 - Oakland 9am-12pm (Deadline is 5/16)
Mon, May 22 - San Francisco 4-7pm (Deadline is 5/16)

NEED MORE INFO?

Join our next live webinar (or watch a recorded one) at www.encorps.org/webinar, see our FAQs at http://encorps.org/educators/faqs/, or get in touch with David Taus, SF Bay Area Program & Recruitment Director at david@encorps.org or 510-708-3224.

With loyal fans around the world and across the internet, Tyler Knott Gregson is part of a new generation of poets reinventing the art for the modern digital age. His use of social media engages readers and supports his creative process as a poet and photographer, resulting in his poetry books hitting bestseller lists, where the genre is rarely represented.

Volunteer as an Usher at this event and attend for free!

opportunities.description:
Reading Partners needs volunteers like you to provide students in under-resourced elementary schools in your community with the proven, individualized reading support they need to read at grade level by fourth grade.

Reading is the foundation for all future learning.The ability to read transforms lives and can empower children to reach their full potential. Research shows that when students can read at grade level by fourth grade, they have a greater opportunity to succeed in school and in life.

With your help, we can equip students with the foundational skills they need to read at grade level. Each week, you will meet one-on-one with your student every week to help them develop strong literacy skills and discover a passion for reading. We'll provide a structured curriculum, in-person training, and ongoing support to help your student thrive. Rigorous research has proven that Reading Partners significantly increases reading proficiency.

No teaching experience required and anyone over the age of 14 can volunteer. Flexible Monday to Thursday volunteer times between 9am and 5pm.

Visit our website at www.readingpartners.org/volunteer to sign up and learn more.

Flexible Monday to Thursday volunteer times between 9am and 5pm. Visit our website at www.readingpartners.org/volunteer to sign up and learn more.

opportunities.description:
Clinic by the Bay is located in the Excelsior district of San Francisco. Many of our patients are monolingual Tagalog speakers and need the assistance of interpreters during their medical appointments to ensure that they receive high quality, culturally appropriate medical care. Tagalog speakers are also needed for various administrative assignments including contacting patients regarding the results of their medical tests, calling patients to remind them about their appointments, and interpreting documents we use for patient education.

Medical appointments are Tuesdays between noon and 8:00pm and Thursdays from 10:00am to 6:00pm. General office hours are Mon, Wed, Thurs & Friday from 10:00am to 6:00pm & Tuesday from noon to 8:00pm.

opportunities.description:
Help restore critical habitat at Lands End and in the Presidio of San Francisco. Volunteer days include a combination of hands-on service and short natural or cultural history lessons. Come out and lend a hand!

Volunteer programs take place on Thursdays and Saturdays, 1-4 pm. Additionally, every 1st Saturday, 9:30 - 12:30pm.

Visit our website to register and learn more about this program: http://www.parksconservancy.org/get-involved/volunteer/drop-in-programs/park-stewardship-san-francisco.html

Volunteers must complete the Volunteer Agreement Form and volunteers under the age of 18 must have the parent/guardian approval section signed.

Wear clothes that can get dirty. Long pants and closed-toe shoes are required. Bring layers for changing weather and rain gear if necessary. Bring a personal water bottle and sunscreen.

Visit our Volunteer Homepage for more details about individual, group, family-friendly, or long-term volunteer opportunities: www.parksconservancy.org/volunteer

The Golden Gate National Parks Volunteer Program is a cooperative parkwide effort of the Golden Gate National Parks Conservancy, the National Park Service, and the Presidio Trust.

opportunities.description:
Seven Tepees Youth Program is a nonprofit, community based organization that provides comprehensive youth development and college access and persistence services to over 1,000 youth annually through two programs: The Learning Center and The College & Career Program. Our Learning Center works with low income middle and high school students as well as recent college graduates for a period of more than ten years - spanning middle school and high school graduation into the first few years of college or career - offering academic support and guidance, college and career advising, environmental education, mentoring, job training and counseling. Our College and Career Program at Mission High School, a public school serving predominantly low income and first generation students, includes college and career advising, scholarship assistance, scholarships, test preparation support and college application assistance. Seven Tepees has an annual operating budget of approximately $1 million and inhabits the top floor of a building owned by the organization.

Mission:
The mission of Seven Tepees is to work with urban youth to foster the skills they need to make lifelong positive choices and to create their own opportunities for success. Founded in 1995 by retired Juvenile Justice Daniel Weinstein and Native American healer Hully Fetico, Seven Tepees began as a summer camp where youth lived in seven tepees - one representing each continent of the world.


Volunteers make Seven Tepees Youth Program possible, as we rely on your support to offer students every opportunity available.


In their 7th grade year, Seven Tepees students are paired with an adult volunteer mentor as part of the ten-year youth development program. While the mentor commitment is one year, the hope is mentor-mentee pairs will continue a long-lasting relationship beyond the structured program.

As a mentor, you will be a role model to a youth who will benefit from long-term one-on-one support from a caring adult. Mentors and youth participate in a wide range of activities together including Seven Tepees events, community service projects and planning expeditions on your own.


The 2016-2017 calendar of mentor events is available now:

  • Thursday, 10/13: Mentor Social (Mentors only)

  • Saturday, 10/22 - Sunday, 10/23: Kayaking Overnight

  • Thursday, 11/17: Games & Goals Night

  • Saturday, 12/10: Rope’s Course

  • Saturday, 1/21: Mentor Conference

  • Thursday, 2/9: Mentor Challenge

  • 6 month check-in with Mentor Coordinator

  • Independent Outing in March: Community Service Project

  • Saturday, 4/22: BBQ & Rox

  • Saturday, 5/13: Scavenger Hunt

  • June, TBD: Giants Game

  • Saturday, 8/5 - Sunday, 8/6: Closing Retreat

Mentors are required to meet their mentee twice per month for one academic year (September 2016 to June 2017). We are looking for individuals who will gain the satisfaction of forming a new friendship and support a youth as they set both academic and personal goals for their future.

Requirements:

  • Age requirement: 21

  • Commitment: 2 outings/month for one year

  • Mentor training will scheduled by the Mentor Program Coordinator based on the potential mentor's availability

  • Must provide (2) references

  • Must provide a copy of car insurance if you have a vehicle

opportunities.description:
The SF Sol Soccer Coach supports the mission of its umbrella non-profit organization Girls Leading Girls: to teach skill, empower leadership, and build character while growing strong athletes with positive female role models. Our club focuses on women coaching girls in soccer. We provide a system of training, motivation, team governance, and game strategy that fits the needs and differences of girls. Currently, our club has 12 teams in prep, travel, and recreational divisions and10 female coaches, all with extraordinary backgrounds in soccer and youth development.

Position Statement

Each SF Sol Coach provides leadership, structure, and support at weekly soccer practices and games. You will gain leadership skills, experience working with youth, and you join a network of female leaders. No former coaching experience necessary.

General Responsibilities

  1. Attend all Girls Leading Girls coach trainings and professional development sessions.
  2. Plan and execute soccer practices for 10 - 16 girls each week, focusing on soccer and lifeskill development. Training curriculum, soccer equipment, and administrative support all provided by GLG.
  3. Warm-up players, provide the starting line-up and strategy, and coach soccer games each weekend.
  4. Commit to showing up on time, properly dressed, and prepared to coach each week.
  5. Communicate regularly and effectively with Girls Leading Girls staff, your team manager, parents, and players.
  6. Read (and respond when necessary) to weekly email bulletins and other communications.
  7. Volunteer at Girls Leading Girls special events, community-service projects, and fundraisers.

Qualifications: Understanding of youth soccer culture and rules of the game. Must have strong verbal and interpersonal communication skills. Must be organized, patient, reliable, and able to multi-task. Taking initiative is required in this role. Background check and TB test are required for coaches over 17. Former coaching experience not required.

opportunities.description:
Making friends in the Bay is HARD. Stop by the market and join our lil family!

Want to give back to your community while volunteering in a fun, outdoor setting?

Want to meet other like-minded folks who care about their community and also want to keep it vibrant?

Like the idea of taking home a basket of organic strawberries or a bunch of greens as a token of our appreciation for your hard work?

Help staff our community market with a two-hour shift between 2pm and 9pm on Thursday evenings!

Pick a 2-hour (or longer) shift and make a difference in your community! Responsibilities include:

  • Greeting patrons as they enter the market
  • Educating community members about the market & answering questions
  • Coordinating youth and nutrition activities
  • Facilitating CalFresh (food stamp) transactions
  • Set up
  • Clean up
  • Dog watching
  • Translating (Spanish/English)
  • And more!!

MCM is a largely volunteer-driven, independent market and we will tailor volunteer responsibilities to your interests. If you've got the drive, we'll find a way to help you give back to your community.

Benefits include:

  • Getting connected to farms, local food producers, and other like-minded
  • Participate in farm trips, volunteer gatherings, and appreciation events
  • Become a part of our pool of volunteers, an eclectic bunch of folks who can give you insider tips or help you network to find a new roommate or job!
  • Make friends or find love at the farmer's market! No joke - we have had a few great relationships bud out of our volunteer pool!
  • Get a free coffee or a snack during your shift (don't be afraid to ask if you're hungry or thirsty) and take home some free or discounted produce when we have it available!

Sound good? Contact us for more information.

opportunities.description:
Immerse yourself in an outdoor classroom to support science instruction while you sift through the soil! We are currently accepting applications for Garden Interns and Volunteers.

POSITION OVERVIEW

The Education Outside garden volunteer position is open to any individual interested in contributing time to our school gardens with garden upkeep or assisting in classroom instruction. The garden volunteer serves a school garden site during school hours under the supervision of the Education Outside instructor.

RESPONSIBILITIES

Garden-Based Education

  • Assist with inquiry-based, hands-on curriculum that the Education Outside instructor designs and leads

  • Set out materials for grade-specific science lessons, cooking lessons, and help with classroom transitions

  • Act as a mentor, enthusiast, and leader in modeling positive behavior and curiosity for learning

Garden Maintenance

  • Water, weed, prune, propagate, transplant, cultivate, amend soil, and manage composting systems

  • Help keep garden infrastructure well-maintained (toolshed, irrigation system, garden beds, structures)

  • Use horticulture skills to support the growth and health of the plants with the instructor

Communication

  • Build awareness and community support by doing outreach at the school with instructor

  • Take pictures and/or write blog posts to feature garden lessons or garden highlights

  • Communicate clearly with instructors on schedule changes, work expectations, and logging hours

OPPORTUNITIES

  • Gain experience maintaining a sustainable urban school garden using horticulture skills

  • Connect the school garden learning space to your area of study (science, education, health, culinary, etc.)

  • Harness skills to improve our students’ learning experience in the outdoor classroom by taking on special projects (e.g. garden art, building garden structures, designing outreach flyers, cooking, etc.)

TIMEFRAME

  • Opportunities are typically Monday through Thursday, 8am to 5pm (may differ throughout sites).

  • We encourage volunteers to complete a minimum of 24 hours with us throughout the school year.

REQUIREMENTS

  • Strong interest or experience in outdoor education and a passion for ecological and social justice

  • Proof of fingerprinting and TB test per SFUSD policy

  • Be willing to lift at least 30 lbs and to work outdoors in a variety of Bay Area microclimates

  • Ability to take initiative, work independently, as well as be part of the school and garden team

  • Be able and willing to commit to volunteer schedule as discussed between both volunteer and instructor

TO APPLY

Please visit www.educationoutside.org/volunteersfor more information. We are accepting applications on a rolling basis.

opportunities.description:
Willpowered Woman is looking for an enthusiastic Peer-to-Peer Fundraising Program Manager to engage and reach new audiences!

A few things this role entails:

  • Strategize to reach a broader base of potential supporters by finding new supporters/leveraging the power of current supporters (as well as their online networks such as, email and social media.)
  • Come up with creative ways for our supporters to champion our cause and raise funds as well as awareness by reaching their friends, families and colleagues.
  • Determine recruitment and communication strategies to accelerate the participation of existing and potential supporters.

This person must be an excellent communicator with strong interpersonal and motivational skills who is confident, organized, pro-active and loves people!

opportunities.description:
Do you love walking around San Francisco? Are you a people-person? Want to make our city safer and more livable? Become a Walk San Francisco Ambassador!

We welcome enthusiastic volunteers who can effectively educate the public about pedestrian safety and city walkability, build awareness for Vision Zero, the goal to end ALL serious and fatal traffic injuries by 2024, and Walk SF's various advocacy campaigns, as well as recruit new members at various fun events throughout the year like Walk to Work Day (April 9), Peak2Peak, Walk & Roll to School Day, Woonerven (the annual members party and fundraiser) and more.

Got four to six hours a month available to volunteer? Contact us to learn more.

Quarterly orientations/trainings available. Next date is Thursday, December 1, 2016 at 6:30 p.m. at Walk SF's offices.

RSVP today (space is limited)

opportunities.description:
The Food Security Network (FSN) was created to secure a food income for our homebound and mobility impaired neighbors in the Richmond Distrcit. FSN partners with the SF-Marin Food Bank and local volunteers to provide free groceries for those in need. Our volunteers make a weekly 20 minute commitment to pick up a bag of groceries from the RDNC and deliver it to a nearby neighbor.

This oppurtunity is ongoing, with just a 20-30 minute commitment each Tuesday or Thursday! This is a great oppurunity for working adults, people looking to meet thier neighbors, or for a volunteer experince the whole family can be a part of.

Grocery pick up is from 3:00-6:00 pm every Tuesday out of Lafayette Elementary School and from 2:30pm to 6:30pm every Thursday out of the RDNC. Food can be delivered at your own convience to recipients who are matched individually after an orientation.

We hope you join our team of wonderful and dedicated volunteers!!

To get involved or find out more about the RDNC's food security programing, please email idalia@rdnc.org

Commitment can be ongoing, short-term, or one time. Board membership opportunities are also available and provide a unique avenue to assist those struggling with HIV/AIDS.

Typing Party!

Your task is to hand-type information from business cards into a spreadsheet. The task requires fast typing, excellent proofreading skills, and squinting at handwritten scribbles on the backs of business cards.

We'll do this in a group, at a public location in San Francisco. Your help is greatly appreciated!

You'll need to bring your own laptop.

opportunities.description:
Join our Talented Volunteers, the All Star Project's award-winning volunteer program, in Youth Outreach!

All Star's volunteers are part of our nationwide team that has grown to over 2,000 people, and are the driving force in all of our programs. Our volunteers are passionate people whose tireless work and contributions have helped us to grow into our role as the new model for inner- city youth development.

In this opportunity, volunteers work side by side with young people and All Stars Project adult volunteers to offer youth in neighborhoods throughout San Francisco an opportunity to produce and perform in our talent show network. A talent show that isn't a talent show, the program is designed to help young people grow and develop. The day includes: training overview and role playing led by youth and adult volunteers; outreach in the community; and discussion of the day's activities. Spanish speakers needed to reach Latino youth, especially in the Mission District.
