opportunities.description:
Call for Conference Volunteers!

Become a Volunteer for ACT-W: April 7th - 8th

ACT-W conferences run on the energy of our volunteers who care about empowering women in technology. The ACT-W Bay Area Conference is an annual one-day action-packed event where talented women can build skills, grow their community, and accelerate their career path by connecting with companies that truly fit them best. The conference includes speaking sessions, hands-on workshops, one-on-one coaching sessions, and more.

As a volunteer, you’ll be a vital part of the conference and help to create a welcoming and outstanding conference experience for about 300 participants from the Bay Area.

The volunteering experience is a unique opportunity to participate in the conference activities. ACT-W Bay Area volunteers will be responsible for various conference duties such as staffing the registration/information booth, crowd management, assisting speakers and pre-conference course instructors, and the communicate information about the conference.

What is expected of me?

As a volunteer, you’ll be expected to be available throughout the entire conference time / your shift - April 7th - 8th, 2017. You’ll also be responsible for any parking and accommodation costs during and from the conference.

Who can volunteer?

  • Anyone 18 and over

Volunteer Positions

(Examples below, but please note that positions may fluctuate on-site due to event needs)

ACT-W Kick-off Happy Hour "Ask Me" Ambassador

These are sociable people that help with set-up, check greet folks at the door, and assist with break-down. You may also guide people to the bar, bathroom, and tables. They will also refer issues to problem solver volunteers or registration/information volunteers as needed.

ACT-W Conference "Ask Me" Ambassador

These are sociable people who are experts on various areas of content: conference schedule content, happy hours, dinners, etc. All of the information they provide is to enhance the attendees’ experiences. They will also assist any overflow attendees by locating alternative sessions they can attend. They will also refer issues to problem solver volunteers or registration/information volunteers as needed.

Registration/Information Booth

These volunteers will locate registration packets and explain contents to attendees. Any registrations issues will be transferred to the load for resolution. They will also act as the source of information about the conference activities, directions and sessions. Volunteers will be required to stay at registration booth for the assigned hours unless otherwise directed.

Event Manager - Sessions, Workshops, Keynotes, and Opening/Closing Ceremonies

These volunteers will act as the liaison to speakers during sessions and workshops. They will introduce speakers with a pre-written script, assists speakers with A/V issues, make sure water has been provided, act as a time-keeper for session/course, act as room monitor to make sure room is not overcrowded, and collect presentations on USB drive at end of sessions and workshops. If room reaches capacity, they will work with Problem Solvers or "Ask Me" Ambassadors to close the session to further attendees. Volunteers will be required to stay in the session/course for the assigned hours.

Social Media / Citizen Journalist

These volunteers will be responsible for covering sessions as a reporter. They will make social media posts, and take pictures during the session. Volunteers will coordinate with communications and social media leads to follow posting requirements.

Problem Solver

These volunteers assist where needed to resolve unexpected issues. We are seeking people who are comfortable being in customer service and resolving problems on the fly. Please note if you are knowledgeable about audio visual, etc, because technical difficulties can occur during the conference where we may need your help.

Volunteer Wrangler

These volunteers ensure that all other volunteers know where they should going and what they need to know and/or have on hand.

Set up / Clean up Crew

These volunteers help set up and/or breakdown the conference area, sessions, workshops, career fair, breakfast, lunch. This includes moving chairs, tables, et. Must be able to lift 25 lbs.

Photographer/Videographer

Help make the memories last forever. We need photographers and videographers for the event as well!

Email jenny.morgan@chicktech.org and mary.spinelli@chicktech.org for more information. Also feel free to look at the website, www.bayarea.act-w.org! See you there!
opportunities.tags: Conferences, inclusion, diversity, women in tech, STEM, event management, Technology

opportunities.description:
If you are passionate about Salesforce and looking to devote your skills to a global cause, help UniversalGiving? and the CEO maintain our Salesforce database system.

Full Description

UniversalGiving?, an award-winning global social-entrepreneurship nonprofit organization, is seeking a Salesforce Admin Intern/Volunteer to join our exciting team. As the Salesforce Admin, you will work directly with our Operations Lead to spearhead a number of Salesforce projects, including: fine-tuning levels of user data access and security, customizing data objects and privacy specifications, backing up data, monitoring and maintaining data exports, and creating mail merges. We are seeking someone who is intimately familiar with Salesforce and has a positive attitude. Additionally, if you are a general technical wiz, please apply for our Salesforce Administrator and Windows System Admin / Technology intern positions, as we will gladly welcome one person who is able to fill both of these roles.

UniversalGiving? internships offer exciting opportunities to those wishing to make a significant impact and contribution to our global communities. Join UniversalGiving and work closely with a dedicated international team, while gaining valuable skills and insight in a social-entrepreneurship nonprofit organization.

Testimonial
"Working with UniversalGiving has given me the chance to participate in critical aspects of business management and partnership facilitation, which are opportunities that would definitely be off-limits to "the intern" at most corporations. The friendly and ultra-supportive executive team here wants their interns to contribute to the main goals and aspirations of UniversalGiving in important ways and helps them to do so, which is what makes working here so rewarding and fun - so fun, in fact, that I will continue to be a part of their team even after leaving the San Francisco office!" --- Emily Stehr, UG Representative at Princeton University, Summer Intern

About UniversalGiving
 UniversalGiving? is an award-winning website allowing people to donate and volunteer with top performing projects all over the world. Our projects are vetted through a proprietary Quality Model? to ensure the most effective, trustworthy philanthropy possible. Unique to UniversalGiving, we take no cut on donations. 100% of your donation goes directly to the cause.

Located in the heart of San Francisco, UniversalGiving has been profiled on CBS and in FOX Business Network, and has also been featured in BusinessWeek Fast Company, CSRWire, WomenEntrepreneur, Oprah.com, NBC News, The Christian Science Monitor, The New York Times, The Financial Times, MarketWatch, CNNMoney.com, Change.org and See Change Magazine. UniversalGiving? is the 2010 winner of the Opportunity Knocks' Best Nonprofit to Work for Award.

CEO Pamela Hawley is a winner of the Jefferson Award (the Nobel Prize in Community Service) and was selected as one of 50 leaders to the White House's Next Generation Leadership and Social Innovation event. She is also a Finalist for Ernst & Young’s Entrepreneur of the Year Award, and a Colburn S. Wilbur Leadership Fellow at the Global Ethics Institute. She has been chosen as a Fast Company Expert Blogger on CSR.


Duration: This is an unpaid internship with a commitment of 5-10 minimum hours per week for 2 to 4 months (4 months preferred). Ideal candidates are available to work in our downtown San Francisco office.

Responsibilities:

  • Work with our Operations Lead on multiple Salesforce projects to identify issues, prioritize efforts, deliver results, and document information
  • Define multiple details for data security
  • Fine-tune user data access levels
  • Customize privacy specifications and settings
  • Back up data, monitor and maintain data exports, and create mail merges
  • Customize data objects
  • Conduct mass data updates and data creation with Apex Data Loader
  • Sync mobile devices
  • Explore and implement new features, enhancements, and tools

Qualifications:

  • Intimate experience with Salesforce Administration
  • General knowledge of Database Management and CRM systems
  • Expertise in syncing mobile devices, preferred
  • Ability to work independently as well as collaboratively as a strong team player
  • Good communication skills, both written and verbal
  • Strong interest in nonprofit work, international issues, philanthropy

Benefits:

  • Experience working at a global, social-entrepreneurship nonprofit
  • Collaboration within a positive team environment
  • Increased understanding of and alignment with global issues
  • Networking with other nonprofit professionals
  • Career mentoring with Pamela Hawley, Founder & CEO of UniversalGiving?
  • With positive work experience, references provided
  • For students, class credit can be arranged according to school requirements

To Apply:

Email your resume and cover letter to volunteers@universalgiving.org with "Salesforce Administrator Intern/Volunteer" in the subject line. Applications are reviewed on a rolling basis. No phone calls please.

UniversalGiving? is committed to understanding and representing the diverse populations it serves worldwide. Members of all ages, genders, sexual orientations, races, ethnicities, nationalities, physical abilities or disabilities, religions or beliefs, and cultures are welcome as employees and volunteers in our organization. We believe that a diverse team will best serve our diverse populations.

UniversalGiving’s vision is to "Create a World Where Giving and Volunteering Are a Natural Part of Everyday Life."?

For more information please visit:

  • UniversalGiving’s website
  • UniversalGiving’s Blog: PhilanthroPost
  • CEO Pamela Hawley’s Blog: Living and Giving
  • Follow Us on Twitter: @ UniversalGiving and @ PamelaHawley
  • Like us on Facebook

opportunities.description:
Looking for a fun volunteer opportunity this summer/fall? Coaching Corps could be a great fit!

Remember what sports did for you as a child? Did they teach you about team work, responsibility, and taking care of your health? Coaching Corps is a non-profit organization that believes every child should have access to quality sports. We are expanding in the Bay Area and are looking for great volunteers to help us grow in your community! College students and community members are highly encouraged! In our mission to improve the health, educational and social outcomes for kids through the power of sports and play, Coaching Corps recruits, trains, and places volunteer coaches at after-school programs in underserved communities.

Coaching Corps aims to find quality coaches to serve as a positive role model and mentor to under-served youth who may not have access to sports otherwise. Sports help kids build self-esteem, get exercise, succeed in school, and gain friendships- and positive adult mentors play a valuable role in their life. Sign up today to volunteer coach at www.coachingcorps.org.

Contact:

Gabi Reyes-Acosta at 510-496-5131 or gabir@coachingcorps.org

There is no experience necessary, we will train you and you will never coach alone!

Join the Coaching Corps Movement and coach a kid today!
Coach youth for one 8-10 week season
A simple 2-6 hr/wk commitment
Training and placement in a local afterschool program
Build your resume while making a huge impact on the lives of young people!

We have opportunities in the East Bay, South Bay, and San Francisco. Call or email us today to learn more!

The Marketing and Administrative Assistant

is responsible for developing and distributing all press releases,

flyers, and related media (including social media) used to promote

all arts, music, dance, and other events, including exhibitions,

receptions, concerts, performances, and fundraisers. In addition to

these duties, the Marketing and Administrative intern will assist

Meridian Gallery staff with various office and administrative tasks,

including, scheduling, filing, and developing archives. Bookkeeping for

Meridian Gallery will also need to be completed.

Flexible scheduling of between 12 and 15 hours a week.

Unpaid internship for either undergraduate student or professional looking to volunteer their time.

opportunities.description:
Northern California Music & Art Culture Center (NCMACC) is a 24-year-old 501(c)3 community-based center in San Francisco. NCMACC's mission is to inspire artistic expression and promote understanding through music and art.

We are currently looking for volunteers to be our office receptionist on Saturday morning once a month. The volunteering hour is 9:00 am - 1:00 pm on the first or third Saturday.

Work description:

- greet and welcome guests

- answer all incoming calls and redirect them or keep messages

- receive letters, packages etc. and distribute them

- check, sort and forward emails

- receive and record payments

- Keep updated records and files

No experience is needed because training will be provided.

If you are interested, please contact us at ncmacc@ncmacc.org.

Thank you!

opportunities.description:
Come volunteer for the St. Francis Living Room and give seniors a healthy breakfast! At St. Francis Living Room, we serve 15,000 nutritious breakfasts annually to low income and homeless seniors annually as well as provide them social, educational and recreational activities for them. Volunteers will help serve breakfast and assist those seniors unable to get through the buffet line.While ongoing volunteers are preferable, one time volunteers are certainly welcome.

Some duties for volunteers include: welcoming our guests, preparing and serving breakfast, assisting with clean up. Breakfast shifts are from 8:15am to 10:00am. Schedules are flexible.

For more information, please contact Greg Moore, our Executive Director, or visit our website at:

http://sflivingroom.org/

Phone Number: (415) 946-1413

Email: greg@sflivingroom.org

opportunities.description:
How will you use digital technology today? Google search? Directions? Email? Shopping? Contacting a doctor? What would life be like if you couldn’t use a computer? Many older adults in the Bay Area experience isolation and disengagement from vital resources because they have not had an opportunity to learn how to connect through digital technology. You can help these adults connect with family and access information by teaching basic computer skills.

Duties:

  • Commit to a weekly tutoring shift
  • Help a senior learn how to use their laptop, smartphone, tablet or e-reader
  • Act as a resource and guide, helping them learn how to find resources and information

We especially need volunteers who speak languages other than English (especially Spanish, Russian, or Cantonese). For more information and to apply for this volunteer position, please visit our website at http://ctnbayarea.org/volunteer/

Time commitment:

Tutors must commit to one shift per week for at least two months. Shifts are at least two hours, Monday through Friday between the hours of 9:00-4:00 pm.

opportunities.title: Train low-income seniors in technology!
opportunities.plaintextDescription: How will you use digital technology today? Google search? Directions? Email? Shopping? Contacting a doctor? What would life be like if you couldn’t use a computer? Many older adults in the Bay Area experience isolation and disengagement from vital resources because they have not had an opportunity to learn how to connect through digital technology. You can help these adults connect with family and access information by teaching basic computer skills. Duties: Commit to a weekly tutoring shift Help a senior learn how to use their laptop, smartphone, tablet or e-reader Act as a resource and guide, helping them learn how to find resources and information We especially need volunteers who speak languages other than English (especially Spanish, Russian, or Cantonese). opportunities.description:
Playwrights Foundation (PF), a center for new play development in San Francisco, is looking for an enthusiastic, ambitious, resourceful and ambitious early to mid-career individual interested in arts administration & the daily operations of running a non-profit arts organization.

PF is part of an extensive creative community nationwide, and has a strong presence in the Bay Area theater scene. Learn more about our 40-year history and work at www.playwrightsfoundation.org

The Arts Administration internship/fellowship offers the opportunity to deeply investigate the administrative side of a well-established arts nonprofit and new works incubator. This position is perfect for anyone interested in theatre management, producing, and/or running an arts organization of their own in future. The interns/fellow will learn and gain valuable experience in basics of nonprofit finance, management of database and administrative systems, development (including fundraising and grant writing/reporting), special event planning, front of house management, and all other daily operations of running an arts organization.

Candidates must be able to commit to a minimum of three months and a maximum of six months, and will require a commitment of 10-15 hours per week.

This is an unpaid position, reporting to the General Manager, with a small travel stipend provided.

Qualifications
  • For Internship: Enrolled at a college or university, and in "good academic standing" as defined by your campus policy.
  • For Fellowship: Graduation from a four-year college preferred, with references.
  • Familiarity in Microsoft Office Suite, & Google Apps.
  • Experience with databases and data entry.
  • Excellent communication & writing skills
  • Manages and completes multiple projects in a timely manner, with strong organizational skills.
  • Experience with online research, analyzing and organizing information desirable. A fine attention to detail.

Hours and Duration: 3/1/17- 7/28/17 (dates are negotiable). 10-15 hours a week. A weekly schedule will be discussed as part of the interview process, based on the intern's availability and the Foundation’s needs.

Program Benefits include:

  • Admission to all Playwrights Foundation events.
  • Recommendation letters (upon request).
  • The applicant must seek academic credit with their program advisor or dean. We will endeavor to provide documentation and evaluation to satisfy requirements for credit. All university requirements and paperwork must be presented on the first day of the internship.
  • Modest travel stipend.
  • Participation in the lively Bay Area theater community

opportunities.description:
Are you a good listener? Are you caring? Do you want to help the GLBT community nationwide?

The GLBT National Hotline provides vital peer-support, community connections and resource information to people with questions regarding sexual orientation and/or gender identity. Our volunteers provides one-to-one peer support that help both youth and adults with coming-out issues, safer-sex information, school bullying, family concerns, relationship problems and much more.

We are looking for GLBT volunteers ages 18 and over.

The Gay, Lesbian, Bisexual and Transgender (GLBT) National Hotline is a program of the GLBT National Help Center. We are a non-profit organization that is dedicated to providing peer-counseling, information, and local resources directly through our toll-free telephone number at 1-888-843-4564. Our mission is to help end the isolation and fear that many people who question their sexuality and/or gender identity go through.

opportunities.description:
Graphic Designers - Pro Bono Print & Brand Work Can Make a Difference

Taproot Foundation is looking for pro bono Graphic Designers, responsible for the visual design of a brochure or branding collateral for a nonprofit. Working with a team of other marketing professionals, the graphic designer plays an essential role in delivering the look and feel a nonprofit needs.

A successful pro bono Graphic Designer

  • Has 3 years of professional experience in graphic design at an agency or as an internal graphic designer
  • Has extensive experience with print design, graphics production, and be familiar with relevant design and production tools (i.e. PhotoShop, Illustrator, QuarkXPress, DreamWeaver, or equivalents)
  • Has worked with marketers and can follow creative briefs, take direction, and create several design options
  • Must provide a portfolio with samples of several designs in at least one of our Service Grant project areas (i.e., print collateral, visual identity systems)

A Service Grant project requires a 3-5 hour commitment each week over the course of approximately 6 months. This opportunity is flexible enough to work around the schedule of a full-time job.

Taproot Foundation makes it easy to make a difference. We’re a nonprofit organization that makes business talent available to organizations that are working to improve society. Our goal is to ensure that one day all organizations with promising solutions will be equipped to successfully take on urgent social challenges. To date, we have engaged close to 7,700 professionals on close to 2,300 pro bono projects benefiting education, health, environment, social service, and arts initiatives.

Now it’s your turn to join the movement and Make It Matter.

opportunities.description:
Playwrights Foundation (PF), a center for new play development in San Francisco, is looking for six enthusiastic, ambitious, and resourceful production interns to assist with our 40th Anniversary season of the Bay Area Playwrights Festival. PF is part of an extensive national creative community, with a strong presence in the Bay Area and national theater scene. Learn more about our 40-year history and work at playwrightsfoundation.org.

This position is designed for an early career theater artist with an interest in the inner workings of a nonprofit playwright accelerator. Interns/Fellows assist with all aspects of festival production, including event planning, scheduling, development, social media, front of house, and production assistance, as well as some daily office tasks. This role requires a creative, thoughtful and extremely proactive individual for whom no task is too small or too large, and who is willing to learn and stretch.

A background and/or education in theater is mandatory; a passion for new plays and playwrights is preferred. Candidates must be available for a minimum 2 month term, with 3 months preferred, and will require a commitment of at least 10-15 hours per week.

This is an unpaid position, reporting to the Festival Producer, with a small travel stipend provided.

Skills and Qualifications
  • For Internship: Enrolled at a college or university, and in "good academic standing" as defined by your campus policy.
  • For Fellowship: Graduation from a four-year college preferred, with references.
  • Fluent in Microsoft Office Suite, Google Apps and Docs. Experience with databases a plus.
  • Strong communication skills, including demonstrated and effective writing and speaking.
  • Completes assignments/projects accurately and in a timely manner, as set by deadlines.
  • Experience with online research, analyzing and organizing information desirable.
  • A fine attention to detail.
  • Knowledge of how to perform calculations and basic analysis.
  • Reliable. Interns are responsible for getting themselves to and from work on time.
  • Strong organizational skills and a commonsense approach to problem solving.

Hours/Duration: 5/15 - 8/15/17 (later start negotiable), 10-15 hours a week; increased hours, nights and weekends required during production. A schedule will be discussed as part of the interview process.

Location: Playwrights Foundation, 1616 16th St, Suite 350, San Francisco CA 94103

Program Benefits include:

  • Admission to all Playwrights Foundation events.
  • Recommendation letters (upon request).
  • The applicant must seek academic credit with their program advisor or dean. We will endeavor to provide documentation and evaluation to satisfy requirements for credit. All university requirements and paperwork must be presented on the first day of the internship.
  • Modest travel stipend.
  • Participation in the lively Bay Area theater community

opportunities.description:
Want to give back to your community while volunteering in a fun, outdoor setting?

Want to meet other like-minded folks who care about their community and also want to keep it vibrant?

Like the idea of taking home a basket of organic strawberries or a bunch of greens as a token of our appreciation for your hard work?

Help staff our community market with a two-hour shift between 2pm and 9pm on Thursday evenings!

Pick a 2-hour (or longer) shift and make a difference in your community! Responsibilities include:

  • Greeting patrons as they enter the market
  • Educating community members about the market & answering questions
  • Coordinating youth and nutrition activities
  • Facilitating CalFresh (food stamp) transactions
  • Set up
  • Clean up
  • Dog watching
  • Translating (Spanish/English)
  • And more!!

MCM is a largely volunteer-driven, independent market and we will tailor volunteer responsibilities to your interests. If you've got the drive, we'll find a way to help you give back to your community.

Benefits include:

  • Getting connected to farms, local food producers, and other like-minded
  • Participate in farm trips, volunteer gatherings, and appreciation events
  • Become a part of our pool of volunteers, an eclectic bunch of folks who can give you insider tips or help you network to find a new roommate or job!
  • Make friends or find love at the farmer's market! No joke - we have had a few great relationships bud out of our volunteer pool!
  • Get a free coffee or a snack during your shift (don't be afraid to ask if you're hungry or thirsty) and take home some free or discounted produce when we have it available!

Sound good? Contact us for more information.

opportunities.description:
Playwrights Foundation (PF), a center for new play development in San Francisco, is looking for an enthusiastic, ambitious, and resourceful Intern Assistant to the Artistic Director (AAD) to assist with company-wide projects, the Resident Playwrights Initiative, the Rough Reading Series, the Bay Area Playwrights Festival (BAPF), and events through April 2017. PF is part of an extensive national creative community, with a strong presence in the Bay Area theater scene. Learn more about our 40-year history and work at playwrightsfoundation.org.

The AAD internship/fellowship is designed for an early career theater artist with an interest in the inner workings of a nonprofit playwright accelerator. Assignments may include (but are not limited to) casting assistance, general correspondence with theater professionals, donors, vendors and others, copy writing, assisting with the rehearsal and presentation of monthly readings, special event planning, scheduling, front of house, and other daily office tasks. This position requires a creative, thoughtful and extremely proactive individual for whom no task is too small or too large, and who is willing to learn and stretch.

A background and/or education in theater is mandatory; a passion for new plays and playwrights is preferred. Candidates must be able to commit to a minimum of three months and a maximum of six months, and will require a commitment of 10-15 hours per week.

This is an unpaid position, reporting to the Artistic Director, with a small stipend provided to offset travel.

Skills and Qualifications
  • For Internship: Enrolled at a college or university, and in "good academic standing" as defined by your campus policy.
  • For Fellowship: Graduation from a four-year college preferred, with references.
  • Fluent in Microsoft Office Suite programs & Google Apps and Docs. Experience with databases a plus.
  • Strong communication skills, including demonstrated and effective writing and speaking.
  • Completes assignments/projects accurately and in a timely manner, as set by deadlines.
  • Experience with online research, analyzing and organizing information desirable.
  • A fine attention to detail.
  • Knowledge of how to perform calculations and basic analysis.
  • Reliable. Interns are responsible for getting themselves to and from work on time.
  • Strong organizational skills and a commonsense approach to problem solving.

Hours/Duration: immediate start-4/28/17 (Negotiable; with an option to extend through July). 10-15 hours a week, expanding to more during the BAPF. Some nights and weekends. A schedule will be discussed in the interview process, based on intern availability and Foundation needs.

Location: Playwrights Foundation, 1616 16th St, Suite 350, San Francisco CA 94103

Program Benefits include:

  • Admission to all Playwrights Foundation events.
  • Recommendation letters (upon request).
  • The applicant must seek academic credit with their program advisor or dean. We will endeavor to provide documentation and evaluation to satisfy requirements for credit. All university requirements and paperwork must be presented on the first day of the internship.
  • Modest travel stipend.
  • Participation in the lively Bay Area theater community

opportunities.description:
The Forgotten International has developed a classroom curriculum called Doing Good that is founded on the principles of gratitude, empathy, compassion, and proactive philanthropy. Long term, we hope that the curriculum will be implemented in classrooms throughout the United States and will give young people an empathetic perspective on the world. The ten lessons incorporated in the curriculum encourage students to think creatively and compassionately to develop real-world projects aimed at helping those struggling with poverty both locally and abroad.

In order to ensure the long-term success of Doing Good, we want to harness the talent of local volunteers to help roll out the curriculum in Bay Area schools. We need a cohort of knowledgeable and capable volunteers that will learn the curriculum and help implement it in classrooms. Following a one-day training course in San Francisco, each volunteer will bring the curriculum to a Bay Area school and work alongside a classroom educator to carry out the lesson plans. Each volunteer will visit their assigned class approximately ten times next semester.

You have been invited to participate as a volunteer in this curriculum and training course. We have not set a date for the training yet, but expect to hold it in early November (4th or the 5th). For the time being, we need to gauge your interest in this opportunity. If you would like to be a part of this exciting new curriculum, please send an email to info@theforgottenintl.org. Ideally, 12 or more volunteers will be needed to introduce Doing Good to the Bay Area starting in Spring 2017.

What does the program look like?

There will be 1-day training for volunteers and it will be for about 6 hours in San Francisco. We haven't picked a date for this training yet, but it will be sometime in early November. Post training, our volunteers will be assigned to a school classroom which they will visit about 10 days in a semester. Each of these classes will last for about an hour, so that means it will be about 10 hours a semester. Some classrooms or schools might require more time, depending on the students and Teacher. During the school visit, volunteers will be teaching the Doing Good curriculum in class along with a teacher, and assisting in learning activities, etc. If you feel comfortable speaking to a classroom and helping implement activities based on global awareness and compassion, you would be a great fit for our program.

If you have any additional questions about the Doing Good curriculum or this volunteer program, please email info@theforgottenintl.org

You can make a difference. Sign-up today!
opportunities.tags: International, children, education, teaching, poverty
opportunities.title: "Doing Good" Volunteer
opportunities.plaintextDescription: The Forgotten International has developed a classroom curriculum called Doing Good that is founded on the principles of gratitude, empathy, compassion, and proactive philanthropy. Long term, we hope that the curriculum will be implemented in classrooms throughout the United States and will give young people an empathetic perspective on the world. The ten lessons incorporated in the curriculum encourage students to think creatively and compassionately to develop real-world projects aimed at helping those struggling with poverty both locally and abroad. In order to ensure the long-term success of Doing Good, we want to harness the talent of local volunteers to help roll out the curriculum in Bay Area schools. We need a cohort of knowledgeable and capable volunteers that will learn the curriculum and help implement it in classrooms. Following a one-day training course in San Francisco, each volunteer will bring the curriculum to a Bay Area school and work alongside a classroom educator to carry out the lesson plans. Each volunteer will visit their assigned class approximately ten times next semester. You have been invited to participate as a volunteer in this curriculum and training course. We have not set a date for the training yet, but expect to hold it in early November (4th or the 5th). For the time being, we need to gauge your interest in this opportunity. If you would like to be a part of this exciting new curriculum, please send an email to info@theforgottenintl.org. Ideally, 12 or more volunteers will be needed to introduce Doing Good to the Bay Area starting in Spring 2017. What does the program look like? There will be 1-day training for volunteers and it will be for about 6 hours in San Francisco. We haven't picked a date for this training yet, but it will be sometime in early November. Post training, our volunteers will be assigned to a school classroom which they will visit about 10 days in a semester. Each of these classes will last for about an hour, so that means it will be about 10 hours a semester. Some classrooms or schools might require more time, depending on the students and Teacher. During the school visit, volunteers will be teaching the Doing Good curriculum in class along with a teacher, and assisting in learning activities, etc. If you feel comfortable speaking to a classroom and helping implement activities based on global awareness and compassion, you would be a great fit for our program. If you have any additional questions about the Doing Good curriculum or this volunteer program, please email info@theforgottenintl.org You can make a difference. Sign-up today!

opportunities.description:
About three times a week, the San Francisco Child Abuse Prevention Center (SFCAPC) hosts family dinners for up to 40 parents and kids. All dinners take place from about 5 PM - 6 PM and end just in time for guests to attend support groups, workshops, and club meetings offered at SFCAPC’s TALK Line Family Support Center in Haight-Ashbury - 1757 Waller Street, San Francisco, CA 94117. As a family dinner volunteer, you’ll help lessen weeknight stress for families traveling from work and school to get to SFCAPC programs. Give families a free meal, a night off, and a chance to build a social network - sign up to cook an upcoming family dinner today!

Volunteer Responsibilities

  • Rally 2-5 friends, relatives, classmates or co-workers to join your volunteer team.
  • Plan a menu and purchase food supplies for 20-40 parents and kids. We will reimburse volunteers up to $75
  • Cook your meal at SFCAPC or at an off-site kitchen of your choice - catered meals are also welcome
  • Serve your meal, dine with families, and clean up

opportunities.description:
Ride along with FUF staff and interns to prune and perform tree care across the city. This is a great way to learn pruning and tree care basics which are essential elements to a healthy urban forest. Bring your own water, and dress appropriately for the weather. We will provide the tools and expertise.

We’ll meet at the FUF offices in the Presidio or you can choose to meet us at our tree-care location.

DATE: EVERY FRIDAY (Please check fuf.net/events)

Time: 10.00am-1.00pm

Location: Changes every week. Volunteers can choose to ride out with us from FUF's office in the Presidio

Dress Code: Outdoor wear, layers for weather, shoes, and personal water bottle

Please RSVP your volunteer spot on www.fuf.net/events
opportunities.title: No-Frown Friday Tree Care

opportunities.description:
Real progress toward a cure has been made, but the lives of young people with cystic fibrosis (CF) are still cut far too short. We urgently need the public’s continued support to fulfill our mission and help add tomorrows for those with the disease.

The Cystic Fibrosis Foundation has raised and invested hundreds of millions of dollars to help develop CF drugs and therapies. Through our efforts, the life expectancy of a child with CF has doubled in the last 30 years, and research to find a cure is more promising than ever before.

Year after year, volunteers make every GREAT STRIDES walk site both fun and successful. Their dedication has helped GREAT STRIDES become one of the most effective and efficient fundraising efforts.

There are many volunteer opportunities available, including photography, site set-up, event wrap-up, event registration, food service, course assistance, customer service, etc.

There is something for everyone!

Walk Setup Join the early bird crew and help set up tables, tents and chairs for the event.

Clean Up Help with breaking down tables, chairs, banners and more.

Registration Volunteers Collect walker pledge envelopes, register participants and hand out T-Shirts and route maps.

Greeters Direct participants to the right area and assist with filling out participant envelopes.

Walk Route Monitors Cheer our walkers along the route with pom-poms and noise makers. Keep them pumped up and motivated while walking. This volunteer position is great for groups!

Kid’s Korner Help make the day fun for kids with arts and crafts and other activities.

Route Marking Assist with marking walk route and setting up signage along the route.

Rest Stops Cheer walkers and hand out beverages at one of our rest stops along the route. This position is also great for groups!

Food Volunteers Food volunteers will help set up food and beverages in the designated area, as well as serve food items to each participant.

Finish Line Volunteers Cheer on walkers as they come in and help set-up and breakdown the area.

Entertainers If you are a clown, magician, balloon artist or have another unique talent and would like to donate your time, please contact us.

Photographers We need photographers who can volunteer to take photos of teams, sponsors, start and finish line, route and celebration photos.
opportunities.tags: great strides, cystic fibrosis, 5k, walk
opportunities.title: Great Strides San Francisco

parentOrg.name: Cystic Fibrosis Foundation - Northern California Chapter

opportunities.description:
Join Proof Lab and United By Blue for a cleanup of the South Bay at Baker Beach. Outlilned by cliffs with views of the iconic Golden Gate Bridge, Baker Beach is a symbol of San Francisco's juxtapostion of nature and the city. Historically, Baker Beach served as a Spanish military base known as the Presidio. Today, it is a part of Golden Gate National Recreation Area and administered by the National Park Service. Baker Beach serves as place of relaxation and adventure for hikers, surfers, beach bums and everyone in between! Please help us cleanup the South Bay and preserve Baker Beach!

United By Blue will provide water, trash bags, supplies, and gloves for all volunteers. All volunteers will have the chance to win prizes during two cleanup games: weirdest trash find and total weight guess. Keep in touch for updates about the cleanup. Groups of all sizes are welcome!
opportunities.tags: cleanup, Surf, san francisco, Golden Gate, Outdoors, beach, environment

opportunities.description:
At March of Dimes we strive to improve the health of all babies by preventing birth defects, premature birth and infant mortality. We fund important research, community services and advocacy campaigns. Each year over 480,000 babies are born in CA and March of Dimes is working to help every one of them.

We have several fundraising projects that are currently ongoing and need volunteer support, including our spring, walk fundraiser.

Volunteers are welcome to come in once or on an ongoing, weekly basis. Hours are available between 9-5 any weekday.

Tasks include:

  • Assist to put together/mail team materials
  • Help make team calls
  • Manage and organize event inventory
  • Assist with general office tasks

Volunteers are at the heart of all March of Dimes activities and our important work can not be done without help from people like you! Please sign up to volunteer at the March of Dimes San Francisco office and assist us with the many tasks required to make this event happen.
opportunities.tags: march of dimes, fundraising, office, administrative, fundraise, event, call, walk, volunteer

opportunities.description:
Full Description

UniversalGiving™, an award-winning global social-entrepreneurship nonprofit organization, is looking for a QA/Web Intern to join our exciting team. The QA/Web Intern will support Product Development, working closely with UniversalGiving's Senior Product Development Manager and coordinating with the Product Development team. The intern is expected to assist in the planning of test procedures, perform rigorous testing of new website features and applications, coordinate with team members to perform additional testing, collect feedback on results, and support numerous ongoing web projects within the Product Development business unit.

UniversalGiving™ internships offer exciting opportunities to those wishing to make a significant impact and contribution to our global communities. Join UniversalGiving and work closely with a dedicated international team, while gaining valuable skills and insight in a social-entrepreneurship nonprofit organization.

Testimonial
“The Product Development team at UniversalGiving is a smart, effective, and responsive group of people. Team members constantly offer each other feedback and support. You never feel that your work is being taken for granted. I feel very lucky to be a part of the PD team!” - Jane Lanman, QA Intern

About UniversalGiving
UniversalGiving™ is an award-winning website allowing people to donate and volunteer with top performing projects all over the world. Our projects are vetted through a proprietary Quality Model™ to ensure the most effective, trustworthy philanthropy possible. Unique to UniversalGiving, we take no cut on donations. 100% of your donation goes directly to the cause.

Located in the heart of San Francisco, UniversalGiving has been profiled on CBS and in FOX Business Network, and has also been featured in BusinessWeekFast Company, CSRWire, WomenEntrepreneur, Oprah.com, NBC News, The Christian Science Monitor, The New York Times, The Financial Times, MarketWatch, CNNMoney.com, Change.organd See Change Magazine. UniversalGiving™ is the 2010 winner of the Opportunity Knocks' Best Nonprofit to Work for Award.

CEO Pamela Hawley is a winner of the Jefferson Award (the Nobel Prize in Community Service) and was selected as one of 50 leaders to the White House's Next Generation Leadership and Social Innovation event. She is also a Finalist for Ernst & Young’s Entrepreneur of the Year Award, and a Colburn S. Wilbur Leadership Fellow at the Global Ethics Institute. She has been chosen as a Fast Company Expert Blogger on CSR.

Duration: This is an unpaid internship with a commitment of 15-20 hours per week for 3 to 4 months (4 months preferred). Ideal candidates are available to work in our downtown San Francisco office.

Responsibilities:

  • Take a critical role in the deployment cycle and production release of application components and interfaces experienced by hundreds of internet viewers around the world
  • Collaborate with our product development team to deliver with quality and efficiency
  • Develop, modify, and execute software test plans to ensure exemplary quality of UniversalGiving's website
  • Coordinate with other team members to perform rigorous testing, collect detailed feedback, track bugs, and report findings
  • Prepare maintenance documentation
  • Work with senior leadership on priority web projects to increase results for the Product Development business unit
  • Manage numerous web projects to identify solutions, prioritize efforts, deliver results, document information, and see projects through to completion
  • Research and provide astute software/upgrade recommendations

Benefits:

  • Applied, hands-on experience owning and leading QA/Web projects for a global website
  • Experience working at a global, social-entrepreneurship nonprofit
  • Collaboration within a positive team environment
  • Increased understanding of and alignment with global issues
  • Networking with other nonprofit professionals
  • Career mentoring with Pamela Hawley, Founder & CEO of UniversalGiving™
  • With positive work experience, references provided
  • For students, class credit can be arranged according to school requirements

To Apply:

Email your resume and cover letter to volunteers@universalgiving.org with “QA/Web Intern " in the subject line. Applications are reviewed on a rolling basis. No phone calls please.

UniversalGiving™ is committed to understanding and representing the diverse populations it serves worldwide. Members of all ages, genders, sexual orientations, races, ethnicities, nationalities, physical abilities or disabilities, religions or beliefs, and cultures are welcome as employees and volunteers in our organization. We believe that a diverse team will best serve our diverse populations.

UniversalGiving’s vision is to “Create a World Where Giving and Volunteering Are a Natural Part of Everyday Life.”™

For more information please visit:

  • UniversalGiving’s website
  • UniversalGiving’s Blog: PhilanthroPost
  • CEO Pamela Hawley’s Blog: Living and Giving
  • Follow Us on Twitter: @UniversalGiving and @PamelaHawley
  • Like us on Facebook

opportunities.description:
Are you looking for a volunteer opportunity to give back to the community? Do you like meeting new people?

Blood Centers of the Pacific, a community-based nonprofit healthcare organization in the Bay Area, is looking for volunteers in the East Bay and Peninsula/South Bay region!

Give back to the community by volunteering with us as a canteen host at our blood drives! Help us keep an eye on the health and safety of our blood donors after their donation. Canteen hosts also get the opportunity to meet our community blood donor heroes while serving them refreshments.

Visit http://www.bloodcenters.org/about-us/volunteer/ for more info about the blood center and email dbingham @ bloodcenters.org to apply.

Corporate/community groups are welcome and required to contact us in advance. Limited space available for groups.

opportunities.description:
SF International High School is an amazing small school in SFUSD of 100% recent immigrant students learning English. We have an amazing community and school, but sadly no music program. I'm a full time English teacher, and also a musician, and I need help running the lunchtime and after school "Rock Band Club!" If you have even the most basic understanding of piano, guitar, bass or drums, come rock with us. It's a club for beginners to learn, and I just need more help to keep up with demand. We have about 18 acoustic guitars, 3 or 4 electric guitars (and amps), 3 or 4 electric basses (and amps), 5 or 6 keyboards (and amps), two drumsets, and a vocal PA. We also have good curriculum and song sheet music in a simplified form great for beginners (including modern pop songs that kids are familiar with).

Normally we have a brief meeting with all students at the start of the club meeting, to listen to the song we are working on learning, and to make a plan. Then we divide up into different classrooms -- guitars in one room, pianos in one, bass and drums in another. You would take a small group of students (2-8 students) and help them learn their part for the song. We are talking SUPER basic chords. Then at the end of club meeting we all join back together and try playing the song together!

Would love to have someone who can come every week during the school year, more or less. It could be during lunch (12:05-12:50) on Mondays, Tuesdays, Thursdays or Fridays, or it could be after school (3:15-4:45) on Mondays or Thursdays. Or some combination of those!

Once we talk to see if it's a good fit, you would need to go through the volunteer induction process at one of our two partner organizations: SF Education Fund or Refugee Transitions (which do background checks, etc.)

opportunities.title: Help recent immigrant students learn guitar, piano, bass or drums!
opportunities.plaintextDescription: SF International High School is an amazing small school in SFUSD of 100% recent immigrant students learning English. We have an amazing community and school, but sadly no music program. I'm a full time English teacher, and also a musician, and I need help running the lunchtime and after school \"Rock Band Club!\" If you have even the most basic understanding of piano, guitar, bass or drums, come rock with us. It's a club for beginners to learn, and I just need more help to keep up with demand. We have about 18 acoustic guitars, 3 or 4 electric guitars (and amps), 3 or 4 electric basses (and amps), 5 or 6 keyboards (and amps), two drumsets, and a vocal PA. We also have good curriculum and song sheet music in a simplified form great for beginners (including modern pop songs that kids are familiar with). Normally we have a brief meeting with all students at the start of the club meeting, to listen to the song we are working on learning, and to make a plan. Then we divide up into different classrooms -- guitars in one room, pianos in one, bass and drums in another. You would take a small group of students (2-8 students) and help them learn their part for the song. We are talking SUPER basic chords. Then at the end of club meeting we all join back together and try playing the song together! Would love to have someone who can come every week during the school year, more or less. It could be during lunch (12:05-12:50) on Mondays, Tuesdays, Thursdays or Fridays, or it could be after school (3:15-4:45) on Mondays or Thursdays. Or some combination of those! Once we talk to see if it's a good fit, you would need to go through the volunteer induction process at one of our two partner organizations: SF Education Fund or Refugee Transitions (which do background checks, etc.)

opportunities.description:
Are you looking for a regular volunteer opportunity where you can work directly with kids? We want you to tutor First Graduate middle school students!

Commitment: Once a week (Monday, Tuesday, Wednesday or Thursday) from 3:30-4:30pm.

Description:First Graduate is a college access program that helps students succeed in middle school, high school, and become the first in their families to graduate from college ready to pursue meaningful careers. On this path to college our students need help improving their academics and becoming the best students they can be. This is where you come in. We're looking for academic coaches to give students homework assistance and help them develop organization and study skills. You will work directly with small groups of First Graduate students (1-5) to help them succeed in school and develop skills beyond the classroom. This is a truly hands-on volunteer opportunity that makes a huge impact on our students' lives.

Academic coaches will be trained and supported by a First Graduate staff member throughout your time volunteering with us. It is our goal to ensure that you start working with students feeling confident, and always have a staff member present. All volunteers will be required to complete a background check before they start volunteering with First Graduate.

(415) 776-8407.

opportunities.description:
The Eviction Defense Collaborative is the principal organization in San Francisco helping low-income tenants respond to eviction lawsuits.The Rental Assistance Disbursement Component (RADCo) department provides interest-free loans and grants to tenants residing in the City and County of San Francisco who have fallen behind in their rent due to a temporary financial setback. Each year we provide emergency legal services and rental assistance to more than 5,000 tenants in the city.

Volunteer opportunities are available in both the legal eviction defense department or the rental assistance department. Law clerk positions are 12+ hours a week and rental assistance coordinator positions are 16+ hours a week for a 2-3 month commitment.

Law clerks:
Under the supervision of an EDC staff attorney, Law Clerks directly counsel tenants facing eviction and prepare paperwork for them to file in court.

EDC strives to create a law clerk team that reflects the diversity of the tenant community we serve. People of color, immigrants, women, and LGBTQ people are strongly encouraged to apply.

Duties and Responsibilities:

  • Counsel and conduct intake interviews with tenants facing eviction.
  • Legal writing.
  • Other duties as assigned.

Rental assistance coordinator
The Rental Assistance Disbursement Component (RADCo) department provides interest-free loans and grants to tenants residing in the City and County of San Francisco who have fallen behind in their rent due to a temporary financial setback.

Duties and Responsibilities:

  • Interview and counsel clients facing eviction for nonpayment
  • Screen clients to determine eligibility for rental assistance
  • Prepare for and assist in court-mandated settlement conferences
  • Work one-on-one with clients to manage their finances by creating budgets
  • Negotiate payment plans with landlords
  • Send out checks to pay off back rent owed in order to keep clients in their homes
  • Other duties as assigned.

Qualifications for both departments:

  • Fluency in Spanish or Chinese strongly preferred
  • Strong commitment to social & economic justice
  • Sensitivity in working with clients from a diverse background.
  • Strong verbal and writing skills.
  • ability to work in a busy clinic environment.
  • Support of the mission of the Eviction Defense Collaborative.

To apply, please submit a cover letter and resume to volunteer@evictiondefense.org

Your volunteer assignment will be assisting patients with enrolling in prescription assistance programs. Prescription enrollment support volunteers need to be available during clinic visit hours: Tuesdays between noon and 8:00pm and Thursdays from 10:00am to 6:00pm so that they can meet with patients who need assistance applying to drug companies for free and low cost medications.

opportunities.description:
A Woman’s Place (AWP) Drop-in is the only women and family specific emergency shelter of its kind in San Francisco. When women have nowhere else to go they come to AWP drop-in center. There they have a safe place to sit with their families, mental health professionals and social workers on site.

A Woman's Place Drop-In is a program of Community Awareness and Treatment Services, inc. (CATS). We operate a network of homeless services providers that work together to end the cycle of homelessness.

Job Summary: Work directly with the Program Coordinator for A Woman’s Place Drop-In to help her maintain an organized and efficient program.

Key Tasks & Responsibilities:

The primary responsibility of the admin assistant will be to update and maintain a resource bulletin for our clients. Crafting and creativity encouraged!

The Program Coordinator will also request help with a number of administrative tasks like

  • Entering demographic data our front-desk staff collects from clients.
  • Helping to maintain organized files.

*Please Note: This position requires you can have and use your personal laptop while on site - unfortunately our program doesn’t have a computer that’s reliably not used.

Desired Experience:

This is perfect for someone who is both creative and highly organized. The volunteer for this position needs to understand how important organization is for our programs to function smoothly.

  • Computer literate
  • Familiarity with Google Drive/Docs
  • Basic math skills (the ability to add and subtract, or use a calculator)

The drop-in center works directly with people currently experiencing homelessness. You need to be comfortable in unpredictable, occasionally loud environments.

opportunities.description:
New Conservatory Theatre Center (NCTC) realized a major facility remodel in summer 2016. The space looks wonderful; however, the AV configuration in our lobby is complicated and needs to be simplified.

Below is a description of our lobby's AV configuration setup and the issues at hand.

Sound System
Runs on four bluetooth-connected speakers through an iPad app called Soundtouch, which groups the speakers together (speakers are located throughout lobby and bar area). Our server plays Spotify, which talks to the Soundtouch app through an iPad with a bluetooth transmitter. Setup is complicated and often breaks down.

Monitor Displays & Projector
Run off of our server and a linux program written by a former staff member. The program automatically pulls whatever files are in a specific folder on the server's shared drive and displays them on the corresponding screens and projector.

Files are just images and the program loops them continuously. The issue? Whenever our server shuts down, we have to reconfigure the monitors and projector (5 monitors total including our server) and getting the correct order of displays is challenging. Like the sound system, setup seems overly complex and isn't reliable.

**In exchange for volunteering, we can offer complimentarty tickets to an NCTC show!**
opportunities.tags: AV, audio, Performing Arts, Tech, theatre, visual
opportunities.title: AV Troubleshooting

opportunities.description:
Problem solving skills and collaboration are key elements of college readiness. You will work with high school students in small groups (4-7 students). These are students who have chosen to take an elective class that supports college readiness. The students are primarily in the "academic middle" with high potential, but some academic struggle. Many aspire to be the first in their family to attend college. Students bring questions they are confused about in other content classes to their tutorial group. The tutor facilitates the group of students in a Socratic Tutorial, where students learn by asking each other questions. Students learn not only the answer to the problem, but critical thinking and problem solving steps. Training is provided for you, the tutor, in this highly effective, research based method, which was developed by AVID (Advancement Via Individual Determination - see www.avid.org for more information). Have the satisfaction of helping an adolescent develop college and career readiness skills.

Upcoming training dates beginning in October and running through February. Begin working with students in Fall 2016 or Spring 2017. Make a difference in just 1-2 hours a week! All tutoring times are during the school day, between 8 AM and 4 PM.

opportunities.description:
The Mission Cultural center for Latino Arts (MCCLA) was originally called the Palmeto Museum, Originated in the early seventies by a group of San Francisco State University students who were frustrated with the lack of Chicano - Latino cultural representation and to promote Latino cultural expression, awareness and growth of the Mission District. These students and some community artist petitioned the city of San Francisco to purchased the old Shaff’s Furniture store located at 2868 Mission which became the Palmeto Museum at the same time three other buildings were purchased for the San Francisco Arts Commission, the Western Addition Cultural Center, the South of Market Cultural Center, and the Bay View Opera House.

MCCLA is seeking volunteers to assist during events year round. Some of the volunteer opportunities are ushering, bartending, admissions and merchandise sells.

Volunteers will learn about Latino Arts & Culture and its role in the community. Great for people who want to share culture and arts to others in a meaningful way. Also, great for people who want to be involved with promoting local artists.

The following are upcoming volunteer opportunites at MCCLA:

November 2, 2016 5:00-11:00pm Day of Dead Celebration

November 9, 2016 6:00-10:00pm

November 16, 2016 5:00-11:00pm Mole Contest

Volunteer opportunities are flexible. If you are interested please contact Volunteer Coordinator Art Campos at volunteers@missionculturalcenter.org or 415-643-2776.

opportunities.description:
Join our Talented Volunteers, the All Stars Project's award-winning volunteer program, as a Donor Development Intern!

All Stars' volunteers are part of our nationwide team that has grown to over 2,000 people, and are the driving force in all of our programs. Our volunteers are passionate people whose tireless work and contributions have helped us to grow into our role as the new model for inner- city youth development.

In this opportunity, work with our Fundraising Manager to assist with a broad range of fundraising activities, including: donor cultivation support and engagement; grassroots outreach; philanthropic research; database management; special events support; coordination of donor-related communications (in-person, phone, etc.); and social media support.

opportunities.description:
Clinic by the Bay is located in the Excelsior district of San Francisco. Many of our patients are monolingual Spanish speakers and need the assistance of interpreters during their medical appointments to ensure that they receive high quality, culturally appropriate medical care. Spanish speakers are also needed for various administrative assignments including contacting patients regarding the results of their medical tests, calling patients to remind them about their appointments, and interpreting documents we use for patient education.

Medical appointments are Tuesdays between noon and 8:00pm and Thursdays from 10:00am to 6:00pm. General office hours are Mon, Wed, Thurs & Friday from 10:00am to 6:00pm & Tuesday from noon to 8:00pm.

• Are you interested in helping refugee and low-income immigrant youth?

  • Would you like to develop valuable teaching and mentoring skills?

  • Are you ready to strengthen your community and have a real impact on someone's life?


Refugee Transitions is seeking committed and culturally sensitive volunteers to become tutors in our after-school program at San Francisco International High School (1050 York, SF, CA). Tutors provide academic support to refugees and low-income immigrant youth in the San Francisco Mission District.

Visit our volunteer page at http://www.reftrans.org/apply to find extensive information about volunteering and fill out an application.

OR

Call us at 415-989-2151 to find out more about other volunteer opportunities!

opportunities.description:
Telegraph Hill Neighborhood Center, TEL HI, invites you to connect with our special community by volunteering your time in one of our programs, helping out with events, or supporting our adminstrative office. If you have a special talent you would like to share, please let us know!

Current opportunities:

  • Tutor in our after school programs (K - 5th grade, Francisco Middle School Beacon, Teen Center or Galileo Academy of Science and Technology Futurama Program)
  • Become a preschool teachers' aide
  • Serve meals in our senior lunch program
  • Lead a class or workshop for our seniors (arts, crafts, basic computer skills)
  • Help with garden upkeep
  • Teach gardening to our preschool and after school children
  • Provide support in our administrative office
  • Help with one-time fundraising and community events

By volunteering at Tel-Hi you not only help strengthen TEL HI's programs, you also gain many benefits yourself. Volunteering can help you:

  • Discover new talents and develop skills
  • Connect more deeply to your community
  • Meet new people

To learn more about volunteer opportunities at TEL HI, please send an e-mail to Yvonne Curley at YCurley@telhi.org. We'll contact you as soon as possible.

opportunities.description:
Do you have a curiosity about global affairs? Lead a U.S. foreign policy discussion group today!

For over 55 years, the Foreign Policy Association's Great Decisions program has brought together people and communities to encourage individuals to engage in the world around them and to think critically about the global issues facing policymakers.

Each year, FPA produces the Great Decisions briefing book, examining eight U.S. foreign policy and global affairs topics. All across the U.S., discussion groups meet to consider and discuss these topics, constituting the largest civil-education network in the country. Discussion group leaders organize and lead these meetings in their communities. Become a group leader now!

opportunities.description:
Position: Writing Coach / Youth Mentor for America SCORES Bay Area

Location: A public elementary school in San Francisco, Oakland, Redwood City or San Rafael

Hours: One day per week for 1 hour between 3-5pm

Start date: March 2017

Position Summary

In this volunteer role you become a "SCORES Coach" to support America SCORES mission: to inspire urban youth to lead healthy lives, be engaged students, and have the confidence and character to make a difference in the world. The SCORES Coach’s role is to help coach and mentor students in a creative writing and community service-learning program for public elementary school kids. This person is supervised by the School Site Coordinator and America SCORES staff.

Qualifications: Comfortable working with urban, multi-ethnic children. Strong verbal and interpersonal communication skills. Patient and able to multi-task. Background check and TB test may be required.

To Apply: Please email Yuri Morales at ymorales@americascores.org

opportunities.description:
HELP A Living Library with our online presence and outreach to the world ! We would love help with PR & Marketing A Living Library to make it more known locally, nationally, and internationally !

We are currently moving our old website (http://www.alivinglibrary.org/) to a new WordPress blog/website http://www.alivinglibrary.org/blog) for greater ease of updating and readability. We would like this Wordpress site to also be a blog, for teachers, students, volunteers, and other community members involved with A Living Library's programs to interact with each other and share their experiences and opportunities online.

We are hoping that our online presence will be a way for our Branch Living Library & Think Park sites in San Francisco (OMI/Excelsior, Bernal Heights, and Chinatown) as well as our site in New York City (Roosevelt Island) to link with each other, share ideas, and link curriculum. We would like to create a "Green-powered Digital Gateway," an innovative way for our stakeholders to connect and communicate.

We will need help developing this new online presence, uploading and updating content (text, images, video, blog), creating a monthly newsletter campaign, and developing further strategies to increase our community and web presence.

opportunities.description:
Bridge HIV at the San Francisco Department of Public Health is now enrolling for new HIV vaccine studies. Historically, vaccines have been one of the most effective ways for preventing disease & infection. Researchers want to find one that can prevent HIV. Participate in a research study to help us find a vaccine for HIV prevention!

We're looking for healthy people who are:

> HIV negative
> and between the ages of 18-50.

If eligible, you will be compensated up to $75 per visit.

Visit http://www.PowerToPreventHIV.org to learn more or contact us at 415 437 7485.

All information is kept strictly confidential. You cannot get HIV from the study vaccine.
Bridge HIV is a Bay Area based leader in innovative global HIV prevention research.

opportunities.description:
Boys Hope Girls Hope is a Bay Area nonprofit that works with underprivileged children to empower them through education so that they can pursue their dreams of going to college. We have an afterschool program in San Francisco that serves boys and girls ranging from 6th-12th grade. We are seeking volunteers who are interested in working closely with our young scholars and supporting their academic success! As a tutor, you will work with our scholars to help them complete homework, prepare for exams, develop good study habits, etc. For our program, we are seeking tutors who can make a weekly commitment and are available between 3pm - 8pm (the time will vary depending on the scholar you work with). We are located at Archbishop Riordan High School, 175 Phelan Ave, San Francisco, CA, directly across from CCSF. BART and MUNI lines run close by. This is a great opportunity to build relationships with our youth and prepare them for college, career, and life!

Take the first step in volunteering with us at BHGH and fill out a volunteer interest form below and if you have any questions please feel free to contact our volunteer coordinator at kugalde@bhgh.org

https://boyshopegirlshope.formstack.com/forms/volunteer_intrest?RequisitionID=a0gj00000027Qkb

opportunities.description:
Make a difference in the future of San Francisco high school students by teaching them economic success skills!

As a volunteer, you will:

  • Receive ready-to-use materials provided by JA
  • Teach up to seven 45-minute lessons to a class of approximately 30 high school students
  • Receive a 1 hour volunteer training

Anticipated program start date is April 7. Prefered day of the week is Friday, but can be flexible to work with your schedule. Available class times are 8 a.m., 9, 10, 12 and 1.

JA Career Success - students will:

  • Session 1: Get Hired: Critical thinking and Creativity - apply to problem solving
  • Session 2: Get Hired: Communication and Conflict Management Skills
  • Session 3: Get Hired: Collaboration and Creativity - high performing teams
  • Session 4: Get Hired: Strong Soft Skills - practice interviewing
  • Session 5: Know Your Work Priorities - use priority setting tools
  • Session 6: Know Who’s Hiring - recognize STEM and other high-growth industries
  • Session 7: Know Your Personal Brand - identify personal-brand and job hunting tools

How to Get Started

Junior Achievement’s proven, turnkey programs make volunteering easy. Simply respond to this listing and Junior Achievement of Northern California will contact you to set up a short training session. Questions? Contact Lucy Rushanova, Program Manager, at 925-465-1082 or lrushanova@janorcal.org.

View a list of our programs here: https://www.juniorachievement.org/web/12659/26

opportunities.description:
Assist library users to print, copy, scan and fax using SFPL multifunction devices (MFDs). The ability to get a copy machine to work often seems to be in inverse proportion to how badly you need the pages! It can be more than frustrating to waste dollars of a limited budget printing out blank pages, or getting only one side of a two-sided document.

Once you know a machine, it's easy,
but first-time and urgent users could use some guidance.

May involve sitting and waiting to help as needed. Great for those wanting to study or do other tasks while volunteering. Training on the machines will be provided.

opportunities.description:
SUMMARY

Mission Economic Development Agency (MEDA) is a community-based, local economic development organization which, for over 42 years, has engaged individuals and small business in community-building strategies that together lead to appropriate and equitable economic development in the Mission District. MEDA primarily serves low-income clients, focusing on the Latino and/or Spanish-speaking community. In accomplishing its mission, MEDA is involved in several distinct activities: small business assistance, housing counseling, workforce development, VITA taxes, financial education, community real estate and community lending.. We also devote resources to research and evaluation, community organizing and advocacy. In the process, MEDA is helping to develop best practices in the field.

DUTIES AND RESPONSIBILITIES

The Volunteer Outreach Intern along with the Volunteer Services Manager, will be responsible for recruiting, training and coordinating volunteers within the various MEDA programs and building the capacity of Mission District residents to take an active part in the activities and work of the community. Focusing specifically on Mission Techies and VITA Program.

  • Research, develop and maintain lists of potential volunteer groups and individuals
  • Help develop outreach material.
  • Attend Corporate site visits, networking events and other outreach events to recruit mentors for Mission Techies.
  • Seek out school and community events and speaking engagements in order to recruit more volunteers for the VITA program.
  • Help manage volunteer outreach using social networking tools such as Facebook, Twitter, Craigslist, Idealist.org, and VolunteerMatch.com
  • Reply to volunteer inquiries providing information about the organization and matching to specific volunteer role
  • Provide scheduled volunteers with necessary documentation in a timely manner, including waivers, directional maps, volunteer FAQs, and other necessary documents
  • Assist with data entry and ensure data quality of volunteer statistics
  • Plan and facilitate Volunteer Committee meetings including distributing agenda and taking minutes

QUALIFICATIONS:

  • Experience in community organization or recruitment.
  • Experience creating Power points and or Prezi presentations.
  • Demonstrated skill in coordinating projects and events.
  • Excellent attention to detail and record-keeping skills.
  • Friendly demeanor, motivating and inspiring to a diverse population of teens and adults.
  • Excellent communication (written and verbal) and interpersonal skills.
  • Poise and confidence with public speaking.
  • Spanish fluency preferred. Professional or personal or experience working with communities of color required.

TIME COMMITMENT:

  • November 2016 -April 2017
  • 12-15 hrs. a week
  • Monday-Friday
  • Between the hours of: 10-7pm

TO APPLY:

Please submit your resume to Lucia Obregon atlobregon@medasf.org
opportunities.tags: community outreach, outreach, volunteer

opportunities.description:
Watch the Wild ™, a program of Nature Abounds needs your help in observing the "wild" in your community. As a Watch the Wild ™ volunteer, you observe and report what is taking place in your community, from trees and plants to weather and wildlife activity. In as little as ten minutes, your observations help us to understand how our eco-systems are changing and helps us to adapt for the future.

Being a Watch the Wild ™ , volunteer is very easy. All you need to do is:

¨ choose a location or route to observe, whether it be your backyard, a route you drive regularly, or an area that you play, visit, or hike in regularly

¨ record your observations and

¨ report your observations to us via mail or email.
