To learn more, attend an open house, and apply, visit: http://www.mindsmattersf.org/get-involved/

ABOUT OUR PROGRAM

Minds Matter of San Francisco is a 100% volunteer-run, educational non-profit that provides low-income students access to strong mentors, instructors and leaders, who help broaden their worldview and prepare them for college and beyond.

Students join us as Sophomores, where they build up their academic foundations in math, science, reading, writing and critical thinking, and learn key life skills, like leadership and public speaking.

As Juniors, our students focus on improving standardized test scores, managing stress and exploring colleges. During the summers after their sophomore and junior years, we encourage and support our students with finding summer programs at different colleges around the country to push them out of their comfort zones and ready them for college.

Finally, as Seniors, our students focus heavily on showcasing their best selves in their college applications and learning more key skills that will ensure that they don’t just graduate from college, but that they thrive during their experience. We also support them with learning about both traditional and creative ways of paying for college, so that finances don't become a barrier to considering a great school.

We’re looking for volunteers to help us with every part of this program from tutoring to mentoring to managing programs. At the heart of our organization are people committed to making an impact in education and these students’ lives.

At Minds Matter, our mentees come first, but our strong community comes in at a close second. Many of our volunteers form lasting friendships and embark on new endeavors together. Whether we’re discussing the latest trends in education over dinner or picnicking in Golden Gate Park, our community knows how to get things done and have fun while doing it.

We invite you to join our community and our cause.


VOLUNTEER COMMITMENT

The opportunity to make an impact on a student’s life comes with important responsibilities. When working with youth, one of the key components to building trust is just showing up. Commitment is key with our program-your presence, proactive communication, and conscientiousness are what makes Minds Matter of San Francisco work.

  • Sessions take place from 10:00 AM - 2:00 PM every Saturday during the school year (August through May, with breaks following standard school holidays)

    • For Sophomores and Juniors, instructional programs take place from 10:00 AM - 12:00 PM and mentoring from 12:00 PM - 2:00 PM

    • For Seniors, college application prep takes place from 11:00 AM - 2:00 PM

  • We require a minimum attendance of 80% of Saturday sessions (approx. 20 of 25 weeks from August through May) and advanced notice of planned absences

  • Building strong relationships with a student is vital for their success and growth, so we strongly prefer a three-year commitment, though we require a minimum of one year



INSTRUCTORS

The instructional component of our programs is designed to equip students with the knowledge and critical thinking skills necessary for achieving academic success at school and in their standardized tests. Our instructors serve as guides and role models for our students, encouraging them to deepen their knowledge base and to enjoy the process of learning. Instructors take on a variety of different roles in our organization: leading a class on a subject area, teaching the SAT/ACT, and developing and delivering workshops on close reading, critical thinking, and statement writing skills for our students and their mentors. We will work with you to find a role that best fits your skills and experience.

What we look for:

  • Presentation and facilitation skills appropriate to a small group and/or classroom setting

  • Depth of knowledge and passion for a particular subject

  • Ability to take a complex concept and simplify it, so that anyone can learn it

  • Unfettered curiosity for how things work-especially when it comes to academics and tests

  • Passion for setting goals and gaining concrete results

  • Ability to work in a team and navigate ambiguity

  • Prior experience designing a curriculum and instructional materials is a plus

MENTORS

Each student is matched with two mentors, who work closely to help their student become well-rounded and navigate the college experience from application to graduation. Mentors work with their students to explore different majors and career paths and learn a variety of skills, like writing resumes and personal statements, managing time and stress, and presenting and discussing a perspective. Our mentors serve as positive role models and catalysts for the students, encouraging them to fulfill their full potential.

What we look for:

  • Ability to hold a high bar and set stretch goals that mentees can achieve

  • Knows how to listen and ask the right questions to build trust in a relationship, including creating a safe space for difficult conversations and being available outside of session

  • Inquisitive and curious about what motivates and excites people

  • Adaptable to a wide variety of personality types, from introverts to extroverts; youth to adults

  • Will take initiative, solve problems, be optimistic-but-realistic, collaborative and reliable

  • Prior mentorship experience with low-income high school students is a plus

To learn more and apply, visit: http://www.mindsmattersf.org/open-volunteer-roles/

opportunities.description:
Join us on Monday February 27th at our Committee Recruitment Mixer to learn more about the RivAlz Committee!

RSVP for this event by emailing Katrina at kkretsch@alz.org or on our facebook event: https://www.facebook.com/events/1350750668280597/

The Alzheimer’s Association is looking for Young Professionals in the greater San Francisco area to assist in planning one of our newest fundraising events to bring awareness and education of Alzheimer’s, support our healthy body healthy brain program, and promote our women’s initiative to a younger demographic. Whether you are looking to meet young professionals, learn marketable skills, improve your resume, get in shape, or give back to the community, then this is the right committee for you!

RivALZ Blondes vs. Brunettes is a women’s flag football league and game to benefit the Alzheimer’s Association. Practice begins in May and game day is in August. The volunteer committee meets monthly year round at the Alzheimer’s Association office.

The planning committee is responsible for the overall event experience and reaching fundraising goals. Committee roles include: fundraising and sponsorship, in-kind donations, game day logistics, volunteer management, advertising and marketing, player recruitment and management, and coaching. Men and women are encouraged to join the Committee and you do not need to play in the league to be a part of the planning committee.

Take the next step to tackle Alzheimer’s by joining the Young Professionals Planning Committee!

opportunities.description:
RRRcomputer.org's vision is "1 Child, 1 Computer" to become a reality. Our mission is to reclaim, refurbish, reuse computers from recycling to reuse for education for low income K-12 kids. We reduce computer waste by refurbishing the computers to put back into circulation for the kids to use for internet search for research, and doing their homework assignment at home. The computers that are going to recycling is still useful for their needs. We do our part in saving the planet and improve the education of children.

Are you a fund raising guru who can help us to raise funds for the operation of our program to help the kids to get free computers for their school? Please let us know how you can help.

Hue

opportunities.description:
"My volunteer is a very important part of my life and a tremendous help. It is hard to quantify how significant he is and I can't imagine what my life would be like without him." - Shanti client

For 42 years, Shanti peer support volunteers have been providing emotional and practical support to people living with life-threatening illness, as well as LGBT isolated seniors and adults with disabilities, much like you would support a friend or family member in need. If you would like to tangibly enhance the life of someone who needs it the most, we encourage you to contact us and learn more about this truly unique opportunity.

As a peer support volunteer, you will:

--Go through the internationally-recognized Shanti Model of Peer Support training

--Be matched 1-on-1 with a client to whom you will provide companionship, a non-judgmental ear and light practical assistance

--Join a community of thoughtful, supportive volunteers and staff

For this program, we ask for a commitment of 2 to 6 hours a week for at least 6 months. We also organize support groups once a month, and ask all volunteers to attend. The 2-6 hours can be done according to volunteer's schedules--a lot of our volunteers visit their clients on weekends or evenings--so it's definitely flexible.

If you decide to enroll in the Peer Support Program there is a mandatory volunteer training. Each interested volunteer must attend ALL of the training dates listed below.

The dates for the next trainings are as follows:

· Friday, March 24th from 6pm-9:30pm

· Saturday, March 25th from 9am-6pm

· Sunday, March 26th from 9am-6pm

· and Wed., March 29th from 6pm-9:30pm

The purpose of this training is to prepare volunteers to work with individuals who are isolated, or living with life-threatening illnesses and other disabilities. The training will supply information about challenges our clients face as well as teach communication and listening skills through a variety of interactive exercise. The training is pretty intensive, but our volunteers typically find it to be an enriching, community-building experience.

You can make an invaluable difference to someone who needs it the most - and have your life changed in the process.

Shanti was founded in 1974. Since its inception, Shanti has trained more than 18,000 individuals in the Bay Area and 600 organizations around the world in compassionately providing emotional and practical support to clients grappling with life-threatening illnesses, social isolation, other disabilities and poverty. Recognized as the first community-based AIDS Organization in the world, Shanti serves over 2,000 of San Francisco’s most vulnerable residents, annually.

To learn more about how to get involved, please contact Volunteer Services at 415-674-4726 or email volunteerservices@shanti.org

To view an inspirational video on the work of a Shanti volunteer, click on the link below:

http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=kAXf8_lRSts

opportunities.description:
Refugee Transitions is looking for committed and culturally sensitive volunteers to become Tutors. Tutors provide support to refugee and immigrant families and play a critical role in helping the agency service its mission. Volunteering with Refugee Transitions is a great way to help your community and have a real impact on the lives of others.

As a Tutor, you have the option of working with clients in either our adult or youth program:

ESL Civics Education and Orientation Program: This program provides adult clients with home-based ESL instruction and civics education. Tutors meet with their student in the comfort of the student's own home, helping them acquire the language and literacy skills needed to engage more actively in their communities, and to access important civic institutions and public resources.

Bridge 2-Success Youth Development Program: This program provides immigrant and refugee youth with the support they need to succeed academically, develop career readiness skills, form healthy attachments, and maintain supportive relationships with adults and peers. We match Tutors with refugee youth aged 6-18 for home-based tutoring and mentoring.

Extensive information about volunteering (schedules, time commitment, all requirements, and more) and volunteer applications are available here: www.reftrans.org/apply. If you have additional questions, please visit our website at www.reftrans.org or feel free to give us a call at 415-989-2151. Thank you for your interest in supporting refugee and immigrant families. We look forward to hearing from you!

opportunities.description:
We are looking for talented branding and marketing managers to join our network of pro bono consultants. At Taproot Foundation, the marketing manager helps to set the strategy on website, brochure, and branding pro bono projects. They are responsible for working with the nonprofit and pro bono consulting team to define the marketing strategy for a project and ensure deliverables are aligned with the strategy.

A successful pro bono Marketing Manager

  • Has 3 years experience creating and executing print, branding, or web marketing programs
  • Has a solid grasp of identity development and audience analysis process
  • Has Marketing Manager, Marketing Specialist, or Director-level experience

A Service Grant project requires a 3-5 hour commitment each week over the course of approximately 6 months. This opportunity is flexible enough to work around the schedule of a full-time job.

Taproot Foundation makes it easy to make a difference. We’re a nonprofit organization that makes business talent available to organizations that are working to improve society. Our goal is to ensure that one day all organizations with promising solutions will be equipped to successfully take on urgent social challenges. To date, we have engaged close to 7,700 professionals on close to 2,300 pro bono projects benefiting education, health, environment, social service, and arts initiatives.

Now it’s your turn to join the movement and Make It Matter.

opportunities.description:
Responsible for helping to maintain the largest GLBT resource database in the United States, with approximately 15,000 listings. Job duties include researching existing information to verify continued accuracy, as well as identifying new organizations to add.


The Gay, Lesbian, Bisexual and Transgender National Hotline and the GLBT National Youth Talkline, are programs of the GLBT National Help Center, a non-profit organization that operates toll-free telephone hotlines both locally in the SF Bay Area and also nationally. We provide information, referrals and peer-counseling to callers who are interested in gay, lesbian, bisexual and transgender issues.

opportunities.description:
Do good for your community while using your professional expertise. Work with talented peers on a rewarding non-profit cause related program. Rare Genomics Institute is making a difference. Rare Genomics Institute is a non-profit organization that helps families in need of genome research.

We are looking for Full Stack Developer with working knowledge of HTML5 /CSS / Java script.

Experience on Mobile App development:

  • Although no previous experience is required, a certification on programming language is mandatory.

  • Ability to write quality unit tests.

  • Understanding of repeatable automated processes ( iterations ) for building the application, testing, documenting, and deploying it at scale.

  • Awareness of security concerns, as each layer presents its own possible vulnerabilities.

  • Experience on requirement compliance submitting a Mobile App to Google Play or Apple Store.

Additional ideal skills/knowledge:

  • Some experience on IONIC framework, Phonegap. Xcode, Ruby on rails, Github repository.

  • Coding guided by dynamic Information architecture based on UX Wireframes ( Balsamiq ) and Prototype ( InvisionApp ) provided by UX team.

  • Code QA and Testing iterations

  • Agile software development

Experience required for the Back-end Development role:

We are looking for committed, and reliable volunteers who would like to join an innovative Mobile App project, which will help to thousand of rare genetic disease Patients, worldwide.

  • AWS Mobile App integration

  • 3rd party APi integration

  • Apple eHealth Platform, Microsoft Vault

  • PKB - Patients know best

  • IBM Watson processing and DB system

opportunities.description:
VOLUNTEER POSITION: GED Classroom Volunteer

ORGANIZATION: HealthRIGHT 360 Resource Center

COMMITMENT: At least 3 hours per week for 3 to 4 months during open class hours. The classroom is open from 9 am to 12 pm Monday through Friday (except Tuesdays). Please contact us regarding our current need for volunteers.

POSITION DESCRIPTION: The GED classroom is a part of Five Keys Charter School and is focused on preparing adult students for the GED, often beginning with remedial skills. We have a credentialed teacher who organizes instruction for approximately 15 students on any given day. As a volunteer, you will provide extra reading support to clients and extra support with basic math (especially decimals and fractions) by working with adult students one-on-one in their assigned coursework.

DESIRED SKILLS, QUALIFICATIONS AND PERSONAL QUALITIES:

  • Ability to tutor clients individually in a group setting
  • Excellent communication, interpersonal and listening skills
  • Able to role model professional behavior and maintain professional boundaries
  • Interest in working with diverse, disadvantaged populations including low literacy, learning disabilities, physical disabilities and impaired cognitive functioning
  • Able to maintain client confidentiality
  • A background or interest in education is a plus but not required

TRAINING AND SUPERVISION: You will be provided with a volunteer orientation. You’ll have the opportunity to shadow the GED classroom prior to working with clients individually. In the classroom, you will work closely with our GED teacher who will be available to address any questions or concerns that arise. In addition, as a valuable asset to our team, we as Resource Center staff are always available to you if you have questions or concerns.
opportunities.tags: adult education, social services, tutoring, GED

In the classroom, you will work closely with our GED teacher who will be available to address any questions or concerns that arise. In addition, as a valuable asset to our team, we as Resource Center staff are always available to you if you have questions or concerns.

opportunities.description:
On pro bono strategy projects, a Taproot Strategy Associate provides much of the data for Strategy Management projects and helps to conduct analysis. They carry out research and data collection, conduct complex quantitative, strategic and financial analysis, and structure their findings for presentation. With a more senior team member, they work to develop and present perspectives and insights for the client.

A successful pro bono Strategy Associate:

  • Has 2 years of experience working for a leading consulting firm on strategy management, for a leading financial institution in equity analysis or M&A, or performing similar functions in a corporation; or is a recent MBA graduate
  • Has at least Associate, Analyst, or Consultant-level experience

A Service Grant project requires a 3-5 hour commitment each week over the course of approximately 6 months. This opportunity is flexible enough to work around the schedule of a full-time job.

Taproot Foundation makes it easy to make a difference. We’re a nonprofit organization that makes business talent available to organizations that are working to improve society. Our goal is to ensure that one day all organizations with promising solutions will be equipped to successfully take on urgent social challenges. To date, we have engaged close to 7,700 professionals on close to 2,300 pro bono projects benefiting education, health, environment, social service, and arts initiatives.

Now it’s your turn to join the movement and Make It Matter.

opportunities.description:
Taproot Foundation is looking for Strategy Consultants, Analytics Consultants, and Data Analysts to work on pro bono program measurement projects. Program measurement is an exciting area of interest for nonprofits that are focused on how to ensure they are making an impact and using their data to measure how they are doing and see what they can do even better.

There are three types of skill sets needed for these projects to succeed:

Strategy Consultants

The pro bono Strategy Consultant is the lead on multiple strategy elements of the Program Measurement project. They facilitate strategy discussions about the nonprofit’s program and help map the goals and strategic objectives that define the program.

A successful Strategy Consultant has 3-5 years of Post-MBA experience.

Analytics Consultants

The Analytics Consultant is the lead on the design of key program metrics and formatting a program dashboard. They translate the team’s understanding of the program into defined, measurable metrics and ensure that the design of the dashboard is user-friendly.

A successful Analytics Consultant has 3-5 years of analytics experience.

Data Analysts Needed

The Data Analyst is the lead on analyzing existing program data for the nonprofit and developing a program dashboard. They map and analyze the quality of existing program data, define the data requirements for the dashboard, and build out the program dashboard. This person should be a data and Excel expert.

For any of these roles, a Service Grant project requires a 3-5 hour commitment each week over the course of approximately 6 months. This opportunity is flexible enough to work around the schedule of a full-time job.

Taproot Foundation makes it easy to make a difference. We’re a nonprofit organization that makes business talent available to organizations that are working to improve society. Our goal is to ensure that one day all organizations with promising solutions will be equipped to successfully take on urgent social challenges. To date, we have engaged close to 7,700 professionals on close to 2,300 pro bono projects benefiting education, health, environment, social service, and arts initiatives.

Now it’s your turn to join the movement and Make It Matter.

opportunities.description:
Come share your passion with elementary students! During the school year, our program runs from 3pm - 6pm, Monday through Friday. We will work with your availability. Volunteers are encouraged to take initiative in building relationships with students in our program in order to best serve our community. Volunteering for our After School Program can include tutoring one on one with students who are behind in their academic grade level, leading science or art activities, coaching a sports team (we have soccer and basketball currently, but open to starting more teams), and assisting in our various venues.

The San Francisco Ray & Joan Kroc Corps Community Center's mission statement is:

In keeping with the mission of The Salvation Army, the Ray and Joan Kroc Corps Community Center provides facilities, programs and services that encourage positive life-changing experiences for children and adults, strengthening for families, and life enrichment for seniors.

opportunities.description:
About

"My volunteer is a very important part of my life and a tremendous help. It is hard to quantify how significant he is and I can't imagine what my life would be like without him." - Shanti client

For 42 years, Shanti peer support volunteers have been providing emotional and practical support to people living with life-threatening illness, as well as LGBT isolated seniors and adults with disabilities, much like you would support a friend or family member in need. If you would like to tangibly enhance the life of someone who needs it the most, we encourage you to contact us and learn more about this truly unique opportunity.

As a peer support volunteer, you will:

--Go through the internationally-recognized Shanti Model of Peer Support training

--Be matched 1-on-1 with a client to whom you will provide companionship, a non-judgmental ear and light practical assistance

--Join a community of thoughtful, supportive volunteers and staff

For this program, we ask for a commitment of 2 to 6 hours a week for at least 6 months. We also organize support groups once a month, and ask all volunteers to attend. The 2-6 hours can be done according to volunteer's schedules--a lot of our volunteers visit their clients on weekends or evenings--so it's definitely flexible.

If you decide to enroll in the Peer Support Program there is a mandatory volunteer training. Each interested volunteer must attend ALL of the training dates listed below.

The dates for the next trainings are as follows:

· Friday, March 24th from 6pm-9:30pm

· Saturday, March 25th from 9am-6pm

· Sunday, March 26th from 9am-6pm

· and Wed., March 29th from 6pm-9:30pm

The purpose of this training is to prepare volunteers to work with individuals who are isolated, or living with life-threatening illnesses and other disabilities. The training will supply information about challenges our clients face as well as teach communication and listening skills through a variety of interactive exercise. The training is pretty intensive, but our volunteers typically find it to be an enriching, community-building experience.

You can make an invaluable difference to someone who needs it the most - and have your life changed in the process.

Shanti was founded in 1974. Since its inception, Shanti has trained more than 18,000 individuals in the Bay Area and 600 organizations around the world in compassionately providing emotional and practical support to clients grappling with life-threatening illnesses, social isolation, other disabilities and poverty. Recognized as the first community-based AIDS Organization in the world, Shanti serves over 2,000 of San Francisco’s most vulnerable residents, annually.

To learn more about how to get involved, please contact Volunteer Services at 415-674-4726 or email volunteerservices@shanti.org

To view an inspirational video on the work of a Shanti volunteer, click on the link below:

http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=kAXf8_lRSts

opportunities.description:
Check in with homebound seniors of San Francisco

Meals On Wheels of San Francisco (MOWSF)

Want to spend some time each week talking to seniors in San Francisco? Imagine someone like your parents or grandparents who are unable to get out but would appreciate a friendly caller checking in to say hello.

Meals On Wheels is seeking a volunteer to make phone calls to some of our more isolated homebound seniors. Volunteers call from our office to check-in with clients and report any concerns to our social work staff. Being a Client Check-In Caller gives you the chance to engage with elders and work closely with the MOWSF social work team. Volunteer hours look good on your resume and you can earn a great future reference!

SCHEDULE:

Agency hours are Monday - Friday, 8:30- 4:30pm. Volunteer times can be worked out according to your schedule. Generally volunteers make calls in weekly 2-4 hour shifts.

QUALIFICATIONS:

Strong interest in working with older adults, sensitivity to situation of homebound seniors, comfortable chatting with seniors on the phone, reliable, six month commitment to the position.

SUPERVISION:

Will be trained by and report to the Client Services Coordinator.

TO APPLY:

Contact Crystal Booth, Client Services Coordinator

cbooth@mowsf.org

To learn more about our agency, visit our website at: www.mowsf.org

Volunteers for the St. Ignatius Shelter Meal Program prepare meals for the homeless in a large "institutional" kitchen located on the campus of the University of San Francisco (USF). Preparing the meals is done on the 2nd and 4th weekends of each month.

You do not need to be an experienced cook. Kitchen duties vary from prepping fruits and vegetables, buttering bread, cleaning pots and pans, and cooking.

To find out more, please visit our web site at:

http://www.stignatiussf.org/program/shelter-meal-program

Once you're there, click on "Shelter Meal Program Schedule" to view the schedule and sign up as a volunteer. You may also e-mail stignatiussheltermeals@gmail.com for additional information.

opportunities.description:
REACH & RISE(tm)

Volunteer Mentoring Program

YMCA OF San Francisco

Reach & Rise is a free one-to-one youth mentoring program that was established to provide young people in our community with positive adult relationships. Through building safe, consistent, and fun relationships, mentors can help youth develop healthy social skills, improve academics, increase self-esteem, enhance decision-making, and cope with family and peer conflicts.


A unique feature of the program is the therapeutic paraprofessional training mentors receive prior to being matched. The training helps mentors prepare to work successfully with at-risk youth by understanding issues facing youth (e.g. mental health issues, risk factors, cultural, and social development), developing relationship-building skills, and how to handle difficult situations. Reach & Rise is committed to on-going training and support for all volunteer mentors.


Once YOU are matched with a youth (we say "you" because we know you're sold at this point), the real fun begins! Let your inner kid plan some fun activities - go to the park, play basketball, visit a museum/aquarium, build sandcastles at the beach, or fly a kite! Be creative!

MAKE A DIFFERENCE TODAY!

  • 1:1 Mentoring for youth 6-17
  • Meet 1-3 hours a week for 1 year
  • Be at least 23 years old
  • Pass Fingerprint Screening

opportunities.description:
Experience Corps Bay Area is looking for caring older adults interested in making a difference in the lives of young students in public schools in Oakland, South San Francisco, Daly City and Atherton.

Volunteers are matched one-on-one or work with small groups of children, with a focus on literacy in grades K-3. These kids get the individualized attention they deserve and need to excel, and you get to stay active and contribute your time in a meaningful and impactful way - a great win-win!

We provide 9 hours of classroom training, on-site staff at each school to support you along the way, and we bring our teams together for peer-to-peer support and connection throughout the year.

You can serve as little as 4 hours/week, or 10 hours/week to become eligible for a paid stipend.

opportunities.description:
Executive Assistant to the CEO Intern

UniversalGiving(r), an award-winning global nonprofit, is seeking a committed, dedicated Executive Assistant Intern to provide top-level assistance to our CEO. You will work closely with our inspiring CEO to support a wide range of high level relationship management and fundraising initiatives. If you are passionate about social change and enjoy working with an international team, come join UniversalGiving!

Full Description

UniversalGiving(r) is an award-winning website allowing people to donate and volunteer with top performing vetted projects all over the world. Unique to UniversalGiving, 100% goes directly to the cause. UniversalGiving Corporate provides Strategy, Operations, and NGO Vetting to scale companies’ CSR programs in more than 120 countries; our Corporate Services allow us to become self-sustaining. UniversalGiving has been featured on the homepage of BusinessWeek, Oprah.com, CBS, T he Wall Street Journa l, and The New York Times.

The Executive Assistant will support the CEO on a day-to-day tasks. These tasks include scheduling meetings, handling travel details and preparing materials for meetings. With proven track record, you may be asked to assist with donor mailing projects. This is a great opportunity to work with our inspiring leader.

As a UniversalGiving intern, you’ll have the opportunity to work with a diverse, passionate team representing over 25 cultures. Our work environment is fast-paced and entrepreneurial, yet collaborative and fun, including monthly potlucks and team events. Come work with us to achieve our vision "To Create A World Where Giving and Volunteering Are A Natural Part of Everyday Life(r)!

Responsibilities:

  • Answer, prioritize and screen incoming phone calls and voicemail messages
  • Manage the CEO’s calendar by planning and scheduling meetings, calls, and conferences
  • Travel scheduling and booking for the CEO
  • Prepare material and taking notes for meetings
  • Maintain confidential relationships: enter and edit data in Salesforce, our Customer Relationship Database
  • Write and post regularly on social media channels
  • Create and edit new content for CEO’s blog
  • Maintain office supplies inventory and order supplies as needed
  • Other duties related to operations and administration

With proven track record

  • Research and outreach to new prospective partners
  • Special projects as needed on an on-going basis

Qualifications:

  • Excellent written and verbal communication skills
  • Meticulous attention to detail
  • Strong critical thinking skills
  • Strong basic working knowledge of in-office technologies (printer, copier, fax, etc)

● Computer skills, Microsoft Word, Excel and PowerPoint

  • Commitment to using and updating Salesforce, our Relationship Database

Benefits:

  • Gain experience at a unique social entrepreneurship that has a global impact
  • Gain entry, exposure, and experience in the nonprofit industry
  • Increase your understanding of and alignment with global issues
  • Collaborate within a positive team atmosphere
  • Network with other for-profit and nonprofit professionals in an open office environment
  • Career mentoring with Pamela Hawley, Founder & CEO of UniversalGiving
  • For students, class credit can be arranged according to school requirements

Duration: Minimum 15-20 hours per week required for the duration of the internship, at least a minimum of 3 to 4 months. Ideal candidates are available to work out of our San Francisco office 3-4 days/week (Monday through Friday).

Testimonial

"I came into UniversalGiving as a shy recent graduate. I soon saw that this internship was like no other-- I worked on high-level projects, I was mentored by the CEO (unheard of!), and I bonded with the grooviest team I have ever come across. The nerves left, but the values and experiences will stay."

Germaine Lau, former Executive Assistant Intern

About UniversalGiving

UniversalGiving’s Mission: To connect people to quality giving and volunteer opportunities worldwide.

UniversalGiving’s Vision: "To Create A World Where Giving and Volunteering Are A Natural Part of Everyday Life"(r)

UniversalGiving(r) is an award-winning website allowing people to donate and volunteer with top performing projects all over the world. Our projects are vetted through a proprietary Quality Model(tm) to ensure the most effective, trustworthy philanthropy possible. Unique to UniversalGiving, we take no cut on donations. 100% of your donation goes directly to the cause.

UniversalGiving Corporate consults with Fortune 500 companies on the Strategy, Operations and NGO Vetting for their international giving and volunteering programs all over the world. Some clients include Cisco, Symantec, Fluor, Sabre, Gap, BHP Billiton, RSF Social Finance, and inovia.

Located in the heart of San Francisco, UniversalGiving has been profiled on CBS and in FOX Business Network, and has also been featured in BusinessWeek, Fast Company, CSRWire, WomenEntrepreneur, Oprah.com, NBC News, The Christian Science Monitor, The New York Times, The Financial Times, MarketWatch, CNNMoney.com, Change.org and See Change Magazine. UniversalGiving has been featured three times on Great Nonprofits’ annual Top Nonprofits lists and is a Webby Award Honoree.

CEO Pamela Hawley is a winner of the Jefferson Award (the Nobel Prize in Community Service) and was selected as one of 50 leaders to the White House's Next Generation Leadership and Social Innovation event. She is a Finalist for Ernst & Young’s Entrepreneur of the Year Award, and a Colburn S. Wilbur Leadership Fellow at the Global Ethics Institute. She is a Fast Company Expert Blogger on CSR.

To Apply:

Email your resume, cover letter, two writing samples (two pages max), and three professional references with contact information (phone and email) to volunteers@universalgiving.org with "Executive Assistant Intern" in the subject line. Applications are reviewed on a rolling basis. No phone calls please.

UniversalGiving(r) is committed to understanding and representing the diverse populations it serves worldwide. Members of all ages, genders, sexual orientations, races, ethnicities, nationalities, physical abilities or disabilities, religions or beliefs, and cultures are welcome as employees and volunteers in our organization. We believe that a diverse team will best serve our diverse populations.

Follow us on social media:

● UniversalGiving’s website

  • Like us on Facebook
  • Follow Us on Twitter: @ UniversalGiving and @ PamelaHawley
  • Follow Us on Pinterest: @ UniversalGiving

● CEO Pamela Hawley’s Blog: Living and Giving

opportunities.description:
Reporting to the National Director Major Gifts, the Major Gifts Chair is an effective regional or national fundraiser who understands the importance of building relationships with regional volunteers, local businesses, corporate representatives, and current and prospective donors. A key component of this role is supporting our donors to fulfill their philanthropic goals in the context of rewarding low income students possessing strength of character with a scholarship award and mentoring to realize their goal of attending and succeeding in college. Together with the Major Gifts Director, the chairs will help Education First get to the next level of impact by doubling our scholarships by 2020.

Candidates, please complete the application on this link:https://educationfirst.ninjagig.com/jobs/volunteer-regional-major-gifts-chair/

Responsibilities Include:

- Supports the expansion of donors and their commitments by sharing Education First’s mission during key events that strengthen ties to the communities served.
- Secures Regional or National gifts at the $1,500 to $3,000 level with a goal of raising $10,000 annually.
- Cultivates and builds trusted relationships with a portfolio of current, lapsed, and prospective donors and corporate partners to generate new and increased giving.
- Collaborates with regional volunteers to identify and cultivate high capacity donors and cultivates relationships with the employers of regional volunteers that might emerge as giving partners.
- Advocates for Education First in their designated Region by attending and inviting influential community and business leaders to local events.
- Assists in building partnerships with local companies to provide an ongoing stream of volunteers and/or scholarship sponsorships.
- Tracks and reports relationship management and solicitation activities to the Major Gifts Director on a monthly basis.
- Researches, creates, and delivers proposals for sponsorship and grants.
- Finds creative ways to thank, recognize, and engage donors and corporate sponsors.
- Financially supports the organization through an annual, personal giving commitment of $500.

Education & Experience

Bachelor’s degree (Master’s preferred)
Two years of non-profit fund raising experience
A working knowledge of philanthropic vehicles (desired)
Self-starter, driven by results

For more information on volunteering check out:
http://www.educationfirst.org/become-a-volunteer.php

opportunities.description:
UniversalGiving(r), an award-winning global nonprofit, is seeking a talented, committed NGO Intern to join the NGO Services team. The Intern will be in charge of researching and outreaching to new NGOs while implementing UniversalGiving’s 24-stage Quality Model(tm), and deepening the engagement with the existing NGO partners. If you are passionate about social change and enjoy working with an international team, come join UniversalGiving!


Full Description

UniversalGiving(r) is an award-winning website allowing people to donate and volunteer with top performing vetted projects all over the world. Unique to UniversalGiving, 100% goes directly to the cause. UniversalGiving Corporate provides Strategy, Operations, and NGO Vetting to scale companies’ CSR programs in more than 120 countries; our Corporate Services allow us to become self-sustaining. UniversalGiving has been featured on the homepage ofBusinessWeek,Oprah.com,CBS, The Wall Street Journal, andThe New York Times.


The NGO Intern will ensure top-quality NGO services through research, outreach, and execution of UniversalGiving’s Quality Model(tm). Before a NGO is published on our website, you will verify information about the NGO and ensure it is top performing. With proven track record, you will be trained in other aspects of NGO Services and given more responsibilities. This is a great opportunity to learn how nonprofits are run and to gain broad exposure to the non-profit industry.


As a UniversalGiving intern, you’ll have the opportunity to work with a diverse, passionate team representing over 25 cultures. Our work environment is fast-paced and entrepreneurial, yet collaborative and fun, including monthly potlucks and team events. Come work with us to achieve our vision "To Create A World Where Giving and Volunteering Are A Natural Part of Everyday Life(r)!


Responsibilities:

  • Post on social media platforms and deepen engagement with existing NGO partners on social media (Twitter, Facebook, LinkedIn)

  • Manage NGO’s profiles on UG’s website to ensure they are updated and accurate

  • Conduct research on and outreach to new NGOs based on NGO Strategy

  • Determine which NGOs fit UniversalGiving’s Quality Model(tm) prior to being published

  • Verify EIN numbers with IRS list of legitimate organizations

  • Verify organizations’ financial information

  • Verify compliance with U.S. Patriot Act

  • Verify affiliations

  • Promote NGO partners through community-based journalism and other marketing partnerships

  • Other duties related to operations and administration

  • Special NGO projects as needed on an on-going basis


Qualifications:

  • Excellent written and verbal communication skills

  • Ability to self direct work and manage independent deadlines

  • Meticulous attention to detail

  • Strong critical thinking skills

  • Flexibility and adaptability to change

  • Computer skills, Microsoft Word, Excel and PowerPoint

  • Commitment to using and updating Salesforce, our Relationship Database

Benefits:

  • Gain experience at a unique social entrepreneurship that has a global impact

  • Gain entry, exposure, and experience in the nonprofit industry

  • Increase your understanding of and alignment with global issues

  • Collaborate within a positive team atmosphere

  • Network with other for-profit and nonprofit professionals in an open office environment

  • Career mentoring with Pamela Hawley, Founder & CEO of UniversalGiving

  • For students, class credit can be arranged according to school requirements


Duration: Minimum 15-20 hours per week required for the duration of the internship, at least a minimum of 3 to 4 months. Ideal candidates are available to work out of our San Francisco office 3-4 days/week (Monday through Friday).


Testimonial

"I came into UniversalGiving as a shy recent graduate. I soon saw that this internship was like no other-- I worked on high-level projects, I was mentored by the CEO (unheard of!), and I bonded with the grooviest team I have ever come across. The nerves left, but the values and experiences will stay."

Germaine Lau, former Executive Assistant Intern

About UniversalGiving

UniversalGiving’s Mission: To connect people to quality giving and volunteer opportunities worldwide.

UniversalGiving’s Vision: "To Create A World Where Giving and Volunteering Are A Natural Part of Everyday Life"(r)

UniversalGiving(r) is an award-winning website allowing people to donate and volunteer with top performing projects all over the world. Our projects are vetted through a proprietary Quality Model(tm) to ensure the most effective, trustworthy philanthropy possible. Unique to UniversalGiving, we take no cut on donations. 100% of your donation goes directly to the cause.

UniversalGiving Corporate consults with Fortune 500 companies on the Strategy, Operations and NGO Vetting for their international giving and volunteering programs all over the world. Some clients include Cisco, Symantec, Fluor, Sabre, Gap, BHP Billiton, RSF Social Finance, and inovia.

Located in the heart of San Francisco, UniversalGiving has been profiled onCBS and inFOX Business Network, and has also been featured inBusinessWeek,Fast Company,CSRWire,WomenEntrepreneur,Oprah.com,NBC News,The Christian Science Monitor,The New York Times,The Financial Times,MarketWatch,CNNMoney.com,Change.organdSee Change Magazine. UniversalGiving has been featured three times on Great Nonprofits’ annual Top Nonprofits lists and is a Webby Award Honoree.

CEO Pamela Hawley is a winner of theJefferson Award (the Nobel Prize in Community Service) and was selected as one of 50 leaders to the White House's Next Generation Leadership and Social Innovation event. She is a Finalistfor Ernst & Young’s Entrepreneur of the Year Award, and a Colburn S. Wilbur Leadership Fellow at the Global Ethics Institute. She is a Fast Company Expert Blogger on CSR.


To Apply:

Email your resume, cover letter, two writing samples (two pages max), and three professional references with contact information (phone and email) to volunteers@universalgiving.org with "NGO Intern" in the subject line. Applications are reviewed on a rolling basis. No phone calls please.

UniversalGiving(r) is committed to understanding and representing the diverse populations it serves worldwide. Members of all ages, genders, sexual orientations, races, ethnicities, nationalities, physical abilities or disabilities, religions or beliefs, and cultures are welcome as employees and volunteers in our organization. We believe that a diverse team will best serve our diverse populations.

Follow us on social media:

  • UniversalGiving’swebsite

  • Like us on Facebook

  • Follow Us on Twitter: @UniversalGiving and @PamelaHawley

  • Follow Us on Pinterest: @UniversalGiving

  • CEO Pamela Hawley’s Blog:Living and Giving

opportunities.description:
Help reduce the anxiety levels of patients about to have liver transplant surgery by meeting them at the hospital the day before surgery and escorting them to their various appointments. Many travel long distances and are unfamiliar with the City. Start your day off in a meaningful way by navigating patients through the hospital.

We are looking for volunteers to give prospective Liver Transplant patients tours of the hospital. Shift times are from 7-8am, Mon., Tues. or Wed. mornings. There is Liver Transplant background and escort training involved. A six month commitment is expected. Thank you for your consideration

opportunities.description:
As an AmeriCorps VISTA at Tandem, your duties will include:

 Collaborating with staff to organize community-based early learning and literacy workshops and events for families.

 Recruiting candidates for Tandem’s Literacy Champions program.

 Supporting the preparation for training and volunteer activities.

 Working with local service agencies to develop activities and events that support families and educators.

We are looking for candidates who are:

 Passionate about early childhood education, and building the capacity of communities to support children and families to close the opportunity gap.

 Clear communicators who are comfortable presenting information to groups of people.

 Excited about planning and organizing events and activities.

 Team players who are eager to collaborate with, and support staff members on a variety of projects.

If this sounds like you, you can find more details and information on how to apply by clicking here:

https://my.americorps.gov/mp/listing/viewListing.do?id=70225&fromSearch=true

opportunities.description:
Do you feel special, talented and want to make a big difference in the world? This is a very remarkable opportunity for a few full time or nearly full-time exceptional volunteers to build a sustainable and viable career for one self with us in the healing field under the tutelage of a world renown healer.

For someone who feels passionately about complementary and alternative medicine and Qigong with excellent management, financial, organizing, and computer skills, website, social media, conference organizing, PR and Fundraising, good with people, like to travel, good cook who knows healthy eating, excellent writer and editor, great sense of humor, creative photographer and videographer, knows the system of health care, interested in learning how to heal with Qigong. One who would like to build a sustainable career for oneself in the healing field while under the tutelage of one of the most world re-known Qigong healer recommended by Deepak Chopra. One who would be excited about teaching others and using this healing tool with others for exceptional healing results, be part of an international healing team to bring C-Qigong into every home in the world....become an extra-ordinary coach for healthy living. Preferred, but not necessary, if person speaks Mandarin, read and write Chinese or other languages. Also preferred, but not necessary, if person is well-versed in the health field, knows anatomy and physiology and has had experience with energy, Qigong, TCM, or other aspects of Complementary/Alternative Medicine. These qualities can be in one person or in a number of persons. Enthusiasm and committment is necessary, and a compelling interest in working with the best experts in the world. Apply by emailing photo and a full wholistic resume to eastwestqi@aol.com

opportunities.description:
If you’re always hanging out on Facebook, Twitter, and similar sites, like spreading online love, write catchy comments and love About-Face’s message, then being a Social Media Activist could be a great volunteer position for you. Use the awesome power you have through your social media networks to get our important message out there! This is especially great if you don’t live in the San Francisco Bay Area. As part of being a volunteer with About-Face, you’ll be invited in person or via videoconference to our All-Team Meetings held about once per month.

To apply: Fill out our Volunteer Application (http://www.about-face.org/volunteer-app/)! We’ll take a look and may contact you for an interview.

People of color, people with disabilities, and LGBTQ candidates are strongly encouraged to apply

opportunities.description:
St. Anthony's Free Clothing Program (FCP) is San Francisco's largest free clothing program serving both individuals and families. FCP provides warm clothes, interview and employment apparel, and children's clothing to low-income families and individuals, including those who are homeless. The Free Clothing Program serves approximately 125 guests a day in three services: Men's Service, Women's Service, and Family Service. It is our goal to distribute the highest quality of clothing possible to ensure that our guests have a positive and dignified shopping experience.

The Personal Shopper volunteers directly with guests, helping men, women, children, and families find the clothing they need. He/she utilizes interpersonal skills to communicate with guests and to assist them in finding the size and style of clothing and other items they are looking for.

Duties & Tasks:

  • Assist with the processing of donations per FCP guidelines and standards.
  • Prepare clothing racks for display in our "store."
  • Communicate with guests to understand their needs and help find the clothing they are looking for.
  • Retrieve clothing and other requested items from the back of house donations for our guests.
  • Organize "store" by picking up fallen clothes, collecting empty hangers, and tidying "shopping" space.

Skills Required:

  • Ability to be professional, polite, and tactful with our guests and maintain appropriate boundaries.
  • Ability to successfully volunteer with a diverse client population including people who are homeless and/or low-income, and people with physical and/or mental health disabilities.
  • Excellent interpersonal, listening, and oral and written communication skills.
  • Excellent volunteer habits: professional, punctual, reliable, cooperative and team oriented.
  • Ability to lift 10 lbs.
  • Commitment to St. Anthony Foundation Statement of Values.

Please contact St. Anthony's Free Clothing Program (FCP) Volunteer Coordinator, Sophie Wasacz, swasacz@stanthonysf.org for more information.
opportunities.tags: children, homelessness, low income, direct service, poverty, women, families, families and children
opportunities.title: Personal Shopper Volunteer: Help Clothe Families in Need

opportunities.description:
Bridge HIV at the San Francisco Department of Public Health is now enrolling for new HIV vaccine studies. Historically, vaccines have been one of the most effective ways for preventing disease & infection. Researchers want to find one that can prevent HIV. Participate in a research study to help us find a vaccine for HIV prevention!

We're looking for healthy people who are:

> HIV negative
> and between the ages of 18-50.

If eligible, you will be compensated up to $75 per visit.

Visit http://www.PowerToPreventHIV.org to learn more or contact us at 415 437 7485.

All information is kept strictly confidential. You cannot get HIV from the study vaccine.
Bridge HIV is a Bay Area based leader in innovative global HIV prevention research.
opportunities.tags: HIV. HIV/AIDS, research
opportunities.title: Warriors Needed To Help Fight HIV

opportunities.description:
Volunteers Needed_Bookkeeping:

Skills helpful: Bookkeeping, organizing, filing and/or someone with reasonable organizational capacities and willingness to help.

We are working with some highly disorganized people, who are significantly impaired, but who need assistance. One of the realms needed includes helping a person organize their income streams, the bills that need to get paid, their filing system or organizational system(s) for handling such things, so that the person will not chronically incur late fees and the like. Keeping track of what has and has not been paid, keeping track of paperwork. Overall improved filing system would be next phase.

Ideal candidates: Business majors? Retired people with bookkeeping backgrounds? Individuals with a lot of patience, organizational skills, who might be able to help.

Hands-on help needed for hoarding and cluttering clients. Help them organize and file, reduce clutter, help them manage their anxiety enough that they can begin to attend better to daily affairs (opening and sorting mail, getting rid of recycling, etc.) Sensitivity and patience required. Good organizational skills required. Ability to be entirely fragrance-free required as many of the people we work with have chemical sensitivities.

Clients we serve are in various parts of the Bay Area (East Bay, San Francisco, Pacifica, etc.) so having a car is a big plus. Please let us know what days of the week and how many hours per week you are available. Supervision group/ training included.

Location: The client for whom we are looking for help lives in Pacifica.

Contact: Deborah Brenner-Liss, Ph.D., Laurel Heights Psychotherapy Associates,

Cell phone: 415-608-6307, to set up appointment; send resume and letter of interest to AptedSF@aol.com.
opportunities.tags: Bookkeeping, organizational; hands-on help
opportunities.title: hands-on help with psychotherapy clinic patients

parentOrg.name: Association of Professionals Treating Eating Disorders

opportunities.description:
St. Anthony’s (FCP) is San Francisco’s largest free clothing program serving both individuals and families. FCP provides warm clothes, interview and employment apparel, and children's clothing to low-income families and individuals, including those who are homeless. The Free Clothing Program serves approximately 125 guests a day in three services: Men's Service, Women's Service, and Family Service. It is our goal to distribute the highest quality of clothing possible to ensure that our guests have a positive and dignified shopping experience.

The Bilingual Personal Shopper volunteers directly with guests, helping men, women, and children find the clothing they need. He/she utilizes their Cantonese or Spanish speaking skills to communicate with guests who may not speak English and to assist them in finding the size and style of clothing and other items they are looking for.

Duties & Tasks:

  • Assist with the processing of donations per FCP guidelines and standards.
  • Prepare clothing racks for display in our "store."
  • Communicate with guests to understand their needs and help find the clothing they are looking for.
  • Retrieve clothing and other requested items from the back of house donations for our guests.
  • Organize "store" by picking up fallen clothes, collecting empty hangers, and tidying "shopping" space.

Skills Required:

  • Have at least conversational speaking skills in Cantonese or Spanish.
  • Ability to be professional, polite, and tactful with our guests and maintain appropriate boundaries.
  • Ability to successfully volunteer with a diverse client population including people who are homeless and/or low-income, and people with physical and/or mental health disabilities.
  • Excellent interpersonal, listening, and oral and written communication skills.
  • Excellent volunteer habits: professional, punctual, reliable, cooperative and team oriented.
  • Ability to lift 10 lbs.
  • Commitment to St. Anthony Foundation Statement of Values.

Please contact St. Anthony's Free Clothing Program (FCP) Volunteer Coordinator, Sophie Wasacz, at swasacz@stanthonysf.org to learn more about this opportunity.

opportunities.description:
Seven Tepees Youth Program is a nonprofit, community based organization that provides comprehensive youth development and college access and persistence services to over 1,000 youth annually through two programs: The Learning Center and The College & Career Program. Our Learning Center works with low income middle and high school students as well as recent college graduates for a period of over ten years - spanning middle school and high school graduation into the first few years of college or career - offering academic support and guidance, college and career advising, environmental education, mentoring, job training and counseling. Our College and Career Program at Mission High School, a public school serving predominantly low income and first generation students, includes college and career advising, scholarship assistance, scholarships, test preparation support and college application assistance. Seven Tepees has an annual operating budget of approximately $1 million and inhabits the top floor of a building owned by the organization.

Mission:

The mission of Seven Tepees is to work with urban youth to foster the skills they need to make lifelong positive choices and to create their own opportunities for success. Founded in 1995 by retired Juvenile Justice Daniel Weinstein and Native American healer Hully Fetico, Seven Tepees began as a summer camp where youth lived in seven tepees - one representing each continent of the world.


Volunteers make Seven Tepees Youth Program possible, as we rely on your support to offer students every opportunity available.

Seven Tepees is currently looking for after-school tutors for the 2016-2017 school year at our Learning Center in the Mission at 3177 17th Street at S. Van Ness.


Tutoring is provided to Seven Tepees students Monday through Thursday as part of the after-school program. Tutors give youth an opportunity to achieve academic success by giving personalized support to each student. Our students are in middle school (6th-8th grades) and high school (9th-12th grades), and their studies include math, science, history and literature. Tutors should be comfortable supporting students in general studies, and tutors with specialized areas of expertise/study are encouraged to apply.


Tutors commit to at least 1 day per week - we welcome more! - for 1.5 to 2 hours depending on grade level. We are currently in need of tutors Monday through Thursday.


Middle School: 4:00 to 6:00 pm
High School: 4:30 to 6:00 pm


To start tutoring with Seven Tepees, please contact Gaëlle Feliz, Volunteer Coordinator, at volunteer@7tepees.org to apply to become a volunteer and to sign-up for our next volunteer orientation.

opportunities.title: Tutor Opportunity in San Francisco
opportunities.plaintextDescription: Seven Tepees Youth Program is a nonprofit, community based organization that provides comprehensive youth development and college access and persistence services to over 1,000 youth annually through two programs: The Learning Center and The College & Career Program. Our Learning Center works with low income middle and high school students as well as recent college graduates for a period of over ten years - spanning middle school and high school graduation into the first few years of college or career - offering academic support and guidance, college and career advising, environmental education, mentoring, job training and counseling. Our College and Career Program at Mission High School, a public school serving predominantly low income and first generation students, includes college and career advising, scholarship assistance, scholarships, test preparation support and college application assistance. Seven Tepees has an annual operating budget of approximately $1 million and inhabits the top floor of a building owned by the organization. Mission: The mission of Seven Tepees is to work with urban youth to foster the skills they need to make lifelong positive choices and to create their own opportunities for success. Founded in 1995 by retired Juvenile Justice Daniel Weinstein and Native American healer Hully Fetico, Seven Tepees began as a summer camp where youth lived in seven tepees - one representing each continent of the world. Volunteers make Seven Tepees Youth Program possible, as we rely on your support to offer students every opportunity available. Seven Tepees is currently looking for after-school tutors for the 2016-2017 school year at our Learning Center in the Mission at 3177 17th Street at S. Van Ness. Tutoring is provided to Seven Tepees students Monday through Thursday as part of the after-school program. Tutors give youth an opportunity to achieve academic success by giving personalized support to each student. Our students are in middle school (6th-8th grades) and high school (9th-12th grades), and their studies include math, science, history and literature. Tutors should be comfortable supporting students in general studies, and tutors with specialized areas of expertise/study are encouraged to apply. Tutors commit to at least 1 day per week - we welcome more! - for 1.5 to 2 hours depending on grade level. We are currently in need of tutors Monday through Thursday. Middle School: 4:00 to 6:00 pm High School: 4:30 to 6:00 pm To start tutoring with Seven Tepees, please contact Gaëlle Feliz, Volunteer Coordinator, at volunteer@7tepees.org to apply to become a volunteer and to sign-up for our next volunteer orientation.

opportunities.description:
Job Title: Participant Engagement Manager

Organization: ChickTech


ChickTech is a multi-generational community supporting women and girls to become technology creators.


We are dedicated to retaining women in the technology workforce and increasing the number of women and girls pursuing technology-based careers. We facilitate hands-on technology-centric events to empower, support, and increase the confidence of women and girls. Through our events, ChickTech builds community, empowers participants to see themselves as leaders, and provides networking and mentoring opportunities in the rapidly growing high tech industry.


We are looking for a Participant Engagement Manager for the seattle chapter of ChickTech. This volunteer role would be responsible for reaching out to educators at local schools and other youth organizations to spread the word about ChickTech and help them through the process of nominating students to the program. Once the students have been nominated, this role would be responsible for maintaining communication with the students to make sure they are kept up-to-date. This role would also be responsible for creating, issuing, and collecting the surveys from the students.


Our ideal candidate will have:

  • Excellent interpersonal skills that establish and maintain credibility and relationships

  • Strong organizational and time management skills

  • Excellent problem solving skills, ability to communicate effectively, both verbally and in writing

  • Good strategic and tactical thinking

  • The ability to work in a collaborative style and move others to action by planning, motivating and organizing work tasks


Key responsibilities include:

  • Establishing and maintaining relationships with local schools and other youth organizations through in-person meetings at events, cold-calling, direct mailing, and other networking methods

  • Providing the resources and information needed to those schools and organizations to begin and complete the nomination process

  • Send out acceptance packets to the locations where we have accepted students from

  • Creating and maintaining the mailing list of students, including, but not limited to information about food allergies, transportation needs, and emergency contact information

  • Working with marketing team members to develop a newsletter and/or other suitable method of keeping the students up-to-date with ChickTech news and schedules on a minimum of a monthly basis (this may involve collaboration with the marketing team and doing this via Twitter/Facebook)

  • Create, distribute, and collect pre- and post-event surveys for the students, and ensure that this information is entered into our database, so the Chapter can track student progress and engagement.

  • Create, distribute, and collect polls to gauge student interest in various topics they’d like to explore or workshops they might want to have

  • Reach out to students from prior years to check-in with where they are now, if they’d be interested in volunteering with ChickTech in the future, and to get their feedback about how we did.


Expected time commitment: 2 to 3 hours/week, possibly more in the run-up to our November kick-off event (August-October). We ask that all leadership team members commit to one year of being on the team if possible, although less can be negotiated!

Please be honest about your time commitments, while we realize it is difficult to forecast what you may be doing four or five months out, we ask potential leadership team members to try their best to upfront with any conflicts, either work or personal. Thank you for your understanding!

opportunities.description:
America for Animals is a startup nonprofit organization headquartered in California. We are a new type of animal welfare organization - one that empowers advocates to promote compassion and fight cruelty in the communities where they live. We do this by developing state-of-the-art web and mobile applications that make it easy and fun to help animals. Our apps are designed to help people find humane places to eat, meet like-minded advocates, campaign to end inhumane practices, and take other simple actions that make the world kinder for our four-legged friends.

AFA is looking for an AdWords Administrator to grow and manage our AdWords campaigns. Via Google Grants, AFA has a large AdWords budget. We want to use it to help people discover our apps and to promote animal welfare.

Requirements:

  • Extensive knowledge of, and experience with, AdWords.
  • Non-profit experience preferred (though not required)
  • Responsiveness to emails and reliability
  • A great attitude and a desire to help animals!
  • 5 hours per week

AFA is an all-volunteer organization. We hope this experience rewards you with...

  • A letter of recommendation.
  • Valuable experience for your r?sum?.
  • The excitement of being at the center of a start-up.
  • A million karma points for saving animals!

opportunities.description:
Your professional skills can help small businesses grow and create jobs. Volunteer as a mentor on MicroMentor.org and make a meaningful connection with a business owner. Mentors join, search for entrepreneurs to assist online, and once connected, serve as a coach and trusted guide.

This volunteer opportunity is extremely flexible. You set the schedule and the expectations with your mentee. Meanwhile, our support staff is by your side every step of the way to help you succeed as a mentor.

Some entrepreneurs need a sounding board or general industry advice, while others are looking for targeted technical advising.

Put your business skills to good use and help a small business owner today.

Join at MicroMentor.org

"Bill's advice has been exactly what I needed and I am very grateful that seasoned professionals like him choose to volunteer their time." - Tracy, business owner on MicroMentor

WHY DO BUSINESS MENTORS VOLUNTEER THEIR TIME?

  • Give Back: Entrepreneurs who work with our mentors grow their revenue by an average of $47,300, or 106%. Our 2013 Business Outcomes Report illustrates the real impact mentors make in the lives of small business owners.
  • Develop your skills: Even though mentors come to the relationship with substantial business experience, they frequently develop new skills as a teacher and coach by mentoring.
  • Learn from entrepreneurs: Connected entrepreneurs on average spend 10 hours with their mentors. Conversations with entrepreneurs expose mentors to new industries, challenges, experiences, and ideas. Our mentors frequently report that they feel like they get much more than they give.

opportunities.description:
We have individual volunteer opportunities at KFS SCHOOL.

We hold Volunteer Orientations monthly and offer FREE Volunteer Trainings for "Long Term Committed" volunteers. This process is for adult volunteers (18+).

3 STEPS TO BECOMING A VOLUNTEER

STEP 1:

Sign up for a volunteer orientation (send an email to: kahlonfamilyschool@gmail.com)

STEP 2:

Attend a Volunteer Orientation:

We hold them monthly throughout the year.

STEP 3:

Clear a background check: You can get this done at the volunteer orientation or on your own.

COMMITMENT

We are always looking for volunteers who are able to commit to two to four hours per week, for at least two months. The times of greatest need for volunteers are:

Mondays and Tuesdays

Academics help from 10am - 12pm.

Enrichment Program (Music and Sports) help from 12:30 - 2:30pm.

Wednesdays (Field Trip Day) in the community

We would kindly prefer to have a full day volunteer apply for Wednesdays from 9:30am to 2:30pm.

Thursdays

Academics help from 10am - 12pm.

Enrichment Program (Music) and Outside Play help from 12:30 - 2:30pm.

Fridays

Visual Arts and STEM activities from 10am - 12pm.

Enrichment Program (Music) help and Outside Play from 12:30 - 2:30pm.

**Some short-term projects and single-event opportunities arise occasionally.


TYPES OF VOLUNTEER ACTIVITIES

ACADEMICS

Volunteers are needed for at least two hours a week to help KFS SCHOOL students with their classroom work under supervision of the classroom teacher. Grade levels are from K - 8 with focus mostly on elementary school levels. Our KFS SCHOOL helpers are acting one-on-one tutors (Shadowing one child)

VISUAL ARTS & STEM

Share your love of arts & hand on activities with our students by supporting our Program. Engage the kids in various projects such as painting, craft, drawing, photography, pottery and more, as well as help to set up and/or clean up art room spaces.

MUSIC

Share your love of music activities with our students by supporting our Program. Engage the kids in various lessons such as Instruments, Voice, Song Writing and Performance, as well as help to set up and/or clean up music room spaces.

SPORTS & WELLNESS

Engage and teach our students how to play sports and/or how to be physically active! Volunteers are needed for at least one to two hours a week to help kids learn fundamentals of sports, new fitness skills, and a love of being active.

We provide free monthly luncheons for seniors in San Francisco, that includes home-cooked food, live music, raffles, and prizes to senior attendees. We are looking for folks to help us with set-up (10am-11:30am), food serving (11:30-1:30pm), and breaking down (1:30-2:30pm).

Even donating 2 hours of your time will help so much!

Luncheons are the 4th Weds of every month at St Cyprian's Episcopal Church, 2097 Turk Street (at Lyon), San Francisco, 94115

opportunities.description:
The Arc San Francisco are looking for volunteers with daytime availability to help out in various programs. We work with adults with developmental disabilities in continuing education, workforce development, and health/wellness. Volunteer roles include helping with job club, art projects, knitting club, and more. If you have an interest, you can share it with our clients!

We're specifically looking for senior and retired volunteers that can bring their breath of expertise to our community! Please email gerkanat@thearcsf.org or call 415-255-7200 and ask for Giovanna.

opportunities.description:
Our elders love company. They like to listen to stories and tell their own stories. AgeSong is located in the heart of Hayes Valley (corner of Hayes and Laguna) in San Francisco. Enjoy a truly rewarding experience being with elders. In addition, every Wednesday at 2:00 pm, AgeSong holds a free Elders Academy Certificate Training one hour a week program that is not manditory for volunteers, but of great value. Constact Sally Gelardin, Enrichment Director, sallyg@agesong.com

Locations throughout the SF Bay area:

  • AgeSong at Hayes Valley, 601 Laguna Street, San Francisco, CA 94102
  • AgeSong Laguna Grove, 624 Laguna Street, San Francisco, CA 94102
  • AgeSong WoodPark, 3121 Fruitvale Ave., Oakland, CA 94602
  • AgeSong University, 350 University Street, San Francisco, CA 94134

For more information, contact: Dr. Sally Gelardin, sallyg@agesong.com

opportunities.description:
You will work with middle school students in small groups (4-7 students). These are students who have chosen to take an elective class that supports college readiness. The students are primarily in the "academic middle" with high potential, but some academic struggle. Many aspire to be the first in their family to attend college. Students bring questions they are confused about in other content classes to their tutorial group. The tutor facilitates the group of students in a Socratic Tutorial, where students learn by asking each other questions. Students learn not only the answer to the problem, but critical thinking and problem solving steps. Training is provided for you, the tutor, in this highly effective, research based method, which was developed by AVID (Advancement Via Individual Determination - see www.avid.org for more information). Have the satisfaction of helping an adolescent develop college and career readiness skills.

Upcoming training dates beginning in October and running through February. Begin working with students in Fall 2016 or Spring 2017. Make a difference in just 1-2 hours a week! All tutoring times are during the school day, between 8 AM and 4 PM.

Francisco needs tutors Tuesdays and Thursdays 10-11 AM and 2:35-3:35 PM.

opportunities.description: The Economic Opportunity Council of San Francisco is seeking someone, versed in financial management, to work with its CFO in analyzing its current financial management systems. The Agency is attempting to improve the efficiency and effectiveness of its fiscal department. The new CFO is working to reorganize the operations and processes of the accounting department to ensure it effectively and accurately reflects the organization's operations. Experience/expertise in forensic accoounting methodologies would be a significant asset in ensuring EOCSF's cost allocation methodology captures and accurately reflects its programs' operations.

opportunities.description:
Refugee Transitions (RT) is a nonprofit organization dedicated to assisting refugee and immigrant families in becoming self-sufficient in the United States. We provide home-based services to help these families attain the English language, life, job and academic skills they need to succeed in their new communities. We currently offer our services in San Francisco, the East Bay, and the South Bay.

Refugee Transitions partners with San Francisco International High School (SFIHS) to offer structured after-school tutoring support to help students with homework, language acquisition, academic skill-building and social adjustment. All students are English Language Learners who have immigrated to the U.S. in the past four years. Most are low-income. Students speak over 20 languages and hail from over 40 countries.

Extensive information about volunteering and volunteer applications are available here: http://www.reftrans.org/apply.

For more information about RT, visit our website http://www.reftrans.org

RRRcomputer.org's mission is to reclaim computers from recycling to reuse for education for low income K-6 kids. We reduce computer waste by refurbishing the computers to put back into circulation for the kids to use for internet search for research, and doing their homework assignment at home. The computers that are going to recycling is still useful for their needs. We do our part in saving the planet and improve the education of children.

We are looking for effective grant writers to help us obtain grants to support our organization to turn as many end of life computers into usuable computers for K-6 kids. Your work is very important to us. Come join our team.

Thank you.

Hue
