opportunities.description:
Reporting to the RareShare Science Director and working with the RareShare team, the Education/Advocacy Content Developer will design, develop, author and implement engaging materials for the Rare Genomics Institute’s rare disease websites and communications. Content may include features on the rareshare.org webpage, written e-books, disease summaries, podcasts, videos and newsletter articles.

Position Responsibilities:

  • The Content Developer works with the scientific team to prepare informational content, expand the organization’s scientific competencies, develop new assessment tools, analyze web traffic to improve outreach and validate content for accuracy.

  • Attend and participate in work group and weekly team meetings via conference call.

  • Enlist and manage other volunteers who can assist in the research and content preparation work.

  • Support the overall efforts of the Rare Genomics Institute and its RareShare team.


Desired Skills and Experience:

  • Bachelor’s or higher degree in life sciences or biomedical field.

  • Ability to interpret, critically assess and validate the accuracy of complex rare disease information.

  • Strong writing, editing, reviewing and verbal communication skills.

  • Proficient computer skills in writing, data analysis and presentation software.

  • 5-10 hour commitment each week.

  • Ability to work collaboratively and independently to achieve stated goals.

  • Ability to organize, engage, lead and mentor others.

opportunities.description:
OUR MISSION: Meals On Wheels of San Francisco, its staff, interns and volunteers provide seniors what they need to live independent and dignified lives -- nutritious food, professional social work, and friendly human contact.

THE POSITION: Meals On Wheels of San Francisco (MOWSF) seeks exceptional candidates to serve as Interns in the Volunteer department. The Volunteer Coordinator Intern for Good Neighbor Programs will learn about volunteer engagement in direct social service programs and will develop skills in volunteer and community recruitment and management. Volunteers in the Good Neighbor Programs work directly with MOWSF clients by being matched with a client (Match), delivering essential items or doing specialized tasks (Client Needs) or cleaning clients’ homes (House Cleaning).

JOB RESPONSIBILITIES: The Volunteer Coordinator Intern will do some or all of the following:

  • Volunteer outreach and communication to support recruitment, on-boarding, and supervision to prospective and current volunteers
  • Client outreach and communication to support the client/volunteer match process and follow up on services provided
  • Help support the Match program in various ways as needed
  • Coordinate the on-boarding process for new volunteers
  • Assign Client Needs volunteers for pick-up, delivery, and special tasks
  • Help coordinate the House Cleaning Program, including polling volunteers for availability, contacting clients, and scheduling
  • Perform relevant administrative tasks, including data entry, volunteer hours collection, and other tasks as required
  • Assist in developing processes and procedures, online and hard copy forms and materials, and recruitment material as needed
  • Assist in volunteer recruitment, orientation, training, and recognition events.
  • Support Volunteer Department staff and other interns when necessary on projects
  • Other duties as requested by Manager of Volunteer Programs

QUALIFICATIONS:

  • Bachelors Degree or current/part-time students
  • Experience/strength/interest in one or some of the following: Volunteerism, Volunteer Management, Gerontology, Social Work, Social Services, Project Management, and/or Non Profit Leadership/Management
  • Experience and/or interest in communicating with seniors
  • The ability to lift 35 lbs

JOB SCHEDULE:

  • Work 2-3 weekdays in our offices at 1375 Fairfax Avenue in the Bayview
  • Minimum of 16 hours/week total for a minimum of 4 month commitment
  • Available occasional evenings/weekends

BENEFITS:

  • Learning from and collaborating with experienced volunteer management, social service, and nonprofit management professionals
  • Networking and exposure to non-profit professional work
  • Being part of a positive, mission-oriented agency doing life-changing work on behalf of seniors throughout the city
  • College credit/fulfilling college requirements
  • Letter of recommendation/references may be provided upon request

SUPERVISION:

  • Reports to the Manager of Volunteer Programs
opportunities.tags: volunteer management, meals on wheels, intern, social services, senior, social work, Internship, seniors, MOWSF

opportunities.description:
Position: General Volunteer

Reports to: Volunteer & Member Manager

Location: Varies; special event, office, member's homes

Description: SFV General Volunteers provide companionship, assist with errands and work in member's homes, working one-on-one with members to provide assistance with activities of daily living. Further, volunteers may be assigned to assist at special events, workshops and classes in an administrative capacity, and at times act in a teaching capacity. For example, as a yoga or music instructor. Some examples of work general volunteers have engaged in include training seniors how to use technology like IPADS or Iphones, having weekly tea or visits with a member, assisting a member with grocery shopping, assisting a member hanging art in their home, just to name a few.

Qualifications: SFV training must be completed (including background check). Volunteers who teach workshops or classes must demonstrate their expertise (degrees, certificates, etc.)

Responsibilities and Duties: Varied; grocery shopping, driving to doctor's appointments, companionship, event help, anything non-medical.

Note: This is an ongoing opportunity so we will be recruiting volunteers on a continual basis

opportunities.description:
The Valentino Achak Deng Foundation was established in 2006 by Valentino Achak Deng and Dave Eggers, after the publication of Eggers's best-selling novel What Is the What, which tells Deng's life story.

We're a very small and friendly non-profit organization. Our interns will have the unique opportunity to gain hands-on experience and directly impact our organization's major projects. VADF currently runs one of the highest ranked high schools in South Sudan. In a country where only 27% of the population can read and write and less than 1% of girls and 5% of boys graduate from high school, secondary education is extremely important in developing the world's newset country.

Responsibilities:

Interns are responsible for a variety of tasks. Creativity and a can-do additude are neccessary to succeed. Making changes to the website, contributing to social media, participating in correspondence with donors, and organizing volunteers are just a few of the day to day tasks that our interns do here at the VAD Foundation.

Qualifications:

College students and graduates are encouraged to apply.

Strong written and verbal communication skills.

Excellent administrative and organizational skills.

A strong and proven work ethic, and the ability to work independently in an unstructured environment.

Prior interest in African issues, especially Sudan-related issues. Those seeking careers in international development, education, or the non-profit sector will receive valuable training and are highly encouraged to apply.

Good working knowledge of standard computer software, Microsoft Word and Excel, and internet research. Knowledge of Adobe software like Photoshop and InDesign a plus.

Time commitment: Flexible; Part-time 10-20 hours/week for at least 2 months

Prior experience: None required, but relevant experience is a plus.

www.vadfoundation.org

Please send resume and cover letter via email to info@vadfoundation.org. Please include the days and times you are available to work. Don't forget to follow us on Facebook and Twitter!

opportunities.description: We need someone who is experienced in Expressions Engine (CMS) to help us manage our website: www.TheEpiphanyCenter.org. Our website was built by UNIT Partners, and it was set up so that we can maintain it through Expressions Engine. However, there doesn't seem to be much room for customizing, or changing the basic structure of the website. It's often very frustrating just getting things to look the way we desire with such limited choices, even for font and image placement, etc. Perhaps we just aren't aware of the features that Expressions Engine offers, thus we are looking for someone to help us learn how to use Expressions Engine so that we are better skilled to maintain our website. We also want to build new donation landing pages but don't know how they will be incorporated into the website we already have.

Touching Lives. Lifting Spirits.

No driving necessary for our Onsite Transport Escort position. Help us provide our mission of enriching the quality of life of older adults (seniors) by escorting our residents and patients to their on-site appointments. Having volunteers escort our residents in a friendly and timely manner greatly reduces the stress and frustration residents can feel when they have to wait for staff.

Contribute on a flexible schedule:

  • Come as little as twice a month
  • Volunteer a two or two and a half hour shift
  • Morning or afternoon hours available

This opportunity is also great for those interested in nursing, social work, physical therapy, just to name a few.

Our volunteer partners make all the difference. Giving of your time is sure to bring joy to the lives of our older adults and surely to yours!

opportunities.description:
Interested in health care that values compassion, respect and dignity for all?

JOIN OUR NEIGHBORHOOD SOLUTION TO THE HEATLH CARE CRISIS TODAY!

Clinic by the Bay is a new, volunteer-powered, free health clinic for the working uninsured. The clinic provides primary care services two evenings per week (Tuesday & Thursday) and eligibility screening services on other days. As a small but growing clinic, we are looking for Front Desk Superstars to provide top quality customer service, answer phones, schedule appointments, scan documents into our electronic medical records system and other fun office activities in a beautiful, modern neighborhood clinic.

Based upon the successful Volunteers in Medicine (VIM) model that engages retired healthcare professionals and community volunteers to provide high quality, free health care to the working uninsured, our clinic is located in the Excelsior neighborhood of San Francisco.

Front desk superstars are needed during clinic hours and regular business hours -- a variety of shifts available Monday thru Friday.

opportunities.description:
Taproot Foundation is looking for Strategy Consultants, Analytics Consultants, and Data Analysts to work on pro bono program measurement projects. Program measurement is an exciting area of interest for nonprofits that are focused on how to ensure they are making an impact and using their data to measure how they are doing and see what they can do even better.

There are three types of skill sets needed for these projects to succeed:

Strategy Consultants

The pro bono Strategy Consultant is the lead on multiple strategy elements of the Program Measurement project. They facilitate strategy discussions about the nonprofit’s program and help map the goals and strategic objectives that define the program.

A successful Strategy Consultant has 3-5 years of Post-MBA experience.

Analytics Consultants

The Analytics Consultant is the lead on the design of key program metrics and formatting a program dashboard. They translate the team’s understanding of the program into defined, measurable metrics and ensure that the design of the dashboard is user-friendly.

A successful Analytics Consultant has 3-5 years of analytics experience.

Data Analysts Needed

The Data Analyst is the lead on analyzing existing program data for the nonprofit and developing a program dashboard. They map and analyze the quality of existing program data, define the data requirements for the dashboard, and build out the program dashboard. This person should be a data and Excel expert.

For any of these roles, a Service Grant project requires a 3-5 hour commitment each week over the course of approximately 6 months. This opportunity is flexible enough to work around the schedule of a full-time job.

Taproot Foundation makes it easy to make a difference. We’re a nonprofit organization that makes business talent available to organizations that are working to improve society. Our goal is to ensure that one day all organizations with promising solutions will be equipped to successfully take on urgent social challenges. To date, we have engaged close to 7,700 professionals on close to 2,300 pro bono projects benefiting education, health, environment, social service, and arts initiatives.

Now it’s your turn to join the movement and Make It Matter.

opportunities.description:
You will work with middle school students in small groups (4-7 students). These are students who have chosen to take an elective class that supports college readiness. The students are primarily in the "academic middle" with high potential, but some academic struggle. Many aspire to be the first in their family to attend college. Students bring questions they are confused about in other content classes to their tutorial group. The tutor facilitates the group of students in a Socratic Tutorial, where students learn by asking each other questions. Students learn not only the answer to the problem, but critical thinking and problem solving steps. Training is provided for you, the tutor, in this highly effective, research based method, which was developed by AVID (Advancement Via Individual Determination - see www.avid.org for more information). Have the satisfaction of helping an adolescent develop college and career readiness skills.

Upcoming training dates beginning in October and running through February. Begin working with students in Fall 2016 or Spring 2017. Make a difference in just 1-2 hours a week! All tutoring times are during the school day, between 8 AM and 4 PM.
opportunities.tags: college readiness, Tutor, Middle School, teaching, AVID
opportunities.title: Tutor at Martin Luther King Middle School, 2016-2017 School Year
opportunities.plaintextDescription: You will work with middle school students in small groups (4-7 students). These are students who have chosen to take an elective class that supports college readiness. The students are primarily in the \"academic middle\" with high potential, but some academic struggle. Many aspire to be the first in their family to attend college. Students bring questions they are confused about in other content classes to their tutorial group. The tutor facilitates the group of students in a Socratic Tutorial, where students learn by asking each other questions. Students learn not only the answer to the problem, but critical thinking and problem solving steps. Training is provided for you, the tutor, in this highly effective, research based method, which was developed by AVID (Advancement Via Individual Determination - see www.avid.org for more information). Have the satisfaction of helping an adolescent develop college and career readiness skills. Upcoming training dates beginning in October and running through February. Begin working with students in Fall 2016 or Spring 2017. Make a difference in just 1-2 hours a week! All tutoring times are during the school day, between 8 AM and 4 PM.

opportunities.description:
Village volunteer drivers avail themselves to help our members get to and from hospital appointments, run errands, fun and social activities and more. The position is flexible in that you can volunteer at anytime you have availability when there is a request. We simply ask that your name go into a pool of drivers and we will either email or call you when a request is made. At that time, you can simply respond if you are available to help one of our senior members.

Please note that to transport SF Village members, you must maintain a valid CA driver's license, insurance and sign and agree to the Volunteer Driver Policy. The San Francisco Village does keep insurance for volunteer driver's in conjunction with the driver's own insurance.

Volunteers may deduct non-reimbursed, out-of-pocket expenses directly related to their volunteer services as a driver, if they itemize deductions.

If interested, please contact the SF Village at 415-387-1375 or by email at info@sfvillage.org.

opportunities.description: The Center for Open Recovery (openrecoverysf.org) needs lots and lots of community volunteers to help make our annual recovery celebration happen. Volunteer for the Road to Recovery SF on April 30, 2017. There are two and three hour shifts availbale starting at 5:00am, 6:00am, 7:00am, 8:00am, and 9:00am. We need well over over 100 folks to help set up, be 5K course monitors, offer support at water stations, provide help with post-run food and pre-run bib/t-shirt pick up, work at activitity booths, help clean-up. Come celebrate all those in our community who are in recovery from addiction. Learn more at roadtorecoverysf.org. Thank you!!!

opportunities.description:
Job Summary: To expand and improve the community building events offered by A Woman’s Place by helping staff organize, fund and launch an Easter party for clients of A Woman’s Place.

Key Tasks & Responsibilities:

  • Work with staff to develop themes and ideas for the Easter party
  • Take the lead on finding and getting in-kind donations whether like food, decorations and entertainment.
  • Help set up event
  • Help to host event

*Please Note: This position requires you can have and use your personal laptop while on site - unfortunately our program doesn’t have a computer that’s reliably not used.

Desired Experience:

The most important thing our volunteers contribute is their reliable time commitment. If you have volunteered reliably in the past we would love to hear about it.

  • This is the ideal position for someone with a strong interest in non-profit development, relationship development, donor engagement or event coordination to get some hands on, results driven experience.
  • The most successful event coordinator will be someone comfortable with representing AWP and CATS to local business and asking for donations.
  • Strong writing skills
  • Strong interpersonal skills
About the Program:

A Woman's Place is the only gender-specific emergency shelter and transitional housing of its kind in San Francisco. We provide a safe haven for homeless women and victims of crimes.

A Woman's Place is a program of Community Awareness and Treatment Services, inc. (CATS). We operate a network of homeless services providers that work together to end the cycle of homelessness

opportunities.description:
Bicycle Angels is a non-profit charity that loans road bicycles for free to people that want to participate and fund raise for an eligible charity cycling or triathlon event, but don’t have a suitable bike to use, and can’t afford one. Our bicycles are loaned to motivated and committed individuals who are passionate about charity fundraising but are not financially capable of owning a bike suitable for endurance cycling.

We help remove a major barrier to charity fundraising, plus engage new people into cycling. About half of our loan recipients later go on to buy their own bike.

Since our inception in late 2009, we have loaned bicycles to over 400 participants who have collectively raised over $1.2 million for 12 important causes. These numbers are growing all the time. Charities that have benefited to date include the Leukemia Lymphoma Society (via Team in Training), Multiple Sclerosis Society, National Diabetes Society, AIDS Lifecycle, Arthritis Foundation, Crohn’s and Colitis Foundation, and Barb’s Breast Cancer Fund. We currently have a fleet of over 130 road bikes for loan.

We currently have operations in Los Angeles, San Francisco, Salt Lake City, and Las Vegas, with more to come in the future.

Our San Francisco Area Manager (our second largest operation) is moving from the area, so we now are seeking one or more individuals to run this location. This is currently an unpaid, volunteer position but may involve pay (stipend or more) in the future as our finances grow.

The duties will eventually be split into two positions when the manpower is available to make that happen.

The main duties of this position are:

Area Fleet Manager Role (our most critical need):
  1. Responsible for fleet for area office.
  2. Storage location as needed, either in a volunteer location (like a private business or garage), rented storage space or garage, or other acceptable secure indoor location.
    1. Issue bicycle loans and receive returns per policy guidelines.
    2. Maintain required information for operations:
    3. Loan paperwork
    4. Fleet status worksheets
    5. Funds raised worksheet
      1. Receive donations of used bikes to add to the fleet. May require picking up bikes from donors.
      2. Optional - work with local used sporting goods or bike store to sell donated bikes that are unsuitable or bikes removed from fleet. Or, sell on Craig’s list or similar.

Area Manager Role:
  1. Interface and coordinate with local charities to increase program participation.
  2. Work to increase local visibility of Bicycle Angels:
  3. Trade shows (booth)
  4. Local media
    1. Maintain finances for area office. Coordinate with corporate Treasurer.
    2. Work to obtain donations of bicycles and funds.
    3. Work to obtain local sponsors:
    4. Bicycle shops
    5. Cycle industry
    6. Other sponsors
      1. Optionally, form a "Team Bicycle Angels" riding group to support local operations.
      2. Coordinate with Board and officers for general operations.
********

Ideally, volunteers will be an experienced cyclist who has completed at least one endurance fundraising event and is familiar with the local cycling community.

If this sounds like a position you'd be interested in, please contact me.

opportunities.description:
The Children's Creativity Museum is a hands-on, multimedia arts and technology experience for kids. We envision a world where the 3Cs of 21st-century literacy - Creativity, Collaboration and Communication - inspire new ideas and innovative solutions. We believe that the success of the next generation will hinge not only on what they know, but also on their ability to think and act creatively as global citizens. Our mission is to nurture these 3Cs in all youth and families.

At the Children's Creativity Museum, Education Interns have the opportunity to:

-Facilitate the Field Trip experience for children ages Pre K--12th grade in our multimedia exhibit spaces

-Work with Educators and volunteers during General Admission hours to teach basic, intermediate and advanced art and technology skills to youth and families

-Prepare, maintain and troubleshoot equipment and supplies in the exhibit/production areas; identify and report status of exhibits and supplies

-Responsible for opening and closing the museum floor and reporting on all issues related to running the museum

-Participate in regular professional development workshops to expand your knowledge base and skill sets!

Commitment:

-Minimum 15 hours per week - Tuesdays from 9:00-4:30 are mandatory, + one other full day W-Sun (or two half days)

-Orientation is Monday, January 30th

-First day is Tuesday, January 31st

-Applicants must be able to commit to the full internship from January 30th through May 28th, 2017

Benefits include:

-Hands-on teaching experience with children ages 2-18

-College Credit (where applicable)

-Regularly meeting with a mentor from the Education Team to further professional development

-A chance to learn about Museum operations and programming

-Experience working in a leading Children’s museum

-Learning how to create projects using stop-motion animation, green screen videos and software programs such as Blockly

-Joining a large network of CCM Education Intern Alumni

-Experience in a creative, fast-paced and supportive work environment, surrounded by entertaining and innovative co-workers!

Our ideal candidate for the Education Internship Program has a strong love of education, art, technology and children. They are creative self-starters with excellent communication skills, experience working with children, general tech savvy, and they love to learn. Our ideal candidate also enjoys highly collaborative, team-oriented environments and values personal growth and professional development.

Minimum Qualifications:

-Strong interest in art, education, museum studies, or media studies strongly desired

-Experience working with children

-Good computer skills on both Macs and PCs, working knowledge of media arts applications and the ability to learn and teach new software

-Strong written and oral communication skills

-Fluency in Spanish, Mandarin, Cantonese, or Tagolog a plus

-Experience working with families and community groups, particularly in the San Francisco Bay Area strongly desired

-Must be working toward or have already earned an undergraduate degree

opportunities.description: In an overburdened and under-funded social welfare system, foster children can slip through the cracks without a caring and consistent adult to speak up on their behalf. SFCASA volunteers change that. They provide judges with the crucial information needed to make sound decisions that affect the lives of foster children. Volunteers help these children by: Advocating for safe, permanent, and nurturing homes Addressing their educational, healthcare, and other urgent needs Helping them to develop permanent connections in the community. Please consider joining us at a 60-minute information session and find out how you can make a difference in the life of a child in foster care in just 3-5 hours a week. Applications, additional info session dates and the current training schedule is available at http://www.sfcasa.org/.

opportunities.description:
Calling all Volunteers!

If you are interested in gaining some event management experience, wanting to get more involved in the arts, or would simply like to help out with our community-serving performances, come join us! The SFCO needs your help at our Main Stage performances!

SFCO Main Stage Concerts are a great way for adults and students to earn community service hours for college applications, work related community service requirements, scholarships, grants, and more. Each Main Stage Concert earns three-to-four (3-4) hours of community service and we have multiple concerts throughout the year, October - April.

We need assistance with leaflet assembly, ushering, attendance tallying, survey distribution, and program distribution. In addition to the satisfaction of making our admission-free concerts possible, we're glad to offer free coffee and snacks for those can help!

Please reply to volunteer@sfchamberorchestra.org if you are interested. Volunteers will work for an hour before the concert, and then can relax and enjoy the show!

opportunities.description:
St. Anthony’s (FCP) is San Francisco’s largest free clothing program serving both individuals and families. We provide warm clothes, interview or employment apparel, and children's clothing to homeless and low-income families and individuals. The Free Clothing Program serves approximately 125 guests a day in three services: Men's Service, Women's Service, and Family Service. It is our goal to distribute the highest quality of clothing possible to ensure that our guests have a positive and dignified shopping experience.

The Donation Processing Lead is part of a core volunteer group that serves as a role model for other Free Clothing Program volunteers. He/she will volunteer in all processing stations (sorting, sizing, hanging, etc.) and is seen as a resource for other volunteers to learn from. They help answer sorting-related questions, maintain effective sorting processes, and ultimately ensure our guests have access to the highest quality of clothing possible.

Duties & Tasks:

  • Assist with the processing of donations per FCP guidelines and standards.
  • Sort donations by clothing type and select highest quality clothing for distribution to guests.
  • Hang, size, steam, and prepare clothing for distribution.
  • Lead clothing processing stations and serve as a resource for other volunteers.
  • Support a team setting with a fun but efficient donation sorting environment.

Skills Required:

  • Excellent interpersonal, listening, and oral and written communication skills.
  • Excellent volunteer habits: professional, punctual, reliable, cooperative and team oriented.
  • Ability to successfully volunteer with a diverse client population including people who are homeless and/or low-income, and people with physical and/or mental health disabilities.
  • Ability to motivate a team to accomplish a shared goal.
  • Ability to lift 20 lbs.
  • Commitment to St. Anthony Foundation Statement of Values.

Please contact St. Anthony's Free Clothing Program (FCP) Volunteer Coordinator, Sophie Wasacz, at swasacz@stanthonysf.org to learn more about this opportunity.

opportunities.description:
Board of Directors

zSharp provides high quality music teachers to Bay Area schools that would otherwise have no formal music education. Our comprehensive, in-school music program currently reaches over 7,600 low-income children in Richmond and Oakland. Our music classes are completely integrated into the school day and curriculum, complementing other academic activities. zSharp provides every child at these schools with at least one music class a week for the entire school year.

We are currently seeking passionate board members to join the zSharp team! As thought partners with the Executive Director, the Board of Directors provides guidance to the overall direction of zSharp and ensure the overall health and wellbeing of the organization.

Primary Responsibilities

  • Advocate to the greater community for zSharp’s mission, vision, and programs.

  • Ensure the financial support of the organization and actively engage in fundraising activities, including personal financial contribution, solicitation of other individuals, and assisting with the solicitation of corporations and foundations.

  • Identify local, regional, and national trends and best-practices for leadership development related to nonprofit and education fields.

  • Recruit new Board members as needed.

Term Length

  • Two years, renewable.

Time Commitment

  • 5-10 hours per month, where applicable

  • Ongoing participation in one committee, as needed

Benefits

  • Directly impacting the students that zSharp serves.

  • Extending your circle of contacts and developing new business opportunities.

  • Hands-on participation in helping zSharp achieve heightened levels of success.

  • Directly assisting in advancing social / nonprofit sector leadership development.

  • Becoming more widely known to the larger communities of practitioners and consumers.

  • Official recognition online and at zSharp events.
opportunities.tags: board of directors, fundraising, development, board, fundraiser, Board Member

opportunities.description:
BECOME A PEER SUPPORT VOLUNTEER FOR RUSSIAN SPEAKING WOMEN'S CANCER CLIENTS

"The Women's Cancer Program staff and my volunteer emotionally gave me a desire to live and fight for my life. The people of Shanti were an example that even through emotional struggle, I can also be an asset to society." - Women's Cancer Program Client

Since 1974, Shanti's peer support volunteers have been providing emotional and practical support to the underserved whom are living with life threatening illnesses as well as LGBT isolated seniors and adults with disabilities. Each year, Shanti serves over 1,600 women and men living with HIV/AIDS and over 450 women living with cancer, most of whom are low-income and medically underserved.

If you would like to tangibly enhance the life of someone who needs it the most, we encourage you to contact us and learn more about this truly unique opportunity.

WE NEED RUSSIAN SPEAKING VOLUNTEERS!

As a peer support volunteer, you will:

- Go through the internationally-recognized Shanti Model of Peer Support training

- Be matched 1 on 1 with a client to whom you will provide companionship, a non-judgmental ear and light practical assistance

- Join a community of thoughtful, supportive volunteers and staff

You can make an invaluable difference to the life of someone who needs it the most, and have your life changed in the process.

Shanti has several volunteer trainings each year, and the next one will be held on the following dates:

Friday, March 24th from 6pm-9:30pm
Saturday, March 25th from 9am-6pm
Sunday, March 26th from 9am-6pm
and Wed., March 29th from 6pm-9:30pm

For more information or to apply, please contact Volunteer Services at show contact info .

Shanti was founded in 1974. Since its inception, Shanti has trained more than 18,000 individuals in the Bay Area and 600 organizations around the world in compassionately providing emotional and practical support to clients grappling with life-threatening illnesses & disabilities, social isolation and poverty. Recognized as the first community-based AIDS Organization in the world, Shanti serves over 2,000 underserved San Francisco's most vulnerable residents.


To view an inspirational video on the work of a Shanti volunteer, click on the link below:

http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=kAXf8_lRSts

opportunities.title: Russian Speaking Volunteers for Women's Cancer Program!
opportunities.plaintextDescription: BECOME A PEER SUPPORT VOLUNTEER FOR RUSSIAN SPEAKING WOMEN'S CANCER CLIENTS \"The Women's Cancer Program staff and my volunteer emotionally gave me a desire to live and fight for my life. The people of Shanti were an example that even through emotional struggle, I can also be an asset to society.\" - Women's Cancer Program Client Since 1974, Shanti's peer support volunteers have been providing emotional and practical support to the underserved whom are living with life threatening illnesses as well as LGBT isolated seniors and adults with disabilities. Each year, Shanti serves over 1,600 women and men living with HIV/AIDS and over 450 women living with cancer, most of whom are low-income and medically underserved. If you would like to tangibly enhance the life of someone who needs it the most, we encourage you to contact us and learn more about this truly unique opportunity. WE NEED RUSSIAN SPEAKING VOLUNTEERS! As a peer support volunteer, you will: - Go through the internationally-recognized Shanti Model of Peer Support training - Be matched 1 on 1 with a client to whom you will provide companionship, a non-judgmental ear and light practical assistance - Join a community of thoughtful, supportive volunteers and staff You can make an invaluable difference to the life of someone who needs it the most, and have your life changed in the process. opportunities.description:
You will work with middle school students in small groups (4-7 students). These are students who have chosen to take an elective class that supports college readiness. The students are primarily in the "academic middle" with high potential, but some academic struggle. Many aspire to be the first in their family to attend college. Students bring questions they are confused about in other content classes to their tutorial group. The tutor facilitates the group of students in a Socratic Tutorial, where students learn by asking each other questions. Students learn not only the answer to the problem, but critical thinking and problem solving steps. Training is provided for you, the tutor, in this highly effective, research based method, which was developed by AVID (Advancement Via Individual Determination - see www.avid.org for more information). Have the satisfaction of helping an adolescent develop college and career readiness skills.

Upcoming training dates beginning in October and running through February. Begin working with students in Fall 2016 or Spring 2017. Make a difference in just 1-2 hours a week! All tutoring times are during the school day, between 8 AM and 4 PM.
opportunities.tags: critical thinking, college readiness, Tutor, teaching, AVID

opportunities.description: Touch a heart. Give a hug. Listen to family stories. If you are an empathetic listener, then volunteering with Hospice by the Bay offers a tremendous opportunity for you to join our Hospice Team. Patient Support volunteers provide companionship to the patient and respite to family caregivers. Generous and compassionate volunteers bring a unique and valuable caring presence. Our patients live at home or in care facilities. Our palliative and hospice services are extended throughout the Bay Area - San Francisco and San Mateo counties are served by our S.F. Hospice by the Bay office.

opportunities.description:
Shanti’s HIV Services provides practical assistance and emotional support to underserved San Franciscans living with HIV/AIDS. Title: HIV Services Intern Type of Internship: Unpaid Hours per Week: 20-40 Internship Length: minimum 3 months, beginning early February 2017 Professional Development Opportunities: Gain skills in peer counseling and client advocacy Gain knowledge of Bay Area HIV/AIDS service providers Gain experience performing client intakes, profile updates and providing information and referral Gain knowledge of non-profit coordination and management, peer counseling, client psychosocial issues, and the harm reduction and active listening models Intern Training Provided: Shadow Care Navigators to gain experience with performing intakes and profile updates Shadow Drop-In Service Center staff, as needed, to become familiar with and experienced in all Drop-In Center tasks and responsibilities Attend required Shanti Peer Support Training* to gain skills in active listening, peer counseling and the Peer Model of Support used by Shanti staff and volunteers Continued consultation with HIV Services Manager *The next Peer Support Volunteer Training will be taking place in January 2017:

Friday January 27th 6-9pm

Saturday January 28th 9-5:30 pm

Sunday January 29th 9-5:30 pm

Wednesday February 1st 6-9:30 pm

Intern Responsibilities: Work a minimum of 20 hours per week Support Drop-in Center activities Provide emotional support, practical assistance and advocacy for assigned clients Update client’s annual verification, profile information, care plans, information and referrals Become familiar with the existing network of services provided. Become familiar with and provide referrals to clients for general information on food, clothing and housing resources Document service to clients through progress notes, database and client hard file. Participate in weekly staff meetings and in-services Receive regular supervision meetings with HIV Services Manager Work as part of an interdisciplinary team of caregivers Participate in program outreach, training and other activities, as appropriate Work with Volunteer Services as assigned Performs other tasks as assigned. Qualifications: Commitment to service as a personal value Ability to make a commitment to provide service at a minimum of 20 hours per week for a minimum of 3 months Completion of on-site training and required Peer Support Training Demonstrate relevant training, course work, employment/volunteer experience or life experience Sensitivity to and/or experience with HIV disease or other life-threatening illness, diversity, substance use, mental illness, homelessness, and marginalized populations Willingness to learn about Bay Area resources Strong written and verbal communication skills Computer literacy, ability to enter data accurately Strong interpersonal skills Ability to work well independently and as part of a team Ability to interact with individuals in diverse environments Receptivity to feedback To apply, please contact Adrienne Elias at aelias@shanti.org or visit our website at www.shanti.org

opportunities.description:
A little more about the Friendship Line, in case you don't already know: We are the only accredited crisis hotline devoted to older adults and people with disabilities in America. We receive and make approximately 10,000 calls a month. The brunt of our calls are considered "warmline" conversations (non-urgent calls), depressed older adults that just want someone to talk to and listen to them. As volunteer you would provide emotional support, reassurance, crisis intervention, well-being checks, in addition to information and referrals.

If this sounds of interest to you I encourage you to fill out our online application:

http://form.jotform.us/form/52255646169159

After we receive your application I’d like to discuss (on the phone) more what volunteering for the Friendship Line looks like. The next step would be an in person interview that one of our supervisors would schedule with you via email.

opportunities.description:
Help maintain and enhance the Presidio’s historic gardens and landscaped areas, Rob Hill Campground, trails, and reforestation areas. Activities include planting, weeding, caring for young trees, and trail maintenance and improvements. Get to know new areas of the Presidio while enjoying a day in this spectacular park!

  • Presidio Campground Stewards:
    1st Tuesday of the month, 10 am-1 pm.
  • Presidio Forest Stewards:
    1st and 2nd Friday of the month, 9 am-noon.
  • Presidio Garden Stewards:
    3rd Thursday of the month, 10 am-1 pm.
  • Presidio Trail Stewards:
    2nd Tuesday of the month, 10 am-1 pm.
Please visit our website for regstration and more details: http://www.parksconservancy.org/get-involved/volunteer/drop-in-programs/

Volunteers must complete the Volunteer Agreement Form and volunteers under the age of 18 must have the parent/guardian approval section signed.

Wear clothes that can get dirty. Long pants and closed-toe shoes are required. Bring layers for changing weather and rain gear if necessary. Bring a personal water bottle and sunscreen.

Visit our Volunteer Homepage for more details about individual, group, family-friendly, or long-term volunteer opportunities: www.parksconservancy.org/volunteer

The Golden Gate National Parks Volunteer Program is a cooperative parkwide effort of the Golden Gate National Parks Conservancy, the National Park Service, and the Presidio Trust.

opportunities.description:
Boys Hope Girls Hope of the San Francisco Bay Area is a non-profit organization with community-based programs for youth who come from situations of significant need. We are seeking mentors for our community-based program, Hope Academy, to work either one-on-one or in a group setting with our scholars, who range from 6th to 12th grade. The mission of Boys Hope Girls Hope is to help academically capable and motivated children-in-need to meet their full potential and become men and women for others by providing value-centered, family-like opportunities and education up to -- and through -- college. To learn more about our organization, visit www.bhghsf.org. As a mentor, you will develop relationships with our scholars and serve as a role model. We are seeking mentors who can commit to spending 3 hours a week with our children. Your schedule can be flexible during the week (the program runs Mon-Thu from about 3-8pm) and will include 1-2 Saturdays a month). We are located at Archbisohp Riordan High School, 175 Phelan Ave, San Francisco, CA, directly across from CCSF. BART and MUNI lines run close by. Ultimately, BHGH-SF aims to help each of our scholars graduate from high school and go on to college. Our goal is to see every child we serve develop academically, personally, and emotionally. This is a great opportunity to build relationships with our youth and make a difference in their lives!

Take the first step in volunteering with us at BHGH and fill out a volunteer interest form below and if you have any questions please feel free to contact our volunteer coordinator at kugalde@bhgh.org

https://boyshopegirlshope.formstack.com/forms/volunteer_intrest?RequisitionID=a0gj00000027Qkb

RRRcomputer.org's mission is "Taking computers from recycling to desks of K-6 kids." We are having a Computer Donation Drive to get the local businesses and companies a chance to donate instead of sending the computers to recycling for parts. If you have contact with companies, it would be great if you can spread the word about our Donation Drive on Last Thursday of Each Quarter at 901 Mission St SF, CA 94103 and 2323 Broadway Oakland, CA 94612.
Please visit RRRcomputer.org for detail info on the drive.
We need help in volunteer to promote throughout the SF and East Bay to businesses to see donating to recycling will not results dismantling into parts. We refurbish their donated computers to be given to low income K-6 kids for their education. Come join the cause to Bridge the Digital Divide.

opportunities.description:
826 Valencia is currently hiring educational programming interns for Fall 2016 and Spring 2017! Come exercise your writing and editing skills, work directly with teachers and students, and gain valuable experience in the many aspects of educational programming, nonprofit administration, and event planning.

Perks of being an 826 Valencia intern:

  • Gain professional development at an exciting educational nonprofit

  • Admission to 826 Valencia events, which often feature very cool authors

  • 15% discount at the Pirate Store

  • Immeasurable joy

Our internship seasons are as follows:

  • Fall, August - December

  • Spring, January - May

  • Summer, June - August


EDUCATIONAL PROGRAMMING INTERNSHIP:

In the educational programming track, you will focus on supporting our student programs, which will involve tutoring students 1:1 and in small groups, developing lesson plans, publishing our students’ writing, and assisting our staff in the ins and outs of program management and scheduling volunteers.


Requirements:

  • Minimum commitment of 15 hours per week for the duration of the semester

  • Excellent written and verbal communication skills

  • Commitment to our mission of supporting youth ages 6-18 with their creative and expository writing skills

  • Proficiency with Microsoft Office

  • Experience with kids in a professional setting is a plus

  • Editing/proofreading experience preferred

*We are currently actively recruiting for candidates with weekly availability within the following timeslots:

12-4pm on Mondays and/or 8am-3pm on Tuesdays and Thursdays, supporting creative writing projects in partnership with teachers in local middle schools and high schools in our In-Schools Program.

9:30-3 pm and/or 2:30-5:30 pm on two or three days between Monday and Thursday, to support creative writing and podcasting workshops at our brand new Tenderloin Center.

9am-2pm on two or three days between Monday and Thursday, supporting high-energy Storytelling and Bookmaking Field Trips at our Mission Center.

For more information, here’s a link to our internship page: http://826valencia.org/internships/.


*Candidates with Spanish, Arabic, Tagalog, Vietnamese, Mandarin, or Cantonese language skills will be given priority.*

opportunities.description:
Organization: Compass Family Services creates a strong safety net for homeless and at-risk families by providing a broad continuum of services that help our clients achieve housing stability, family well-being, and self-sufficiency.

Program: Compass SF Home provides rental subsidies for up to two years, coupled with intensive support services, to eligible families. The program helps families in danger of homelessness to retain their housing and rapidly re-houses homeless families so that they can work towards long-term self-sufficiency.

Opportunity: Help case managers communicate efficiently and effectively with their Vietnamese-speaking clients. We are looking for a volunteer to translate for one hour twice a month.

opportunities.description:
California Pacific Medical Center is one of the largest private, not-for-profit, academic medical centers in Northern California and is a Sutter Health affiliate. Our Mission is to provide the best quality service to our patients. In 2002, we were honored to be named one of the top 50 medical centers in the United States by a AARP survey. Volunteers are integral to the Medical Center's mission of providing compassion service.

California Pacific Medical Center provides access to leading edge medicine while delivering the best possible personalized care. We provide a wide variety of services, including acute, post-acute and outpatient hospital care; home care and hospice services; preventive and complementary care and health education. Through our medical education program and our Research Institute, physicians at California Pacific are able to bring health care innovation to the bedside.

The Medical Center enjoys a rich history of caring for the people of San Francisco since it is comprised of the three oldest hospitals in the City.

We have more than 150 volunteer service descriptions for you to consider.

Volunteers can serve patients and their families by writing letters for patients ... supporting anxious families...helping Alzheimer's sufferers through music, storytelling and art, helping patients make menu choices ... helping in the emergency room. You can help provide more efficient service to patients and their families by organizing files ... pulling files for patients' appointment ... or tackling computer related projects ...

Terms: Site is handicapped accessible

Benefits: Accident / Liability, Training

Other Information Requested of Volunteers: We ask for a minimum 100 hour commitment

opportunities.description:
Our Mission: The mission of the American Cetacean Society (ACS) is to protect whales, dolphins, porpoises, and their habitats through public education, research grants, and conservation actions.

Our Vision: Together, we can protect cetaceans and their habitats in ways that restore ecosystem health, and in doing so, secure hope for humankind.

ACS SF Bay: ACS - San Francisco Bay Chapter (ACSSF) is far more than a conservation organization. We build communities of members - uniting caring people in a common purpose - protecting whales, dolphins, and porpoises. In doing so, we build hope that 'tomorrow’s child’ will live in a world where these magnificent creatures continue to thrill the hearts of people and inspire a sense of awe and commitment to stewardship.

ACSSF Education: We serve as a bridge between science and lay communities and develop innovative, interactive education programs through whale watch naturalist programs, expert presentations at chapters, speakers bureau, festivals and events, classroom curricula, social media, websites, and more.

The American Cetacean Society is committed to incorporating sound scientific principles and best practices in the development and implementation of our educational programs.

The ACSSF Education Director is responsible for planning and managing educational programs and activities that further the ACS mission. The Education Director plays a key role in growing the organization’s capacity to develop and motivate teams of volunteers with a "many hands make light work" philosophy; maintaining working relationships with experts in the marine science fields; and assessing the organization’s programmatic needs and readiness.

The Education Director is a volunteer position on the chapter’s board of directors. The board of directors is a working board in an all-volunteer-organization. The expected time investment for the Director of Education is 4 to 8 hours per week. During a special program or project the time investment may temporarily increase.

Duties

  • Assess needs, requirements, and readiness for educational activities for volunteer staff and the general community.
  • Manage the naturalist training course, our content and educational support for the Citizen Schools curriculum, and other educational programs as they are developed.
  • Develop and manage instructional methods and activities.
  • Manage education operations by gathering resources; resolving operation problems; maintaining reference manuals; and implementing new procedures.
  • Investigate, evaluate, and recommend supplies and equipment.
  • Manage projects, timelines, and deliverables. Monitor program outcomes. Communicate program updates to leadership.
  • Work with the board to ensure that annual educational goals, objectives, and activities are in alignment with the organization’s mission statement and plan. Collaborate with the fundraising team to identify and apply for mission-relevant funding.
  • Recruit and manage volunteers for the education team, standing committees, and/or ad hoc committees. This includes guest experts, informal educators, and clerical assistants. Delegate responsibilities to team members and track progress.
  • Promote a motivational environment that maintains the education team as a cohesive unit.
  • Work with chapter outreach coordinator/volunteers to promote education offerings to the community.
  • Liaison with clients, constituents, community leaders, and marine science experts to ensure that our education strategies are relevant, valid, and accessible.

opportunities.description:
Spend just a couple of hours a week and help ensure success for a young person! San Francisco Public Library is bringing its FOG Readers program to the Main Library, to help young people catch up to grade level reading or strengthen their skills.

We are seeking volunteers to work on-on-one with students using the FOG (Free Orton-Gillingham) Readers method, which employs multisensory learning, phonics based instruction, and other tools to demystify the process of reading. Volunteers will attend two three-hour training sessions and then be matched with a student in grades 2-6. Volunteers and their learners will meet at least once a week at the library after school. SFPL will provide all materials and training, as well as offer ongoing support.

Volunteers should:

  • Enjoy working with young people and exhibit patience
  • Be at least 16 years of age
  • Be willing to undergo a standard fingerprinting and background check
  • Commit to the two training sessions and at least one hour of tutoring per week, probably in the afternoons.
  • Be excited to share a passion for reading!

Benefits of volunteering:

  • Make a meaningful, lasting difference for a child by building critical literacy skills.
  • Serve your community.
  • Learn valuable skills tutoring and mentoring that can be applied to other areas of life.

Interested in helping out? Please e-mail laura.lay@sfpl.org to start the process.

RRRcomputer.org's vision is "1 Child, 1 Computer" to become a reality. Our mission is to reclaim, refurbish, reuse computers from recycling to reuse for education for low income K-12 kids. We reduce computer waste by refurbishing the computers to put back into circulation for the kids to use for internet search for research, and doing their homework assignment at home. The computers that are going to recycling is still useful for their needs. We do our part in saving the planet and improve the education of children.

We are looking for a secretary who can record the RRR General Meeting and Board Meeting. We are looking for someone who does this before and also has time to attend the meetings. Thank you.

opportunities.description:
WHAT: Generation Citizen is a nonprofit organization dedicated to empowering young people as agents of political change in their own communities. We place college student volunteers - called "Democracy Coaches" - into local middle and high school classrooms, to help youth take action on a community issue of their choice.

Classes have worked on issues ranging from affordable housing and police-community relations, to public transit and school discipline policy. Democracy Coaches commit to roughly 4 to 6 hours per week, including in-class teaching (2 hours), weekly check-in meetings on campus (1 hour), and independent lesson planning time (1-3 hours).

WHEN: Democracy Coaches visit their classroom twice per week for a semester, teaching Generation Citizen's innovative in-class curriculum. Volunteer placements are flexible and based on volunteers' schedules and location, and happen during the school day (8:00am - 4:00pm).

WHERE: In Spring 2017, Democracy Coaches will be matched with middle and high school classrooms in the school districts of Berkeley, Oakland and San Francisco. Democracy Coaches work with one classroom and teacher for the semester.

WHO: Generation Citizen is looking for passionate undergrads (or graduate students) who believe we can strenghten our democracy by empowering young people to take real action in the political process. Current Democracy Coaches come from UC Berkeley, Mills College, St. Mary's College of California, San Francisco State, University of San Francisco and City College of San Francisco.

WHY: Democracy Coach volunteers have the opportunity to gain exceptional experience in classroom teaching, community organizing, project management, networking and public speaking. Democracy Coaches are also invited to apply to campus leadership positions with their college after serving one semester in a classroom.

HOW: Learn more and apply online at www.generationcitizen.org. For more info, email Caitlin Paul, Program Manager at cpaul@generationcitizen.org.

No prior teaching experience necessary. Generation Citizen provides training and ongoing support throughout the semester. GC will also cover transportation costs for volunteers as needed.
opportunities.tags: civics, education, Civic Education, teaching, politics, youth, community organizing, Advocacy, classroom
opportunities.title: Bay Area college students! Become a Democracy Coach in a classroom this Spring 2017

  • Groups are welcome.. group of 10 will be divided to serve-bus tables - dishwashing-and final clean up for the next day.

opportunities.description:
The Graphic Design Intern will be involved with the branding and visuals for our CEO’s website (pamelahawley.com), blog (Living and Giving), and social media. The Intern will design brand new components and redesign pre-existing components.Our ideal candidate will have experience designing for online marketplaces, with a profound understanding of the user experience. Interns must be able to meet deadlines in a dynamic environment. This is a great opportunity to work directly with the CEO, gaining valuable skills and insight within a social entrepreneurship nonprofit organization.

As a UniversalGiving intern, you’ll have the opportunity to work with a diverse, passionate team representing over 25 cultures. Our work environment is fast-paced and entrepreneurial, yet collaborative and fun, including monthly potlucks and team events. Come work with us to achieve our vision "To Create A World Where Giving and Volunteering Are A Natural Part of Everyday Life(r)!

Responsibilities:

  • Recommend visual design and branding changes for website components and existing interfaces

  • Design marketing materials including gift cards, one-pagers, and other promotional materials

  • Update CEO official webpage with new photos and news

  • Maintain and update design of CEO blog, Living and Giving

  • Create CEO powerpoint presentations and visuals for speaking engagements

Qualifications:

  • Excellent verbal and communication skills

  • Critical attention to detail

  • Flexibility and adaptability to change

  • Proficiency in Microsoft Office programs (Word, Excel, Powerpoint), Adobe Creative Suite (Adobe Photoshop, Adobe Illustrator), and Google applications (some training provided)

  • Prior experience with Salesforce preferred

  • Experience creating and updating designs in Adobe Photoshop

  • Meticulous attention to detail

  • Ability to collaborate effectively and communicate clearly with team members

Benefits:

  • Gain experience at a unique social entrepreneurship that has a global impact

  • Gain entry, exposure, and experience in the nonprofit industry

  • Increase your understanding of and alignment with global issues

  • Collaborate within a positive team atmosphere

  • Network with other for-profit and nonprofit professionals in an open office environment

  • Career mentoring with Pamela Hawley, Founder & CEO of UniversalGiving

  • For students, class credit can be arranged according to school requirements

Our work environment is fast-paced and entrepreneurial, yet collaborative and fun, including monthly potlucks and team events. Come work with us to achieve our vision \"To Create A World Where Giving and Volunteering Are A Natural Part of Everyday Life(r)! Responsibilities: Recommend visual design and branding changes for website components and existing interfaces Design marketing materials including gift cards, one-pagers, and other promotional materials Update CEO official webpage with new photos and news Maintain and update design of CEO blog, Living and Giving Create CEO powerpoint presentations and visuals for speaking engagements Qualifications: Excellent verbal and communication skills Critical attention to detail Flexibility and adaptability to change Proficiency in Microsoft Office programs (Word, Excel, Powerpoint), Adobe Creative Suite (Adobe Photoshop, Adobe Illustrator), and Google applications (some training provided) Prior experience with Salesforce preferred Experience creating and updating designs in Adobe Photoshop Meticulous attention to detail Ability to collaborate effectively and communicate clearly with team members Benefits: Gain experience at a unique social entrepreneurship that has a global impact Gain entry, exposure, and experience in the nonprofit industry Increase your understanding of and alignment with global issues Collaborate within a positive team atmosphere Network with other for-profit and nonprofit professionals in an open office environment Career mentoring with Pamela Hawley, Founder & CEO of UniversalGiving For students, class credit can be arranged according to school requirements

opportunities.description:
Account Directors - Use Your Strategy Management Skills Pro Bono

Taproot Account Directors lead teams of 5-6 pro bono consultants on pro bono projects for a nopnprofit.

The Account Director’s role is to staff the team, manage relationships, and keep a bird’s-eye view of the project. The Account Director also works with a Taproot Program Manager to track progress, resolve challenges, and ensure the successful completion of each project.

A successful Account Director:

  • Has 10 years experience in corporate strategy management and/or financial analysis
  • Has managed leadership teams
  • Can negotiate executive or board-level relationships
  • Has Director, VP, or partner-level experience

A Service Grant project requires a 3-5 hour commitment each week over the course of approximately 6 months. This opportunity is flexible enough to work around the schedule of a full-time job.

Taproot Foundation makes it easy to make a difference. We’re a nonprofit organization that makes business talent available to organizations that are working to improve society. Our goal is to ensure that one day all organizations with promising solutions will be equipped to successfully take on urgent social challenges. To date, we have engaged close to 7,700 professionals on close to 2,300 pro bono projects benefiting education, health, environment, social service, and arts initiatives.

Now it’s your turn to join the movement and Make It Matter.

opportunities.description:
Boys Hope Girls Hope is a Bay Area nonprofit that works with underprivileged children to empower them through education so that they can pursue their dreams of going to college. We have an afterschool program in San Francisco that serves boys and girls ranging from 7th-12th grade.

We are seeking volunteers who are interested in working closely with our young scholars and supporting their academic success! Specifically, we need biology, algrebra, geometry, and calculus tutors.

As a tutor, you will work with our scholars to help them complete homework, prepare for exams, develop good study habits, etc.

For our program, we are seeking tutors who can make a weekly commitment and are available between 3pm - 8pm (the time will vary depending on the scholar you work with). We are located at Archbisohp Riordan High School, 175 Phelan Ave, San Francisco, CA, directly across from CCSF.

BART and MUNI lines run close by.

This is a great opportunity to build relationships with our youth and prepare them for college, career, and life!

Email kugalde@bhgh.org for more information.

opportunities.description:
At Make-A-Wish, we grant wishes for kids with life-threatening medical conditions to enrich the human experience with hope, strength, and joy. The Greater Bay Area Chapter is headquartered in San Francisco, and covers 17 counties of Northern California, granting an average of 330 wishes per year. In order to raise money to fund the wishes of the children we serve, we work with individual and corporate donors. For each donation, we need to send the donor an official thank you letter for his/her tax purposes, and to show our appreciation for the gift.

We are looking for a volunteer who can help two days per week in shifts of 2-3 hours, on a regular, weekly basis. The days and times can be flexible, but should be non-consecutive business days. Some examples would be schedules like 2-4pm Monday and Thursday, 10am-12pm Tuesday and Friday, etc. All the office work will be done at the Make-A-Wish office in San Francisco, during our office hours (9am-5pm M-F).We also require that the volunteer be willing to agree to a minimum six-month commitment.

Duties include:

  • Running queries in the database to pull lists of donors to thank
  • Printing, folding, stuffing, and mailing official donor acknowledgment (thank you) letters.
  • Data entry - entering corporate sponsor information in our database, Raiser’s Edge, as well as tracking interactions with the companies

The volunteer should be an organized, administrative volunteer with an attention to detail. Experience with Microsoft Excel and Word required. Experience with data entry and administrative work required. Experience with Raiser’s Edge (or similar database) strongly preferred. The Donor Appreciation Assistant must be at least 18 years old. If you are interested in this position, please email our Volunteer Manager at volunteer@sfwish.org to express interest, and include a resume.

opportunities.description:
Want to make a difference in the life of someone loving with MS? Give us a few hours of your time for one day. You supply the smile and the energy and we will supply the t-shirt and opportunity.

The Northern California Chapter of the Multiple Sclerosis Society is hosting a 5k and 1 mile walk at Justin Herman Plaza, San Francisco. Proceeds from the event will support research & better treatments to help those who are affected by MS.

We are looking for volunteers to assist with a variety of tasks on event day, between the hours of 6:00 am - noon, a variety of shifts available. We need assistance with set-up, check-in, t-shirt & food distribution, route support and assistance at the finish line.

Contact Heather Kiuttu, heather.kiuttu@nmss.org or 415-230-6678 x73018

The volunteers offered at this event are:

Set-up: 6:00-8:00 a.m. Help set up tables, chairs, etc.
Volunteer check-in: 6:30 a.m.-11:30 a.m.
T-shirts/prizes: 6:30 a.m.-11:30 a.m.
Greeters: 7:30 a.m.-9:00 a.m.
Registration (Must be 18 years or older): 7:45-9:00 a.m.
Team Tent Concierge: 7:00 a.m.-11:30 a.m.. Act as concierge for top fundraisers.
Food tent: 6:30 a.m.-11:30 a.m.
Route marking: 6:00 a.m.-9:00 a.m. and then 11:00 a.m.-12:00 p.m.
Sweep/SAG driver: 18 years or older with valid driver’s license and proof of insurance. Will drive route as aid for walkers.
Rest Stops: 7:30 a.m.-11:30 a.m.
Volunteer photographer: 8:00 a.m.-12:00 p.m.
Tear down: 10:45 a.m.-12:00 p.m.

opportunities.description:
Tai chi (Mandarin: tàijí 太極, an abbreviation of tàijí quán 太極拳, literally "Supreme Ultimate Boxing") is an internal Chinese martial art 武术 practiced for both its defense training and its health benefits. Though originally conceived as a martial art, it is also typically practiced for a variety of other personal reasons: competitive wrestling in the format of pushing hands (tui shou), demonstration competitions, and achieving greater longevity. As a result, a multitude of training forms exist, both traditional and modern, which correspond to those aims with differing emphasis. Some training forms of t'ai chi ch'uan are especially known for being practiced with relatively slow movements.

From 2-3pm, Monday-Friday, we'd like to have someone come in to lead Tai Chi practice in our beautiful open common area while clients wait for their rides home. Come lead Tai Chi with Adults with Developmental Disabilities at the Arc SF! Email gerkanat@thearcsf.org if interested. We are flexible with commitments.

opportunities.description:
Join Shark Stewards is celebrating and protecting the Ocean in San Francisco for World Oceans Day.

World Oceans Day is a global day of ocean celebration and collaboration for a better future.

Shark Stewards will be hosting our 8th annual World Oceans Day event and is seeking an organized and motovated event planner to help really kick off a great ocean celebration in San Francisco on June 8.

These education and outreach activities are directed at the public, educating and celebrating sharks and marine conservation and supporting the work of Shark Stewards.

We are seeking an enthusiastic oceann lover to plan an ocean party and help us raise funds to continue our marine protection campaigns.

Duties include determining venue (We used Pier 23 last year and can again), planning, helping with scheduling, commuicating to the public and volunteers, and organizing the event the day of. The event planner can help recruit others or use our volunteer base to help, including a donation lead and help solicit donations for a raffle or silent auction.

opportunities.plaintextDescription: Join Shark Stewards is celebrating and protecting the Ocean in San Francisco for World Oceans Day. World Oceans Day is a global day of ocean celebration and collaboration for a better future. Shark Stewards will be hosting our 8th annual World Oceans Day event and is seeking an organized and motovated event planner to help really kick off a great ocean celebration in San Francisco on June 8. These education and outreach activities are directed at the public, educating and celebrating sharks and marine conservation and supporting the work of Shark Stewards. We are seeking an enthusiastic oceann lover to plan an ocean party and help us raise funds to continue our marine protection campaigns. Duties include determining venue (We used Pier 23 last year and can again), planning, helping with scheduling, commuicating to the public and volunteers, and organizing the event the day of. opportunities.description:
An Internship at Tandem provides an opportunity to gain a comprehensive understanding of the day-to-day and long-term workings of a non-profit organization. Interns work closely with their supervisor to create learning goals at the start of the internship that include a special project within their department.

The Communications Intern is an unpaid part-time position reporting to the Communications Manager. The CI may also work in coordination with the Executive Director and the Directors of Programs, Development, and Operations to support departmental priorities.

S/he is responsible for assisting the Communications Manager with written and electronic communications for program, development, and marketing purposes, including e-newsletters, web content, blog and social media content, press releases and media interviews, collateral materials, internal and external organizational templates, and print and digital program materials for a variety of intended audiences.

Please send cover letter and resume to jobs@tandembayarea.org

In subject line, please write: YourLastName_Communications Intern. No calls please!

opportunities.description:
"My volunteer is a very important part of my life and a tremendous help. It is hard to quantify how significant he is and I can't imagine what my life would be like without him." - Shanti client

For 42 years, Shanti peer support volunteers have been providing emotional and practical support to people living with life-threatening illness, as well as LGBT isolated seniors and adults with disabilities, much like you would support a friend or family member in need. If you would like to tangibly enhance the life of someone who needs it the most, we encourage you to contact us and learn more about this truly unique opportunity.

As a peer support volunteer, you will:

--Go through the internationally-recognized Shanti Model of Peer Support training

--Be matched 1-on-1 with a client to whom you will provide companionship, a non-judgmental ear and light practical assistance

--Join a community of thoughtful, supportive volunteers and staff

For this program, we ask for a commitment of 2 to 6 hours a week for at least 6 months. We also organize support groups once a month, and ask all volunteers to attend. The 2-6 hours can be done according to volunteer's schedules--a lot of our volunteers visit their clients on weekends or evenings--so it's definitely flexible.

If you decide to enroll in the Peer Support Program there is a mandatory volunteer training. Each interested volunteer must attend ALL of the training dates listed below.

The dates for the next trainings are as follows:

· Friday, March 24th from 6pm-9:30pm

· Saturday, March 25th from 9am-6pm

· Sunday, March 26th from 9am-6pm

· and Wed., March 29th from 6pm-9:30pm

The purpose of this training is to prepare volunteers to work with individuals who are isolated, or living with life-threatening illnesses and other disabilities. The training will supply information about challenges our clients face as well as teach communication and listening skills through a variety of interactive exercise. The training is pretty intensive, but our volunteers typically find it to be an enriching, community-building experience.

You can make an invaluable difference to someone who needs it the most - and have your life changed in the process.

Shanti was founded in 1974. Since its inception, Shanti has trained more than 18,000 individuals in the Bay Area and 600 organizations around the world in compassionately providing emotional and practical support to clients grappling with life-threatening illnesses, social isolation, other disabilities and poverty. Recognized as the first community-based AIDS Organization in the world, Shanti serves over 2,000 of San Francisco’s most vulnerable residents, annually.

To learn more about how to get involved, please contact Volunteer Services at 415-674-4726 or email volunteerservices@shanti.org

To view an inspirational video on the work of a Shanti volunteer, click on the link below:

http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=kAXf8_lRSts

opportunities.description:
As an AFS Host Familiy you share your home with a new family member. Participants are carefully matched, and volunteers are always on hand to make sure that you and your student have the support and tools needed for a positive experience.

As a leader in international high school exchange for more than 65 years, AFS differs from many other exchange organizations. Among the most important distinctions is that AFS has a network of thousands of volunteers in the US, many of whom have hosted themselves or studied abroad with AFS. These local volunteers support families, students, and schools in gaining the most from the hosting experience.

Hosting an international student means more than providing a bed and meals. As an AFS Host Family, you’ll welcome a new member into your home, share your everyday lives, and grow as you get to know one another. You’ll be surprised at how much you learn about yourself, your family and community by hosting a student from another culture. Have a life-changing experience in your own home.

More information: http://www.afsusa.org/host-family

AFS SF Bay Area International Students to host: http://www.afsusa.org/san-francisco-bay/Host-Exchange-Student-San-Francisco-Bay-Area/

opportunities.description:
McKinley Elementary needs your help to run our 10th annual DogFest, a community fundraiser, dog show, and family fun event. The event will include dog competitions throughout the day, family activities, local vendors, fantastic food, a dog rescue zone and a fabulous silent auction. The event requires more than a hundred volunteers to run smoothly so we are seeking outside volunteers to help our huge crew of parent volunteers. Every penny raised will go to support academic and enrichment programs for more than 390 children at our small public school in the center of San Francisco.

Volunteers will help with any of a variety of tasks including running carnival games and the bouncy house, helping sell lunch and bake sale items, selling sno cones, cotton candy and popcorn, helping at the dog rescue center, merchandise sales, face painting and button making. You can also help us get setup in the morning or break everything down after the event.

Volunteers are welcome for the whole day or a portion of the event. Shifts generally run from 11-1:30 and 1:30-4, with check-in 15 minutes prior to your shift. Setup is from 8-11 (or whenever you can get there), and cleanup from 4-6.

http://mckinleyschool.org/dogfest/

opportunities.description:
Status: Unpaid volunteer position
Times Available: Wednesday - Sunday, 9:30am to 4:30pm (shifts are either: 9:30-1:30, 11:00-3:00 or 1:30-4:30)

Position Description: The Education Volunteer is responsible for ensuring our exhibit spaces (Imagination Lab, Innovation Lab, Tech Lab, Animation Studio and Music Studio) run smoothly and create meaningful experiences with children and families.

Responsibilities:

  • Greet visitors to each space and explain how to get started.
  • Assist and facilitate activities in each of our spaces and check in with visitors for help and support.
  • Direct visitors to different spaces.
  • Reset and tidy up each space - pick up paper, keep supplies filled and reset stations.
  • Alert managers and staff to any immediate needs.
  • Learn the basics of stop motion animation, robot coding, music studio software, and the process of innovating.

Application Process: Fill out our volunteer application online at creativity.org/volunteer, and indicate which exhibit space you are most interested in! It could be more than one!
