opportunities.description:
On March 2nd 2017, Jumpstart will be hosting an event at the San Francisco Public Library in celebration of Read Across America Day. Read Across America Day is a national celebration of reading and learning held every year on Dr. Seuss's birthday. At our San Francisco celebration, program staff and volunteers will host readings of The Cat in the Hat by Dr. Seuss as well as many interactive learning stations for 100 local preschoolers.

This is a great way for individuals or groups to engage with the children and families of their communities in a fun way while also promoting early literacy and a love for reading!

We are seeking a volunteer to help in our offices. The tasks include filing; helping to sort confidential files and filling in where the social workers need help. Our social workers support over 2500 seniors with important home visits. Details of the positon are : copying compiling handbooks updating files (both by hand and electronically) assisting with other projects as needed Working as a social worker volunteer gives you the chance to provide valuable support for the services we provide to our SF community of seniors and adults with disabilities. SCHEDULE : Hours and days are flexible within the agency work hours, Monday - Friday,

opportunities.description:
What happens when social convening converges with artistic performance? You get a fabulously rich and transformative experience of people, culture, and place. At the Red Poppy Art House, we produce 140 such events annually, and we’re always looking for people to come out once or twice a month to assist. Volunteering even just once a month wins you free access to all the performances throughout the year.

Volunteer shifts include helping to set up the performance space, engaging with guests and community members, and then occupying one of two roles: handling admissions at the door (and welcoming guests as they arrive), or concessions at the counter. Each night requires two volunteers (sign up with a friend?) that join with two Poppy hosts that, together, serve to transform an ordinary evening into a spontaneous present-time exchange between artists and community/audience members. In the process, you might find your own social-cultural horizon expanding!

For more information on volunteering at the Poppy, visit http://redpoppyarthouse.org/participate/volunteer/ or contact volunteer@redpoppyarthouse.org. To sign-up directly for a volunteer shift, go to http://vols.pt/EVLK5G
opportunities.tags: culture, arts, performances, events, community engagement

opportunities.description:
Problem solving skills and collaboration are key elements of college readiness. You will work with high school students in small groups (4-7 students). These are students who have chosen to take an elective class that supports college readiness. The students are primarily in the "academic middle" with high potential, but some academic struggle. Many aspire to be the first in their family to attend college. Students bring questions they are confused about in other content classes to their tutorial group. The tutor facilitates the group of students in a Socratic Tutorial, where students learn by asking each other questions. Students learn not only the answer to the problem, but critical thinking and problem solving steps. Training is provided for you, the tutor, in this highly effective, research based method, which was developed by AVID (Advancement Via Individual Determination - see www.avid.org for more information). Have the satisfaction of helping an adolescent develop college and career readiness skills.

Upcoming training dates beginning in October and running through February. Begin working with students in Fall 2016 or Spring 2017. Make a difference in just 1-2 hours a week! All tutoring times are during the school day, between 8 AM and 4 PM.
opportunities.tags: college readiness, Tutor, AVID
opportunities.title: Tutor at Mission High School, 2016-2017 School Year

opportunities.description:
Teaching assistant volunteers will assist in teaching single or multi-session courses (MS Windows 7, MS Word, Excel, Web Intro, Gmail, File management, and Social Networking), ultimately helping students resolve technical related questions. As a candidate you must be willing to work with a variety of student abilities to meet everyone's needs. This position requires a strong background in computers and technology, with an understanding this is a free service offered to the residents of the Tenderloin.

Responsibilities:

  • Assist students in accessing and utilization of computer and various resources. (e.g. learning modules, internet research)
  • Assists in the preparation of lesson plans and teacher's prep-sessions.
  • Assists the teacher with room setup within the learning environment.
  • Protect confidentiality of personal/student information shared.
  • Periodic check-ins via phone, email, or in person with volunteer supervisor/point of contact.

Required Skills:

  • Educational/ Trainining experience with computer, internet and email.
  • Appropriate experience in chosen software and creativity in teaching methods.
  • Excellent interpersonal, written and verbal communication skills, inlcuding: conflict management, customer service and problem solving.
  • Ability to work with diverse and low-income populations.
  • Successful with minimal supervision in a fast-paced environment.
  • Polite, patient, tactful, with the ability to be firm with students.
  • Punctual, reliable, collaborative, and team-oriented 

opportunities.description:
Casting Call For Ushers!

Come join the Playhouse family! We're looking for volunteers to help us with our diverse, thought-provoking and dynamic performances year-round, and we'd love to have your talents. Volunteer ushers are a very important part of the San Francisco Playhouse family. It costs nothing but time to become a volunteer usher, and in exchange you get to see the show for free! There’s no better time to usher for our fresh and growing theatre company.
Please send an email to usher@sfplayhouse.orgfor more information. Questions may be sent to the same email address. More info about our seasonand our company at sfplayhouse.org.
ABOUT THE SF PLAYHOUSE:
The word "family" is central to what this new theatre means to us. All the actors, directors, designers, and technicians we have worked with over the years and want to work with again, and all the playgoers who have supported our work over the years are members of this family that make our theatre possible. And now, more than ever, our ushers will help ensure the success of our productions.

This is a multi faceted postion at our Information Desk and in high traffic corrirdors. Duties include welcoming and conversing with a wide-variety of people, finding solutions to problems, escorting people to their destination (if able) and most importantly, being a friendly, helpful smiling person who can ease others fears.

This volunteer position sets the tone for all those who enter the hospital and is a wonderful opportunity for people who are hospitable and enjoy being of service.

Positions available at the following CPMC campuses: Davies, Pacific, California, and St Luke's.

opportunities.description:
The Gift Shops provide a sanctuay for patients, their families and staff. Volunteers provide a listening ear and assist customers with their purchases. Proceeds are used to support various projects such as infant bed warmers, hand knit blankets for our pediatric patients, and to purchase updated equipment.

CPMC has a gift shop at each of our 4 campuses. Shifts are 3 to 4 hours. Training provided in customer service, how to operate the cash register and make change. Our cash registers are state of the art, Point-of-Sale.

opportunities.description:
Seeking Bilingual Interpreters/Outreach Support to assist with Computer Donation/Distribution Drive to reach Asian communities for them to receive information on how to apply for a free computer from RRRcomputer.org. You will be directly helping children from your communities to get their computers.

Must be fluent in English and one of the following languages:

  • Mandarin/Cantonese
  • Vietnamese
  • Korean
  • Japanese
  • Tagalog

Please reply with a short 2-3 sentence blurb about yourself and which language(s) you speak.


RRRcomputer.org's mission is to reclaim computer from recycling to reuse for education for low income K-6 kids. We reduce computer waste by refurbishing the computers to put back into circulation for the kids to use for internet search for research, and doing their homework assignment at home. The computers that are going to recycling is still useful for their needs. We do our part in saving the planet and improve the education of children.

opportunities.description:
Tenderloin Neighborhood Development Corporation (TNDC) provides affordable housing and services for low-income people in the Tenderloin and throughout San Francisco, to promote equitable access to opportunity and resources. Please check us out at www.tndc.org.

TNDC's Health and Wellness Program is searching for dedicated volunteers to help on a weekly basis at their Supportive Housing Pantry. In partnership with the SF-Marin Food Bank, TNDC is looking to make an impact in the Tenderloin neighborhood by offering access to free, nutritious food to those residents who live in supportive housing.

Volunteers are needed on Thursday mornings starting from 9:45am-12:30pm. Food from the SF-Marin Food Bank will be dropped off at our distribution center located at 476 Eddy St. The volunteers are needed to distribute food, assist with line management, and clean up. Along with the help of the volunteers, there are 4-5 staff members onsite to assit with the distribution.

Volunteers are encourage to commit to a time period of 3 months or longer to help build rapport with the staff and the residents of the Tenderloin.

If you are interested in volunteering with TNDC and their Supportive Housing Pantry, please contact Alyssa Santos at asantos@tndc.org or via phone at (415)358-3987.

**Tentative start date for first pantry distribution is October 13th.**

opportunities.description:
What is Sit, Stay, Love?

This program is designed for K-2 nd Grade and is open to all San Francisco Schools. Our mission for this program is to instill kindness and compassion to all living things through the miracle of reading. The books we are using have been carefully chosen based on their humane-theme towards animals.

Sit, Stay, Love is based around 5 visits (each 30 minutes long) with each class that signs up for the program. Each volunteer will book 5 visits with each class on a weekly or bi-weekly basis.

Who are we looking for?

Individuals who are:

  • Passionate about children, animals, and education
  • Driven, independent, and are comfortable setting their own schedule directly with teachers
  • Able to get to school sites on their own
  • 18 years and older
  • Must have access to a computer and email

What are the requirements?

  • Must be willing to get finger-printed at your own cost.
  • Must attend our Sit, Stay, Love training - Email us for current training date!
  • Must be willing to have 2 school visits per month.
  • Must be willing to volunteer for a minimum of 3 months.
  • Must have access to email in order to self-schedule with San Francisco teachers.

What does the SFSPCA provide?

  • All 5 books used in the program
  • Sit, Stay, Love Volunteer T-shirt
  • Sit, Stay, Love Training (this training is part of a nation-wide reading-program called Red Rover Readers. For more information on Red Rover Readers you can look here: https://redrover.org/program/redrover-readers)
  • When teachers are interested in a Sit, Stay, Love program, we will forward their contact information to you in order for you to set up a schedule with them directly
  • Staff support if you have any questions, concerns, or issues with any teachers or classrooms
opportunities.tags: Humane, reading, children, education, literacy, teaching, youth, animal shelters, animals

opportunities.description:
Workers’ Advocate

Volunteer Opportunity Announcement

SF Day Labor Program and Women’s Collective


The San Francisco Day Labor Program and Women’s Collective (DLP/WC) is a grassroots-organized program deeply rooted in the community with strong support of key stakeholders. For over 20 years, the DLP/WC has been extremely successful at uniting, empowering, and organizing immigrant workers for dignified work and fair wages in San Francisco. Workers are organized in two collectives, one of men and one of women, to build collective power, develop skills, and operate a business.

Members of the collectives work together to eradicate the injustices that affect day laborers and domestic workers, fostering an organized environment where all workers can build their dignity, power and leadership. Members share a vision of a community where day laborers and domestic workers have the same opportunities and rights than any other worker. They accomplish this by offering each other opportunities to learn, work and participate in the movement of immigrant and domestic workers. The collectives are co-founders and leaders in the National Day Labor Organizing Network, National Domestic Workers Alliance, Progressive Workers Alliance, California Domestic Workers Coalition, Jobs with Justice, San Francisco Rising, among others.

In 2015, the DLP/WC started an exciting reorganization process with the objective of establishing a more sustainable and scalable model that enhances the impact of the program in the lives of immigrant workers.

The DLP/WC is looking for a worker advocate that can support the operations of the worker center. The ideal candidate is a passionate individual with advanced skills in negotiation and advocacy.

Candidates must be available for 2 hours in person and 8 remotely each week.

Position Objective: This position negotiates and advocates for workers’ fair wages.

This position is part of a volunteer team that supports the operations of the worker center. It is directed to transforming the lives of low-wage immigrant workers at a personal level, in order to develop leaders who can promote the dignity of their work and transform the industries in which they work. This position has the following responsibilities.


Responsibilities:

  • Receive and review wage-theft claims made by workers in a timely manner

  • Interview affected worker(s) to better understand the details of the claim

  • Contact employers involved in the claim to better understand their perspective on the matter

  • Act as a fair negotiator between employer and worker, advocating for fair wages

  • Document the case progress as conversations move forward

  • Follow up with employer and worker with negotiation outcomes so they take appropriate actions

  • Confirm with worker that both worker and employer have taken agreed actions

  • Make appropriate internal and external case referrals if/when needed

  • Document case outcome in a timely manner

  • Report cases statuses weekly at member meetings


Expected Commitment:

  • 2 hours per week in-person to report case status

  • 8 hours per week remotely to process claims


Desired Skills:

  • Highly developed communication and negotiation skills

  • Bilingual in Spanish and English

  • Commitment to social justice, specifically worker and immigrant rights

  • Compassionate and caring approach to supporting immigrant workers

  • High level of professionalism

  • Extremely organized and highly motivate
opportunities.tags: Advocate, Worker Advocate, fair-wages, immigration, labor laws, wage-theft claim
opportunities.title: Worker's Advocate for the Day Labor Program & Women's Collective

opportunities.description:
Become an involved citizen and meet interesting people! This is your opportunity to help make government more efficient and effective. The duty of the Civil Grand Jury is to investigate the operations of the City & County's officers, departments, and agencies.

Each Grand Jury chooses its own methodology as well as the areas that they investigate. During investigations, jurors may inspect and audit books, records and financial expenditures; interview civil servants and others who have pertinent information; inspect government facilities, and issue reports with findings and recommendations.

After the report has been review by the Presiding Judge of the Superior Court, the reports are sent to the affected department heads that are then required by law to respond.

Civil Grand Jury members must be able to serve for a 1 year term, from July through June. Work is done both during and after regular business hours. Members will receive a $15 per diem for each meeting attended during the term.

Interested volunteers must apply. Applications may be downloaded from http://civilgrandjury.sfgov.org/join.html

APPLICATION DEADLINE: MAY 31, 2017
opportunities.title: Be a Government "Watchdog" -- Serve as a member of the Civil Grand Jury

opportunities.description:
Are you interested in orienting visitors from all over the world as they visit this iconic landmark? Would you enjoy engaging diverse audiences as you help them to connect with the story of the Golden Gate Bridge and the surrounding Golden Gate National Recreation Area (GGNRA) lands? Are you passionate about public speaking, customer service, and creating future stewards for all of the GGNRA? If so, this volunteer opportunity is for you!

Join our dynamic team and help us build a strong community of local and international visitors who connect to the various GGNRA sites through programming to gain a deeper understanding of the Golden Gate Bridge’s role in American history and their own lives. Volunteers will provide efficient, courteous services and helpful information to park visitors. This involves ensuring visitor safety, and enhancing public speaking skills. The Volunteer’s primary responsibilities will be to provide orientation and information to visitors as they arrive at the site, rove the site, and give visitors information about other parklands.

opportunities.description:
Warm-up your spirit fingers, lace up your sneakers and inspire a group of girls to be strong and healthy. We are looking for enthusiastic people who want to be positive role models and are committed to developing and celebrating youth.

Position Summary: Coaches are volunteers who work in teams of three to facilitate the Girls on the Run curriculum to program participants (girls in 3rd, 4th, and 5th grade). Coaches co-lead practice for their team of 12-16 girls twice a week for 10 weeks, with each session lasting 75 minutes. You should anticipate a time commitment of 5 hours per week, with additional time required for coach training and the culminating Girls on the Run 5K.

Core Duties and Responsibilities:

  • Attend a full 1-day coach training before the start of program (Saturday January 21st in Berkeley, Saturday February 4th in San Francisco, OR Sunday February 5th in San Francisco) and a weekday evening mid-season meeting
  • Make time with your co-coaches to prepare ahead for each lesson in our curriculum
  • Model effective communication, problem-solving, and conflict negotiation skills
  • Facilitate each of the 20 lessons in an engaging and nurturing manner
  • Interact with parents as needed
  • Coordinate a group community service project
  • Attend the end-of-season Girls on the Run 5K with your team (Sunday May 7th, 2017)
  • Inspire and motivate others to believe in the Girls on the Run mission


Qualifications:

  • Awareness of the developmental and social needs of girls
  • Experience working directly with youth (preferred, not mandatory)
  • Does not have to identify as a runner, though you must be willing to jump in and train for the 5k alongside the girls!
  • Men and women encouraged to apply
How to Apply: To learn more and apply to be a coach, please fill out an application today at http://www.gotrbayarea.org/get-involved/coach

opportunities.description:
UniversalGiving(r) is an award-winning website allowing people to donate and volunteer with top performing vetted projects all over the world. Unique to UniversalGiving, 100% goes directly to the cause. UniversalGiving Corporate provides Strategy, Operations, and NGO Vetting to scale companies’ CSR programs in more than 120 countries; our Corporate Services allow us to become self-sustaining. UniversalGiving has been featured on the homepage of BusinessWeek, Oprah.com, CBS, The Wall Street Journal, and The New York Times.

The Marketing Returnee will work closely with our CEO to develop future and manage existing high-level strategic partnerships, lead the marketing team, and develop a marketing strategy that differentiates us locally and globally. Our ideal candidate has significant experience in strategic marketing and business development. He/She is ready to give back to a smart, efficient, and globally impactful nonprofit. Excellent writing skills and attention to detail are required.

UniversalGiving’s Returnship Program offer exciting opportunities to those wishing to make a significant impact and contribution to our global communities. Returnships are for experienced professionals returning to the workforce who desire to gain new skills, change professions, or simply yearning to give back.


Responsibilities:

  • Collaborate with the CEO to identify, achieve, and manage marketing partnerships

  • Lead the marketing team to attain qualitative and quantitative marketing goals and metrics

  • Develop and implement strategic priorities for the marketing team for long-term growth of the organization

  • Review the current Marketing Plan and implement other strategies as needed

  • Increase brand awareness globally

  • Coordinate brand both offline, online, and on the UniversalGiving website

  • Update and utilize Salesforce for CRM

  • With proven success and positive attitude, work on significant partnerships with CEO, and play a major leadership role

Qualifications:

  • Bachelor’s degree

  • Minimum of 5 years of professional experience in marketing or communications field

  • Strong command of marketing principles and ability to implement them creatively

  • Proven experience with digital marketing including social media

  • Excellent verbal and communication skills

  • Strong leadership capabilities

  • Ability to motivate a team and communicate objectives clearly

  • Critical attention to detail and commitment to excellence

  • Proficiency in Microsoft Office programs (Word, Excel, Powerpoint) and Google applications (some training provided)

  • Prior experience with Salesforce is a plus

Benefits:

  • Contribute your high-level skills to UniversalGiving’s mission

  • Gain experience at a unique social entrepreneurship nonprofit that has a global impact

  • Gain exposure, and experience in the nonprofit industry

  • Increase your understanding of global issues

  • Work directly with our CEO, Pamela Hawley

  • Collaborate with a positive and innovative team

  • Network with other for-profit and nonprofit professionals in an open office environment


Duration: Minimum of 15-20 hours per week for a minimum of 3 months. Ideal candidates are available to work in our San Francisco office 2-3 days/week (Monday through Friday) with the possibility of some work completed remotely. As this is a leadership position, the majority of work should be done in-office.

We value our interns and volunteers and take these positions very seriously. For this reason, we ask for a $200 fully refundable retainer to secure your position. This check pays for the your seat in our coworking space, professional training and management guidance that you will receive. Because our interns are such an integral part of UniversalGiving, we implemented this policy several years ago to ensure the accountability of all team members. We return your full deposit on the last day of your internship. Please do not hesitate to contact us with further questions


About UniversalGiving

UniversalGiving(r)is an award-winning website allowing people to donate and volunteer with top performing projects all over the world. Our projects are vetted through a proprietary Quality Model(tm)

to ensure the most effective, trustworthy philanthropy possible. Unique to UniversalGiving, we take no cut on donations. 100% of your donation goes directly to the cause.

UniversalGiving Corporate consults with Fortune 500 companies on the Strategy, Operations and NGO Vetting for their international giving and volunteering programs all over the world. Some clients include Cisco, Symantec, Fluor, Sabre, Gap, BHP Billiton, RSF Social Finance, and inovia.

Located in the heart of San Francisco, UniversalGiving has been profiled on CBS and in FOX BusinessNetwork, and has also been featured inBusinessWeek, Fast Company, CSRWire, WomenEntrepreneur, Oprah.com, NBC News, The Christian Science Monitor, The New York Times, The Financial Times, MarketWatch, CNNMoney.com, Change.org and See Change Magazine. UniversalGiving has been featured three times on Great Nonprofits’ annual Top Nonprofits lists and is a Webby Award Honoree.

CEO Pamela Hawley is a winner of the Jefferson Award (the Nobel Prize in Community Service) and was selected as one of 50 leaders to the White House's Next Generation Leadership and Social Innovation event. She is a Finalist for Ernst & Young’s Entrepreneur of the Year Award, and a Colburn S. Wilbur Leadership Fellow at the Global Ethics Institute. She is a Fast Company Expert Blogger on CSR.

UniversalGiving’s Mission: To connect people to quality giving and volunteer opportunities worldwide.

UniversalGiving’s Vision: "To Create A World Where Giving and Volunteering Are A Natural Part of Everyday Life"(r)


Testimonial

"I came to UniversalGiving at a time when I was looking for a way to have more meaning with my work. After years in management consulting, finance, and then home raising two young children, I was ready to give back to the world in a different way. I began as a volunteer in their Returnship program and four years later, am leading Operations. UniversalGiving is a professional environment that has given me meaning, experience in new realms, and flexibility in my work schedule. I am so proud to be a part of this amazing team that is doing great things in the world."

Adriana Rabkin, Former Senior Manager of Operations


To Apply:

Please email your resume, cover letter, a brief writing sample, and three professional references to volunteers@universalgiving.org with "Marketing Returnship" in the subject line. Applications are reviewed on a rolling basis. No phone calls please.

UniversalGiving(r) is committed to understanding and representing the diverse populations it serves worldwide. Members of all ages, genders, sexual orientations, races, ethnicities, nationalities, physical abilities or disabilities, religions or beliefs, and cultures are welcome as employees and volunteers in our organization. We believe that a diverse team will best serve our diverse populations.


Follow us on social media:
  • UniversalGiving’s website
  • Like us on Facebook
  • Follow Us on Twitter: @ UniversalGiving and @ PamelaHawley
  • Follow Us on Pinterest: @ UniversalGiving
  • CEO Pamela Hawley’s Blog: Living and Giving

opportunities.description:
Hi There,

We are a small, dynamic team.

We are a French cultural center, we offer a lot of fun events:

- Every tuesday : movie night (7:00-9:00pm, volunteers 6:30-7:30pm)

- Every Thursday : Apero conversation French happy hour (6:00 to 8:00pm)

One big event each month (sometimes more), we always need volunteers to welcome everyone, check or sell the tickets, count the people attending, do the service, prepare the food...

Upcoming events :

- October 21 th :French Vocal group at 6pm.

- November 4th ; the huge success movie "demain" is coming for an event starting at 6:00pm

- December 3 rd our fundraiser gala. We need a lot of cvolunteers for this event to make it a memorable event. Service, Welcoming, Helping for the decorations, in the kitchen, at the front desk, singer, artist, photographer ... If you have free days november 21-23 and/or november 28-december 3, We need you!

Speaking french or learning French is a plus but not mandatory, if you are interested in French culture!

We hope to see you soon!

We are flexibles, you don't have to be available for every event.

Our volunteers are really great! You will definitely have new friends.

The AFSF team

opportunities.description:
Go! Team Members support Boys Hope Girls Hope's efforts to reach young people, ages 10-18 who have barriers to school success and college matriculation. Barriers can include poverty and precipitating conditions such as absence of parents due to death, incarceration or abandonment, abuse or neglect, neighborhood violence, substance abuse in the home, homelessness, domestic violence and other risk factors for dropping out as defined by the National Center for Dropout Prevention.
AmeriCorps members' efforts will ensure that volunteers and the community are engaged in the important work of moving children in their communities from poverty to self-sufficiency. Working in coordination with other Go! Team members and BHGH staff, the Go! Team Member will work in a team at an assigned project site, and focus their efforts on ensuring BHGH Scholars are accruing the skills, confidence and aspirations necessary to achieve college enrollment. Activities will focus on academic preparation, college counseling, co-curricular learning and the development of ongoing opportunities for scholars to better understand cultural diversity through service-learning projects. Additional resources will include boosting parental involvement in scholar activities, and educating and encouraging community collaboration.

An Academic Coach supports our scholars through tutoring, coaching, and providing supplemental instruction in the areas of literacy, mathematics and science. Members assigned to this role can also train and support volunteer tutors and coordinate tutor activities with the classroom and school-designed interventions.
Activities can include:
* Establishing relationships with classroom educators in order to coordinate efforts and monitor scholar progress
* Encouraging out-of-school reading
* Administering and designing interventive responses to literacy-related assessments such as MAZE and CRI, or math related assessments such as STAR
* Designing interventions to address needs identified in the LASSI scales
* Leading Teen Read Week
* Connecting the program to literacy or science resources in the community such as young adult librarians, local authors and scientist
* Engaging scholars and community in literacy or STEM related enrichment
* Providing leadership and structure for activities including book clubs and reading (or STEM) activities in the program

For more details please contact our executive director, Suzanne Palmer, at spalmer@bhgh.org or at (415) 657-9302.

opportunities.description:
Kids’ Turn is a workshop series for families navigating separation and divorce offered in 5 counties throughout the Bay Area (cities include: San Mateo, Pleasanton, San Rafael, San Francisco, Oakland). Kids’ Turn volunteers help workshop facilitators keep youth participants engaged by distributing learning materials, reinforcing instructions, and answering questions. Volunteers commit to the full life-cycle of a single workshop series - one 2.5-hour session per week for one month (typically 4 Saturday mornings). All volunteers must be at least 16 years of age to participate and complete a Background Check. Workshops run in two semesters: January - May and August - December.

As of 2/13/2017, upcoming workshop dates are as follows:

Pleasanton
Feb. 25 - Mar. 18
Saturdays, 10am - 12pm

San Mateo
Mar. 4 - 25
Saturdays, 2:30pm - 4:30pm

San Rafael
Apr. 22 - May 13
Saturdays, 10am - 12pm

San Francisco
April 29 - May 20
Saturdays, 10am - 12pm

Oakland
May 1 - 22
Mondays, 6pm - 8pm

Please inquire here on VolunteerMatch and expect follow-up from a the Kids' Turn Volunteer Coordinator.

opportunities.description:
Community volunteers needed to present to 6th, 7th & 8th grade students during Junior Achievement's Career Day at Rooftop Middle. Minimum volunteer commitment is making one, 30-minute presentation to a class of up to 35 students.

Class periods range throughout the day between 8am-12:30pm.

A one hour training is provided by JA staff prior to your first classroom visit. All needed materials, including a detailed lesson plan, will be provided at the time of training. We ask that volunteers speak to students about own career journey and the education, skills, and resources needed to achieve success in that field.

No teaching background required! College students to retirees are welcome, as well as groups of volunteers.

We are looking to fill immediately for this exciting, one-day opportunity.

Please contact Lucy Rushanova, District Manager, at lrushanova@janorcal.org or (415) 966-8800. For more information about Junior Achievement of Northern California and our programs, please visit us at: https://www.juniorachievement.org/web/ja-norcal/japrograms

Please contact Lucy Rushanova, District Manager, at lrushanova@janorcal.org or (415) 966-8800. For more information about Junior Achievement of Northern California and our programs, please visit us at: https://www.juniorachievement.org/web/ja-norcal/japrograms

opportunities.description:
We are seeking well qualified candidates to join our Board of Directors.

Board Member - Roles

To serve as an ambassador in the communtiy supporting IOFF's history, mission, goals, ocean awareness efforts, and creating a sustainable future for the film festival.

The role of a Board of Director is to promote and endorse the IOFF efforts throughout the communities it serves. All Directors are selected to help support the mission and produce a world-class, effective and memorable film festival. To achieve this, Board members are expected to volunteer their time, skills, and knowledge to promote the festival to their personal and professional networks in an effort to increase awareness about the mission of the festival and its films.

We are specifically looking for candidates with at least 3-5 years of board member experience, ideally in the following skills categories: Public Relations, Fundraising, Education Outreach and Marine Sciences Expertise.

When responding, please include a resume and a brief description of your experience and interest in our mission.

opportunities.description:
Position description: Docents lead small groups of visitors and school groups on an educational walking tour through San Francisco’s Chinatown to promote a better understanding of the history of Chinatown, the Chinese American community, and the role of the Chinese Culture Center in Chinatown. Docents are often the first and lasting impression of an entire community; as such, docents will be required to attend extensive training, be available for tour preparation, and be open to learning that will rework the meaning of a "tour experience." Knowledge about Chinatown history is not required, but a plus.

The Chinese Culture Foundation is also developing more tours (Chinatown art, food, etc.) and is looking for people interested in helping with research and development.


Duties/Tasks/Responsibilities:

  • Attend Informational Session & docent training (6-10 hours)

  • Willingness to be part of an art, historical, and cultural learning community

  • Learn components of tour route(s) and key aspects of Chinatown

  • Lead a group of 15-20 people (often school-age children) on walking tour minding for safety and enjoyment of participants

  • Disseminate historic components of Chinatown and cultural aspects of Chinese in America

  • Responsible for mindfully serving as a community representative for the Chinese Culture Center, and the Chinatown community within a historically accurate socio-political context.


Qualifications:

  • Willingness to learn, create dialogue, share different perspectives, and stimulate discussion with the public about Chinatown and Chinese America

  • Willingness to convey nuances and challenge preconceptions about Chinatown/Chinese Americans as a community

  • Connection to the SF Chinatown community or a willingness to become invested in the community and share that connection with others in a meaningful way

  • Excellent communication, public speaking, and presentation skills. Ability to tell a story a plus

  • Flexible and able to problem-solve in situational circumstances. Responsible, dependable, and punctual

  • Ability to comfortably walk the hills of Chinatown

  • Enjoys interacting and engaging with the public especially school children. Friendly and outgoing personality a plus

  • Bilingual Chinese is a plus. Previous docent or tour guide experience a plus.


Benefits

  • Excellent training and community involvement

  • Meet like-minded people interested in sharing and learning about history, culture, and heritage

  • Opportunity to explore culture and see Chinatown through a new lens

  • Opportunity to create a relationship with Chinatown and redefine boundaries in a meaningful way

  • Flexible schedule


Please send your resume and letter of interest to: tour@c-c-c.org
opportunities.tags: tour, education, guide, docent, Chinatown

opportunities.description:
Work one-on-one with one of our Parent Leaders as they build technology skills that will benefit their work and families. Mission Graduates is recruiting our next cohort of Latina Tech Mentors.

As a mentor, you will

  • meet twice a month (commitment 2 hours/month) with your mentee
  • develop a personalized work plan
  • begin to tackle areas parents feel will support their outreach work for Mission Graduates
  • help navigate online academic resources that will support their own child's academic success

We will provide curriculum, resources, and ongoing training and support you throughout the 6 month commitment.

If you are a Spanish-speaking woman, available to meet in the Mission District Monday-Friday between 9am-5pm, please respond to this posting or email Jenna Casey, Community Engagement Manager, at jenna@missiongraduates.or.

--

Mission Graduates is a nonprofit organization that increases the number of K-12 students in San Francisco’s Mission District who are prepared for and complete a college education. Our Parent Partner Program builds parent participation and bridges relationships at our partner school sites throughout the Mission neighborhood.

opportunities.description:
The TechLab Guest Associate volunteer works to identify and address the educational needs and goals of our guests. This position involves direct customer service inlcuding: setting a welcoming and respectful tone, ensuring a positive tech lab experience, following guidelines, and adhering to policies to help create an optimal learning environment.

The ideal volunteer candidate is very comfortable meeting and interacting with people from diverse backgrounds experiencing: homelessness, trauma, substance use/abuse/recovery, mental and physical health challenges, learning disabilities, and other challenges that can cause barriers with computers and technology.

Want to learn a lot about yourself and others? Consider applying to join our team as a volunteer!

Preferred Requirements:

  • Excellent interpersonal, written and verbal communication skills and experience, including problem resolution, conflict management and customer service.
  • Strong computer skills - Word, Excel, Outlook, data entry, data search, internet research.
  • Ability to function with grace and humor in a demanding environment.
  • Ability to be polite, tactful, and firm with clients the program serves, including the ability to maintain professional boundaries at all times.
  • Punctual, reliable, collaborative, and team-oriented.

opportunities.description:
Lands End, San Francisco

Observe the birds of Lands End in San Francisco, while you work to improve their habitat. The East Wash, a site within the interior of Lands End, is known for its high avian diversity, including resident species such as White-crowned Sparrow and migrants such as Townsend's Warbler. Golden Gate Audubon and the Golden Gate National Parks Conservancy are partnering to hold this restoration workday.

Next Volunteer Event:

Saturday, April 8, 2017 from 1-4pm

Directions: Participants should meet at the Merrie Way parking lot.

Please wear comfortable clothing and sturdy shoes. Tools, water, and snacks will be provided.

opportunities.description:
COOKS NEEDED FOR FAMILY WORKSHOP
February 22 - April 26
3pm - 4:30pm

SFCAPC is hosting a 10-week workshop for parents and kids called "Superheroes" and we need volunteers to prepare meals for the participants. Superheroes teaches parents and kids to hone their social and emotional superpowers - positive self-esteem, communication skills, resiliency and more - through fun superhero-themed activities. Dinner is served before the start of each workshop session. Volunteers are needed to:

  • Plan a menu
  • Purchase dinner supplies
  • Prepare the meal (catered meals are okay)
  • Set up the meal buffet-style for families to serve themselves
  • Clean up meal prep area and supplies

Quick Tips

  • Prepare for 20 guests (about 10 kids, 10 adults)
  • Include a vegetarian option
  • Ensure dinner is prepared and set up by 4:15 sharp
  • If you wish to be reimbursed, keep your receipt. SFCAPC will mail a reimbursement check of up to $90.
  • Dinner can be prepared in our kitchen or at an off-site kitchen of your choice. Catered meals are fine too!

Volunteer dates are available February 22; March 1, 8, 15, 22, 29; and April 5, 12, 19, 26

If interested, please email volunteer@sfcapc.org and specify which dates you'd like to prepare a meal. Thanks for your interest in volunteering with SFCAPC!

opportunities.description:
We rely on our volunteers to help distribute food out to those who need it most in our community. Types of volunteer projects at the SF-Marin Food Bank include helping to sort and package the food we distribute to food pantries, children's snack programs and soup kitchens throughout San Francisco and Marin. Projects typically involve gleaning fresh produce, repackaging bulk food into family-sized quantities, assembling grocery boxes for seniors, and sorting donations from food drives and grocery stores. In a single shift, you will be helping thousands of people get the food they need. At the end of a shift your Project Leader will announce specific stats for the poundage your shift helped to move.

Schedule a visit online today!
SF Warehouse https://volunteer.sfmfoodbank.org/welcome
Marin Warehouse https://volunteermarin.sfmfoodbank.org/


We have shifts 7 days a week.

  • Sunday to Saturday: 9:00 am - 12:00 pm and 12:30 pm - 3:30 pm
  • Additional shifts:
    Tuesdays & Wednesdays 6:00 pm - 8:00 pm
    Thursday evenings 4:00 pm - 6:00 pm
  • Children are welcome to volunteer, too! Our minimum age limit is 8 years old during Saturday projects, and 4 years old during Sunday projects. Each elementary-aged child must be accompanied by an adult. (Middle School and High School students are welcome to participate in all project shifts.)

opportunities.description:
Brand Strategists - Lend Your Expertise Pro Bono to a Great Nonprofit

On a Taproot Foundation pro bono project, the Brand Strategist is the most experienced branding professional on his or her team and serves as a strategic expert to the nonprofit’s executive staff and board members. You’ll work as a content leader for a key messages, visual identity, or naming project for a nonprofit that needs a branding refresh.

A successful Brand Strategist:

  • Has 5 years of experience at a marketing or creative agency
  • Has extensive experience in developing messaging concepts
  • Has Brand Manager, Branding Consultant or Senior Manager-level experience
  • Lives in the Chicago, NY, DC, Los Angeles, or San Francisco area.

A Service Grant project requires a 3-5 hour commitment each week over the course of approximately 6 months. This opportunity is flexible enough to work around the schedule of a full-time job.

Taproot Foundation makes it easy to make a difference. We’re a nonprofit organization that makes business talent available to organizations that are working to improve society. Our goal is to ensure that one day all organizations with promising solutions will be equipped to successfully take on urgent social challenges. To date, we have engaged close to 7,700 professionals on close to 2,300 pro bono projects benefiting education, health, environment, social service, and arts initiatives.

Now it’s your turn to join the movement and Make It Matter.

opportunities.description:
Every day almost 180 elders are served breakfast and lunch in Curry Senior Center's Dining Room. Lunch is not just for food, but for socializing and simply getting out of the small rooms or apartments San Francisco's seniors call home.

Volunteers are needed each day to help serve the meals and interact with seniors. Volunteers are needed to assist them in serving meals, organizing bingo games and socializing with clients.1-5 volunteers are needed daily from 6:30 a.m. until 9:30 a.m. and Friday-Sunday 10:00 a.m. until 1:15 p.m.

We need volunteers daily, so this is an ongoing listing. Pick the date and we'll let you know if there are volunteer opportunities available!

This is a great opportunity for groups and corporate volunteers!!

opportunities.title: Serve Breakfast or Lunch to seniors!
opportunities.plaintextDescription: Every day almost 180 elders are served breakfast and lunch in Curry Senior Center's Dining Room. Lunch is not just for food, but for socializing and simply getting out of the small rooms or apartments San Francisco's seniors call home. Volunteers are needed each day to help serve the meals and interact with seniors. Volunteers are needed to assist them in serving meals, organizing bingo games and socializing with clients.1-5 volunteers are needed daily from 6:30 a.m. until 9:30 a.m. and Friday-Sunday 10:00 a.m. until 1:15 p.m. We need volunteers daily, so this is an ongoing listing. Pick the date and we'll let you know if there are volunteer opportunities available! This is a great opportunity for groups and corporate volunteers!!

opportunities.description:
Join Shark Stewards in our support for our National Marine Heritage Area at Aquatic Park.

We are conducting ongoing marine debris surveys as part of an ongoing beach clean up and cigarette butt assessment.

We meet every other Saturday at 0900 by the west end of the San Francisco Dolphin Club- our sister organization sipporting the abatement of trash going into the San Frncisco Bay.

Join us on Facebook at https://www.facebook.com/AquaticParkStewards/

We are partnering with the National Parks Service during the Centennial celebration to keep the beach and Bay clean as part of a No Butts in the Bay program.

All materials provided. Join us, pitch in or donate to support Shark Stewards Healthy Bay initiatives and shark research and conservation.

Learn more at Sharkstewards.org
opportunities.tags: san francisco, clean up, butts, beach, sharks, Aquatic Park, Dolphin Club, National Parks Service Centennial

opportunities.description:
Internship Description:

The rural communities served by the vast and varied services ofAlternativa,have several opportunities for an Agriculture and Sustainable Farming Intern to complete project work towards improving the quality of life of families, individuals, and livestock.

Alternativa’s vision is to be a real alternative: promoting small business competitiveness, creating a financial resource base by providing loans and organizing communal banks and cooperatives, leading financial training workshops, and conducting outreach to the most vulnerable sectors of the population. Alternativa currently serves 1,200 clients through loans and other services. About 75 percent of Alternativa’s clients are women and the organization reflects a strong commitment to women’s rights and sustainable economic development.

This volunteer intern will work on the following objectives and/or activities:

  • Many rural constituents who may own a small piece of land are not necessarily using their land for food and/or income production purposes. These communities would benefit greatly from programs/workshops/campaigns teaching successful and sustainable farming methods, crop selection and rotation strategies, etc.
  • Developing appropriate technological solutions for crop management and sustainable farming
  • Workshops focusing on proper care and utilization of livestock in sustainable farming method

Qualifications:

  • Students studying environmental or natural sciences, engineering, agriculture
  • Motivated to work in rural areas and among underserved populations
  • Self-motivated, able to work independently and with little material resources
  • Culturally respectful, wants to learn more than teach
  • Curious, innovative, and quick learners
  • Resilient, open-minded, and hard-working
  • Creative and positive problem-solver, adaptable to challenging environments
  • Genuinely interested in community development and integrating into the community
  • Conversational Spanish for placements in Latin America

Schedule:

Interns will receive in-country orientation upon arrival facilitated by the FSD site team, which includes training in sustainable development principles, health and safety, cultural integration, and project management. After orientation, interns live with host-families and work full-time at the organization Monday-Friday. In the first week at the organization, the intern will gain an understanding of ongoing initiatives and conduct field visits to learn about the communities they serve. The supervisor and intern will collaborate to develop a workplan and budget that focuses on a specific youth/environmental project that addresses the long-term needs of the community. FSD will facilitate reflections and a midterm retreat, as well as provide project planning support and collect deliverables.

Internship program includes airport pick up, accommodation and meals, supervision, pre-departure training, on-site orientation and in-country support, medical/evacuation insurance, and project seed fund.
opportunities.tags: International Internship, Nicaragua, farming, agriculture
opportunities.title: Agriculture and Sustainable Farming Engineering Intern in Nicaragua

opportunities.description:
What: Sunday Streets Mission!

All volunteers will receive a free lunch and a Sunday Streets Volunteer T-shirt.

Sunday Streets creates 8 events annually that transform car-congested San Francisco streets into vibrant community spaces for all to enjoy. Bringing together neighborhood groups, local merchants, and nonprofits, Sunday Streets helps tens of thousands of San Francisco residents reimagine their streets as public spaces during a 5-hour car-free extravaganza. Sunday Streets encourages residents and visitors to go outside and get physical while celebrating their local communities.

All programs and activities are FREE and open to the public.

Shifts offered:

  • Setup Crew
  • Intersection Monitor
  • Mystery Shift
  • Breakdown Crew

Shifts are 2.5 hours long. Volunteers are in charge of the operations and logistics to make the event run smoothly. Volunteers under 18-years-old must have a parent or guardian sign a waiver and an adult must accompany those under 16-years.

Where: Valencia Street between Duboce and 26th Street

When: Sunday, March 12th from 11am - 4pm; Volunteer shifts start as early as 9:30am and end at 4:30pm.

How to sign up: To sign up either respond to VolunteerMatch or go to http://sundaystreetssf.com/get-involved/volunteers/

Volunteers are the heart and soul of Sunday Streets. You keep Sunday Streets running and make each event safe and fun for thousands of San Franciscans! We couldn't do it without you!

For questions or more information, contact volunteer@livablecity.org

opportunities.description:
Account Directors - Lead with your Marketing Skills Pro Bono

Taproot Account Directors lead teams of 5-6 pro bono consultants who work on highly structured pro bono projects for a nonprofit. On a project, the Account Director staffs the team, manages relationships, and keeps a bird’s-eye view of the project. The Account Director also works with a Taproot Program Manager to track progress, resolve challenges, and ensure the successful completion of each project.

A successful pro bono Account Director:

  • Has 10 years experience in Marketing/Branding/Print
  • Has managed leadership teams
  • Can negotiate executive or board-level relationships
  • Has Director, VP, or partner-level experience

A Service Grant project requires a 3-5 hour commitment each week over the course of approximately 6 months. This opportunity is flexible enough to work around the schedule of a full-time job.

Taproot Foundation makes it easy to make a difference. We’re a nonprofit organization that makes business talent available to organizations that are working to improve society. Our goal is to ensure that one day all organizations with promising solutions will be equipped to successfully take on urgent social challenges. To date, we have engaged close to 7,700 professionals on close to 2,300 pro bono projects benefiting education, health, environment, social service, and arts initiatives.

Now it’s your turn to join the movement and Make It Matter.

opportunities.description:
You will work with middle school students in small groups (4-7 students). These are students who have chosen to take an elective class that supports college readiness. The students are primarily in the "academic middle" with high potential, but some academic struggle. Many aspire to be the first in their family to attend college. Students bring questions they are confused about in other content classes to their tutorial group. The tutor facilitates the group of students in a Socratic Tutorial, where students learn by asking each other questions. Students learn not only the answer to the problem, but critical thinking and problem solving steps. Training is provided for you, the tutor, in this highly effective, research based method, which was developed by AVID (Advancement Via Individual Determination - see www.avid.org for more information). Have the satisfaction of helping an adolescent develop college and career readiness skills.

Upcoming training dates beginning in October and running through February. Begin working with students in Fall 2016 or Spring 2017. Make a difference in just 1-2 hours a week! All tutoring times are during the school day, between 8 AM and 4 PM.

Aptos needs tutors on Tuesdays and Thursdays from 10 AM - 12 PM.

opportunities.description:
The Mission Community Beacon at Everett Middle School provides afterschool programming, support during the school day itself, and parent engagement through collaboration with program partners.

Volunteers will spend time with our middle school students and develop meaningful relationships. Each day, our students receive targeted academic interventions in study hall and then get to explore their interests in various electives, including cooking, science club, dance, recreation, STEM club, and more. Jump in and join us in our dynamic afterschool program!

The program meets at Everett Middle School (450 Church Street, SF CA 94114) from 3:30 - 6:00pm Monday-Thursday. On Fridays we have program from 12:30-6:00pm, which includes a fun field trip. Assistance is really needed during the time of 3:30 - 4:00pm, as the children are doing their academics during study hall.

Note: The school year began August 17, but we can get started on paperwork and have you ready to begin!

opportunities.description:
Seeking Coder Instructors to teach basic coding and computer usage to K-6 kids and their parents. Our goal is to potentially inspire children and their parents to pursue coding or other technology related fields as a hobby or career. Solid coding background and teaching abilities are imperative, as well as a talent for inspiring others and nurturing an excitement for education.

Please reply with your resume or URL to your LinkedIn profile.

RRRcomputer.org's vision is "1 Child, 1 Computer" to become a reality. Our mission is to reclaim, refurbish, reuse computers from recycling to reuse for education for low income K-12 kids. We reduce computer waste by refurbishing the computers to put back into circulation for the kids to use for internet search for research, and doing their homework assignment at home. The computers that are going to recycling is still useful for their needs. We do our part in saving the planet and improve the education of children.

opportunities.description:
Shadhika will be hosting its 25th Anniversay Gala and we are looking for volunteers to help with set up, various tasks during the event, and tear-down. This is a wonderful event and our volunteers are essential in helping make it happen!

Volunteers will work in shifts of 4 to 5 hours at a time, if you are available the entire time then that's great too!

Volunteer set-up duties include setting up tables and chairs, placing table covers and centerpieces on each, loading and setting up an Indian bazaar, and any additional set-up tasks. Take-down duties will include packing event materials, loading them into cars, and helping with clean-up.

We are also looking for volunteers to help check guests in, sell items at the event, and work donation tables.

For any questions please contact Farrah Salisbury, the Donor Outreach Manager, at fsalisbury@shadhika.org
opportunities.tags: exciting, fun, India, event, volunteer, shadhika, gala

opportunities.description:
Our mission at the National MS Society is a collective of passionate individuals who want to do something about MS now - to move toward a world free of multiple sclerosis. MS stops people from moving. ... We are moving politicians and legislation to champion the needs of people with MS through activism, advocacy and influence.

Under the Development Department, the Corporate Partner Research Intern will gain professional experience researching, tracking and cultivating corporate partners for fundraising events. This internship will help with gathering information on corporate partner leads, adding their information to our database and in forming and executing a plan to cultivate major event corporate partners throughout the year. Must be an upbeat self-starter, organized and enjoy a fast-paced work environment.

JOB RESPONSIBILITIES

Research

  • Work from list of current corporate partner leads and gather information helpful to cultivation (what types of organizations they fund, fiscal year cycle, current employees involved with Walk MS or Bike MS)
  • Review past participants corporate connections for potential partner leads
  • Research types of benefits corporations are being offered by events similar to NMSS events

Tracking

  • Add all pertinent information from research into database
  • Check back on top potential partners and update with new information as needed

Program Administration

  • Work with the Corporate Relations Manager to review and update event corporate partner materials for Walk MS and Bike MS

Cultivation

  • Work with Corporate Relations Manager to create a year-round, multi-channel, cultivation plan that includes current corporate partners and potential leads
  • Execute the cultivation plan by helping prepare targeted messages for email, Facebook and event websites

SKILLS AND QUALIFICATIONS

  • Excellent Internet and typing skills, proficiency with Excel and Word are required
  • Ability to study and organize data
  • Ability to communicate with event participants and potential corporate partners by phone
  • Highly collaborative team approach
  • Clean driving record
  • Ability to lift 50+ lbs

BENEFITS

  • Gain professional experience managing projects and balancing multiple priorities
  • Work within a high-functioning and inspiring workplace atmosphere
  • Learn and contribute in a local non-profit environment with a national reach

TRAINING & EVALUATION

  • Norther California Volunteer Orientation
  • Online training courses (as relevant to internship)
  • Individual training with supervisor for special projects
  • Ongoing evaluation / feedback provided throughout internship

COMMITMENT

  • 3 quarter long timeframe
  • Ongoing, flexible scheduling based on course load
  • Option to join NMSS staff at Walk MS and Bike MS

APPLICATION PROCESS

Submit the following to Harmeet.bath@nmss.org

  • Resume and cover letter
    • Two or three samples of design work

opportunities.description:
It will take a global family to complete all seven installation of the Human Family Tree/A Walk Through Paradise... and to build the Center for the Human Family.

Think Round, Inc. needs volunteers for the varied aspects of these two vast, expansive projects of our nonprofit. If you have interest in becoming involved here are some of the areas of our needs:

  • project development and managment
  • subject family recruitment
  • fund raising/grant writing
  • public outreach: print and electronic publicity and social media
  • research/education
  • panel discussions/convenings/summit
  • pre-and-post event evaluations
  • 3D modelling and visual effects
  • web presentation design: virtual reality, Prezi, Google slides, etc.
  • graphic design: SketchUp, TurboCAD, AutoCAD, etc.
  • venue sites and property location for final installation
  • installation setup and takedown/final construction
  • sourcing materials: fabric, panels, installation armetures, plants, lighting, etc.
  • volunteers: gallery sitters, exhibition docents, and international food service

If you believe you can help in any of these areas of need or if you have ideas to share about any of them, please contact Heidi Hardin/Think Round, Inc. by phone or email.
opportunities.tags: Project Management, fundraising, diversity, faith, Board Development, community outreach, art, grant writing, family

Think Round, Inc. needs volunteers for the varied aspects of these two vast, expansive projects of our nonprofit. If you have interest in becoming involved here are some of the areas of our needs: project development and managment subject family recruitment fund raising/grant writing public outreach: print and electronic publicity and social media research/education panel discussions/convenings/summit pre-and-post event evaluations 3D modelling and visual effects web presentation design: virtual reality, Prezi, Google slides, etc. graphic design: SketchUp, TurboCAD, AutoCAD, etc. venue sites and property location for final installation installation setup and takedown/final construction sourcing materials: fabric, panels, installation armetures, plants, lighting, etc. volunteers: gallery sitters, exhibition docents, and international food service If you believe you can help in any of these areas of need or if you have ideas to share about any of them, please contact Heidi Hardin/Think Round, Inc. by phone or email.

Primary focus willl be on Worldreader's Read to Kids project in India, but volunteer's work may also contribute to Worldreader's projects throughout the global south.

opportunities.description:
Crisis Text Line provides free, nationwide, 24/7 support for people in crisis, all via text message. The service is powered by volunteer Crisis Counselors who work remotely anywhere with a computer and secure internet connection. Crisis Counselors answer texts from people in crisis, bringing them from a hot moment to a cool calm through active listening, collaborative problem solving, and safety planning. Apply to volunteer at crisistextline.org/volunteer

HOW DO YOU BECOME A CRISIS COUNSELOR?

  • Step 1: Fill out the 30-minute application at crisistextline.org/volunteer
  • Step 2: Consent to a background check
  • Step 3: Complete the 34-hour web-based training
  • Step 4: Take your first shift and start changing lives! You will commit to volunteer 4 hours a week for one year. Volunteering can be done in 2 hour increments.

THE PERKS

  • Learn skills. In 34 hours, you’ll walk away knowing active listening, collaborative problem solving, and crisis management. (These are skills that will help in your personal relationships too!)
  • Train & volunteer from the comfort of your home.
  • Oooh, impressive! Our Crisis Counselors highlight the training on their resumes when interviewing for jobs, applying to grad school, and building out their LinkedIn profile.

VOLUNTEER WORK THAT ENRICHES YOUR LIFE

  • Level up. Earn volunteer leadership positions. Get the first crack at Crisis Text Line internships and job openings. Gain access to special privileges, including discounts and gifts.
  • Hone your skills. Work alongside volunteers who are also social workers, therapists, and psychiatrists to sharpen your crisis counseling skills-while in your jammies, at home!
  • Feel supported. This is a community. We support each other. We are a big awesome family.
WE LOVE THE BAY AREA

  • We have over 200 Crisis Counselors in the Bay Area! We love holding fun meet-ups to swap tips and self-care methods, and just hang out - sometimes we even hold free yoga sessions!

  • Crisis Text Line’s presence is growing in the BayArea. In fact, we recently partnered with Golden Gate Bridge, Caltrain, San Francisco Department of Public Health, and SF Giants to spread the word about our resource. And this is just the beginning!

READY TO VOLUNTEER?

APPLY HERE: crisistextline.org/volunteer

Questions? Email: support@crisistextline.org

opportunities.description:
You will work with high school students in small groups (4-7 students). These are students who have chosen to take an elective class that supports college readiness. The students are primarily in the "academic middle" with high potential, but some academic struggle. Many aspire to be the first in their family to attend college. Students bring questions they are confused about in other content classes to their tutorial group. The tutor facilitates the group of students in a Socratic Tutorial, where students learn by asking each other questions. Students learn not only the answer to the problem, but critical thinking and problem solving steps. Training is provided for you, the tutor, in this highly effective, research based method, which was developed by AVID (Advancement Via Individual Determination - see www.avid.org for more information). Have the satisfaction of helping an adolescent develop college and career readiness skills.

Upcoming training dates beginning in October and running through February. Begin working with students in Fall 2016 or Spring 2017. Make a difference in just 1-2 hours a week! All tutoring times are during the school day, between 8 AM and 4 PM.

Washington High School needs tutors:

Wednesday 8:45-10:15 AM & 11 AM - 2:30 PM

opportunities.description:
It’s a new year, dive into an opportunity to share your passion for STEM with a younger generation. Join the EnCorps STEM Teachers Program!

Students need you. STEM achievement and career opportunities are disproportionately limited for youth in under-resourced school districts. The severe shortage of high-quality teachers in these schools leaves low-income and minority students particularly vulnerable.

Join a network of over 600 EnCorps leaders in California making a profound and immediate impact by taking their working knowledge and passing it on to the next generation.

The EnCorps STEM Teachers Program empowers STEM industry experts to become exceptional teachers, tutors, and educators. Heading into our 10th year of public service, we are the only nonprofit in the nation that enables STEM professionals, military veterans, and retirees to explore a career transition to teaching in a highly supported way.

Do your part to address inequalities in education. Don't let zip code determine destiny.

OUR INNOVATIVE MODEL

  • Begin immediately working with high need students as a tutor and/or guest teacher
  • Receive mentorship from EnCorps staff and a host teacher
  • Decide on an EnCorps track of volunteering or full time (paid) teaching
  • Receive exam support and credentialing guidance, scholarship opportunities and access to networks and schools for full time teaching employment
  • Engage in a robust slate of professional development and a cohort of peers to share ideas, support and best practices

"I want them to know that they are capable of success no matter their background or what anyone else may have told them."

-EnCorps Fellow Tyran Richards

HOW TO APPLY

The EnCorps Fellowship is a selective fellowship for current STEM professionals who are interested in exploring their personal role in teaching and education. *You do not need prior experience in education, and you must not currently hold a California single subject credential*

Selection for the 2017 Cohort is underway! Apply online at http://encorps.org/apply. When your application is successfully submitted, you may be invited to one of our Bay Area Interview Day events this spring:

  • Wed, January 18 - Belmont 4-7pm (Deadline is 1/13)
  • Wed, February 22 - San Jose 2-5pm (Deadline is 2/17)
  • Wed, March 15 - Oakland 4-7pm (Deadline is 3/10)
  • Sat, March 25 - San Francisco 9am-2pm (Deadline is 3/22)
  • Tues, April 11 - Redwood Shores 2-5pm (Deadline is 4/8)
  • Wed, May 17 - San Jose 2-5pm (Deadline is 5/16)
  • Sat, May 20 - Oakland 9am-12pm (Deadline is 5/16)
  • Mon, May 22 - San Francisco 4-7pm (Deadline is 5/16)
FIND OUT MORE

  • Join our next live webinar at http://encorps.org/join/calendar-of-events/

  • Browse our website's Applicant FAQs: http://encorps.org/join/applicant-faqs/

  • Get in touch with David Taus, Bay Area Program & Recruitment Director: david(at)encorps.org, 510-708-3224

opportunities.description:
Sunday Streets creates miles of car-free space for people to get outside and be active. We transform neighborhoods into one big recreational space for the day. Our 2016 season will run from April-November, on once a month Sundays, in various neighborhoods.

To make sure our event is a safe and car-free environment, it takes hundreds of "no-parking" signs posted along the route to let drivers know their vehicles aren't allowed on the road for the day. In order to do so, we need to make sure all proper information is included on our signs. You can assure volunteering with us at our monthly volunteer movie nights achieves our goal.

When: Wednesday, March 1st from 6pm - 8 pm

What: We will enjoy wathcing a family friendly movie while preparing our no-stopping signs. Tasks will include relabeling and restringing signs, and having fun. Light snacks and drinks are provided.

Where: Livable City Offices, 333 Hayes St, Suite 202

How to sign up: Respond to VolunteerMatch or go to www.sundaystreetssf.com/get-involved/volunteers to sign up

Feel free to email volunteer@livablecity.org for any questions or concerns
opportunities.tags: volunteer work, community service, movie, volunteer
opportunities.title: Enjoy watching a movie while getting work done? Volunteer with Sunday Streets

opportunities.description:
UniversalGiving Returnships are intended for strong professionals seeking new opportunities. We understand that there are accomplished professionals who may be making a change in their career for several reasons. Perhaps you are re-entering the workforce after time off, a sabbatical or family leave. You may be hoping to make a career shift more in line with your goals and values, or perhaps you simply want to learn a new skill. UniversalGiving is eager to work together with you, forwarding the organization’s goals and yours as well.

A Marketing Partnerships Returnship is intended for a professional who can work with our CEO on high-level marketing partnerships. This person should have a strong command of marketing principles and the ability to target and forge long-term relationships driving results. The individual is a creative professional with leadership experience. Specific experience with cause-related marketing or high-level marketing relationships is considered a plus.

UniversalGiving™ (UG) is an award-winning website which allows people to give and volunteer with the top-performing projects all over the world. 100% of each donation goes directly to the project. UniversalGiving performs due diligence on all its projects through its unique, trademarked Quality Model™. UniversalGiving has been profiled on CBS and in FOX Business Network, and has also been featured in BusinessWeek, WomenEntrepreneur, Oprah.com, NBC News, The Christian Science Monitor, The New York Times, The Financial Times, MarketWatch, CNNMoney.com, Change.org and See Change Magazine.

UniversalGiving™ is committed to understanding and representing the diverse populations it serves worldwide. Members of all ages, genders, sexual orientations, races, ethnicities, nationalities, physical abilities or disabilities, religions or beliefs, and cultures are welcome as employees and volunteers in our organization. We believe that a diverse team will best serve our diverse populations.

Benefits include:

  • Gaining exposure and experience in a new industry
  • Building new relationships
  • Getting entry into an industry that is often difficult to access, where new positions do not open up frequently and are hard to obtain
  • Working with CEO Pamela Hawley
  • Upon positive execution, potential recommendation

Responsibilities include:

  • Increase brand awareness
  • Coordinate brand both offline, online, and on the UniversalGiving website
  • With proven success and positive attitude, work on significant partnerships with CEO, and play a major leadership role
  • Work with team to meet both quantitative and qualitative goals and objectives

Qualifications:

  • Bachelor’s degree
  • Minimum of ten years of professional experience in marketing or communications field
  • Excellent writing and communication skills
  • Critical attention to detail
  • Interest in nonprofit work and international issues, and a passion to support our mission to advance international giving and volunteering
  • Commitment to using and updating Salesforce, our Customer Relationship Database; prior experience considered a plus
  • Computer proficiency in Microsoft Office programs including Word, Excel, and Powerpoint

To Apply:
Email your cover letter, resume, and professional writing sample to volunteers@universalgiving.org. Please no phone calls.

opportunities.description:
Thursday evenings, a dedicated group of senior ladies from the Former Soviet Union gets together to play Bingo in the dining room of their apartment building just off the Panhandle of Golden Gate Park, from 7 to 8:30 in the evening (start and end time are flexible).

The simple act of turning the small bingo wheel and calling out the numbers in a strong, clear voice brings joy into their lives! A punctual, kind, and patient volunteer is needed for Thursdays Volunteering alternate weeks is fine. No Russian is necessary, but if you do speak Russian, this is a good chance for a little practice.
