opportunities.description:
UniversalGiving Returnships are intended for strong professionals seeking new opportunities. We understand that there are accomplished professionals who may be making a change in their career for several reasons. Perhaps you are re-entering the workforce after time off, a sabbatical or family leave. You may be hoping to make a career shift more in line with your goals and values, or perhaps you simply want to learn a new skill. UniversalGiving is eager to work together with you, forwarding the organization’s goals and yours as well.

A Corporate Returnship with UniversalGiving will give you the opportunity to work directly with the CEO to develop and implement Corporate Social Responsibility strategy atUniversalGiving™. You will have the opportunity to listen in on significant CSR calls with Fortune 500 companies, and with proven expertise, outreach to companies to develop new corporate relationships. You may also be called to engage with existing client partnerships. We are seeking an individual to lead premier research on companies working in key areas; demonstrate ability to build long-term relationships; analyze competitors through engagement with our competitive matrix, and/or find best practices and integrate them into our CSR plan.

With press in CBS, FOX Business Network, BusinessWeek, WomenEntrepreneur.com, Oprah.com, NBC News, and The Christian Science Monitor, UniversalGiving has established a strong global presence. UniversalGiving Corporate handles the strategy, operations and NGO vetting for corporations, to ensure the success of their international giving and volunteering programs.

Two core services include NGO Vetting and Launch a City. NGO Vetting vets all nonprofits with a proprietary Quality Model, safeguarding against terrorist activity. Launch a City helps companies expand their CSR programs city by city, in accord with legal, cultural and policy ramifications in each country. UGC works with companies to strengthen their global brand; increase corporate employee giving and volunteer rates; increase employee attraction/retention; increase client attraction/retention; and build a stronger, more loyal client base for our corporate partners. Sample clients include Cisco, Symantec, MTV and BEA.

UniversalGiving™ (UG) is an award winning marketplace which allows people to give and volunteer with the top-performing projects all over the world. 100% of each donation goes directly to the project. UniversalGiving™ performs due diligence on all its projects through its unique, trademarked Quality Model™.

UniversalGiving™ is committed to understanding and representing the diverse populations it serves worldwide. Members of all ages, genders, sexual orientations, races, ethnicities, nationalities, physical abilities or disabilities, religions or beliefs, and cultures are welcome as employees and volunteers in our organization. We believe that a diverse team will best serve our diverse populations.

Benefits include:

  • Gaining exposure and experience in a new industry
  • Building new relationships
  • Getting entry into an industry that is often difficult to access, where new positions do not open up frequently and are hard to obtain
  • Working with CEO Pamela Hawley
  • Upon positive execution, potential recommendation

Responsibilities include:

  • Develop key corporate partnerships
  • Develop and execute strategies to advance UniversalGiving’s presence in the CSR arena
  • Develop internal policies and procedures to ensure CSR strategies are consistent, effective, and fully integrated across business units
  • Maintain and update Corporate Social Responsibility plan
  • Work with team to meet both quantitative and qualitative goals and objectives
  • Conduct research on best practice CSR strategies and integrate into UniversalGiving CSR Plan
  • Represent UniversalGiving at events
  • Work with the larger corporate team, and with managers across all business units

Qualifications:

  • Bachelor’s degree
  • Minimum of ten years of professional experience and demonstrated awareness of best practices in Corporate Social Responsibility
  • Excellent writing and editing, communication, and organization skills
  • Critical attention to detail
  • Interest in nonprofit work, international issues, philanthropy, volunteerism and passion to support our mission to advance international giving and volunteering
  • Commitment to using and updating Salesforce, our Customer Relationship Database; prior experience considered a plus
  • Computer proficiency in Microsoft Office programs including Word,Excel and Powerpoint
  • Prior experience in CSR a plus

To Apply:
Email your cover letter, resume, and professional writing sample to volunteers@universalgiving.org. Please no phone calls.

opportunities.description:
Seeking a dedicated IT Manager to bring in industry expertise to train technicians for service calls.

Managerial responsibilities will include handling technical documentation for Knowledge Base (KB) and supervising special IT projects. 3-5+ years' managerial experience in IT is desired.

RRRcomputer.org's mission is to reclaim computers from recycling to reuse for education for low income K-6 kids. We reduce computer waste by refurbishing the computers to put back into circulation for the kids to use for internet search for research, and doing their homework assignment at home. The computers that are going to recycling is still useful for their needs. We do our part in saving the planet and improve the education of children.

opportunities.description:
Cooking Matters is a program offering free, six-week-long series of cooking and nutrition classes to low-income families. Classes are taught by volunteer culinary and nutrition instructors working in teams. We partner with host sites including clinics, shelters, housing sites, and after-school programs to offer courses in communities throughout the Bay Area. Volunteer for our program as a chef, nutritionist, or class assistant. Join us!

The Cooking Matters curriculum was created by Share Our Strength, a national nonprofit dedicated to ending childhood hunger in America. Nonprofits across the country use Cooking Matters to teach valuable skills in vulnerable communities.

Chef Job Description: During class, the chef will discuss topics such as food budgeting, planning meals, making healthy cooking choices, benefits of fruits and vegetables, healthy snacking, reading labels, and making better selections at the grocery store. The classes are intended to be highly participatory cooking demonstrations. It is important to keep the participants busy with various tasks and allow for hands-on learning in the kitchen. Some cooking skills to demonstrate and practice in class are basic cooking techniques and terminology, proper knife handling, various cooking methods, food safety and sanitation measures.

Nutrition Educator Job Description: As an educator, you must have a strong background in nutrition, food science, dietetics, or a related field. Important things to discuss include the food pyramid as a tool for healthy eating, planning balanced meals, benefits of fruits and vegetables, improving eating habits, cutting the fat, food budgeting, serving sizes, reading labels, and physical activity. The classes are intended to be interactive and the nutritionist will often act as facilitator for the activities and visual aids that are provided. The nutritionist also serves as a positive role model by emphasizing the benefits of nutritious eating and motivating participants to improve their eating habits.

Class Assistant Job Description: Volunteer class assistants help instructors and facilitators with classroom set-up, food preparation, class activities and clean up. Other duties may include packing groceries for participants to take home, unloading and loading kitchen equipment, and washing dishes. Volunteers with an interest in cooking and/or nutrition are encouraged to apply for this position. Volunteer shoppers are also needed to help secure ingredients for each week's class.

Time Commitment: Classes meet once a week for four to six weeks depending on the curriculum. Classes are held anytime between 9:00AM and 8:00PM, every day of the week. Each week, the classes require a time commitment of two hours plus half an hour of prep-time and fifteen minutes of clean up. In addition, communication with the Cooking Matters coordinator regarding class scheduling and the curriculum is necessary. Volunteers are encouraged to contribute to all facets of the class, including set-up, clean up and food preparation.
opportunities.tags: Food, cooking, nutrition

opportunities.description:
The Jewish Community Center San Francisco (JCCSF) is looking for additionalvolunteerUshers to join our exceptional team. Come have fun, meet new people, see part of a show or hear a lecture as you assist our staff and other guests attending events.

We seek people who are friendly, courteous, possess a desire to help others and can stay for the entire program to ensure maximum safety for our guests. Candidates must be able to stand for extended periods of time and be comfortable guiding patrons up and down stairs. Our motto as Ushers is to inform, assist and guide. Our goal is to provide a world-class theatre experience for our guests. An average usher shift is approx. 3 hours.

The JCCSF presents emerging and established performers, artists, writers and thinkers, all coming together to explore the far reaches of the Jewish imagination while reflecting and embracing the diversity of the San Franciscocommunity. The JCCSF is located in PresidioHeightson the corner of Californiaand Presidio. Check out our upcoming schedule at www.jccsf.org/arts-ideas/

All potential ushers must attend a one and half hour information session. Come participate in helping one of the most vibrant community centers in the country.

Contact Dee Leitner at dleitner@jccsf.org for information and an application or indicate your interest in ushering at specific event using this form: https://app.smartsheet.com/b/form?EQBCT=0b970e03bb84447d88fb6649abdf1a51

Thanks!

opportunities.description: EOCSF needs assistance in raising funds either through grantwriting or development. Although the Agency is totally funded through government grants, it has never made use of a grantwriter. Currently the entity's staff is thin, so having a grantwriter to assist it in funding itself would be a tremendous help to the organization. In addition, the organization has never pursued unrestricted funds. Having this type of funding would give EOCSF greater financial flexibility. Therefore, now is a perfect time for it to put a fundraising strategy in place.

opportunities.description:
You can use the professional skills and business experience you’ve earned on the job to create good jobs for working people and economic opportunity across America. Pacific Community Ventures' BusinessAdvising.org program recruits skills-based volunteers to work as mentors to small businesses in underserved communities.

You might be thinking, "Who has time to volunteer?" But the truth is, it takes less than 5 hours a month to make a big difference in someone else’s life. Don’t worry if you’ve never worked for or run your own small business. We'll match you with the right small business based on what you can contribute. And, skills-based volunteer advising can be done through email, phone, or Skype - whatever’s easiest for you.

In the last few years, people just like you have volunteered over 13,000 hours and created more than 15,000 new jobs for the people and communities that need them most.

Pro bono business advisors are needed with skills and experience in:

  • Marketing (Digital marketing; Social media; Sales; and Strategy)
  • Banking; Financial services; and Investment
  • Human resources and job creation
  • And more!

Get started as a mentor at https://businessadvising.org/advisors/ - you can even sign in with your LinkedIn account to create your profile.

opportunities.description:
On Taproot Foundation pro bono projects, the Project Manager is the primary day-to-day point of contact with a nonprofit client, and the day-to-day leader of pro bono consultant team. The Project Manager acts as one the most senior consultants on each team, owns the project schedule, ensures effective task delegation, and leads regular communication. Project Mangers also contribute subject matter expertise when relevant.

A successful Project Manager:

  • Has 5 years of experience in strategy management and/or financial analysis
  • Has 2 years of experience leading teams of strategy professionals
  • Is organized and detail-oriented
  • Has Principal, VP, Senior Consultant or Manager-level experience

A Service Grant project requires a 3-5 hour commitment each week over the course of approximately 6 months. This opportunity is flexible enough to work around the schedule of a full-time job.

Taproot Foundation makes it easy to make a difference. We’re a nonprofit organization that makes business talent available to organizations that are working to improve society. Our goal is to ensure that one day all organizations with promising solutions will be equipped to successfully take on urgent social challenges. To date, we have engaged close to 7,700 professionals on close to 2,300 pro bono projects benefiting education, health, environment, social service, and arts initiatives.

Now it’s your turn to join the movement and Make It Matter.

opportunities.description:
Go! Team Members support Boys Hope Girls Hope's efforts to reach young people, ages 10-18 who have barriers to school success and college matriculation. Barriers can include poverty and precipitating conditions such as absence of parents due to death, incarceration or abandonment, abuse or neglect, neighborhood violence, substance abuse in the home, homelessness, domestic violence and other risk factors for dropping out as defined by the National Center for Dropout Prevention.
AmeriCorps members' efforts will ensure that volunteers and the community are engaged in the important work of moving children in their communities from poverty to self-sufficiency. Working in coordination with other Go! Team members and BHGH staff, the Go! Team Member will work in a team at an assigned project site, and focus their efforts on ensuring BHGH Scholars are accruing the skills, confidence and aspirations necessary to achieve college enrollment. Activities will focus on academic preparation, college counseling, co-curricular learning and the development of ongoing opportunities for scholars to better understand cultural diversity through service-learning projects. Additional resources will include boosting parental involvement in scholar activities, and educating and encouraging community collaboration.

A Community Resource Coordinator creates and sustains infrastructure for volunteer engagement across an affiliate’s operations.
Activities can include:
* Recruiting, training, supporting and recognizing volunteers, mentors and tutors
* Delivering volunteer generation plans
* Creating community partnerships and connections that support scholar development
* Developing best volunteer practices
* Ensuring all volunteers meet state and Boys Hope Girls Hope licensing requirements

For more details please contact our executive director, Suzanne Palmer, at spalmer@bhgh.org or at (415) 657-9302.
opportunities.tags: san francisco, human resources, education, outreach, bay area, recruitment, youth development
opportunities.title: Community Resource Coordinator (AmeriCorps position)

opportunities.description:
* Marketing Committee *

PR Position Description

Are you passionate about food, community and social impact? If you are an experienced PR professional who wants to help create the brand and build awareness for one of Northern California’s most vibrant and diverse food-oriented social enterprises, we would like to talk with you!

About the San Francisco Wholesale Produce Market

The San Francisco Wholesale Produce Market (the "Market") offers the most diverse community of merchants with the widest selection of great-tasting fruits and vegetables to help Northern California food businesses meet their customers’ unique produce needs.

As San Francisco’s original - and only - wholesale produce market, we are creating a thriving and sustainable food center that delivers unique value to our customers while giving back to the community and neighborhood.

Our mission is to link the produce and food communities of SF and beyond, by successfully developing and operating the Market. We operate as a non-profit social enterprise, collaborating with the City of San Francisco, our Merchants and the Bayview Hunters Point neighborhood to curate the area’s widest selection of local, organic, ethnic and conventional produce and to responsibly develop the Market.

It is an exciting time to market the Market. We are investing in our future by continuing to upgrade our 485,000 square feet of warehouse and logistics space and increasing the impact of our programs, which include creating jobs, supporting local farmers and expanding our food recovery program.

Work of THE MARKETING Committee

The Market’s Marketing Committee was formed earlier this year and is composed of seven volunteers and two staff members. Members are Merchants at the Market, current members of the Board of Directors and qualified volunteers with extensive marketing experience. We currently seek an additional volunteer with food-related PR expertise to join the Marketing Committee.

The Marketing Committee’s goals include building brand and demand for the Market by:

1) Becoming experts on current and past marketing/outreach activities of Merchants, the Market and other wholesale markets, and understanding existing opportunities and needs in marketing, branding, and communications

2) Making recommendations to the Board of Directors about proposed goals, strategy and approaches for marketing, branding, and communications for the Market

3) Recommending action plans for implementation to the Board

4) In collaboration with the Board, supporting implementation of the action plans through active Committee engagement and additional resources.

Committee Roles and Responsibilities

Role

Responsibilities

Committee Co-chairs

  • Conduct outreach to potential Committee members
  • Finalize agendas and run Committee meetings
  • Share responsibilities as listed below for committee members

Committee Member

(including Merchant representatives)

  • Attend regularly scheduled Committee meetings
  • Provide insight at meetings and in follow-on work
  • Complete tasks committed to in Committee meetings

Other Merchants on the Market

  • Provide input to Committee as requested
  • Provide feedback on Committee outputs
  • Potentially serve on Committee or sub-committees

Staff support for Committee

  • Schedule meetings and communicate about logistical details
  • Prepare and distribute materials prior to meetings
  • Support Committee chair(s) as needed and help with agendas for Committee meetings
  • Support implementation of marketing/outreach and branding plans

Qualifications

We seek 1 additional committee member that feels confident s/he will be able to volunteer his or her time to do media outreach to secure coverage for the Market. S/he should have the following qualifications:

  • Expertise in Public Relations - specifically in food-related PR
  • Knowledge of and relationships with local media outlets, both traditional and digital - particularly those that highlight food stories
  • Experience in successfully delivering key messages through various media outlets (TV, newspapers, blogs, social media, etc.)

Commitment

We ask that committee members make a one year commitment. The Committee currently meets monthly with marketing activities occurring between meetings.

Service on Market’s committees is a volunteer position without remuneration.

If interested, please contact Michael Janis, General Manager, at 415-550-4495 or mjanis@sfproduce.org
opportunities.title: Marketing Committee Public Relations

opportunities.description:
Looking to volunteer with your community group or employees? Do you want to give back to the community? Get involved with Sunday Streets!

What is Sunday Streets? Sunday Streets is an open streets program where we create miles of car-free streets for communities to get outdoors and be active in diverse San Francisco neighborhoods. We transform city streets into recreational space for the day and have tons of FREE activities. Sunday Streets encourages health, recreation, community activities and fun.

Groups: We coordinate volunteer group of various sizes. Minimum of 4 or more people.

When & Where: We have 8 events this year, from March to November.

  • March 12 - Mission
  • April 9 - Bayview/Dogpatch
  • April 30 - Tenderloin
  • June 11 - Sunset/Golden Gate Park
  • July 16 - Mission
  • August 20 - Tenderloin
  • September 10 - Western Addition
  • Ocotber 1 - Excelsior

How to sign up: To sign up, please email volunteer@livablecity.org or respond to VolunteerMatch.

Moreinformation: For more information visit www.sundaystreetssf.com/get-involved/volunteers

Thank you for your interest!
opportunities.tags: san francisco, group, Open Streets, group volunteer, volunteer work, community service, sunday streets, volunteer

March 12 - Mission April 9 - Bayview/Dogpatch April 30 - Tenderloin June 11 - Sunset/Golden Gate Park July 16 - Mission August 20 - Tenderloin September 10 - Western Addition Ocotber 1 - Excelsior How to sign up: To sign up, please email volunteer@livablecity.org or respond to VolunteerMatch. More information: For more information visit www.sundaystreetssf.com/get-involved/volunteers Thank you for your interest!

opportunities.description:
Mission Graduates' Extended Day Program (EDP) is an after-school program that focuses on positive youth development outcomes and helping needy children excel academically. The EDP serves 400 children across three elementary school sites, spanning K-5th grades.

Volunteers spend time with our elementary school students and develop meaningful relationships. Each day, you would help students with their class work, participate in our themed-lessons and academic enrichment activities and support our Classroom Coordinators with daily lesson plans.

Our students receive targeted academic interventions and get to explore their interests in various electives, including cooking, science club, dance, recreation, STEM club, and more. Jump in and join us in our dynamic afterschool program!

Programs run from 2:00-6:00pm Monday-Friday. If you can volunteer at least once a week for two hours, this is a perfect opportunity.

Note: The school year begins August 17, but we can get started on paperwork and have to you ready to begin!

opportunities.description:
Telephone Aid in Living with Kids, TALK Line, is a 24-hour parent helpline hosted by the San Francisco Child Abuse Prevention Center (SFCAPC), staffed primarily by volunteers. TALK Line handles over 3,800 calls per year, offering round-the-clock telephone counseling to anyone seeking support on topics related to caring for children.

Volunteer Responsibilities:

  • Spend 4-hours per week answering calls at the TALK Line Family Support Center in Haight-Ashbury for a minimum of 6 months
  • Serve as a compassionate, objective listener for parents and caregivers in need of support
  • Complete 27+ hours of initial and ongoing training led by professional psychologists

No previous counseling experience necessary!

Do you need parenting support yourself? Call the line: 415-441-KIDS (5437)!

opportunities.description:
This position is a unique opportunity to work with a leading-edge, creative, environmental and educational nonprofit, Life Frames, Inc., dedicated to integrating community resources and creating transformative ecological and multicultural learning landscapes. Called A Living Library & Think Park, this program works with local schools and other community resources, to build on-site educational organic gardens and content-rich landscapes interlaced with other ecological elements, including the arts and digital technologies. A Living Library is linked to the curricula of the schools and animates all subjects through real-world experience. Students, together with adults, are involved in all aspects of the research, planning, design, implementation, use, maintenance, management and communications of the transformed learning environments and integrated community programs.

(Life Frames, Inc. is an equal opportunity employer with a strong commitment to establishing a team of staff and volunteers who reflect the multicultural and linguistic diversity of the communities that we serve.)

Job Description:
Dynamic, Inspired Teacher For Middle School & High School, plus K-5 Students:
Organic Gardening / California Natives / Ecology / Multi- Arts / Technology / Literacy / Nutrition Teacher (part time)

This dynamic, inspired, cheerful, with positive, can-do attitude - Outdoor Educator - will be leading groups of K-12 students and teachers, in hands-on learning and doing, in diverse activities: organic & native gardening and tree planting, multi-arts including digital media, literacy and nutrition projects, as well as leading students in researching local ecology, history, watersheds, and existing local community, including its natural, multicultural, and built resources. You will be doing extensive student outreach & recruitment, attracting students for hands-on, learning programs, and leading gardening, related landscape, and arts activities as standards-based learning processes. You will be communicating about sustainability, ecological systems and native landscapes as well as performing community outreach activities with children and adults in ways that are fun, educational, and relevant. You will also help with some administration of program. For qualified, right individual, can grow to leadership position.

Qualifications:
• The exceptional candidate must have at least a B.A. and knowledge of science, organic gardening, California native species, and the arts; digital media a plus !

• Must have extensive experience teaching, including Elementary, Middle School and High School students - working creatively and artistically with all learners with knowledge of Common Core Standards
• Must be excellent and have ease in managing and leading groups and classes of students with good classroom management skills in an outdoor setting
• Must have a dynamic, outgoing, positive, can-do, personality and ability to attract and recruit middle school youth's participation in hands-on afterschool and summer program, as well as captivate and hold young students' attention and involvement in hands-on activities
• Must be an excellent organic gardener, tree planter, and landscaper with knowledge of botany, cycles of life, insects, natural pest management, companion planting, California Native species, plant communities, nutrition & health
• Knowledge about San Francisco ecology and watershed systems very important !
• Must have excellent communication, writing, research skills & experience with curriculum development; knowledge of Common Core standards a plus
• Must have an evolved aesthetic/design sensibility; ability to draw well is fantastic and be able to make attractive digital flyers a real win; carpentry skills are desired; digital & social media, video & other art skills a real plus!
• Bilingual or Multilingual Spanish, Tagalog, Cantonese, Mandarin, or other, a real plus !!!
• Must be creative, hard-working, strong, a self-starter, resourceful, flexible, can-do team player, and be able to also take direction from Director
• Ability & willingness to do some administrative work, social media, blogging, and outreach !
• Able to be liason with teacher's, school principals, and parents
• For qualified, right individual, can grow to leadership position

To find out more about A Living Library:
please visit our blog: www.alivinglibrary.org/blog

Reply to the Founder & Director with cover letter & resume

opportunities.description:
VOLUNTEER POSITION: Computer Class Assistant Volunteer

ORGANIZATION: HealthRIGHT 360 Resource Center

COMMITMENT: 3 hours per week for at least 3 to 4 months every Monday from 1-4pm.

POSITION DESCRIPTION: The Computer Class Assistant will assist the full-time Computer Lab Instructor during a weekly computer class/workshop on Mondays from 1-4pm. Class sizes generally range from 8-12 people and include clients from a wide spectrum of abilities, from highly proficient to no computer experience at all. The Computer Class Assistant will help clients one-on-one while the Instructor facilitates and teaches the curriculum. Certain portions of the class are self-directed, whereas others require following along with the Instructor. In addition, some clients, because of their advanced level, may be working independently on other activities.

DESIRED SKILLS, QUALIFICATIONS AND PERSONAL QUALITIES:

  • Extremely patient and able to tutor clients individually in a group setting
  • Able to make sure that clients are following along with the lesson
  • Answering individual clients’ basic computer questions, e.g., Internet, email, Craigslist, Microsoft Word
  • Providing help with other class-related activities dependent on your skills and interest
  • Excellent communication, interpersonal and listening skills
  • Able to role model professional behavior and maintain professional boundaries
  • Interest in working with diverse, disadvantaged populations including low literacy, learning disabilities, physical disabilities and impaired cognitive functioning
  • Able to maintain client confidentiality
  • A background or interest in education is a plus but not required

TRAINING AND SUPERVISION:

You will be given a volunteer orientation and you will have the opportunity to observe the Wednesday computer class/workshop and become familiar with the Computer Class Assistant role. If you find that the position is a good fit, you will then begin assisting the class every week and working closely with the Computer Lab Instructor. In addition, as a valuable asset to our team, we as Resource Center staff are always available to you if you have questions or concerns.

opportunities.description:
Heroes Wanted!

  • Are you 50+?
  • Interested in volunteering?
  • Passionate about reading or literacy?
  • Want to give your time to children?

Would a little financial assistance help you make a commitment? We can help! Contact Experience Corps Bay Area to get started.

Experience Corps Bay Area is a time-tested, innovative, inter-generational tutoring and mentoring program that has served Bay Area schools and students since 1998. Our volunteers, age 50+, help students in grades K-3 gain the reading skills needed to succeed in school.

Experience Corps partners with AmeriCorps to offer modest stipends for your time and experience working with children! If you have 10 or more hours a week to give in service, this may be the program for you!

Our AmeriCorps stipend deadline is approaching, so contact us ASAP!

Benefits:

  • AmeriCorps stipend of approximately $200/month
  • Additional $1200 education award upon completion of service (This award may be used for college tuition or student loans. It can be transferred to a child, grandchild, or foster child.)
  • Leadership opportunities
  • Ongoing coaching and training
  • Membership in a team of likeminded people, age 50+, who become a vital part of a school community

We need tutors and mentors in schools in San Francisco, Oakland, and Berkeley.

A winning volunteer experience is based on realistic expectations. What we will need from you:

  • A commitment of as little as 4 hours/week (10+ hours for a stipend)
  • A desire to work with young students and help them succeed in school
  • A high school degree or GED
  • Conversational English skills. A second language is a plus!
  • A background check
  • A TB test

Experience Corps is a program for adults age 50 and over.

Call 415-759-4222 or email ecba.today@gmail.com for more info. Or take part in an upcoming info session.

Upcoming Info Sessions:

November 18, 2:30-3:30 - Glen Park Library, San Francisco

December 16, 1:30-2:30 - Potrero Hill Library, San Francisco

opportunities.description:
Support for Families is seeking a Development Assistant Volunteer to help support our team with outreach, fundraising and preparation for events.

Duties:

  • Provide support to our team at various events.
  • Make phone calls to solicit items and donations from local businesses.
  • Assist with outreach for volunteer program and events.
  • Research and input information into database.
  • Assist with large mailings, preparation of packets and other projects.
  • Create signage, posters, and other marketing materials.

Requirements:

  • Ability to work independently as well as in a team setting.
  • Experienced with Microsoft Word, Excel, PowerPoint, Outlook, and/or Publisher.
  • Excellent written and verbal communication skills.
  • Exceptional organizational skills with impeccable attention to detail.
  • Professional speaking style and demeanor.
  • Enthusiastic and positive attitude.

Hours/Time Commitment:

Commitment of 4 hours or more per week from September to December. Available to volunteer at the following events: Wine + Design (Oct. 9), Halloween Party (Oct. 24), & Holiday Ice Skating Party (Dec. 19).

To Apply:

Please fill out our online Volunteer Application (resume optional): http://www.supportforfamilies.org/volunteer/volunteer-application.html

opportunities.description:
St. Anthony’s (FCP) is San Francisco’s largest free clothing program and is the only one which serves families. FCP provides warm clothes, interview and employment apparel, and children’s clothing to low-income families and individuals, including those who are homeless. We refer to the people we serve as our "guests."

One of the biggest obstacles for our guests seeking a job is obtaining appropriate job interview clothing. One of our guests named Steven B. said it best: "I don’t even feel comfortable filling out a job application, let alone going on a job interview, because my clothes are dirty and smelly." To remedy this, the Free Clothing Program has worked to provide brand new suits and shoes to our male guests who are unemployed and seeking work.

The Tailor will assist our guests by identifying their clothing sizes, helping them choose appropriate job interview clothing, and tailoring suits to a perfect fit. Such service provides men not only with a fitted new suit, but also gives our guests a confidence boost that can enhance prospects for a new job. Duties & Tasks:

 Assist and instruct guests on how to determine their clothing sizes.

 Assist and instruct guests on how to put together an appropriate job interview outfit.

 Tailoring of new suits.

 Assist in restocking racks with the highest quality clothing possible.

SKILLS REQUIRED:

 Tailoring and/or sewing experience.

 Ability to be professional, polite, and tactful with our guests and maintain appropriate boundaries.

 Ability to successfully volunteer with a diverse client population including homeless, low-income, and mentally-disabled persons.

 Excellent interpersonal, listening, and oral and written communication skills.

 Excellent volunteer habits: professional, punctual, reliable, cooperative and team oriented.

 Ability to volunteer with minimal supervision and as part of a team.

 Adherence to guidelines explained in the Volunteer/Intern Handbook.

 Commitment to St. Anthony Foundation Statement of Values and desire to volunteer for a social service agency serving the homeless and low-income.

Commitment:

Minimum of 4 hours per month for 6+ months between 8am-4:30pm Mondays-Fridays.

You'll learn about our design goals, constraints, and current dilemmas.

Then, you'll propose solutions.

Coffee and a light lunch will be served.

opportunities.title: Hardware Product Designer, Inventor, Engineer, 2+ hours on weekends
opportunities.plaintextDescription: Not a youth event. Each Saturday, 11am to 3pm, a small group of inventors and mechanical engineers get together to complete the design of our hardware kit. We teach our apprentices how to build this kit. You'll learn about our design goals, constraints, and current dilemmas. Then, you'll propose solutions. Coffee and a light lunch will be served.

opportunities.description:
JOB SUMMARY

Our mission at the National MS Society is a collective of passionate individuals who want to do something about MS now - to move toward a world free of multiple sclerosis. MS stops people from moving. ... We are moving politicians and legislation to champion the needs of people with MS through activism, advocacy and influence.

Under the Development Department, the Corporate Partner Research Intern will gain professional experience researching, tracking and cultivating corporate partners for fundraising events. This internship will help with gathering information on corporate partner leads, adding their information to our database and in forming and executing a plan to cultivate major event corporate partners throughout the year. Must be an upbeat self-starter, organized and enjoy a fast-paced work environment.

JOB RESPONSIBILITIES

Research

  • Work from list of current corporate partner leads and gather information helpful to cultivation (what types of organizations they fund, fiscal year cycle, current employees involved with Walk MS or Bike MS)
  • Review past participants corporate connections for potential partner leads
  • Research types of benefits corporations are being offered by events similar to NMSS events

Tracking

  • Add all pertinent information from research into database
  • Check back on top potential partners and update with new information as needed

Program Administration

  • Work with the Corporate Relations Manager to review and update event corporate partner materials for Walk MS and Bike MS

Cultivation

  • Work with Corporate Relations Manager to create a year-round, multi-channel, cultivation plan that includes current corporate partners and potential leads
  • Execute the cultivation plan by helping prepare targeted messages for email, Facebook and event websites

SKILLS AND QUALIFICATIONS

  • Excellent Internet and typing skills, proficiency with Excel and Word are required
  • Ability to study and organize data
  • Ability to communicate with event participants and potential corporate partners by phone
  • Highly collaborative team approach
  • Clean driving record
  • Ability to lift 50+ lbs

BENEFITS

  • Gain professional experience managing projects and balancing multiple priorities
  • Work within a high-functioning and inspiring workplace atmosphere
  • Learn and contribute in a local non-profit environment with a national reach

TRAINING & EVALUATION

  • Norther California Volunteer Orientation
  • Online training courses (as relevant to internship)
  • Individual training with supervisor for special projects
  • Ongoing evaluation / feedback provided throughout internship

COMMITMENT

  • 3 quarter long timeframe
  • Ongoing, flexible scheduling based on course load
  • Option to join NMSS staff at Walk MS and Bike MS

APPLICATION PROCESS

Submit the following to Harmeet.bath@nmss.org

  • Resume and cover letter
    • Two or three samples of design work

opportunities.description:
The Green Team is a drop-in gardening group that supports maintenance of San Francisco Botanical Garden. Volunteers work with SF Recreation & Parks gardeners, helping weed, mulch, plant, and otherwise maintain our rare and unique collections.

The Green Team volunteers on Tuesday & Thursday from 10-1pm, and Saturday and Sunday from 9-12pm.

We are seeking a coordinator to assist gardeners with organizing and supervising the Green Team during their shift. Responsibilities include: distributing tools and snacks, and returning tools at end of the shift; welcoming new members; assisting the supervising gardener in ensuring that volunteers are following best practices; ensuring that safety rules are followed; reporting to volunteer manager on issues involving volunteers or gardener; cleaning and organizing tools; tracking attendance; gardening!

The Green Team coordinator should be someone who can commit to working with the GT weekly, for a minimum of 6 months. This position provides a valuable opportunity for both gardening and supervising experience, and is ideal for horticulture students.

opportunities.description:
Vintage: Wine, Beer, and Spirits Labels from the Kemble Collections on Western Printing and Publishing

This exhibition explores CHS's exquisite collection of vintage wine, beer, and spirits labels produced by the now-forgotten Lehmann Printing and Lithographing Company of San Francisco. Designed during the terrible privation and unrest of the Great Depression, Lehmann's labels graced hundreds of thousands of bottles of mass-manufactured, highly alcoholic wines and liquors, invoking deliciously unrealistic fantasies of peace, plenty, and the high-class life. Marrying design with consumer ideology, the Lehmann oeuvre represents a forgotten high point of American commercial art. The exhibition features hundreds of colorfully illustrated labels, ephemera, and stock label catalogue books from Lehmann Printing.

Open through April 23, 2017

opportunities.description:
Welcome to San Francisco Suicide Prevention. We are looking for empathic and reliable individuals to staff our 24-hour crisis hotline. We have 56-hour trainings available five times yearly, where we teach prospective volunteers basic counseling skills, suicide assessment, emergency services, mental health referrals, LGBTQ issues, text-based support and HIV services.

San Francisco Suicide Prevention has been in operation since 1962, and was the first community based suicide hotline in the country. We operate with an emphasis of volunteers coming from all walks of life to provide peer-based support to those in crisis. There is a one-year or 200-hour minimum commitment.

All applicants must complete a volunteer application, available at the following URL:

http://www.sfsuicide.org/volunteers-and-interns/hotline-volunteers/

opportunities.description:
At Make-A-Wish, we grant wishes for kids with life-threatening medical conditions to enrich the human experience with hope, strength, and joy. The Greater Bay Area Chapter is headquartered in San Francisco, and covers 17 counties of Northern California, granting an average of 330 wishes per year. For each wish, we send the child a bag with a t-shirt, a ballcap, a pin, a backpack, and various other items to enhance the wish. 70% of our wishes involve travel, so for those wishes, we send an itinerary with travel information (hotel, rental car, flight information). The Program Department is looking for a volunteer to assist with assembling the bags and itineraries, as well as sending out thank you letters to our the generous donors who donate goods and services to kids' wishes.

We are looking for a volunteer who can help 3-4 hours per week, on a regular, weekly basis. The shift must be done during our office hours - 9am-5pm M-F. We can mutually decide what shift time works with your schedule (e.g. Monday 2-5pm, Wednesday, 10am-1pm, or whatever works best with your schedule). We also require that the volunteer be willing to agree to a minimum six-month commitment. All the office work will be done at the Make-A-Wish office in San Francisco.

Duties include:

  • Wish bags - putting together bag with items, decorating folder unique to wish and completing with appropriate inserts
  • Wish Itineraries - Prepping and finishing itineraries for all wish types - travel, material, etc.
  • Re-supply Wish Folders by Wish Type in drawer
  • Draft and send out monthly thank you letters to vendors who have discounted and donated to wishes
  • Oversee Program Supply Room - alert department when running low on certain items to order
The volunteer should be detail-oriented and an arts-and-crafts type person with an eye for what would look fun for kids. Experience with Microsoft Excel and Word required. Experience with graphics and/or Microsoft Publisher preferred. The Wish Bag and Itinerary Assistant must be at least 18 years old. If you are interested in this position, please email our Volunteer Manager at volunteer@sfwish.org to express interest, and include a resume.
opportunities.tags: children, crafts, gift bags, graphics, creative, creativity, decorate, art, images, decoration, kids, wish

opportunities.description:
JOIN OUR NOBLE QUEST AS A VOLUNTEER

American CareQuest Hospice is looking for kind and passionate volunteers who want to support the elderly and the sick. Our volunteers’ empathy and time make an enormous difference in the lives of those affected by terminal illness. The volunteer’s role is greatly rewarding and perfect for those interested in working with older adults, working in the healthcare field, or having a general passion of helping others. Duties may include administrative tasks, calling patients or their families or making visits to patients’ homes. Your specific role and time commitment as hospice volunteer are flexible and dependent upon your preferences and availability.

We welcome you to join our great team!

Please call us at (415) 885-9100 or send your resume to:

hr@americancarequest.com

Please reply with your resume or URL to your LinkedIn profile.

Help spread the word of our mission to help low income families by increasing our social media footprint.

RRRcomputer.org is seeking a Social Media Specialist to generate and actively monitor our presence across pertinent social media platforms. Astute news judgment and strong interpersonal skills are desired. The ideal volunteer should have a professional background within social media or marketing industry.

RRRcomputer.org's mission is to reclaim computers from recycling to reuse for education for low income K-6 kids. We reduce computer waste by refurbishing the computers to put back into circulation for the kids to use for internet search for research, and doing their homework assignment at home. The computers that are going to recycling is still useful for their needs. We do our part in saving the planet and improve the education of children.

opportunities.description:
The Gubbio Project is seeking applicants to join our Board of Directors.

Description

The Gubbio Project is a unique program that provides refuge for the homeless in the sanctuary of two churches. Housed in the beautiful Saint Boniface Catholic Church in the heart of the Tenderloin District and St. John the Evangelist in the Mission District of San Francisco, The Gubbio Project offers sanctuary and sacred sleep during the day, along with blankets, toiletries and clean bathrooms, to our neighbors without homes. It also provides opportunities for engagement and connection with the homeless to those in the neighborhood, the church, and the school communities. According to ABC News coverage, Saint Boniface is the only church that has successfully initiated and continued such a program for six years.

Goals and Activities

The goals of The Gubbio Project are two-fold:

  • To provide a clean, beautiful, quiet, and safe space for people to rest during the day
  • To cultivate a sense of community among the homeless and a sense of understanding and shared responsibility in the broader church, school and neighborhood communities

We are seeking to expand our Board of Directors, which currently includes 7 committed, diverse individuals. We are especially seeking applicants who have experience with fund development, legal matters, financial matters, and/or board development. If you have questions, please feel free to contact us.

Thank you for your time and consideration.

opportunities.description:
Plant Coordinator/Green Skills Job Training Teacher for High School Youth to 21called A.L.L. ECO Stewards in Native Plantings/Plant Establishment Stewardship/Watershed/ Ecology/Gardening/Green Skills with some Multi-Arts/Literacy/Nutrition (part time) (Bernal Heights-Begin NOW)

This position is a unique opportunity to work with a leading-edge environmental and educational nonprofit, Life Frames, Inc., dedicated to integrating community resources and creating the Bernal Heights Living Library & Think Park Nature Walk, a transformative ecological, multicultural learning landscape linking diverse community resources, leading to hidden Islais Creek. This Nature Walk is prototype for linking eleven communities of Islais Creek Watershed, the largest in SF.

Called A Living Library & Think Park, this program works with local schools and other community resources, to build on-site Nature Walks, content-rich learning landscapes, and educational organic gardens, all interconnected with other elements, including the arts and digital technologies.

A Living Library is linked to the curricula of the schools and animates all subjects through real-world experience. Students, together with adults, are involved in research, planning, design, implementation, use, maintenance, management and communications of the transformed learning environments and integrated community programs.

(Life Frames, Inc. is an equal opportunity employer with a strong commitment to establishing a team of staff and volunteers who reflect the multicultural and linguistic diversity of the communities that we serve.)

Job Description:
Leader /Teacher for HS Youth to 21 years in California Natives / Planting & Plant Establishment Stewardship / Ecology & Watersheds / Organic Gardening / (part time). Students will receive a monetary stipend for their successful involvement and hands-on participation.

The successful candidate will be leading groups of low to moderate income High School Students to Age 21, in native tree and understory planting and care, ecology, learning about local watershed, plant communities, habitat restoration, organic gardening, and some multi-arts including digital media, literacy, nutrition projects. The Leader will also work with students to understand local ecology, history, watersheds, and existing dynamics of local community, with its natural, multicultural, and built resources. You will be leading hands-on activities as standards-based learning processes, communicating about ecological systems. You will also first recruit students from local schools and other community resources to join and participate in A.L.L. ECO Stewards program. You will also help with Administration of program.

Qualifications:
• The candidate must have at least a B.A. and good knowledge of science, California native species, watersheds, organic gardening. Skilled in nutrition, arts, digital media, including photography a plus !
• Must be an excellent tree and shrub planter, landscaper, organic gardener, with knowledge of botany, cycles of life, insects, natural pest management, companion planting, California native species, plant communities, nutrition & health
• Must have extensive experience teaching, including especially High School Students - working creatively and artistically with all learners; knowledge of CA. State Standards and Common Core Standards a plus !
• Must be excellent in managing, motivating, and leading groups of students with good classroom management and motivational skills in an outdoor setting
• Knowledge about San Francisco ecology and watershed systems is essential !
• Must have excellent communication, writing, research, social media skills & experience with curriculum development and creating magnetic, visual outreach flyers
• Evolved aesthetic/design sensibility desirable; ability to draw well; carpentry skills a plus; digital media, video & other art skills a bonus!
• Bilingual Spanish, Cantonese, or Mandarin, a real plus !!!
• Must be creative, hard-working, positive, strong, cheerful, a self-starter with can-do attitude, team player, and able to also take direction from Director
• Ability & willingness to do Outreach to Recruit Students and Administrative work !

To find out more about A Living Library, please visit our blog: www.alivinglibrary.org/blog

Reply to the Founder & Director with cover letter & resume
This is a part-time job - available NOW
This is at a non-profit organization.

Compensation: tbd

State Standards and Common Core Standards a plus ! • Must be excellent in managing, motivating, and leading groups of students with good classroom management and motivational skills in an outdoor setting • Knowledge about San Francisco ecology and watershed systems is essential ! • Must have excellent communication, writing, research, social media skills & experience with curriculum development and creating magnetic, visual outreach flyers • Evolved aesthetic/design sensibility desirable; ability to draw well; carpentry skills a plus; digital media, video & other art skills a bonus! • Bilingual Spanish, Cantonese, or Mandarin, a real plus !!! • Must be creative, hard-working, positive, strong, cheerful, a self-starter with can-do attitude, team player, and able to also take direction from Director • Ability & willingness to do Outreach to Recruit Students and Administrative work ! To find out more about A Living Library, please visit our blog: www.alivinglibrary.org/blog Reply to the Founder & Director with cover letter & resume This is a part-time job - available NOW This is at a non-profit organization. Compensation: tbd

opportunities.description:
An opportunity to gain valuable work experience at the California Coastal Commission while making a difference for our coast and ocean. We are seeking up to two detail-oriented, highly motivated individuals for volunteer internships with our Public Education Program, assisting with the Coastal Art & Poetry Contest for K- 12 students. The bulk of the work will take place between February 1, 2017 and April 29, 2017.

This is an unpaid, part-time position(s) with flexible hours, approximately 8 hours per week. Background: The Coastal Commission is a State agency charged with protecting coastal resources and managing coastal development in California. The Coastal Commission's Public Education Program works to increase public knowledge of coastal and marine resources and to engage the public in coastal protection and restoration activities. Visit our Public Education website at www.coastforyou.org to learn about all of our programs. The Public Education Program is staffed by a small team of professionals who work closely together. The Position: The Volunteer Environmental Intern(S) will assist with the annual California Coastal Art & Poetry Contest for K-12 students. Duties will include tasks such as opening and sorting the contest entries, scanning artwork and poetry, and data entry. The intern(s) may have the opportunity to contribute to an outreach plan for the contest, and take part in contest judging.

The bulk of the work begins after the entry deadline of January 31, 2017 and lasts for a maximum of three months, in downtown San Francisco, conveniently located near Embarcadero BART.

Desired Skills and Abilities:

  • Close attention to detail and ability to follow instructions
  • Well organized
  • Experience with scanners or confidence to learn
  • Basic-level knowledge of Photoshop (for sizing and saving scanned work) or confidence to learn
  • Ability to work well independently
  • An interest in student artwork and poetry and a love of the California coast!

https://documents.coastal.ca.gov/assets/jobs/PE_Volunteer_Intern.pdf

opportunities.description:
Do you or someone you know suffer from a headache disorder, specifically, migraine, cluster headache, and chronic daily headache? Strike back at head pain by joining our team!

Volunteers are needed to help plan and prepare for our races, as well as on race day. See the sections below for the various ways you can get involved.

Help with Race Planning - Race Committee Open Positions

Volunteers are needed for publicity, race planning, marketing, and finding donors and sponsors.

Race Day Volunteers

Course Monitors:

Many volunteers are needed to be cheerleaders on the course and to make sure participants are going in the right direction. Course monitors are needed from approx. 6:30 am - 11:30 am depending on event distance. Thirty to forty enthusiastic volunteers are needed as course monitors.

Water Station:
Volunteers are needed to setup and man the water stops from approx. 6:30 am - 11:00 am.

Registration:
Volunteers needed to assist with registration from 6:30 am - 9:00 am. Six to eight volunteers are needed. Should be organized and familiar with race registration process to assist in this area.

Video and Onsite Social Media:

Help us capture the moment on race day through video or social media support. Some pre-race day planning required along with post-race follow up and race day support.

opportunities.description:
Making It Home is a project that serves to transform the empty shell of an apartment into an inviting home for a family lacking housing stability. Every month we help homeless families find and secure permanent housing throughout the Bay Area. Unfortunately, our families lack the resources to be able to afford beds for their kids, a dining room table for family dinners, and basic necessities like dressers to store clothes and desks for homework. It is not uncommon for us to arrive at an apartment to see sleeping bags on cold floors and nothing else. Making It Home ensures that families don’t have to do that again!

Making it Home volunteers will meet on a given move-in day at our storage center in San Francisco, help load a moving truck with furniture that has been pre-determined to meet the needs of the family, and then drive to the location of the family’s new home (within 25 miles of downtown SF), and unload and set up in the apartment. We provide barely used furniture from donors and purchase brand new pillows and linens. We then create living rooms with couches, chairs, coffee tables, and entertainment centers; bedrooms with brand new sheets, comforters, and pillows; and dining rooms with a table and chairs to fit the whole family. It is a truly transformative experience for volunteers, Compass staff, and ultimately the family. Please help us change a house into a home for those who have been missing out for far too long! Those like Teana and David:

Teana and David moved from Compass Family Shelter to an apartment in Vallejo in August 2015. They owned almost no furniture and had a one-month-old baby at the time. Fortunately, Making it Home was there for them and outfitted their entire apartment soon after they moved in. Teana described her gratitude, not only for the furniture, but for the experience itself. She said she felt "pampered" because the volunteers went above and beyond her expectations and did everything from making the bed with perfect hospital corners to fluffing the pillows on their couch. A year later, Teana said, "I can’t explain how happy I felt that day."

Making it Home was just the beginning of Teana and David’s good fortune. Six months later, they won a housing lottery and moved into an affordable housing unit in San Leandro. With the help of friends and family, they were able to move all of their Making it Home furniture into their new place, where they have now lived happily for eight months. Making it Home truly turned an empty apartment into a beautiful and warm home for this new family when they needed it most. But more importantly, the thoughtful ness of the volunteers and the care they put into the delivery day made this family, who had faced more than their fair share of challenges, feel incredibly special.

David and Teana are now engaged and will be married in December, 2016.

Qualifications:

  • Must be able to lift furniture such as mattresses, box springs, couches, tables, and more.
  • Must be able to transport yourself or carpool with other group members
  • Spanish speakers are encouraged to apply
opportunities.tags: children, nonprofit, homelessness, moving, homeless, Driving, lifting, families, kids, housing, volunteer, family

opportunities.description:
VOLUNTEER POSITION: Practice Interview Volunteer

ORGANIZATION: HealthRIGHT 360 Resource Center

COMMITMENT: Fridays from 9 am to 12 pm or Thursdays from 1 pm to 4 pm for 3-4 months.

POSITION DESCRIPTION:

Make a difference in our clients’ lives! You will be doing a number of things within our department, with a focus on conducting mock interviews for our clients who are re-entering the workforce. Many of our clients haven’t had an interview in years and the practice and feedback you give them is extremely helpful as they strive to create productive and sustainable lives after treatment.

DESIRED SKILLS, QUALIFICATIONS AND PERSONAL QUALITIES:

  • Ability to perform and debrief mock interviews with sensitivity
  • Provide positive yet truthful feedback
  • Must be able to quickly take legible handwritten notes
  • Excellent communication, interpersonal and listening skills
  • Ability to role model professional behavior and maintain professional boundaries
  • Interest in working with diverse, disadvantaged populations including low literacy, learning disabilities, physical disabilities and impaired cognitive functioning
  • Willingness to maintain client confidentiality
  • Prior professional experience in hiring or management is a plus but not required

TRAINING AND SUPERVISION: You will be provided with a volunteer orientation. You’ll have the opportunity to shadow staff or other volunteers who complete practice interviews with clients, and will be given thorough instructions and support prior to having your own practice interview appointments with individual clients. In addition, as a valuable asset to our team, we’re always available to you if you have questions or concerns.

opportunities.description:
Do you enjoy meeting new people and hanging out with an international crowd? HI Downtown San Francisco hosts a hostel Pub Crawl on Thursdays which lead guests to 4 or 5 different bars and pubs in the City Center. Pub crawls are a great way for guests to meet each other and create lasting experiences. Leaders should have an outgoing personality, be sociable and responsible. Each pub crawl will always have 2 leaders and will typically host 20 to 50 guests. Pub Crawls are great fun for both guests and volunteers!

You can volunteer once a month or every week. We can work with your schedule! If you have a friend that wants to volunteer we can set it up to where you lead the pub crawls together. What could be better? Hanging out with your friend, volunteering and meeting cool people from around the world!

opportunities.description:
Welcome to Camping Unlimited! Since 1957, Camping Unlimited has offered exciting recreational-educational programs for children and adults of all disabilities. Participants with Down Syndrome, Cerebral Palsy, Autism and other physical/emotional challenges enjoy a wide variety of weekend programs with the assistance of our wonderful group of Volunteer Counselors and staff.

Campers, staff and Volunteers participate in a great selection of events for all to enjoy! We hike, explore beautiful state parks, cheer at sporting events, enjoy theatrical productions, picnics in the park, visit museums, community fairs, festivals and more. On certain weekends we head for the Santa Cruz Mountains and stay at Camp Krem, our nearly 100 acre resident camp in Boulder Creek. Together we dance, create with arts n'crafts, enjoy performing arts with karaoke, talent shows, skits. We also garden, play sports, games and have magical campfires celebrate with special events for Halloween, Thanksgiving and Christmas. Our Campers also trek to the snow country and out of town camping locations to enjoy other exciting type of adventure such as our favorite tradition, going to Apple Hill near Lake Tahoe in the fall.

Volunteers may assist on a variety of weekend options per their own availability. We are currently seeking Volunteer "Counselors" for our extremely popular weekend overnights. This is great experience for those interested in Medicine, Therapeutic Recreation, Education, Physical-Occupational Therapy.


The typical schedules available to volunteer are:

1. Saturday Day Trips - 9 - 5

2. Saturday/Sunday weekend overnights, (includes a 1-night stay at our beautiful Camp Krem) Saturday, 9 - to Sunday 5

3. Or extended weekends from Friday at 3pm to Sunday at 5pm.

4. Special Travel Camps - TBA

RESPONSIBILITIES: Volunteers "Counselors" should be good role-models and mentors, offering friendship to children or adults of all ages and abilities. They assist with supervision, providing guidance and interacting during activities. They also help with mealtimes prep, cleanup and support Campers who need assistance with personal care.

Being a Volunteer Counselor can be both physically and emotionally challenging. Camp Counseling can also include strenuous activities and long hours. Volunteers become a part of our team and are provided with ongoing support and training by our experienced Program Director and staff.

Our staff, Volunteers and Campers travel to all destinations via our Camping Unlimited bus. The trip pick up points are in Emeryville and San Jose (Campbell), California. Volunteers may also be able to drive to/from to the camp according to special scheduling.

There are no fees to become a Volunteer Counselor or to participate in any of our programs. All volunteers must complete an application, provide references and will be background checked.

TO APPLY : To become a Volunteer Counselor, please visit our website at www.campingunlimited.org. Our Volunteer interest page is available and you may express your interest in volunteering using the following link; http://campingunlimited.org/volunteer-opportunities/

See photos taken on some of our wonderful trips on FACEBOOK "Camping Unlimited". View our website for photos and current information also! www.campingunlimited.org. Please also enjoy our video of summer camp at Camp Krem!

Thank you for your interest in being a Camping Unlimited Volunteer!

Staff of Camping Unlimited


***** ******** NEW WEEKEND SPRING TRIPS -

February 25-26:Mardi Gras Overnight at Camp Krem

Let the festivities begin! This weekend, as well as the usual camp fun, we’ll be making masks, dancing, parading and cooking up some delicious Cajun food.

March 4:Pippi Longstocking

Let’s head into San Francisco to see the Bay Area Children’s Theatre production of Pippi Longstocking!

March 18: Sky High Sports & Movie Trip

We’re off to Sky High Sports to bounce the morning away, before heading to the cinema to relax and enjoy a movie!

March 24-26: Mini Spring Break at Camp Krem

Let’s celebrate the arrival of Spring with our mini Spring Break weekend at Camp Krem. We’ll spend some time getting the garden ready, enjoying the beautiful hiking trails and will take a day trip to the beach for a cook-out!

April 1: Old Sacramento Day Trip
Join us as we take in some history in Old Sacramento. We'll spend the day exploring, checking out railroads, museums, riverboats and the many different sights Old Sacramento has to offer, as well as enjoying a picnic lunch!
April 7-9: New Camper Overnight*
Come join us for a weekend of fun based around all that Camp Krem has to offer! Activities will be focused around exploring all the beauty of the Camp Krem property. Perfect to get to know the place... or to fall in love with it all over again!
*(Returning campers are welcome, but new campers get enrollment priority for this weekend)

April 15: Dance-a-Thon for Autism
Put on your dancing shoes and let's boogie at the SF Autism Society's Dance-a-Thon for Autism! This is a fundraising event to benefit Camp Krem and six other fabulous autism-serving recreation programs! Let's show off the fabulous dancing talent our Camp Krem campers have!

April 22-23: Overnight & Beach BBQ
Ready to have some fun on the beautiful California Central Coast? So are we! This respite will feature a beach-side barbecue cookout and some tide pool exploration! Whether you want to kick back in the sand or get your feet wet next to some anemones, this respite has something for everyone.

May 5-7: Watsonville KOA Camp-Out
We will be returning to the award-winning KOA in Watsonville for this trip. The KOA offers fun activities every night, nearby beaches and a putt-putt course. Don't miss out on the fun!

Thank you for your interest in volunteering with Camping Unlimited!

Staff of Camping Unlimited

Perfect to get to know the place... or to fall in love with it all over again! *(Returning campers are welcome, but new campers get enrollment priority for this weekend) April 15: Dance-a-Thon for Autism Put on your dancing shoes and let's boogie at the SF Autism Society's Dance-a-Thon for Autism! This is a fundraising event to benefit Camp Krem and six other fabulous autism-serving recreation programs! Let's show off the fabulous dancing talent our Camp Krem campers have! April 22-23: Overnight & Beach BBQ Ready to have some fun on the beautiful California Central Coast? So are we! This respite will feature a beach-side barbecue cookout and some tide pool exploration! Whether you want to kick back in the sand or get your feet wet next to some anemones, this respite has something for everyone. May 5-7: Watsonville KOA Camp-Out We will be returning to the award-winning KOA in Watsonville for this trip. The KOA offers fun activities every night, nearby beaches and a putt-putt course. Don't miss out on the fun! Thank you for your interest in volunteering with Camping Unlimited! Staff of Camping Unlimited

opportunities.description:
We are a non-profit project located in the middle of Chinatown of San Francisco to empower youth through computer literacy.

For more info: www.chinatowncodes.org

Our program not only teaches kids HTML/CSS, we also get kids familiar with using a laptop as well as having drop in hours on the week days where students could borrow a laptop to finish up homework.

We currently are looking for volunteers for Monday/Wednesday 5:30-7pm as well as Saturday afternoon.

Geographically, this is one of the most dense neighborhood in the area, and children In this neighborhood are mostly low income youths with no resources for laptops.

opportunities.description:
VOLUNTEER OPPORTUNITIES AVAILABLE NOW!

Become a GED Tutor to an incarcerated youth in San Francisco, CA

Please visit our website at http://www.eoro.org/volunteers/other-volunteer-opportunities and complete the application form if you are interested in this volunteer opportunity.

Volunteer Details:

ADream and A Plan for Tomorrow (ADAPT) provides weekly, after-school study hall sessions that offer one-on-one academic tutoring, group educational activities, and life skills workshops to youth in detention facilities.

Each One Reach One (EORO) pairs the participants with college students and other community members who serve as mentors and tutors for the duration of the young person's incarceration.

The study hall sessions focus on helping the youth pass the GED, and allow the youth to realize their academic and vocational goals. All student assignments are prepared for all volunteers.

Thank you!

opportunities.description:
Alzheimer's Association's RivAlz Blondes vs. Brunettes is a volunteer event that brings the passion and spirit of young community leaders together to support the Alzheimer’s Association. The event is an organized women’s flag football game in which the two participating teams are divided based on the age-old rivalry between blondes and brunettes.

Help us Tackle Alzheimer's by volunteering for the Planning Committee! Committee meetings are held 1-2 times a month. Please join us at the Committee Recruitment Mixer on 2/27/17 at Sports Basement. Enjoy appetizers and beverages while learning more about this volunteer opportunity.

Funds raised at Blondes vs. Brunettes events benefit the care, support, advocacy and research efforts of the Alzheimer’s Association. Blondes vs. Brunettes was established in 2005 in Washington DC and is now played in 35 cities across the county. Help us reach our goal in 2017 of raising $75k and managing over 50 players.

The planning committee is responsible for the overall event experience and reaching fundraising goals. Committee roles include: fundraising and sponsorship, in-kind donations, game day logistics, volunteer management, advertising and marketing, player recruitment and management, and coaching. Men and women are encouraged to join the Committee and you do not need to play in the league to be a part of the planning committee.

Committee Recruitment Mixer: Monday, February 27th from 6:30-8pm at Sports Basement, 1590 Bryant Street. Enjoy appetizers and beverages while meeting fellow volunteers to learn more about joining the planning committee.

Please RSVP for the mixer to our Commitee CoChair, Katrina Kretsch at kkretsch@alz.org.

Chapter Website: www.alz.org/norcal

Facebook: www.facebook.com/ALZBvBSF

opportunities.description:
CalFresh, formerly known as the Food Stamp program, is a federally funded supplemental nutrition assistance program that provides eligible low income households with a means to purchase food. In San Francisco County, only about half of the people eligible for CalFresh participate in the program. Given this information, the Food Bank’s CalFresh Outreach Program is seeking bilingual volunteers to assist city residents in applying for CalFresh benefits. (This is different than volunteering in the Food Bank warehouse! Please see warehouse opportunities at vol.sffb.org/welcome). Volunteers will help our small team do outreach and pre-screen community members in the Mission, Excelsior, Bayview, Visitacion Valley and Potrero Hill neighborhoods. As a volunteer you will provide community members with a brief explanation of the CalFresh program, discuss eligibility guidelines, dispel common myths about CalFresh participation, gather pre-screening contact information, and/or make follow-up calls to interested participants. Unfortunately, because of the nature of our work, we cannot guarantee monolingual English speakers consistent volunteer hours.

Volunteer Availability:
Volunteers should be able to commit a minimum of 20 hours over the course of the year following the initial training session. Volunteer outreach can vary from about 2-4 hours per event. Hours available vary depending on how many events are scheduled, but weekday availability is a huge plus. Volunteers must be at least 18 years old.

Duties and Responsibilities
Volunteers who join the outreach team will be expected to:
-Attend an initial orientation/training session. During this session staff will present an overview of the program and basics of CalFresh participation guidelines, the application process, and how to pre-screen participants.
-Understand and explain the misconceptions, fears, and myths about CalFresh participation.
-Maintain client confidentiality.
-Must be able to communicate in a language other than English (limited proficiency is fine): Spanish, Cantonese, Vietnamese, Russian, Tagalog, Arabic, etc.
-Attend Food Bank distributions and community events to assist our participants with the pre-screening process.
-Some on site office work: follow up calls, logging pre-screening data, etc.
-Potential for increased responsibility based on capacity and commitment to the program.

Profile of an ideal candidate
-Ability to work well with others, including food bank staff, CBO staff, and volunteers.
-Fluency in a second language (Spanish, Cantonese, Vietnamese, Russian, Tagalog etc.).
-Availability on weekday mornings is a huge plus.
-Interest in social justice, community organizing, issues of hunger/food security.
-Ability and willingness to work with diverse communities.
-Some knowledge of the communities where we work: Mission, Excelsior, Bayview, Visitacion Valley, Potrero Hill.
-Basic computer skills and ability to learn new software programs.
-Good verbal communication skills.
-Must be able to commit to at least 20 hours to the program over the course of 1 year.

Benefits of Participation in Volunteer Program
-Collaborating with many community serving organizations in San Francisco.
-Experience working within a public social service program.
-Learning about food security issues in San Francisco.
-Potential for further training opportunities.
Orientation/Training
-Must attend our orientation/training session prior to community outreach.

Contact Information:
Francesca Costa
CalFresh Outreach Program Coordinator
415.282.1900 ext. 304
fcosta@sfmfoodbank.org

Thank you for your interest in working with our team!

opportunities.description:
Project Read is the adult literacy program of the San Francisco Public Library. Since 1983, trained volunteer tutors have been working one-to-one with English-speaking adults seeking to improve their basic reading and writing skills.

Tutors are required to attend an orientation, complete twelve hours of basic tutor training and make a year-long commitment to tutoring. Our training equips tutors with a variety of teaching ideas, techniques and strategies designed to help adult learners improve their reading and writing skills. After training, we ask that our tutors meet with an adult learner one to two times a week for one year.

opportunities.description:
Help a senior male remain connected and engaged by checking in once a week with a phone call or visit! Spend time conversing and sharing time together. Providing undivided attention to a senior can boost their spirit and help them to overcome obstacles that may otherwise lead them into a senior home. Spend a little time with a homebound elder and you will make a big difference!

95% of us want to grow old in the comfort of our own home. NEXT's goal is to help the elderly in Northeast SF does just that! We also work to increase the member's well being by reducing social isolation and loneliness by hosting workshops, cultural events and outings. Some of our members have lived in their homes/apartments for 40 years. Volunteers help by: Providing companionship. Taking someone to the grocery store, and if needed, help them carry their groceries up to their apartment. Providing transportation to medical appointments or offering a lift to our social events. Helping with technology. Leading a class or speaking about something interesting to a group.

Become a part of our NEXT Neighbor team and start making a difference today!

opportunities.description:
Are you a good listener? Are you caring? Do you want to help the GLBT community nationwide?

The GLBT National Youth Talkline provides vital peer-support, community connections and resource information to people with questions regarding sexual orientation and/or gender identity. Our volunteers provides one-to-one peer support that help youths with coming-out issues, safer-sex information, school bullying, family concerns, relationship problems and much more.

We are looking for GLBT volunteers ages 18 and over.

The GLBT National Youth Talkline is a program of the GLBT National Help Center. We are a non-profit organization that is dedicated to providing peer-counseling, information, and local resources directly through our toll-free telephone number at 1-800-246-PRIDE. Our mission is to help end the isolation and fear that many young people who question their sexuality and/or gender identity go through.
